description: The CompTIA Project+ show is a series that discusses, shows and examines different project management skills needed to successfully manage projects.  The series is designed for the person needing to gain the core knowledge and skills to manage, lead, direct or even be part of small to medium scale projects.  It is also based on the PK0-003 exam objectives, covering each domain and objective for the CompTIA Project+ candidate.  The goal is therefore twofold:  to provide knowledge for the professional certification candidate as well as to provide practical knowledge and skills for the project participant and project management professional.

The goal is therefore twofold:  to provide knowledge for the professional certification candidate as well as to provide practical knowledge and skills for the project participant and project management professional. __[Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__

166
00:08:55.270 --> 00:08:55.920

167
00:08:55.920 --> 00:08:56.790
Well, thank you so much for

168
00:08:56.790 --> 00:09:01.130

169
00:09:01.130 --> 00:09:04.300

170

If that sounds like something

171
00:09:07.170 --> 00:09:10.700

172
00:09:10.700 --> 00:09:13.100
Until then, we'll see you next time.

173
00:09:13.100 --> 00:09:18.400
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel start walking you through pre-project setup. They begin by taking you through the pre-project steps, starting with identifying the project which helps to describe the template of what the project will accomplish. The next step covered is validation, where the justification and feasibility is inspected as well as demand and possible stakeholders.
episodes.title: Explain Pre-Project Setup

00:02:34.100 --> 00:02:36.900

Somewhere at some point in time, somebody

And so a lot of times project

That's were we make mistakes

00:10:17.200 --> 00:10:21.610
A lot of times what ends up happening is

But when it comes down to project and

Project management skills

Well if I were to take

00:11:47.990 --> 00:11:51.690

00:12:30.330 --> 00:12:34.330

00:12:34.330 --> 00:12:38.270

00:12:38.270 --> 00:12:43.180
It begins with an idea

00:12:43.180 --> 00:12:44.440
That's what we have to understand.

00:12:44.440 --> 00:12:48.200

00:12:50.020 --> 00:12:53.040

We actually then at

00:13:03.210 --> 00:13:06.930
From that point, once all the planning's

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue explaining the pre-project planning steps, picking up here with project selection and decision models. They take the time to explain the common decision models like Benefits Measurements which include, Cost/Benefit, Scoring, Payback Period, and Economic, as well as Constrained Optimization and Expert Judgement.

00:27:21.560 --> 00:27:24.328
So they might make the wrong decision,
it's possible.

529
00:27:24.328 --> 00:27:27.390
And you're gonna have to
take the hit if they do.

530
00:27:27.390 --> 00:27:31.310
But, you probably are making a very safe
bet with someone that has done this for

531
00:27:31.310 --> 00:27:32.450
a very long time.

532
00:27:32.450 --> 00:27:36.185
>> There really is, expert judgment is
a big part of doing project management.

533
00:27:36.185 --> 00:27:38.520
There's no way to get around it, right.

534
00:27:38.520 --> 00:27:41.700
Why are you gonna try and reinvent
the wheel when you know someone that

535
00:27:41.700 --> 00:27:46.340
may have done a similar project, already
has experience in guiding that project all

536
00:27:46.340 --> 00:27:49.390
the way through and can tell you
where some of the pitfalls are.

537
00:27:49.390 --> 00:27:52.036
You can rely on those models to
help you to do this choice and

538
00:27:52.036 --> 00:27:53.170
decision that you need.

539
00:27:53.170 --> 00:27:57.942
But if you know someone that absolutely
says, yes, your company can handle this,

540
00:27:57.942 --> 00:28:01.870
or no it can't, that's the person
you really want to rely on.

541
00:28:01.870 --> 00:28:04.230
So the selection technique is a big one,
right,

542
00:28:04.230 --> 00:28:06.850
that you actually go
through at this point here.

543
00:28:06.850 --> 00:28:11.670
Whether it's actually formal or informal,
okay, whether you actually use any of

544
00:28:11.670 --> 00:28:14.880
those models at all, remember that in
a small company you're probably going to

545
00:28:14.880 --> 00:28:18.370
actually end up with those that get
more influence from the outside or

546
00:28:18.370 --> 00:28:23.330
from knowing who the person is, than if
you rely on those mathematical models.

547
00:28:23.330 --> 00:28:27.320
But, on the mathematical models, you take
a chance of actually end up saying, yeah,

548
00:28:27.320 --> 00:28:30.740
any of the ones that you picked,
Ronnie, at least in handing in?

549
00:28:30.740 --> 00:28:32.230
Yeah, they're not gonna work for
us at all.

550
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:34.920
And that means you have to
start that process over.

551
00:28:34.920 --> 00:28:39.310
So, you do have to actually figure out
where your company's actually going to go

552
00:28:39.310 --> 00:28:44.720
from this point if you're actually gonna
be doing some type of project selection.

553
00:28:44.720 --> 00:28:48.450
So remember, you're also not doing
this in a vacuum is the key.

554
00:28:48.450 --> 00:28:52.100
You're doing this along with the help of
those stakeholders that you've identified.

555
00:28:52.100 --> 00:28:55.820
You're making sure that whoever the
project sponsor is, whoever came up with

556
00:28:55.820 --> 00:28:59.540
the idea or whoever's willing to stand
behind you and the project manager.

557
00:28:59.540 --> 00:29:02.870
And you're actually saying here's
our best selection that we have.

558
00:29:02.870 --> 00:29:05.550
We just need to submit them and see if
our company will actually be able to do

559
00:29:05.550 --> 00:29:07.690
something like that in
a more formalized process.

560
00:29:07.690 --> 00:29:11.330
If not, you go up to the individual who's
gonna make the decision and say yes or no,

561
00:29:11.330 --> 00:29:13.120
and you actually know
actually kind of immediately,

562
00:29:13.120 --> 00:29:16.600
instead of after a long process of
trying to do a bunch of accounting.

563
00:29:16.600 --> 00:29:19.976
But just realize that all these
are actually part of the process and

564
00:29:19.976 --> 00:29:22.928
it's also,
something else that I realize too, Daniel,

565
00:29:22.928 --> 00:29:25.054
is that you let me talk
again way too long.

566
00:29:25.054 --> 00:29:27.950
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, it's fun talking about this stuff.

567
00:29:27.950 --> 00:29:29.180
>> Yeah, it is, it is.

568
00:29:29.180 --> 00:29:32.013
And it's a good topic,
especially if you're into Project Manager,

569
00:29:32.013 --> 00:29:35.097
you're trying to get Project Plus because
you want to be a project manager.

570
00:29:35.097 --> 00:29:37.988
These are the kinds of things you're
going to be rolling around inside

571
00:29:37.988 --> 00:29:38.679
your head a lot.

572
00:29:38.679 --> 00:29:40.454
So it's good that we
really vet them out so

573
00:29:40.454 --> 00:29:43.613
I'm not really too worried a lot about
letting you just ramble on Ronnie.

574
00:29:43.613 --> 00:29:46.649
>> [LAUGH]
>> Go for broke, find every little nuance

575
00:29:46.649 --> 00:29:51.530
that'll help us be better project
managers as we get on into our career.

576
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:54.420
So Ronnie is there anything else that
we need to cover in this episode?

577
00:29:54.420 --> 00:29:55.450
>> Not in this episode, but

578
00:29:55.450 --> 00:29:59.710
we still have a lot to cover in our
project, pre-project set up here.

579
00:29:59.710 --> 00:30:02.740
And so, we still got a lot to go over.

580
00:30:02.740 --> 00:30:04.625
So I think we're gonna have to extend
this to another episode, Daniel.

581
00:30:04.625 --> 00:30:06.679
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I'm looking forward to that,

582
00:30:06.679 --> 00:30:07.410
hopefully you are as well.

583
00:30:07.410 --> 00:30:09.340
Hopefully you're getting
a lot out of this series,

584
00:30:09.340 --> 00:30:11.210
that's what we're trying to accomplish.

585
00:30:11.210 --> 00:30:12.630
That's our project, right Ronnie?

586
00:30:12.630 --> 00:30:13.260
>> It is.

587
00:30:13.260 --> 00:30:16.330
>> So, that being said, we're gonna go
ahead and call it a day for this episode.

588
00:30:16.330 --> 00:30:17.740
Hopefully we'll see you in the next.

589
00:30:17.740 --> 00:30:20.490
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

590
00:30:20.490 --> 00:30:21.200
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

591
00:30:21.200 --> 00:30:22.150
>> We'll see you next time.

592
00:30:22.150 --> 00:30:30.660
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel conclude their exposition of the pre-project setup steps, starting here with preparing a Project Charter which is the official documentation and guidelines of the project. Then they explain the Charter approval process; wrapping things up with where the Project Manager fits into the process with regards to their role and expected skills.
episodes.title: Explain Pre-Project Setup Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.066 --> 00:00:10.066
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.820 --> 00:00:16.100
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.100 --> 00:00:19.140
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.140 --> 00:00:22.600
that's right we are continuing
on with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:27.126
Joining us back in the studio again today
for a part three is our good friend, Mr.

6
00:00:27.126 --> 00:00:27.770
Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:27.770 --> 00:00:28.860
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:28.860 --> 00:00:30.410
>> Well thank you again for having me.

9
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:33.050
As we continue on taking a look here at,
of course,

10
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:36.990
CompTIA's Project+,
we wanna make sure that we understand,

11
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:40.280
that as we continue on, right,
that we're only in the initiation phase.

12
00:00:40.280 --> 00:00:45.020
So we've gone through a bit when we talk
about initiation and pre-project setup.

13
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:48.120
And now we're continuing on, and
hopefully finish this one up as well for

14
00:00:48.120 --> 00:00:50.420
us, as we take a look.

15
00:00:50.420 --> 00:00:54.980
So in previous episodes, right,
we went ahead and we took a look at,

16
00:00:54.980 --> 00:00:56.870
of course the beginnings here.

17
00:00:56.870 --> 00:01:00.460
Making sure that we understand what
a project is as far as identifying it for

18
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:00.990
what we need.

19
00:01:00.990 --> 00:01:03.000
We validated the overall project.

20
00:01:03.000 --> 00:01:05.220
We took a look at project
selection techniques, and

21
00:01:05.220 --> 00:01:07.820
that's kind of where we ended
the last episode that we had.

22
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:10.340
So if you're picking up now and
you're going wow,

23
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:13.230
he's kind of jumping in the middle
of things, make sure you go back and

24
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:16.840
check out those other episodes
that we had before this point.

25
00:01:16.840 --> 00:01:19.590
As we continue on tinkering we've
got some of things that we have.

26
00:01:19.590 --> 00:01:22.450
Remember that before we spend
a single dime on our project,

27
00:01:22.450 --> 00:01:23.860
before we assign any resource,

28
00:01:23.860 --> 00:01:27.205
before we do any of that, I wanna make
sure that we have a good project,

29
00:01:27.205 --> 00:01:31.890
pre-project, plan setup so that we know
what is actually gonna end up happening.

30
00:01:31.890 --> 00:01:33.540
Now, after we get in line, right.

31
00:01:33.540 --> 00:01:35.530
In other words,
after we line up everything else.

32
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:38.270
We've now selected our project.

33
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:40.800
Okay, we've got everything that we need.

34
00:01:40.800 --> 00:01:43.450
The thing that we have
as a project manager or

35
00:01:43.450 --> 00:01:44.780
I shouldn't say the thing that we have.

36
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:46.870
The thing that we don't
have as a project manager,

37
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:52.080
I think is more apt here,
is what we call approval or authorization.

38
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:55.900
Okay, so this is something that's
actually kind of a conundrum for

39
00:01:55.900 --> 00:01:57.610
most project managers.

40
00:01:57.610 --> 00:02:00.413
If you're brought in from the outside,
let's say that you work for

41
00:02:00.413 --> 00:02:03.680
a project management group and
you're brought in from the outside.

42
00:02:03.680 --> 00:02:09.870
It doesn't mean that once the company says
here's a project I need you to work on,

43
00:02:09.870 --> 00:02:11.420
it doesn't mean that you
just get to go ahead,

44
00:02:11.420 --> 00:02:14.190
all right, I'm ready to go and start.

45
00:02:14.190 --> 00:02:17.090
I know that that sounds strange.

46
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:20.460
But it's true there's not a lot of
times he can actually able to do that.

47
00:02:20.460 --> 00:02:24.400
And that's because in project management
there's a process we have to have

48
00:02:24.400 --> 00:02:28.420
which says that you are authorized
to start here, okay.

49
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:32.870
And this is only that you as a project
manager may have actually end up doing

50
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:37.850
which is what we call of course, preparing
what we call the project charter, okay.

51
00:02:37.850 --> 00:02:40.790
Now when it comes down to
the project charter itself,

52
00:02:42.070 --> 00:02:47.140
it is the official documentation
that we have, okay.

53
00:02:47.140 --> 00:02:50.800
That says that the project can now exist.

54
00:02:50.800 --> 00:02:53.190
I know that's strange,
you're going, well we selected it.

55
00:02:53.190 --> 00:02:56.730
But now you're actually formally
allowing people to say hey,

56
00:02:56.730 --> 00:02:59.020
the project now actually exists.

57
00:02:59.020 --> 00:03:02.470
It has backing behind it and
it has authorization.

58
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:05.810
All right, so now that we have this,
right, we have a document that says that

59
00:03:05.810 --> 00:03:08.690
we are authorized to be
able to use resources here.

60
00:03:08.690 --> 00:03:10.820
And that's what I put,
authorizes the release and

61
00:03:10.820 --> 00:03:13.100
use of organizational resources.

62
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:17.500
Now it becomes something on
the actual organization's radar,

63
00:03:17.500 --> 00:03:20.160
more than anything else, right.

64
00:03:20.160 --> 00:03:23.130
Up to this point we've been talking,
we've been negotiating a little bit.

65
00:03:23.130 --> 00:03:28.150
We've tried to get project sponsors, or
not sponsors, stakeholders on our side.

66
00:03:28.150 --> 00:03:30.910
We've tried to make sure that
we've covered all of our bases.

67
00:03:30.910 --> 00:03:34.110
But getting a project charter is
something that is very important.

68
00:03:34.110 --> 00:03:37.170
You can go through this entire
process believe it or not, Daniel.

69
00:03:37.170 --> 00:03:38.670
Get everything in line.

70
00:03:38.670 --> 00:03:40.960
Prove that it's actually a great project.

71
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:42.750
Do the cost-benefit analysis.

72
00:03:42.750 --> 00:03:44.340
We know it's gonna work.

73
00:03:44.340 --> 00:03:47.210
But, somebody doesn't sign off
on that in your organization,

74
00:03:47.210 --> 00:03:49.620
that actually says, yes you can do it.

75
00:03:49.620 --> 00:03:52.010
Well you now have a great
project that just sits there.

76
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:52.800
And it just sits there.

77
00:03:52.800 --> 00:03:53.350
And sits there.

78
00:03:53.350 --> 00:03:56.760
And it doesn't actually get
anywhere it needs to go.

79
00:03:56.760 --> 00:04:01.840
So in other words, your project
really is not going to formally exist

80
00:04:01.840 --> 00:04:07.070
until you get this particular
charter here approved and

81
00:04:07.070 --> 00:04:11.070
that normally requires a formal
signature of some sort.

82
00:04:11.070 --> 00:04:13.310
And that's what we actually
have to worry about.

83
00:04:13.310 --> 00:04:16.790
The key benefit though is that once
you have this project charter in hand,

84
00:04:16.790 --> 00:04:21.280
right, is that it will actually
go ahead and allow you

85
00:04:21.280 --> 00:04:26.750
to have what we call a well defined,
a project start and project boundary.

86
00:04:26.750 --> 00:04:30.320
In other words,
it actually states that authorize is,

87
00:04:30.320 --> 00:04:33.032
here it is,
we're going to start this project, and

88
00:04:33.032 --> 00:04:36.570
here is actually what the limitation
of this project is going to be.

89
00:04:36.570 --> 00:04:38.870
That way,
there is nobody that comes along and

90
00:04:38.870 --> 00:04:41.740
says you're not supposed to be doing that,
you can't do that.

91
00:04:41.740 --> 00:04:42.825
You're stepping on mine.

92
00:04:42.825 --> 00:04:45.300
We can actually now say
no we've been approved.

93
00:04:45.300 --> 00:04:49.440
We have our authorized project here and we
are ready to go forward with it as well.

94
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:50.170
>> Yeah Ronnie.

95
00:04:50.170 --> 00:04:52.828
This does tend to seem
a bit like red tape, right.

96
00:04:52.828 --> 00:04:53.554
In which we hate.

97
00:04:53.554 --> 00:04:57.987
Bureaucracy is the is just a killer of
projects because you gotta get some one to

98
00:04:57.987 --> 00:04:58.535
do this.

99
00:04:58.535 --> 00:04:59.580
You gotta get someone to do that.

100
00:04:59.580 --> 00:05:00.490
It has to be approved.

101
00:05:00.490 --> 00:05:03.540
You gotta go through these
channels to make sure it happens.

102
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:08.090
But you gotta remember, and trust me,
I'm no fan of the red-tape gun at all.

103
00:05:08.090 --> 00:05:10.620
I like to just say this is what
needs to be done, let's just do it.

104
00:05:10.620 --> 00:05:12.260
But like Ronnie said,

105
00:05:12.260 --> 00:05:15.610
what if I'm just doing projects cuz
I feel like they need to be done?

106
00:05:15.610 --> 00:05:16.810
I'm using company resources.

107
00:05:16.810 --> 00:05:20.560
I've got no authorization
from anybody who actually

108
00:05:20.560 --> 00:05:23.880
has management decisions inside
of that company to do that.

109
00:05:23.880 --> 00:05:25.700
They're not gonna be very happy with me.

110
00:05:25.700 --> 00:05:28.970
And you want this to save you.

111
00:05:28.970 --> 00:05:32.990
This is to also protect you as
the project manager to say,

112
00:05:32.990 --> 00:05:36.790
I'm working well within the charter
boundaries, cuz I can show it to you.

113
00:05:36.790 --> 00:05:40.800
Look at subsection C, right here
it says buy this type of material.

114
00:05:40.800 --> 00:05:43.460
And if you bought that material,
they can't hold you accountable

115
00:05:43.460 --> 00:05:47.180
if it's structurally inadequate for
the job that you tried to make it do.

116
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:47.990
That's not your fault.

117
00:05:47.990 --> 00:05:50.260
That was what was told to buy,
that's what you bought.

118
00:05:50.260 --> 00:05:54.210
If you buy anything else, even if it's
better, they can blame you for something,

119
00:05:54.210 --> 00:05:55.830
or if you do anything outside of it.

120
00:05:55.830 --> 00:05:59.500
So you stay well within a very
well defined set of guidelines,

121
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:01.630
and that's really what
the charter is there for.

122
00:06:01.630 --> 00:06:03.750
It helps beyond what we know.

123
00:06:03.750 --> 00:06:07.830
So everything that Daniel said is
absolutely correct that the very fact is

124
00:06:07.830 --> 00:06:09.400
you've got to have something like this.

125
00:06:09.400 --> 00:06:12.390
But the other thing that it does,
right, is now that you have that

126
00:06:12.390 --> 00:06:16.820
formal project charter and
you have it approved and what you need.

127
00:06:16.820 --> 00:06:19.940
It now gives those functional
managers inside your company

128
00:06:19.940 --> 00:06:23.460
something that they can accept or
they can outright complain about.

129
00:06:23.460 --> 00:06:25.160
I know that sounds strange, but

130
00:06:25.160 --> 00:06:28.070
they really can't complain about you
if you don't have something official.

131
00:06:28.070 --> 00:06:29.900
And you might go well that's
the better way to go, but

132
00:06:29.900 --> 00:06:32.890
then you don't have access to
resources when you need them.

133
00:06:32.890 --> 00:06:35.790
So this is actually one of those
things that really does set

134
00:06:35.790 --> 00:06:39.477
into place in your organization
that your picker project can exist.

135
00:06:39.477 --> 00:06:42.690
And that it maybe where other managers,

136
00:06:42.690 --> 00:06:46.220
even if they're not project managers,
need to be able to work with you, okay.

137
00:06:46.220 --> 00:06:49.060
And so that's something that
has to actually be there.

138
00:06:49.060 --> 00:06:52.830
Now the key component to this
of course is also the idea of

139
00:06:52.830 --> 00:06:54.780
making sure we get an approval.

140
00:06:54.780 --> 00:06:57.580
But let me kinda show you
a format that can be done now.

141
00:06:57.580 --> 00:07:01.910
Not every project charter that you
have will end up looking like this.

142
00:07:01.910 --> 00:07:05.940
But you can go out there and find some
templates out there if you want to,

143
00:07:05.940 --> 00:07:06.980
to do something.

144
00:07:06.980 --> 00:07:09.880
So normally what's actually
included in this project charter,

145
00:07:09.880 --> 00:07:12.960
right, is of course the project title.

146
00:07:12.960 --> 00:07:17.060
The sponsor, okay, who in the world
is the sponsor at this point.

147
00:07:17.060 --> 00:07:21.310
This is the person that is gonna give
you the ultimate authorization, okay,

148
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:23.150
is what you actually need here.

149
00:07:23.150 --> 00:07:26.710
Of who's gonna actually back
this particular project up and

150
00:07:26.710 --> 00:07:29.350
saying it's a good idea
formally in the organization.

151
00:07:29.350 --> 00:07:31.380
The project manager, hopefully that's you.

152
00:07:31.380 --> 00:07:36.300
The customer part here can be an internal
customer as well as an external customer.

153
00:07:36.300 --> 00:07:37.480
Remember that if you do this,

154
00:07:37.480 --> 00:07:42.830
let's say like an example that Daniel
gave us earlier here, the client user.

155
00:07:42.830 --> 00:07:45.896
What is the, I can't remember.

156
00:07:45.896 --> 00:07:46.995
>> Golly [LAUGH].

157
00:07:46.995 --> 00:07:50.120
>> [LAUGH] The insurance one that you
were giving a little bit earlier.

158
00:07:50.120 --> 00:07:52.310
>> The claims users, yes, the claims user.

159
00:07:52.310 --> 00:07:53.922
>> Client user, I'm so
used to IP networking.

160
00:07:53.922 --> 00:07:58.896
The claims users department, well it might
not actually be a project just for them.

make sure these teams work together.

00:19:07.130 --> 00:19:11.180
It's amazing the amount of technique
that has to be done there for

391
00:19:11.180 --> 00:19:13.010
them to accomplish everything
that's gonna happen.

392
00:19:13.010 --> 00:19:16.370
>> Yeah, Ronnie, you've made a beautiful
illustration, a great point.

393
00:19:16.370 --> 00:19:18.980
I love how you have that
he coaches the team.

394
00:19:18.980 --> 00:19:21.980
And you mentioned this really quickly, but

395
00:19:21.980 --> 00:19:23.880
you said you don't wanna
become a micro-manager.

396
00:19:23.880 --> 00:19:25.090
This is something everybody hates.

397
00:19:25.090 --> 00:19:26.930
Nobody loves to be micromanaged.

398
00:19:26.930 --> 00:19:29.470
And you would think that,
since that's common knowledge,

399
00:19:29.470 --> 00:19:32.500
that we wouldn't have micro-managers,
but they're a dime a dozen.

400
00:19:32.500 --> 00:19:35.080
Because it's typically that
they wanna get in the game.

401
00:19:35.080 --> 00:19:37.530
The coach doesn't run out there with
the quarterback and stand behind him.

402
00:19:37.530 --> 00:19:38.460
Well just give me the ball.

403
00:19:38.460 --> 00:19:39.390
I'll throw it, right.

404
00:19:39.390 --> 00:19:40.410
They don't do that.

405
00:19:40.410 --> 00:19:42.720
They say go do your job.

406
00:19:42.720 --> 00:19:44.030
Here's how you can do it better.

407
00:19:44.030 --> 00:19:45.490
Do you need anything from me?

408
00:19:45.490 --> 00:19:48.410
Can I coordinate with your
offensive line a little bit better?

409
00:19:48.410 --> 00:19:51.370
And to make you be able to throw
the ball at a better time,

410
00:19:51.370 --> 00:19:55.780
that's his job is to see the big picture,
orchestrate what's going on, and

411
00:19:55.780 --> 00:19:59.510
make sure everybody has the resources they
need, that if anything is going wrong he

412
00:19:59.510 --> 00:20:02.800
can help them out with that, figure
out what they would need to fix that.

413
00:20:02.800 --> 00:20:05.060
That is the role of the project manager.

414
00:20:05.060 --> 00:20:07.380
I really like that
illustration of a coach.

415
00:20:07.380 --> 00:20:10.120
>> The coach is kind of
the big one once the execution

416
00:20:10.120 --> 00:20:13.590
phase comes on hand
>> But you also end up seeing that the key

417
00:20:13.590 --> 00:20:17.880
idea behind this is that he is that
leader for the entire project.

418
00:20:17.880 --> 00:20:19.260
The idea of leadership skills come on.

419
00:20:19.260 --> 00:20:22.130
Now, you might be saying, well, Ronnie,
why did you tack that on at the end.

420
00:20:22.130 --> 00:20:23.620
Because it's project managers, right?

421
00:20:23.620 --> 00:20:26.300
If you're actually in that point where
you're actually trying to see whether or

422
00:20:26.300 --> 00:20:29.010
not you will become one,
>> it doesn't mean if you don't have all

423
00:20:29.010 --> 00:20:31.010
of these skills right now that you can't,
okay?

424
00:20:31.010 --> 00:20:34.150
But what it does mean, though,
is that you do need to take time and

425
00:20:34.150 --> 00:20:37.160
develop some of these
skills as much as you can

426
00:20:37.160 --> 00:20:40.770
if you are going to be taking on
the role of a project manager.

427
00:20:40.770 --> 00:20:43.900
The very fact is you will need
leadership skills because

428
00:20:43.900 --> 00:20:48.600
people will be looking to you to do some
of the problem solving that they can't do.

429
00:20:48.600 --> 00:20:50.460
To be able to arrange and

430
00:20:50.460 --> 00:20:55.420
rearrange resources that they
can't actually do anything with.

431
00:20:55.420 --> 00:20:59.720
The very fact is that will actually
require of you those communication skills,

432
00:20:59.720 --> 00:21:03.580
problem solving skills and that all falls
underneath that idea of leadership.

433
00:21:03.580 --> 00:21:06.450
Being able to know what's actually
effective and what isn't.

434
00:21:06.450 --> 00:21:09.550
All that actually has to come
underneath for the project manager.

435
00:21:09.550 --> 00:21:12.950
Remember that the goal here is to
accomplish whatever was on that

436
00:21:12.950 --> 00:21:15.460
project chart that you said
would be accomplished.

437
00:21:15.460 --> 00:21:17.920
You can't do that if you
are doing that micromanaging.

438
00:21:17.920 --> 00:21:20.745
And that's why you have to be doing
the coaching that we talked about.

439
00:21:20.745 --> 00:21:22.320
So,where do you learn that stuff?

440
00:21:22.320 --> 00:21:25.140
Well, you can take classes
is pretty much the key.

441
00:21:25.140 --> 00:21:28.140
You can go to other people that
are already in project management and

442
00:21:28.140 --> 00:21:31.880
let them know your focus and
where you believe your strengths

443
00:21:31.880 --> 00:21:36.450
are versus your weaknesses, and
get advice from them as you do this.

444
00:21:36.450 --> 00:21:38.860
So a project manager doesn't
always have to be born that way.

445
00:21:38.860 --> 00:21:41.070
Are there people that are like that?

446
00:21:41.070 --> 00:21:41.980
Yeah.
Is Ronnie like that?

447
00:21:41.980 --> 00:21:43.570
No.
You just have to watch and

448
00:21:43.570 --> 00:21:44.260
you have to learn.

449
00:21:44.260 --> 00:21:47.420
And you have to be willing to
take it on the chin sometimes and

450
00:21:47.420 --> 00:21:50.500
go, man that really did hit me
in a way I didn't expect it to.

451
00:21:50.500 --> 00:21:52.700
But then you get up and you continue on.

452
00:21:52.700 --> 00:21:58.830
So project management is the idea of
juggling so many different things.

453
00:21:58.830 --> 00:22:01.150
Being able to keep track of them and
then going,

454
00:22:01.150 --> 00:22:03.760
all right, we're still gonna accomplish
whatever goal that we actually had here

455
00:22:03.760 --> 00:22:06.790
while you're actually having
to have to do all that stuff.

456
00:22:06.790 --> 00:22:10.360
So, that is in your future
as a project manager.

457
00:22:10.360 --> 00:22:15.870
But remember, at least for initiation,
we've kind of covered all the basis then,

458
00:22:15.870 --> 00:22:19.240
of what normally goes on
during that initiation stage.

459
00:22:19.240 --> 00:22:21.780
Making sure we have a project on hand.

460
00:22:21.780 --> 00:22:22.310
Okay?

461
00:22:22.310 --> 00:22:26.140
And not just ongoing work that we're
just continuing on for somebody.

462
00:22:26.140 --> 00:22:29.620
Ensuring that once we have that,
that we can validate that project,

463
00:22:29.620 --> 00:22:33.710
make sure our stakeholders are there, make
sure we do have a justification for it.

464
00:22:33.710 --> 00:22:36.960
The justification shouldn't just be,
well, I have nothing better to do.

465
00:22:36.960 --> 00:22:40.180
It should absolutely be something
that your business needs or

466
00:22:40.180 --> 00:22:43.100
there's a demand for
inside of your organization.

467
00:22:43.100 --> 00:22:48.720
Moving on from that point, we actually go
into the idea of the selection techniques,

468
00:22:48.720 --> 00:22:52.650
as well as understanding what the project
charter does and then, of course,

469
00:22:52.650 --> 00:22:55.640
ultimately, understanding
the role that you're gonna have.

470
00:22:55.640 --> 00:22:59.610
And that's kind of a key element,
is to understand your role in it.

471
00:22:59.610 --> 00:23:04.020
If not, we tend to slip back into
that functional type of person.

472
00:23:04.020 --> 00:23:06.410
We get into our groove and
we just hide out.

473
00:23:06.410 --> 00:23:07.840
And we go, no, I can do this part well.

474
00:23:07.840 --> 00:23:09.860
I don't care about dealing with the rest.

475
00:23:09.860 --> 00:23:13.710
A project manager cannot do that and
that's what we have to realize here.

476
00:23:13.710 --> 00:23:16.880
So if you're actually ready for
more, there's actually gonna

477
00:23:16.880 --> 00:23:20.170
be more episodes coming up in which
we'll be going into the planning stage.

478
00:23:20.170 --> 00:23:21.450
But right now though, Daniel,

479
00:23:21.450 --> 00:23:23.930
I think we've kind of covered
the initiation fairly well.

480
00:23:23.930 --> 00:23:27.360
>> Yeah, and if I learned anything from
this episode, listening to you Ronny,

481
00:23:27.360 --> 00:23:29.850
is that if you fail to plan,
you plan to fail.

482
00:23:29.850 --> 00:23:30.550
>> That's true.
>> So

483
00:23:30.550 --> 00:23:34.630
you have to put in the proper steps and
procedures, get everything in line and

484
00:23:34.630 --> 00:23:37.930
make sure that you're ready for
when your projects come down the line.

485
00:23:37.930 --> 00:23:40.205
And now we have the understanding
on how to do that.

486
00:23:40.205 --> 00:23:43.400
Ronny, thank you so much for joining us
today, we appreciate your insight and

487
00:23:43.400 --> 00:23:44.960
your wisdom on these topics.

488
00:23:44.960 --> 00:23:45.990
We thank you for joining us.

489
00:23:45.990 --> 00:23:48.310
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for IT ProTV.

490
00:23:48.310 --> 00:23:49.830
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

491
00:23:49.830 --> 00:23:50.490
>> I'm Ronny Wong.

492
00:23:50.490 --> 00:23:51.430
>> And we'll see you next time.

493
00:23:51.430 --> 00:23:56.735
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel take the time to help properly identify the characteristics of a project. They also go through the attributes of an operation, so that you are able to properly discern the difference betwixt the two.
episodes.title: What is a Project
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.866 --> 00:00:13.750
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.750 --> 00:00:16.310
And welcome to another
great episode of IT ProTV.

4
00:00:16.310 --> 00:00:18.200
I'm your host, Daniel Lowery.

5
00:00:18.200 --> 00:00:19.370
And in today's episode, well,

6
00:00:19.370 --> 00:00:22.710
we are continuing on with
our project plus series.

7
00:00:22.710 --> 00:00:27.220
Joining us back again in the studio today
to lend his expertise on that said topic

8
00:00:27.220 --> 00:00:28.580
is none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:29.560
Ronnie, welcome back to the show.

10
00:00:29.560 --> 00:00:30.640
How are you doing today, sir?

11
00:00:30.640 --> 00:00:34.140
>> I appreciate being invited back,
first of all, and of course,

12
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:36.790
you are watching
the CompTIA Project Plus That

13
00:00:36.790 --> 00:00:40.000
means you're interested in learning
a little more about project management.

14
00:00:40.000 --> 00:00:44.036
In a couple of previous episodes we
actually went through the pre planning

15
00:00:44.036 --> 00:00:44.613
stages.

16
00:00:44.613 --> 00:00:46.712
Pre setup, pre project setup,

17
00:00:46.712 --> 00:00:50.750
that's the way that you hear
inside of comp ts language.

18
00:00:50.750 --> 00:00:55.724
A project management inside of the pmp
where you'd heard the term initiation

19
00:00:55.724 --> 00:01:00.697
as we go through some of the different
phases as well and what we are doing today

20
00:01:00.697 --> 00:01:05.440
is a little unusual is that we're taking
a little more in depth look at some

21
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:09.373
of the concepts inside of that
pre project setup phase here.

22
00:01:09.373 --> 00:01:13.741
And one make sure that we begin and we
understand this is because fairly heavily

23
00:01:13.741 --> 00:01:17.315
covered on the exam that we can
actually distinguish the ideas of

24
00:01:17.315 --> 00:01:21.300
what a project actually is, and
so that's where we want to begin.

25
00:01:21.300 --> 00:01:23.923
So let's go ahead and
take a look at my computer and

26
00:01:23.923 --> 00:01:28.489
we'll kind of review some of these things
that we've been talking about, all right?

27
00:01:28.489 --> 00:01:33.317
Just about every project management course
that you go through lines itself with

28
00:01:33.317 --> 00:01:38.003
what we call, of course, the PMBK,
the Project Management Book of Knowledge

29
00:01:38.003 --> 00:01:42.407
that's from the PMI organization, and
that organization is not one that

30
00:01:42.407 --> 00:01:47.379
necessarily says here's the rules they
essentially say, here are some of the best

31
00:01:47.379 --> 00:01:52.370
guidelines that we have, when we talk
about managing different projects.

32
00:01:52.370 --> 00:01:55.540
And so, the way that the PMI sets it up,
is that we go through

33
00:01:55.540 --> 00:01:59.980
five different stages, or five
different phases of project management.

34
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:03.300
And we take a look at the idea
of initiation, right?

35
00:02:03.300 --> 00:02:06.690
The very beginning of a project
doesn't begin with spending money,

36
00:02:06.690 --> 00:02:08.380
doesn't begin with any real action.

37
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:12.530
It begins with the idea of hey, there's
a project that might need to be done.

38
00:02:12.530 --> 00:02:15.310
Let's make sure that we
understand what that project is.

39
00:02:15.310 --> 00:02:19.160
From that point, we get into specifics
where we start planning for the work

40
00:02:19.160 --> 00:02:23.450
to be done, and so planning is normally
our largest stage that we take a look at.

41
00:02:23.450 --> 00:02:27.540
And after those plans then are actually
ready to go, it's at that point we ask

42
00:02:27.540 --> 00:02:31.510
you to start to take a look at executing,
as well as monitoring and controlling.

43
00:02:31.510 --> 00:02:34.140
Now when you normally see
this inside of the PMBK,

44
00:02:34.140 --> 00:02:37.140
you're gonna see it as
a sequential order here.

45
00:02:37.140 --> 00:02:41.200
Where it goes initiation,
planning, execution, monitoring and

46
00:02:41.200 --> 00:02:43.900
controlling, and
then lastly closing out a project.

47
00:02:43.900 --> 00:02:46.370
Essentially ending that project as well.

48
00:02:46.370 --> 00:02:49.730
But overall though what you'll end up
finding out about project management

49
00:02:49.730 --> 00:02:52.530
is that it's a fairly cyclical process and

50
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:55.980
everything that you do is
really a cyclical process here.

51
00:02:55.980 --> 00:02:59.620
Even though planning normally
does lead to the execution but

52
00:02:59.620 --> 00:03:03.860
at the same time you're also gonna end up
doing monitoring as well because if not,

53
00:03:03.860 --> 00:03:06.750
imagine you finishing everything
that you do with a project.

54
00:03:06.750 --> 00:03:08.520
And then you go back and
say, now it's time for

55
00:03:08.520 --> 00:03:12.900
me to go into quality control and quality
assurance and doing all these things, and

56
00:03:12.900 --> 00:03:15.630
then realizing half the stuff
that you did is wrong.

57
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:19.470
So yes, you do have these things
going on simultaneously, and

58
00:03:19.470 --> 00:03:22.760
also notice these red arrows
that I have here too.

59
00:03:22.760 --> 00:03:26.520
What you'll end up finding out as you
start executing certain things inside your

60
00:03:26.520 --> 00:03:28.140
project start monitoring and

61
00:03:28.140 --> 00:03:32.470
controlling, you might find out that some
of your project plan was not realistic.

62
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.830
I shouldn't say not realistic, was not
exactly where you thought it would be.

63
00:03:35.830 --> 00:03:40.730
And so that those now become
inputs back into your project plan

64
00:03:40.730 --> 00:03:43.480
that allows you to change
whatever the execution is.

65
00:03:43.480 --> 00:03:47.800
And then maybe even modify whatever that
controlling aspect of it is if you need to

66
00:03:47.800 --> 00:03:51.630
to help bring the project forward
into its ultimate conclusion.

67
00:03:51.630 --> 00:03:54.290
So ideally of course that means
at the end of monitoring and

68
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:58.960
controlling, we now have a quality product
and the project close out but essentially

69
00:03:58.960 --> 00:04:02.210
these things finish at the same time and
that's why you see this yellow arrow here.

70
00:04:02.210 --> 00:04:06.060
It's not really in existence it's just
something that happens at the same time,

71
00:04:06.060 --> 00:04:11.180
now where are we right now in our series
inside of CompTia's project plus.

72
00:04:11.180 --> 00:04:14.610
We're still taking a look
at the initiation here and

73
00:04:14.610 --> 00:04:17.710
we're kind of deep diving
into that a little more.

74
00:04:17.710 --> 00:04:21.956
Where we talked about the idea
of that pre project set up and

75
00:04:21.956 --> 00:04:26.550
what we want to begin with is this
particular process right here

76
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:30.034
where we take a look at what is a project,
okay?

77
00:04:30.034 --> 00:04:34.421
What is a project and that's actually very
important to everything that we actually

78
00:04:34.421 --> 00:04:36.390
need to understand here.

79
00:04:36.390 --> 00:04:40.680
Very easy for someone, maybe new
to the idea of project management,

80
00:04:40.680 --> 00:04:45.180
to take a look at everything that they've
dealt with as being some type of project.

81
00:04:45.180 --> 00:04:47.910
And don't get me wrong,
it's possible that they actually started

82
00:04:47.910 --> 00:04:51.290
off in an organization in which
everything was a project.

83
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:54.820
But most of us though have
come along in organizations

84
00:04:54.820 --> 00:04:56.960
in which there is a functional manager.

85
00:04:56.960 --> 00:05:00.220
There's departments, and
what you essentially end up doing as you

86
00:05:00.220 --> 00:05:04.030
enter into that department is that
you really have one supervisor.

87
00:05:04.030 --> 00:05:07.440
That particular supervisor
also has one supervisor.

88
00:05:07.440 --> 00:05:10.900
That supervisor probably has one
supervisor that he's reporting to.

89
00:05:10.900 --> 00:05:13.380
And the work just continues
to get done that way.

90
00:05:13.380 --> 00:05:15.090
And then orders are handed down.

91
00:05:15.090 --> 00:05:17.570
And then you end up with
actually fulfilling that order.

92
00:05:17.570 --> 00:05:20.010
And then again, you report to
whoever's actually above you.

93
00:05:20.010 --> 00:05:23.620
And that works, and
that's the way that certain things are.

94
00:05:23.620 --> 00:05:27.880
But the fact is that's actually different
than the work of what we talk about inside

95
00:05:27.880 --> 00:05:29.080
of our project.

96
00:05:29.080 --> 00:05:34.630
So the most basic sentence definition
of what our project really is,

97
00:05:34.630 --> 00:05:36.070
begins right here.

98
00:05:36.070 --> 00:05:43.470
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create
a unique product, service, or result.

99
00:05:43.470 --> 00:05:46.990
Now I'm keying in on the term unique here,
okay?

100
00:05:46.990 --> 00:05:51.000
And the key is that idea is that
whatever is actually resulted

101
00:05:51.000 --> 00:05:55.280
from the idea of this project is
something that is actually unique.

102
00:05:55.280 --> 00:06:00.230
But it doesn't mean that we also avoid the
rest of this sentence definition that we

103
00:06:00.230 --> 00:06:04.920
have here too, we also need to key in on
the terms, of course, temporary endeavor.

104
00:06:04.920 --> 00:06:09.060
As well as the idea of
creating that unique project.

105
00:06:09.060 --> 00:06:11.330
So when we talk about the ideas here,

106
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:14.090
I want to actually give three examples,
okay?

107
00:06:14.090 --> 00:06:18.200
Because of the way that it describes
here as being a unique product,

108
00:06:18.200 --> 00:06:22.030
a unique service, or
even some type of unique result.

109
00:06:22.030 --> 00:06:26.700
So the first one that I thought
about is the idea of a product,

110
00:06:26.700 --> 00:06:30.890
that's also came from the result
of a project as well.

111
00:06:30.890 --> 00:06:32.720
Which is something like men's razors.

112
00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:36.620
Now don't get me wrong, I've been
shaving the hell out in less than 25,

113
00:06:36.620 --> 00:06:39.350
30 years now at least.

114
00:06:39.350 --> 00:06:41.380
I'm going to say 30 plus years now.

115
00:06:41.380 --> 00:06:45.130
And razors have actually undergone
changes during those 30 years.

116
00:06:45.130 --> 00:06:47.611
>> I'm not familiar with this
term razors and shaving.

117
00:06:47.611 --> 00:06:49.120
[LAUGH]
>> [CROSSTALK] You might

118
00:06:49.120 --> 00:06:51.705
actually think that I'm not
familiar with it either,

119
00:06:51.705 --> 00:06:55.486
but I shave around the outside, I don't
really tend to shave too much any more.

120
00:06:55.486 --> 00:06:57.222

they cannot just be well just get it done.

569
00:30:17.690 --> 00:30:19.270
That doesn't make sense to us.

570
00:30:19.270 --> 00:30:21.090
They have to be realistic
in what figure or

571
00:30:21.090 --> 00:30:23.380
time period know these things and timely,

572
00:30:23.380 --> 00:30:26.960
in other words we have to finish this
actually within those requirements there.

573
00:30:26.960 --> 00:30:29.900
We need to make sure that the stake
holders understand that as well.

574
00:30:29.900 --> 00:30:34.830
So inside of a project, right there's a
lot of elements that we need to make sure

575
00:30:34.830 --> 00:30:38.110
that we can actually do and
that we can characterize in this.

576
00:30:38.110 --> 00:30:41.590
Because when it comes down
to project manager, right?

577
00:30:41.590 --> 00:30:44.770
All of project management,
everything that we end up doing

578
00:30:44.770 --> 00:30:48.060
actually makes us work within what we
call three different constraints here.

579
00:30:48.060 --> 00:30:49.960
Let me show you what I'm talking about.

580
00:30:49.960 --> 00:30:53.220
Those constraints a lot of times that
you hear about and everybody does this

581
00:30:53.220 --> 00:30:57.140
a little bit differently, I do this on the
points most of the time when you see this

582
00:30:57.140 --> 00:31:00.740
people actually line up these different
qualities or whatever you want to on

583
00:31:00.740 --> 00:31:05.770
the side which is perfectly fine but
we talk about the idea of scope, time and

584
00:31:05.770 --> 00:31:09.930
cost you may hear the terms
requirement schedule and budget.

585
00:31:09.930 --> 00:31:11.030
So what does that mean?

586
00:31:11.030 --> 00:31:12.700
That means that when
your working a project.

587
00:31:13.810 --> 00:31:15.190
You have to keep all these in balance.

588
00:31:15.190 --> 00:31:16.320
Or what happens?

589
00:31:16.320 --> 00:31:18.640
If I emphasize that I want to save money.

590
00:31:19.650 --> 00:31:20.680
Right here more.

591
00:31:20.680 --> 00:31:21.330
Okay.

592
00:31:21.330 --> 00:31:25.800
If that is my overall go as
the pinpoint the idea of budget.

593
00:31:25.800 --> 00:31:29.730
Or what ends up happening is that, that
will automatically affect requirement and

594
00:31:29.730 --> 00:31:31.640
of course the schedule, okay?

595
00:31:31.640 --> 00:31:34.910
The budget means I'll actually go
ahead and maybe I'll cut short on

596
00:31:34.910 --> 00:31:39.250
the requirements, as quality will go low,
or it will take me a lot longer in time.

597
00:31:39.250 --> 00:31:43.180
If I emphasize you have
to be done on the 31st,

598
00:31:43.180 --> 00:31:47.910
it may cost me a lot more money, or
I may cut on out on a requirement.

599
00:31:47.910 --> 00:31:51.110
If I emphasized that
quality has to be the best

600
00:31:51.110 --> 00:31:55.750
it might take me a lot longer in time and
a lot more expenses here.

601
00:31:55.750 --> 00:32:00.030
So normally the old adage, and again I
hate being cliche, but it works here.

602
00:32:00.030 --> 00:32:04.370
Is that everybody want something good,
fast, and cheap, okay?

603
00:32:04.370 --> 00:32:06.230
That's what every project wants to do.

604
00:32:06.230 --> 00:32:08.770
But the reality is you can
only really accomplish

605
00:32:08.770 --> 00:32:10.690
all three if you keep them in balance.

606
00:32:10.690 --> 00:32:13.760
But you're not gonna actually
be able to do all of that, okay?

607
00:32:13.760 --> 00:32:16.270
So in other words, you'll be able to
do two out of the three is what will

608
00:32:16.270 --> 00:32:17.240
end up happening.

609
00:32:17.240 --> 00:32:21.050
You focus in on cheap,
don't expect fast and good, okay?

610
00:32:21.050 --> 00:32:23.970
You focus in on good,
don't expect fast and cheap, okay?

611
00:32:23.970 --> 00:32:28.060
Focus on the fast, you're not gonna
get good and it might be cheap, but

612
00:32:28.060 --> 00:32:31.230
overall though, just kind of realize
it might not be cheap either.

613
00:32:31.230 --> 00:32:35.650
So you do have this kind of unusual
constraint that every project manager and

614
00:32:35.650 --> 00:32:38.090
every project is gonna be constrained by.

615
00:32:38.090 --> 00:32:41.800
If you actually find some task that you've
actually worked on that is not constrained

616
00:32:41.800 --> 00:32:45.130
by these things, more than likely,
it's operational type of work.

617
00:32:45.130 --> 00:32:46.510
>> That's excellent stuff Ronnie.

618
00:32:46.510 --> 00:32:48.450
This is the meat and potatoes.

619
00:32:48.450 --> 00:32:52.320
So that when you walk into that exam
environment, you're gonna be able to

620
00:32:52.320 --> 00:32:56.140
answer the questions adequately, and then
start talking about what is a project,

621
00:32:56.140 --> 00:32:59.390
you're gonna be able to discern
the difference between that project and

622
00:32:59.390 --> 00:33:01.290
an operation, something ongoing.

623
00:33:01.290 --> 00:33:04.760
Thank you Ronnie so much for
helping us be able to do that very thing,

624
00:33:04.760 --> 00:33:08.340
we appreciate you stopping by
the studio today and to do that for us.

625
00:33:08.340 --> 00:33:10.750
We also appreciate you guys watching.

626
00:33:10.750 --> 00:33:14.330
Well we are gonna sign off we are kinda
out of time for this here episode.

627
00:33:14.330 --> 00:33:16.740
So that being said,
signing off for ITProTV.

628
00:33:16.740 --> 00:33:18.350
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

629
00:33:18.350 --> 00:33:19.000
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

630
00:33:19.000 --> 00:33:21.043
And we'll see you next time.

631
00:33:21.043 --> 00:33:26.460
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel walk you through the project validation process. They begin by showing the need to justify a project due to some demand or business need such as market demand, customer request, technology advance, or legal requirement. They also look at how benefits to the organization are grounds for a project's existence. Finally, they also cover topics like feasibility and strategic plan alignment.
episodes.title: Validate a Project
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.040 --> 00:00:16.690
Alright, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another fantastic episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:19.660
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:23.300
we're continuing on with
CompTIA's Project+ series.

5
00:00:23.300 --> 00:00:26.590
Joining me in the studio today to help
lend his expertise on that very topic

6
00:00:26.590 --> 00:00:28.158
is none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:28.158 --> 00:00:30.568
>> [LAUGH]
>> Welcome to the show, sir.

8
00:00:30.568 --> 00:00:31.168
How you doing today?

9
00:00:31.168 --> 00:00:32.228
>> Well, I'm doing well.

10
00:00:32.228 --> 00:00:33.120
I was afraid that you forgot my name.

11
00:00:33.120 --> 00:00:34.650
>> It was a little pregnant pause there.

12
00:00:34.650 --> 00:00:35.860
>> Yes, very nice.

13
00:00:35.860 --> 00:00:37.175
But hey, here we are.

14
00:00:37.175 --> 00:00:40.955
We're back with CompTIA Project+ and
we are ready to get started now.

15
00:00:40.955 --> 00:00:44.830
Now, what we're doing today is we're gonna
talk about validating an actual project

16
00:00:44.830 --> 00:00:49.010
as we get started here with some of
the things that we need to be able

17
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:49.520
to do, right?

18
00:00:49.520 --> 00:00:54.360
So in previous episodes, we've already
taken a look at the pre-project phases for

19
00:00:54.360 --> 00:00:59.090
our project, and we also went back and
we emphasized what our project is.

20
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:00.630
We talked about those
different characteristics

21
00:01:00.630 --> 00:01:04.580
that we have to understand, and now we're
also continuing to move on through here.

22
00:01:04.580 --> 00:01:09.560
But we need to take a little bit more
detailed look into validating the project.

23
00:01:09.560 --> 00:01:12.200
And when it comes out to
a project validation,

24
00:01:12.200 --> 00:01:15.350
we're going to actually end up looking
at two real overall scopes, but

25
00:01:15.350 --> 00:01:19.420
we're going to go into detail on each
of those two sub-phases instead.

26
00:01:19.420 --> 00:01:22.251
So let's go ahead and
start off with our reminder here,

27
00:01:22.251 --> 00:01:25.240
where projects actually begin and
where they end.

28
00:01:25.240 --> 00:01:27.740
Remember that every single
project is gonna have

29
00:01:27.740 --> 00:01:31.940
about five different phases that
projects tend to work through, right?

30
00:01:31.940 --> 00:01:36.910
The very initiation, or what we call
the pre-project planning, the pre-project

31
00:01:36.910 --> 00:01:40.100
setup, I want to call it planning
because we're so used to planning, but

32
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:43.570
it's called pre-project setup here,
is gonna be the initiation.

33
00:01:43.570 --> 00:01:45.900
Before anything is actually ever done,

34
00:01:45.900 --> 00:01:48.880
we need to be able to know
what project we're working on.

35
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:52.990
We need to be able to set it up and verify
that this is the project that we want.

36
00:01:52.990 --> 00:01:56.908
And so make sure you go back and
check those episodes out as we do so.

37
00:01:56.908 --> 00:02:01.133
From that point, once you do
have that final project charter,

38
00:02:01.133 --> 00:02:04.420
that is when we start switching phases,
right?

39
00:02:04.420 --> 00:02:06.848
The project charter gives us
the authorization that we need.

40
00:02:06.848 --> 00:02:09.130
From that point,
we enter into the planning phase.

41
00:02:09.130 --> 00:02:13.705
And the planning phase, normally,
is gonna take the longest part of our

42
00:02:13.705 --> 00:02:18.055
project management because a lot has
to go into the planning phase for

43
00:02:18.055 --> 00:02:20.990
us before we can actually
even begin any work.

44
00:02:20.990 --> 00:02:24.771
We wanna make sure we show the detail, the
time, and the effort inside that planning

45
00:02:24.771 --> 00:02:28.350
to make sure that we've actually covered
all that we actually needed to there.

46
00:02:28.350 --> 00:02:32.913
Once we have all the plans in place, we
then begin to transition into execution,

47
00:02:32.913 --> 00:02:35.948
in which the project work
is now being accomplished.

48
00:02:35.948 --> 00:02:40.160
And also, we now turn into more

49
00:02:40.160 --> 00:02:42.430
a controlling agent at that point.

50
00:02:42.430 --> 00:02:44.270
Keeping things on schedule, right?

51
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:49.810
According to time, cost, and, of course,
work effort that we have on-hand here.

52
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:53.430
And remember that even though these
things might continue to move forward,

53
00:02:53.430 --> 00:02:56.270
we might find out that what it does is,
as we move forward,

54
00:02:56.270 --> 00:02:58.620
we run into different things

55
00:02:58.620 --> 00:03:00.814
That may change our planning for

56
00:03:00.814 --> 00:03:03.530
may even change some of the outcomes

57
00:03:03.530 --> 00:03:08.378
So those can also bring in inputs

58
00:03:08.378 --> 00:03:11.898

59
00:03:11.898 --> 00:03:14.378
And ultimately, of course,

60
00:03:14.378 --> 00:03:18.590

end, hopefully to the result that we want,

61
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:22.390
to the product or service that we
thought we've actually created.

62
00:03:22.390 --> 00:03:26.890
So that's kind of a brief overview of the
way that all projects end up running, and

63
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:29.480
if you're sitting there going Ronnie, you
say this at the beginning of every show,

64
00:03:29.480 --> 00:03:33.210
there's a reason why, because it's fairly
important that we understand that.

65
00:03:33.210 --> 00:03:36.910
So now what we're doing is we
are now moving on then, right?

66
00:03:36.910 --> 00:03:39.840
We've described the idea of being able
to identify the difference between

67
00:03:39.840 --> 00:03:44.680

a project that we would end up working on.

68
00:03:44.680 --> 00:03:47.810
And now what we need to do, of course,

00:03:47.810 --> 00:03:52.900

70
00:03:52.900 --> 00:03:55.490
And in other words,
why does it actually exist?

71

And that is something that
we need to understand.

00:03:57.165 --> 00:04:00.110
Okay?
And the whole point of this is not saying

I know I why the project needs to exist.

In your mind, that's perfectly fine.

75
00:04:04.420 --> 00:04:07.933
But remember that as a project manager
you're gonna be working with a ton of

76
00:04:07.933 --> 00:04:11.335
different people, and right at
the beginning, it's gonna be a project

77
00:04:11.335 --> 00:04:15.690
stakeholder at least that's going to be
somewhat like the project sponsor itself.

78
00:04:15.690 --> 00:04:19.060
And there may be a team of people
that you end up working with, and

79
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:21.320
what you need to do is you
need to formalize process.

80
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:23.420
In other words, it needs to be documented.

81
00:04:23.420 --> 00:04:27.046
And the validation itself needs to
be documented in the process, and

82
00:04:27.046 --> 00:04:30.650
what actually makes this project
need to come into existence.

83
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:32.100
And that's what we're gonna look at today.

84
00:04:32.100 --> 00:04:35.820
All right, so what we're really doing
is we're preparing a business case.

85
00:04:35.820 --> 00:04:37.510
Now, remember that the business case for

86
00:04:37.510 --> 00:04:40.660
us is trying to make sure
that there is some reason,

87
00:04:40.660 --> 00:04:45.600
some real justification, not just because
well, it's what we want to do here.

88
00:04:45.600 --> 00:04:50.130
So what does that boil down to when
it comes down to project management?

89
00:04:50.130 --> 00:04:51.570
What is it that we depend on?

90
00:04:51.570 --> 00:04:54.570
Remember what I said, you can't just
depend on your feelings to do so.

91
00:04:54.570 --> 00:04:58.590
Well, there's really seven areas that we
need to cover if we want to take a look at

92
00:04:58.590 --> 00:05:02.730
the idea here of taking a look at
why a project might actually exist.

93
00:05:02.730 --> 00:05:06.540
And normally, again, it kind of breaks
down into this, that there's a demand or

94
00:05:06.540 --> 00:05:10.280
business need that
the project actually exist.

95
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:12.370
So what we're gonna do is
we're gonna slowly and

96
00:05:12.370 --> 00:05:16.810
carefully take a look at these seven
different business cases that we have.

97
00:05:16.810 --> 00:05:19.891
And let's go ahead and
take a look at my screen here and

98
00:05:19.891 --> 00:05:22.792
then we can talk about them

99
00:05:22.792 --> 00:05:25.840
Looks like, actually, let me see if
I can zoom in just a little bit more.

100
00:05:25.840 --> 00:05:26.690
There we go.

101
00:05:26.690 --> 00:05:28.265
That might make it a little
bit easier to see.

102

>> Now Ronny, I noticed one of these

00:05:31.510 --> 00:05:33.370
It's not on that list.

104
00:05:33.370 --> 00:05:35.840
>> Yeah,
it doesn't seem to be on that list, and

105
00:05:35.840 --> 00:05:39.640
that's kind of neat that it really isn't,
but it's very easy to fall into.

106
00:05:39.640 --> 00:05:43.189
Daniel is probably working for an

108
00:05:47.300 --> 00:05:48.490
Because we can.

Some people, because of their authority

00:05:53.310 --> 00:05:56.530
more than anything else, they were just

But as a project manager,

But a lot of times though, the money

that means if you're actually going to

00:06:09.020 --> 00:06:12.730
some justification that's gonna

117
00:06:14.340 --> 00:06:17.930
So the first one is really

119
00:06:21.590 --> 00:06:22.660
Okay?

What ends up happening is that you see,

00:06:33.960 --> 00:06:37.970
An opportunity that we can
see that drives the need for

124
00:06:37.970 --> 00:06:40.380

00:06:40.380 --> 00:06:41.080
Okay?

126
00:06:41.080 --> 00:06:46.030
And that is by far probably the reason

00:06:46.030 --> 00:06:49.676

128
00:06:49.676 --> 00:06:51.550
Into future developments or
product developments, and

130
00:06:53.020 --> 00:06:57.020
Now, what I want to do is, I want to take

00:06:57.020 --> 00:06:59.870

I came from the day before

00:07:07.430 --> 00:07:12.020
So I had the original flip phone, I had
the brick phone, I had all these things.

00:07:12.020 --> 00:07:13.920
Essentially, they were just phones, right?

135
00:07:13.920 --> 00:07:15.900
They weren't really accessories.

136
00:07:15.900 --> 00:07:16.930
Dan, you remember those days?

137
00:07:16.930 --> 00:07:18.570
When they just weren't really accessories,

138
00:07:18.570 --> 00:07:20.797
they were just things that you
had cause you had to have them?

139
00:07:20.797 --> 00:07:22.510
>> Yeah, I totally remember having those.

140
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:24.378
>> Yeah.

141
00:07:24.378 --> 00:07:24.940
>> I had a flip phone I had a bag phone.

142
00:07:24.940 --> 00:07:26.590
>> A bag phone?
>> Yeah, back in the day.

143
00:07:26.590 --> 00:07:30.525
>> Yeah, you didn't just carry that around

144
00:07:30.525 --> 00:07:31.090
>> Yeah, no.

145
00:07:31.090 --> 00:07:33.670
[LAUGH]
>> So most of us didn't do that, but

146
00:07:33.670 --> 00:07:37.890
one of the phenomenons that I realized,
that actually had a market demand,

147
00:07:37.890 --> 00:07:41.370
which was something I didn't realize

148
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:43.960
is that all of a sudden people
started buying iPhones.

149
00:07:43.960 --> 00:07:45.240
Now, I'm not talking
about the iPhone itself.

150
00:07:45.240 --> 00:07:46.870
Don't get me wrong,
that's a great project.

151
00:07:46.870 --> 00:07:50.380
It has made more money for
Apple than anything else on the planet.

152
00:07:50.380 --> 00:07:54.242
But along with that, people started
realizing my gosh, if I carry this around,

153
00:07:54.242 --> 00:07:55.578
it's gonna get scratched.

154
00:07:55.578 --> 00:07:56.970
It's gonna get, you know.

155
00:07:56.970 --> 00:08:01.707
And so people started kind
of polishing them every day.

156
00:08:01.707 --> 00:08:06.247
But after a while someone saw
a need that was there, okay.

157
00:08:06.247 --> 00:08:10.877
And these are all those companies that
have produced those different covers for

158
00:08:10.877 --> 00:08:12.200
the iPhones, right?

159
00:08:12.200 --> 00:08:14.460

And you might think about something
like that, but the very fact is

That city needs to actually

This is the responsibility

Part of project validation is actually

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the components of a project Charter. They take you through common elements found in a project Charter; elements such as the Problem Statement, constraints, risks, and objectives. Understanding how to draft a Charter will give your projects a well defined scope and boundaries.

As different components here,

Remember that this is actually

What problem are we trying to solve?

00:11:16.361 --> 00:11:19.420

Because even though people deal in

Now the reason why that's

So overall though, you want to make

00:12:54.890 --> 00:12:56.190
In that project charter,

Why in the world do we need the project?

00:13:01.590 --> 00:13:06.860
What is it specifically that we can

00:13:06.860 --> 00:13:10.666
And then, what is that ultimate

00:13:10.666 --> 00:13:13.350
So being able to have those basic,

00:13:13.350 --> 00:13:18.030

Most of the time when you actually do

00:13:23.940 --> 00:13:27.255
They're trying to examine them, your

00:13:32.260 --> 00:13:36.380

00:13:36.380 --> 00:13:40.370
So these are things that we really want to

00:13:47.680 --> 00:13:52.220

Subject matter expert,
that's what I was trying to think of.

00:14:06.690 --> 00:14:10.780
So, again my words are getting a little
bit twisted up, but you come together and

00:14:10.780 --> 00:14:14.500
you're trying to make sure is this
project is something that can be done?

00:14:14.500 --> 00:14:17.230
Is everything that we need right here and

00:14:17.230 --> 00:14:22.330
so you wanna make sure that that's

00:14:22.330 --> 00:14:26.740
So, those are two kind of very basic
elements that we need to think about but

00:14:26.740 --> 00:14:29.270
after that though,
we also have to present some facts and

00:14:29.270 --> 00:14:32.260
some details as what we also need to do.

00:14:32.260 --> 00:14:35.640
So, that is the third thing that we
also want to take a look at as well.

253
00:14:36.660 --> 00:14:38.210
So, when we start taking a look here,

254
00:14:38.210 --> 00:14:40.870
we talk about some of the different
high level assumptions.

255
00:14:42.230 --> 00:14:45.200
Again, I'm gonna be cliche Dan,

00:14:45.200 --> 00:14:48.500
you know we've all heard this,
what happens when we assume things?

00:14:48.500 --> 00:14:50.840
We make a-
>> We are correct 100% of the time.

You're giving them the opportunity

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel continue explaining how to prepare a project charter. Here they get into the development of the charter consisting of the previously discussed elements (inputs and tools/techniques). They will also describe other components of a charter(output) like key deliverables, milestones, cost estimates and stakeholders.
