get that project charter to the point
where the actual sponsor says yes,

550
00:29:59.992 --> 00:30:02.325
that is something I can approve of, okay?

551
00:30:02.325 --> 00:30:06.993
So, you might actually have
to facilitate the dialog.

552
00:30:06.993 --> 00:30:09.315
You might have to facilitate
whatever it needs to,

553
00:30:09.315 --> 00:30:12.015
to bring everybody into
an agreement in the way that needs.

554
00:30:12.015 --> 00:30:15.082
And this again depends on
this environmental factor,

555
00:30:15.082 --> 00:30:16.755
condition that you face too.

556
00:30:16.755 --> 00:30:21.093
And might find out that you have to
get let's say three out of five of

557
00:30:21.093 --> 00:30:24.893
your department heads to agree
that this is great, okay,

558
00:30:24.893 --> 00:30:27.930
before you can even submit that for
approval.

559
00:30:28.960 --> 00:30:32.208
So in other words you may actually find
out that you have to facilitate what it

560
00:30:32.208 --> 00:30:35.503
takes to do so, you may have to go to
every single project manager to do so, but

561
00:30:35.503 --> 00:30:37.628
you kind of realize that
you'll have to do that.

562
00:30:37.628 --> 00:30:42.293
Ultimately though okay, what we hope of
course at the end we end up with that

563
00:30:42.293 --> 00:30:46.680
project charter with all those
elements that we talked about, okay.

564
00:30:46.680 --> 00:30:50.380
In the very end here as the output notes,
what is the final doc?

565
00:30:50.380 --> 00:30:52.914
What is it that we're trying
to gain from this proposal,

566
00:30:52.914 --> 00:30:55.850
which is that project charter, okay.

567
00:30:55.850 --> 00:31:00.730
Once we have that project charter, right,
that means we now have a formal document

568
00:31:00.730 --> 00:31:03.640
in hand that we can now
present to somebody for

569
00:31:03.640 --> 00:31:07.260
signature, which is a key
element of the project charter.

570
00:31:07.260 --> 00:31:12.290
And then that now begins the process
of saying that it can be authorized for

571
00:31:12.290 --> 00:31:16.660
the release of funds and resources,
and for the project to move from

572
00:31:16.660 --> 00:31:22.520
the initiation stage now into the planning
stage, is what we're hoping for.

573
00:31:22.520 --> 00:31:26.890
So if you actually do need to make
a project charter, usually the way that we

574
00:31:26.890 --> 00:31:31.220
begin is by using these inputs, running
through those tools and techniques, and

575
00:31:31.220 --> 00:31:34.560
then producing the output right there
of the project charter that we need.

576
00:31:34.560 --> 00:31:35.193
>> Awesome stuff, Ronnie.

577
00:31:35.193 --> 00:31:38.131
Well you've done a really good job of,
something's wrong.

578
00:31:38.131 --> 00:31:39.830
No?

579
00:31:39.830 --> 00:31:41.111
>> I thought it was locked up,
but it wasn't.

580
00:31:41.111 --> 00:31:42.678
>> Okay.
>> [LAUGH]

581
00:31:42.678 --> 00:31:44.445
>> Cuz I saw her go-

582
00:31:44.445 --> 00:31:45.389
>> Well I clicked it and

583
00:31:45.389 --> 00:31:48.158
it didn't go and I was like,
crap, it must be frozen.

584
00:31:48.158 --> 00:31:50.712
>> No.
>> I don't know what that was.

585
00:31:50.712 --> 00:31:52.803
Sorry.
>> That's fine, no problem.

586
00:31:52.803 --> 00:31:53.836
>> Start back from you again.

587
00:31:53.836 --> 00:31:56.960
[LAUGH] All right.

588
00:31:56.960 --> 00:31:59.158
>> We care not about these things.

589
00:32:03.967 --> 00:32:06.344
Tip of the tongue, teeth, and the lips.

590
00:32:06.344 --> 00:32:10.312
[LAUGH] Awesome stuff, Ronnie.

591
00:32:10.312 --> 00:32:14.750
Obviously you've done a really good job of
taking us through the beginning phases.

592
00:32:14.750 --> 00:32:17.300
What we need, those inputs,
moving into tools and

593
00:32:17.300 --> 00:32:20.600
techniques of what we can use to
start formulating that charter.

594
00:32:20.600 --> 00:32:24.980
And then ultimately the end result being
a charter that can be authorized, and

595
00:32:24.980 --> 00:32:26.450
then work can begin.

596
00:32:26.450 --> 00:32:29.520
So thank you so much for
walking us through that process.

597
00:32:29.520 --> 00:32:30.370
Did a great job with that.

598
00:32:30.370 --> 00:32:32.840
Thank you for joining us today,
and thank you guys out there for

599
00:32:32.840 --> 00:32:33.810
joining us today as well.

600
00:32:33.810 --> 00:32:35.970
We're gonna go ahead and
sign of for ITProTV.

601
00:32:35.970 --> 00:32:37.451
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

602
00:32:37.451 --> 00:32:38.356
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

603
00:32:38.356 --> 00:32:39.226
>> And we'll see you next time.

604
00:32:39.226 --> 00:32:47.309
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the elements that make up Process Groups, which includes Inputs, Tools, and Outputs. Then they explain how to outline the 5 process groups, specifically initiation/pre-project setup, planning, executing, monitoring, and closing.
episodes.title: Outline Process Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.169 --> 00:00:10.169
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.019 --> 00:00:16.163
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.163 --> 00:00:19.424
I'm you're host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.424 --> 00:00:22.340
well, we are continuing on
with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.340 --> 00:00:25.042
Joining us again in the studio today
is none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:25.042 --> 00:00:27.090
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

7
00:00:27.090 --> 00:00:27.660
>> Well thank you for

8
00:00:27.660 --> 00:00:32.570
having me back as we continue on taking
a look at CompTIA's Project+, and

9
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:35.840
we are continuing on our series
here through the initiation phase.

10
00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:40.420
And today is really more of a review
of that initiation phase, making

11
00:00:40.420 --> 00:00:45.390
sure that we cover all of our bases before
we move on into the areas of planning.

12
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:47.300
Where really the majority of the work for

13
00:00:47.300 --> 00:00:51.540
project management really does lie
on the project manager himself.

14
00:00:51.540 --> 00:00:54.050
And he has a responsibility
to get all of that done.

15
00:00:54.050 --> 00:00:56.060
But what we wanna also
take a look at here,

16
00:00:56.060 --> 00:00:59.600
of course, is where it breaks down and
what we actually have to remember.

17
00:00:59.600 --> 00:01:02.700
And we're gonna take a look
at those five process groups

18
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:06.900
in which every single project ends up
moving through and making sure that

19
00:01:06.900 --> 00:01:10.480
we do understand what goes on in each
of those process groups as well.

20
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:15.041
Now before we do that, there's a couple
of unusual things that are also

21
00:01:15.041 --> 00:01:19.222
going on at the same time here,
in which things have been changing

22
00:01:19.222 --> 00:01:23.347
during the time of the existence
of the CompTIA Project+ exam.

23
00:01:23.347 --> 00:01:26.720
And so you might see some of
these changes as well, okay?

24
00:01:26.720 --> 00:01:29.240
So let me show you what I'm
talking about here, okay?

25
00:01:29.240 --> 00:01:34.720
So CompTIA specifically takes a look
at the idea of project management,

26
00:01:34.720 --> 00:01:39.150
and it says look, we're basing everything
really off of what is in the PMBOK.

27
00:01:39.150 --> 00:01:43.120
The PMBOK is that
Project Management Book of Knowledge.

28
00:01:43.120 --> 00:01:45.210
And at this point as of
the filming right now,

29
00:01:45.210 --> 00:01:49.330
the current edition of it is either
in the fifth or sixth edition.

30
00:01:49.330 --> 00:01:54.988
Now when the CompTIA Project+ though first
came out, it was in an earlier edition.

31
00:01:54.988 --> 00:01:58.585
And this means that you might
find yourself with a mix

32
00:01:58.585 --> 00:02:02.266
of different questions which
will call out things and

33
00:02:02.266 --> 00:02:06.080
which aren't gonna be in
line with the current PMBOK.

34
00:02:06.080 --> 00:02:07.478
So let me give you an example.

35
00:02:07.478 --> 00:02:10.200
What we've been going through right now,
right,

36
00:02:10.200 --> 00:02:15.140
is of course what's actually found inside
of the PMBOK and the way that they do it.

37
00:02:15.140 --> 00:02:19.960
And the process of project management
breaks down into five separate processes

38
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:24.880
here, right, the initiation phase,
the idea of the planning phase,

39
00:02:24.880 --> 00:02:29.010
execution, monitoring and
controlling, and closing.

40
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:33.218
And that's how you tend to see them in
sequence inside of the PMBOK in its

41
00:02:33.218 --> 00:02:34.354
current edition.

42
00:02:34.354 --> 00:02:39.406
Now, that particular process,
five different process groups,

43
00:02:39.406 --> 00:02:44.840
I should say, break down into
47 different processes, okay.

44
00:02:44.840 --> 00:02:49.960
So, that's they way that it currently is
right now inside of the actual PMBOK, and

45
00:02:49.960 --> 00:02:53.640
that's how we're actually developing
the courses along those lines.

46
00:02:53.640 --> 00:02:59.440
But, when this particular exam is
actually also current, is that you

47
00:02:59.440 --> 00:03:04.630
actually end up seeing that an earlier
addition of the PMBOK, instead of talking

48
00:03:04.630 --> 00:03:10.270
about five process group, called out
project management knowledge areas.

49
00:03:10.270 --> 00:03:11.656
Now, is it the same thing?

50
00:03:11.656 --> 00:03:16.398
Yes, they just chose to present
the material group differently is

51
00:03:16.398 --> 00:03:17.506
what they did.

52
00:03:17.506 --> 00:03:22.360
And so, what I want you to actually be
able to focus in on, for those of you that

53
00:03:22.360 --> 00:03:27.217
are preparing for the exam as a candidate,
right, is that if you hear the term

54
00:03:27.217 --> 00:03:32.370
project management knowledge area, or
which of the knowledge areas here.

55
00:03:32.370 --> 00:03:36.620
They are talking about these nine areas,
is what they're talking about.

56
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:38.390
Now, they didn't actually add in or

57
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:41.120
take away anything when
the new edition came out.

58
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:43.760
They just regrouped some of this stuff

59
00:03:43.760 --> 00:03:46.800
to actually say where it
actually went instead.

60
00:03:46.800 --> 00:03:50.840
So, all the project management
guys that came in and

61
00:03:50.840 --> 00:03:54.890
the PMI came together and said look, it's
not that the knowledge areas are bad, but

62
00:03:54.890 --> 00:03:56.930
they really don't focus in on the process.

63
00:03:56.930 --> 00:03:59.430
In other words, you're talking about
all the knowledge that you need,

64
00:03:59.430 --> 00:04:00.360
which is great.

65
00:04:00.360 --> 00:04:04.010
These are areas in which project
managers should be familiar with.

66
00:04:04.010 --> 00:04:06.600
But really project management is not

67
00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:11.110
really about the idea of being
the most knowledgeable person,

68
00:04:11.110 --> 00:04:14.690
it's about the person that can actually
manage what all of this stuff.

69
00:04:14.690 --> 00:04:18.360
So that's why, instead,
that they chose to break it down into

70
00:04:18.360 --> 00:04:23.263
different five process groups that
help you to manage your project,

71
00:04:23.263 --> 00:04:27.860
okay, along these particular steps
because that's what they went through.

72
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:30.860
So, I did wanna make sure that
we pointed these things out,

73
00:04:30.860 --> 00:04:34.920
okay, in that project
management knowledge area

74
00:04:34.920 --> 00:04:37.920
as well as the progress groups cuz
that's gonna be very important.

75
00:04:37.920 --> 00:04:42.181
And if those of you also are perhaps
taking a look at maybe additional

76
00:04:42.181 --> 00:04:45.171
study guides and
study aids that are out there,

77
00:04:45.171 --> 00:04:49.530
the actual official Sybex book calls
out this one right here, okay?

78
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:53.330
And they're saying that this is
what the PMBOK is broken up into.

79
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:55.700
So you may actually see
them referring to that.

80
00:04:55.700 --> 00:04:59.780
Now I can't tell you on the exam whether
they're actually just gonna call out

81
00:04:59.780 --> 00:05:02.990
the second one or
whether they're just gonna call out these.

82
00:05:02.990 --> 00:05:04.620
I can't tell you that, okay?

83
00:05:04.620 --> 00:05:07.670
But the very notion is,
if you hear the term knowledge area,

84
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:12.050
make sure you're familiar
with this terminology here.

85
00:05:12.050 --> 00:05:15.440
And if you actually see where they
mentioned five process groups,

86
00:05:15.440 --> 00:05:17.540
make sure you know this terminology.

87
00:05:17.540 --> 00:05:18.150
A lot of times,

88
00:05:18.150 --> 00:05:22.600
especially on CompTIA exams, knowing the
terminology is actually kinda the bigger

89
00:05:22.600 --> 00:05:26.700
part of a lot of things that you have
to deal with so get used to both.

90
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:27.840
Be prepared for both.

91
00:05:27.840 --> 00:05:30.785
It's not gonna actually trip you up that
much, but if you hear the term knowledge

92
00:05:30.785 --> 00:05:33.798
areas, remember that they're actually
probably referring to an earlier part.

93
00:05:33.798 --> 00:05:37.469
And if you hear the term progress group,
I'm not gonna be able to say that,

94
00:05:37.469 --> 00:05:41.730
progress group, they're probably
referring to the current edition as well.

95
00:05:41.730 --> 00:05:46.202
And this happens when you end up getting
a large pool of the exam questions where

96
00:05:46.202 --> 00:05:49.047
some of the exam questions
are a little bit dated,

97
00:05:49.047 --> 00:05:51.510
and they may refer to the knowledge areas.

98
00:05:51.510 --> 00:05:53.390
But then when they start
adding in new questions,

99
00:05:53.390 --> 00:05:55.985
they'll probably actually base it
on the newer updated material.

100
00:05:55.985 --> 00:06:00.440
So I think that's a great point for
us to make sure we emphasize, Daniel,

101
00:06:00.440 --> 00:06:02.010
is that you may see both.

102
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:02.580
>> Awesome.

103
00:06:02.580 --> 00:06:05.880
Now Ronnie, is there some
common elements that we would

104
00:06:05.880 --> 00:06:08.540
typically find in each one
of these process groups?

105
00:06:08.540 --> 00:06:10.150
>> There definitely is going to be that.

106
00:06:10.150 --> 00:06:13.350
And that's what the PMBOK
really wanted to focus in on.

107
00:06:13.350 --> 00:06:17.601
Those nine areas that we talked about
in the earlier way that the PMBOK was

108
00:06:17.601 --> 00:06:20.860
presented made it kind of
a little bit difficult for

109
00:06:20.860 --> 00:06:22.810
most project managers, right.

110
00:06:22.810 --> 00:06:24.470
You might've been good in finance.

111
00:06:24.470 --> 00:06:26.300
Now Daniel,
I don't know if you are or not.

112
00:06:26.300 --> 00:06:27.741
But I'm not.
I'm not good in math.

113
00:06:27.741 --> 00:06:28.287
>> Horrible in math.

114
00:06:28.287 --> 00:06:31.895
>> If we go into financial formulas and
stuff like that,

115
00:06:31.895 --> 00:06:34.150
I don't know anything about it.

116
00:06:34.150 --> 00:06:39.420
So much that my wife just says Ronnie,
here's ten bucks, make it stretch a week.

117
00:06:39.420 --> 00:06:40.820
And I can do something like that.

118
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:45.000
But, overall though, I might not be
the best financial wizard at doing that.

119
00:06:45.000 --> 00:06:48.260
But when you take a look at those nine
areas, though, it seems like that

120
00:06:48.260 --> 00:06:52.610
the project manager should what,
be an expert at all nine areas, okay.

121
00:06:52.610 --> 00:06:54.362
The very realistic fact is,

122
00:06:54.362 --> 00:06:57.430
you're probably not gonna be
an expert in all those nine areas.

123
00:06:57.430 --> 00:06:59.011
So instead that's when
the PMBOK said look,

124
00:06:59.011 --> 00:07:00.686
you don't have to be
an expert in all the areas.

125
00:07:00.686 --> 00:07:05.328
But as far as the processes go, though,
and then understanding what falls in that

126
00:07:05.328 --> 00:07:09.701
progress group, that's what you actually
have to be able to understand or,

127
00:07:09.701 --> 00:07:12.618
process group, I said progress,
process group.

128
00:07:12.618 --> 00:07:14.825
And that's what we want
to understand instead.

129
00:07:14.825 --> 00:07:16.248
So that's what we're gonna focus in on.

130
00:07:16.248 --> 00:07:21.107
And what we'll actually find out, Daniel,
is between all of these different

131
00:07:21.107 --> 00:07:25.376
process groups here, is that we end
up developing them in the same way

132
00:07:25.376 --> 00:07:30.180
that we actually in every single one,
we develop them in the same way.

133
00:07:30.180 --> 00:07:33.860
We have what we call inputs
to each process group.

134
00:07:33.860 --> 00:07:37.410
We have a set of tools and
techniques that we'll use, and

135
00:07:37.410 --> 00:07:42.000
every progress group is expected
to produce some type of output.

136
00:07:42.000 --> 00:07:45.612
The output, of course, is the deliverable
from that particular progress group.

137
00:07:45.612 --> 00:07:50.415
The inputs, of course, is what actually
influences and what information that we

138
00:07:50.415 --> 00:07:54.256
need to make sure everything in
that process group continues on.

139
00:07:54.256 --> 00:07:58.303
And then the tools and techniques is how
we massage Based on the information to

140
00:07:58.303 --> 00:08:00.246
actually our project deliverable.

141
00:08:00.246 --> 00:08:03.647
So, let me show you an example
of what I'm talking about here,

142
00:08:03.647 --> 00:08:05.780
based on the initiation phase.

143
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:08.530
So, let me go scroll over here.

144
00:08:08.530 --> 00:08:12.670
Now, we're gonna be using pretty much an
outline like this throughout the remainder

145
00:08:12.670 --> 00:08:14.080
of our course.

146
00:08:14.080 --> 00:08:17.950
So that we can clearly keep
this particular idea in mind

147
00:08:17.950 --> 00:08:21.180
of what is common between
all those process groups.

148
00:08:21.180 --> 00:08:22.683
So now think about it,

149
00:08:22.683 --> 00:08:28.630
if you now have a junior project manager
that you are now mentoring up, you know?

150
00:08:28.630 --> 00:08:32.319
And somebody's saying, well what about
these nine areas and they're looking,

151
00:08:32.319 --> 00:08:36.117
they're like, you have to become an expert
in time management, cost management,

152
00:08:36.117 --> 00:08:38.270
resource management, schedule management.

153
00:08:38.270 --> 00:08:40.360
I have to become an expert
in all that stuff?

154
00:08:40.360 --> 00:08:43.100
Well, you can really trip out and
go, absolutely.

155
00:08:43.100 --> 00:08:44.250
Better believe it.

156
00:08:44.250 --> 00:08:47.930
But what if you tell them, hey,
here are the five process groups, and

157
00:08:47.930 --> 00:08:50.220
they pretty much fall in the same line.

158
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:53.580
You need to find out what is it that
we actually need to begin with.

159
00:08:53.580 --> 00:08:55.750
Where is your base knowledge coming from.

160
00:08:55.750 --> 00:09:01.590
Those are the inputs, what goes into
the making up of that initiation stage.

161
00:09:01.590 --> 00:09:05.560
You find all of those elements out and
you glean the information from them.

162
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:10.160
And then you use tools and techniques
that we know that have been tried and

163
00:09:10.160 --> 00:09:15.010
true, that help us to produce the overall
output or element that we have.

164
00:09:15.010 --> 00:09:19.640
So we can take not only in this project
initiation, trying to get rid of that,

165
00:09:19.640 --> 00:09:21.050
get that off the board.

166
00:09:21.050 --> 00:09:25.560
Now, not only can we take this then and
apply it just to the project initiation or

167
00:09:25.560 --> 00:09:29.220
to the pre project setup, but
I can now move into the planning and

168
00:09:29.220 --> 00:09:30.470
do the same thing.

169
00:09:30.470 --> 00:09:33.650
Entirety of planning it,
there's gonna be a lot more inputs because

170

leads us into the idea of closing.

622
00:32:31.200 --> 00:32:34.790
Closing is the formal acceptance
of the project work itself and

623
00:32:34.790 --> 00:32:37.780
this can come in a couple of
different ways here, okay?

624
00:32:37.780 --> 00:32:40.390
We need a way to actually say
that everything is complete and

625
00:32:40.390 --> 00:32:43.165
that we can now take the resource
that we have assigned to our project,

626
00:32:43.165 --> 00:32:47.690
re-assign them to other projects or
release them from the project itself.

627
00:32:47.690 --> 00:32:49.740
We also do a full review,

628
00:32:49.740 --> 00:32:52.910
cuz that way we actually learn from
what we call our lessons learned here,

629
00:32:52.910 --> 00:32:56.190
to see if another project's
actually available for us to go on.

630
00:32:56.190 --> 00:33:00.280
And then we go ahead and we hand off
now whatever it is that we're creating

631
00:33:00.280 --> 00:33:04.160
to some type of operation and
see what happens from there.

632
00:33:04.160 --> 00:33:07.530
Now, there's still things that might
need to be negotiated at this point

633
00:33:07.530 --> 00:33:08.760
as far as the hand off.

634
00:33:08.760 --> 00:33:11.880
You might find out that they're saying,
look, we really want Daniel

635
00:33:11.880 --> 00:33:15.305
on board with us for the next three months
to ensure that the training gets done.

636
00:33:15.305 --> 00:33:17.474
Well, you can negotiate
that if you need to.

637
00:33:17.474 --> 00:33:20.830
Or maybe while you're sitting alone
know Daniel's not gonna do that and so

638
00:33:20.830 --> 00:33:23.330
this is actually the end,
here's the product, take it or leave it,

639
00:33:23.330 --> 00:33:24.840
and you don't want that either.

640
00:33:24.840 --> 00:33:27.310
But overall, though you have
to actually figure that out.

641
00:33:27.310 --> 00:33:31.060
So, the last stage is not by far
the most technically challenging stage.

642
00:33:31.060 --> 00:33:34.900
But it is an important stage that says
I should release all of my member,

643
00:33:34.900 --> 00:33:37.480
all of the members of my project team.

644
00:33:37.480 --> 00:33:41.340
If not, now the actual customer or

645
00:33:41.340 --> 00:33:45.062
whoever it might be, comes back and says,
well, I really didn't like that project,

646
00:33:45.062 --> 00:33:47.640
well Ron, now you've released
all your project members.

647
00:33:47.640 --> 00:33:51.140
Well, now you're actually in trouble
again because now all the project team is

648
00:33:51.140 --> 00:33:53.120
gone and dispersed in the way they want.

649
00:33:53.120 --> 00:33:55.220
But just kind of realize in
these different elements, right,

650
00:33:55.220 --> 00:33:59.000
that there are specific things
that are associated with them and

651
00:33:59.000 --> 00:34:02.750
also take a look at those process groups
and know that the breakdown is actually

652
00:34:02.750 --> 00:34:05.686
fairly simple when we start
to begin to manage projects.

653
00:34:05.686 --> 00:34:08.400
>> Yeah, I liked your little last
bullet point there that said,

654
00:34:08.400 --> 00:34:09.970
Hand off to operations.

655
00:34:09.970 --> 00:34:11.530
That is the ultimate closer.

656
00:34:11.530 --> 00:34:14.780
The project is done, we've gone
through each one of the steps, and

657
00:34:14.780 --> 00:34:17.120
now it is something we
do on a daily basis.

658
00:34:17.120 --> 00:34:18.860
We're not still working on it,
trying to figure it out.

659
00:34:18.860 --> 00:34:20.290
Is this gonna work, is that gonna work?

660
00:34:20.290 --> 00:34:22.040
No, it's something we've figured out.

661
00:34:22.040 --> 00:34:26.550
It is implemented as an operational
procedure on a daily basis,

662
00:34:26.550 --> 00:34:27.540
it's what we do.

663
00:34:27.540 --> 00:34:28.530
Ronnie, awesome.

664
00:34:28.530 --> 00:34:32.840
You've definitely taken us through each
one of these phases very, very well.

665
00:34:32.840 --> 00:34:35.970
I understand them all myself,
hopefully you guys as well.

666
00:34:35.970 --> 00:34:37.870
Is there anything else we need to add for
this episode?

667
00:34:37.870 --> 00:34:40.457
>> Well, not for this episode, but don't
think that we're done with, of course,

668
00:34:40.457 --> 00:34:41.180
project management.

669
00:34:41.180 --> 00:34:45.010
Now you may think so, right, because we
went through the actual preplanning stage

670
00:34:45.010 --> 00:34:46.690
and we talked about all the processes.

671
00:34:46.690 --> 00:34:49.290
And this may give you a level
of confidence and this should.

672
00:34:49.290 --> 00:34:52.250
But it doesn't mean that you know all the
other elements that are actually involved

673
00:34:52.250 --> 00:34:53.690
in much more detail.

674
00:34:53.690 --> 00:34:57.930
So, if you're still actually hankering for
more, as far as details go,

675
00:34:57.930 --> 00:35:00.770
especially in the planning stage, cuz
that's where we're actually gonna get into

676
00:35:00.770 --> 00:35:04.480
the nitty gritty of project management,
planning is pretty much our job.

677
00:35:04.480 --> 00:35:07.090
That we're actually gonna take
a very deep dive into it,

678
00:35:07.090 --> 00:35:10.532
a lot of episodes coming up,
so stay tuned for more there.

679
00:35:10.532 --> 00:35:12.880
>> All right, well thanks again Ronnie for
stopping by and

680
00:35:12.880 --> 00:35:14.530
thank you guys for watching.

681
00:35:14.530 --> 00:35:16.510
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

682
00:35:16.510 --> 00:35:18.080
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

683
00:35:18.080 --> 00:35:18.690
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

684
00:35:18.690 --> 00:35:20.507
>> And we'll see you next time.

685
00:35:20.507 --> 00:35:28.042
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the different types of organizational structures and how the role of a project manager fits into those structures. The organizational structures covered include Functional, Weak Matrix, (Balanced) Matrix, Strong Matrix, and Projectized. They also look at the impact each type of organizational structure has on Project Management.
episodes.title: Explain Organizational Structures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.922 --> 00:00:16.762
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.762 --> 00:00:19.746
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:19.746 --> 00:00:22.083
we're continuing on with
our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.083 --> 00:00:26.517
Joining us back in the studio again today
is our friend and mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:26.517 --> 00:00:27.907
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

7
00:00:27.907 --> 00:00:29.267
>> Appreciate being invited back,

8
00:00:29.267 --> 00:00:33.347
as we continue to take a look
at more of CompTIA's Project+.

9
00:00:33.347 --> 00:00:36.077
And what we're actually gonna
be spending our time in today,

10
00:00:36.077 --> 00:00:40.057
is to take a look at the idea of
different organizational structures.

11
00:00:40.057 --> 00:00:43.007
And to actually think about where
project management normally fits

12
00:00:43.007 --> 00:00:44.287
into these structures.

13
00:00:44.287 --> 00:00:46.987
Because it's very important that
we understand that as project

14
00:00:46.987 --> 00:00:48.350
managers as well.

15
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:51.140
A lot of times when we start
to take on something new,

16
00:00:51.140 --> 00:00:53.400
something like project management,
it does.

17
00:00:53.400 --> 00:00:55.680
It gives us knowledge that
we didn't have before.

18
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:57.680
It makes us feel very confident.

19
00:00:57.680 --> 00:01:00.221
It allows to be able to think that
we can accomplish everything.

20
00:01:00.221 --> 00:01:04.003
And normally, though,
even though that's all good stuff,

21
00:01:04.003 --> 00:01:06.121
at least mentally for ourselves.

22
00:01:06.121 --> 00:01:09.878
Sometimes, you've gotta actually
understand the realization though,

23
00:01:09.878 --> 00:01:12.560
is that not every single
company you end up working for

24
00:01:12.560 --> 00:01:16.196
is gonna see project management in
the same glowing light that Daniel and

25
00:01:16.196 --> 00:01:17.882
I are actually gonna put it into.

26
00:01:17.882 --> 00:01:20.668
And so that means we actually have
to understand how we work, and

27
00:01:20.668 --> 00:01:22.425
actually understand the advantages and

28
00:01:22.425 --> 00:01:25.800
benefits to these different types
of organizational structures.

29
00:01:25.800 --> 00:01:29.670
And see where the project manager
actually fits into this as well.

30
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:33.280
So that's what we're gonna take a look at
today is those organizational structures,

31
00:01:33.280 --> 00:01:36.490
and we're gonna see that it breaks
down into five different types of

32
00:01:36.490 --> 00:01:38.110
organizational structures.

33
00:01:38.110 --> 00:01:41.029
I wanna take a look briefly
at each one of those, so

34
00:01:41.029 --> 00:01:43.892
that we understand where we might end up,
okay?

35
00:01:43.892 --> 00:01:48.278
Now Daniel, we really have traditionally,
at least in the past few episodes,

36
00:01:48.278 --> 00:01:51.092
we talked about where
companies normally begin and

37
00:01:51.092 --> 00:01:54.112
most of them don't begin
with just projects, right?

38
00:01:54.112 --> 00:01:57.340
So let's take for an example,
the insurance company that you worked for.

39
00:01:57.340 --> 00:01:58.990
I'm pretty sure there were
projects that went on but

40
00:01:58.990 --> 00:02:01.760
it was probably set up as
different departments, right?

41
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:02.580
>> Yeah, definitely.

42
00:02:02.580 --> 00:02:07.148
Every department has their own set of
projects and goals that they're trying to

43
00:02:07.148 --> 00:02:11.664
meet for each year or whatever amounts
of time we've set forth as the defacto.

44
00:02:11.664 --> 00:02:15.650
And in that, we would have to
sit across resources and staff,

45
00:02:15.650 --> 00:02:18.344
personnel I guess would be a better word.

46
00:02:18.344 --> 00:02:21.279
And so that they can obtain those
projects, get them completed, and

47
00:02:21.279 --> 00:02:23.364
then that would benefit
the company in some way.

48
00:02:23.364 --> 00:02:23.998
>> Yeah, and so

49
00:02:23.998 --> 00:02:27.950
you do have organizations that realize
that projects are very important.

50
00:02:27.950 --> 00:02:30.470
And so, they take that time and
they take the money and

51
00:02:30.470 --> 00:02:33.540
they take everything into account and
they add that in.

52
00:02:33.540 --> 00:02:36.220
But, what if you actually end
up working for a company,

53
00:02:36.220 --> 00:02:39.730
though, that really didn't
take any of that into account?

54
00:02:39.730 --> 00:02:43.540
But now realize that projects need
to be done within the company?

55
00:02:43.540 --> 00:02:48.710
So, normally what you'd have there is what
we call a functional type of organization.

56
00:02:48.710 --> 00:02:53.720
Let me kind of show you an organizational
chart in which this one breaks down for

57
00:02:53.720 --> 00:02:56.920
us a little bit easier for
us to understand, right?

58
00:02:56.920 --> 00:03:00.330
So when we talk about
a traditional functional type of

59
00:03:00.330 --> 00:03:05.076
organizational structure normally,
we do have a hierarchical structure.

60
00:03:05.076 --> 00:03:06.790
And right here, at the top I just put CEO,

61
00:03:06.790 --> 00:03:09.990
you put whoever is the head
of your organization.

62
00:03:09.990 --> 00:03:13.030
And then from that point,
it breaks down into departments.

63
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:13.590
And essentially,

64
00:03:13.590 --> 00:03:16.800
department heads are actually in
control at each of those departments.

65
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:18.430
The hierarchy is there.

66
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:23.410
A staff from, lets say, Human Resources,
doesn't directly report to the Finances,

67
00:03:23.410 --> 00:03:26.260
or Marketing, or even directly to the CEO.

68
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:30.220
Usually, the people within that particular
organizational structure, let's say under

69
00:03:30.220 --> 00:03:34.620
Human Resources and they report to
anybody, is gonna be their one direct

70
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:39.830
supervisor above them inside of that
Human Resources department itself, okay?

71
00:03:39.830 --> 00:03:43.510
So, when you have all those
structures in place and now,

72
00:03:43.510 --> 00:03:46.900
you realize that projects
actually need to take place.

73
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:50.010
And the company now
hires a Project Manager,

74
00:03:50.010 --> 00:03:53.760
where does he fit in to this
organizational structure?

75
00:03:53.760 --> 00:03:56.240
Is he a part of the human resources team?

76
00:03:56.240 --> 00:03:59.814
Is he part of finances, marketing,
production, customer relations?

77
00:03:59.814 --> 00:04:02.872
Does he work hand in hand with the CEO?

78
00:04:02.872 --> 00:04:06.999
Well, in this type of structure,
because a hierarchy has existed,

79
00:04:06.999 --> 00:04:09.572
a form line type of structure has existed.

80
00:04:09.572 --> 00:04:14.511
It doesn't mean that the Project Manager
actually fits very neatly in to any one of

81
00:04:14.511 --> 00:04:15.737
these categories.

82
00:04:15.737 --> 00:04:20.745
And so you can imagine then,
if you had several department heads,

83
00:04:20.745 --> 00:04:22.897
and now CEO Dan Lowrie says.

84
00:04:22.897 --> 00:04:27.900
Hey, I wanna introduce you guys to
someone which is a Project Manager.

85
00:04:27.900 --> 00:04:30.020
Well, imagine what they're thinking.

86
00:04:30.020 --> 00:04:31.490
Imagine these department heads going,

87
00:04:31.490 --> 00:04:34.840
whoa, wait a minute,
why is the CEO introducing this guy?

88
00:04:34.840 --> 00:04:38.440
He doesn't have a department behind him,
he's just a Project Manager.

89
00:04:38.440 --> 00:04:40.172
So where does he fit in?

90
00:04:40.172 --> 00:04:44.800
That's a hard place to be in this type
of organization, is to realize something

91
00:04:44.800 --> 00:04:48.752
that, hey, this guy was hired by
the CEO to get some projects done.

92
00:04:48.752 --> 00:04:52.215
And what does that mean, that he's
actually gonna be a Project Manager, and

93
00:04:52.215 --> 00:04:53.720
he's just told all of us up here.

94
00:04:53.720 --> 00:04:55.560
We're actually the department heads.

95
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:57.730
Does he have more authority than we do?

96
00:04:57.730 --> 00:04:59.670
How is this actually gonna end up working?

97
00:04:59.670 --> 00:05:03.200
So you can see why this
might actually be something,

98
00:05:03.200 --> 00:05:05.100
which is a little bit more daunting.

99
00:05:05.100 --> 00:05:08.770
And why in a functional organization,
Project Managers and

100
00:05:08.770 --> 00:05:14.810
project management seem to be more of
a side type of thing that's done, right.

101
00:05:14.810 --> 00:05:19.470
A side project, this is something
personal the CEO wants to see done, and

102
00:05:19.470 --> 00:05:22.300
he's actually who's hired
to do something like this.

103
00:05:22.300 --> 00:05:24.840
So, when you start seeing that,
you can realize,

104
00:05:24.840 --> 00:05:28.550
then, that the Project Manager
does not have an easy time

105
00:05:28.550 --> 00:05:32.180
in getting the projects done that
he believes that should be done.

106
00:05:32.180 --> 00:05:35.360
Don't get me wrong,
in this particular type of organization,

107
00:05:35.360 --> 00:05:38.980
a project manager's
authority is relatively low.

108
00:05:38.980 --> 00:05:43.940
In comparison, and what has to happen
here is that the Project Manager,

109
00:05:43.940 --> 00:05:47.430
he has to be able to influence to
get his project team built, so

110
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:49.610
that he can get his project accomplished.

111
00:05:49.610 --> 00:05:51.620
Now, who does he actually work on?

112
00:05:51.620 --> 00:05:54.940
Well, what I did is,
I made this kind of oval here to try and

113
00:05:54.940 --> 00:05:58.390
help us to understand his sphere
of influence at this point.

114
00:05:58.390 --> 00:06:01.370
Is at more than likely for
him to be able to get his projects done.

115
00:06:02.710 --> 00:06:06.310
He's gonna need to be able to influence
essentially those department heads, okay?

116
00:06:07.350 --> 00:06:11.370
So, even though he has a project
that he knows that needs to be done.

117
00:06:11.370 --> 00:06:15.920
This particular type of Project Manager
really doesn't have any real authority to

118
00:06:15.920 --> 00:06:19.312
be able to go into every one of
these departments here and say.

119
00:06:19.312 --> 00:06:21.919
I need two people from
the marketing department,

120
00:06:21.919 --> 00:06:24.712
I need another person from Production,
I need this,

121
00:06:24.712 --> 00:06:28.870
and just send them to me, and
we're gonna work on our project, okay?

122
00:06:28.870 --> 00:06:30.380
He really doesn't.

123
00:06:30.380 --> 00:06:33.380
Daniel, can you guess what in
the world this Project Manager

124
00:06:33.380 --> 00:06:35.840
may have to do to be able to
get one of those resources in?

125
00:06:35.840 --> 00:06:38.554
>> He's probably gotta grease
a lot of pockets or palms or

126
00:06:38.554 --> 00:06:41.332
whatever it is you line the pockets or
grease the palms.

127
00:06:41.332 --> 00:06:44.167
I think what I'm getting from you here,
Ronnie,

128
00:06:44.167 --> 00:06:47.613
is that in this functional type
of organizational structure

129
00:06:47.613 --> 00:06:52.060
the Project Manager seems to have more
influence than he does authority.

130
00:06:52.060 --> 00:06:56.910
He works through influencing, saying,
hey, human resources manager,

131
00:06:56.910 --> 00:07:00.620
man it'd be nice if I could get a couple
of your guys, would that be possible?

132
00:07:00.620 --> 00:07:03.600
Where he doesn't have the direct
authority to go, human resources manager

133
00:07:03.600 --> 00:07:07.280
give me two of your people right now and
I need them for my project.

134
00:07:07.280 --> 00:07:10.120
>> And that's exactly what has to happen,
right?

135
00:07:10.120 --> 00:07:13.270
The Project Manager is not here to
change the entire organization.

136
00:07:13.270 --> 00:07:15.352
He's working through
the existing structures.

137
00:07:15.352 --> 00:07:18.979
And that means if he does need somebody
from the finances department or

138
00:07:18.979 --> 00:07:21.012
the human resources department here.

139
00:07:21.012 --> 00:07:23.154
He really does need to go
to the Project Manager and

140
00:07:23.154 --> 00:07:25.340
establish fairly solid relationships.

141
00:07:25.340 --> 00:07:27.425
Now I'm not gonna go as far as
Daniel in bribing those guys.

142
00:07:27.425 --> 00:07:29.025
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, I'm joking.

143
00:07:29.025 --> 00:07:30.765
>> That's how business is done.

144
00:07:30.765 --> 00:07:33.264
>> But that's what has to happen, right?

145
00:07:33.264 --> 00:07:37.976
He really does need to establish a very
good and cordial relationship with

146
00:07:37.976 --> 00:07:43.060
these guys that then will be able to
work with him and be able to help him.

147
00:07:43.060 --> 00:07:47.330
As he actually influences them to say,
hey, here's a project needs to be done.

148
00:07:47.330 --> 00:07:50.890
Hey, can you help me figure out
who I need to get to do this?

149
00:07:50.890 --> 00:07:52.780
And so it does have to happen there.

150
00:07:52.780 --> 00:07:56.229
Now, in this type of organization,
the reason he has to do that,

151
00:07:56.229 --> 00:08:00.306
if he just goes in and says, okay,
I'm gonna take this guy from Marketing And

152
00:08:00.306 --> 00:08:03.476
there's something big in
marketing that needs to be done.

153
00:08:03.476 --> 00:08:07.009
That marketing executive at that point
is probably not gonna be very happy with

154
00:08:07.009 --> 00:08:10.541
the project manager who just takes away
his best person on the staff right there

155
00:08:10.541 --> 00:08:14.052
so that he can work on the side project
and leaves him with the rest of the team.

156
00:08:14.052 --> 00:08:17.200
It's not that the team shouldn't
be able to handle it, but

157
00:08:17.200 --> 00:08:20.310
now that he's taken the key player out,
it's not one of those.

158
00:08:20.310 --> 00:08:24.830
So what has to happen, then, is that
there is this divided authority, right?

159
00:08:24.830 --> 00:08:28.970
If the marketing goes to that person that
Daniel says he wants on his project team.

160
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:30.290
Says, no, you're not working on that.

161
00:08:30.290 --> 00:08:32.280
You're working on my stuff.

162

00:20:17.960 --> 00:20:22.417
His particular matter and influence is
coordination, integration, and of course,

391
00:20:22.417 --> 00:20:23.338
just influence.

392
00:20:23.338 --> 00:20:26.110
Whether its actually at
the department head level or

393
00:20:26.110 --> 00:20:29.630
what is actually with its the staff
inside those departments.

394
00:20:29.630 --> 00:20:33.700
>> Yeah, now, Ronnie,
now it's not the only matrix game in town,

395
00:20:33.700 --> 00:20:39.178
I know there's a more zen-like approach,
more balanced approach to these matrices.

396
00:20:39.178 --> 00:20:41.878
>> Their normally is, okay?

397
00:20:41.878 --> 00:20:44.660
Depending on the size of the organization.

398
00:20:44.660 --> 00:20:49.020
In a balanced matrix approach here,
I just did one of these instead.

399
00:20:49.020 --> 00:20:52.240
What you'll end up seeing
instead is that the CEO does not

400
00:20:52.240 --> 00:20:55.440
bring in a Project Manager for
the whole company and

401
00:20:55.440 --> 00:20:58.110
says, he's gonna be in
charge of all the projects.

402
00:20:58.110 --> 00:20:59.160
Essentially, he says,

403
00:20:59.160 --> 00:21:02.960
look each department needs to actually
take someone on their staff and

404
00:21:02.960 --> 00:21:08.110
they are gonna become, let's say, the
Project Manager for that department, okay?

405
00:21:08.110 --> 00:21:13.500
And, when he does something like that,
that Project Manager here, has the ability

406
00:21:13.500 --> 00:21:17.410
to do some of the coordination and
influence that we've talked about before.

407
00:21:17.410 --> 00:21:22.544
But, notice that he's actually a member
of a particular department and

408
00:21:22.544 --> 00:21:27.268
so his particular influence can
actually extend out to everyone.

409
00:21:27.268 --> 00:21:31.703
Or maybe just to the people that he
needs on his staff at that point,

410
00:21:31.703 --> 00:21:34.808
to be able to work at
the stuff that he needs to.

411
00:21:34.808 --> 00:21:38.730
For whatever project that that particular
department ends up needing here.

412
00:21:38.730 --> 00:21:41.577
And so you might have one for
finance, marketing, production,

413
00:21:41.577 --> 00:21:42.888
customer relations as well.

414
00:21:42.888 --> 00:21:46.343
You might have all those individual
Project Managers instead and

415
00:21:46.343 --> 00:21:49.688
they're actually working
together a little bit more, okay?

416
00:21:49.688 --> 00:21:54.428
When you start doing stuff like
the idea of this balance matrix, okay?

417
00:21:54.428 --> 00:21:56.796
Now,when we take a look, then, okay?

418
00:21:56.796 --> 00:22:00.080
At this point, this is where it
becomes a little bit more balanced.

419
00:22:00.080 --> 00:22:03.770
The authority is actually because they
are actually the project manager for

420
00:22:03.770 --> 00:22:04.750
that team.

421
00:22:04.750 --> 00:22:10.120
And he's given whatever authority that
the department head says he can have.

422
00:22:10.120 --> 00:22:12.550
So it can be Low to
Moderate at this point.

423
00:22:12.550 --> 00:22:15.680
He doesn't actually have full
charge of the entire department but

424
00:22:15.680 --> 00:22:19.430
he does have some more ability than
what the other two would have too.

425
00:22:19.430 --> 00:22:24.720
Resource Availability again, is limited
by who can he get on his team, okay?

426
00:22:24.720 --> 00:22:29.008
And once again, when you start
thinking about that, on your team.

427
00:22:29.008 --> 00:22:32.881
You might be able to take away more
resources and head of department says,

428
00:22:32.881 --> 00:22:36.198
okay, that's cool because he's
working on a project for me.

429
00:22:36.198 --> 00:22:39.855
But you may end up finding out
something here, that at the same time,

430
00:22:39.855 --> 00:22:42.458
you're not gonna get it from everybody,
okay?

431
00:22:42.458 --> 00:22:45.205
In this one on the project budget here,

432
00:22:45.205 --> 00:22:49.708
it is a mixed type of authority
as far as the management, right?

433
00:22:49.708 --> 00:22:54.620
Because a project may actually come from
what the entire budget of that department.

434
00:22:54.620 --> 00:22:58.560
So in other words,
that now says that the department head,

435
00:22:58.560 --> 00:23:01.800
the functional manager, comes in and
says, all right, here it is.

436
00:23:01.800 --> 00:23:05.040
Here's my entire budget of $500,000, we're
setting aside a hundred thousand dollars

437
00:23:05.040 --> 00:23:09.550
and that now becomes the authority
of the project manager.

438
00:23:09.550 --> 00:23:14.078
So it's partial, he still had to actually
relate that back, but it is partial.

439
00:23:14.078 --> 00:23:15.398
But at this point though,

440
00:23:15.398 --> 00:23:18.998
the project manager rolled him as
full-time within that department.

441
00:23:18.998 --> 00:23:22.452
And whoever actually gets assigned
from that department probably is gonna

442
00:23:22.452 --> 00:23:25.098
be working full-time for
that project manager as well.

443
00:23:25.098 --> 00:23:26.638
So, you do see that.

444
00:23:26.638 --> 00:23:31.566
Now, there's two more here and we're
just gonna kind of go over them cuz you

445
00:23:31.566 --> 00:23:34.186
tend to see this a little bit more often.

446
00:23:34.186 --> 00:23:37.943
And actually, this last one you don't tend
to see super often unless the company is

447
00:23:37.943 --> 00:23:39.240
really, really gigantic.

448
00:23:40.390 --> 00:23:44.870
So in this one that we call
a strong matrix here, notice,

449
00:23:44.870 --> 00:23:47.470
I just replaced one of these teams here.

450
00:23:47.470 --> 00:23:50.341
So instead of having
that customer relation,

451
00:23:50.341 --> 00:23:53.516
there is a Project Management department,
okay?

452
00:23:53.516 --> 00:23:58.211
So, you can actually have that at Project
Management department here in which,

453
00:23:58.211 --> 00:23:59.738
who I do have on the staff?

454
00:23:59.738 --> 00:24:00.803
Project Managers,okay?

455
00:24:00.803 --> 00:24:02.297
So that makes sense so

456
00:24:02.297 --> 00:24:07.540
now they have equal authority as all
the other functional departments do.

457
00:24:07.540 --> 00:24:14.310
And now each of these project managers do
have the authority because they are equal.

458
00:24:14.310 --> 00:24:17.160
To say they're working for
the good of the entire organization and

459
00:24:17.160 --> 00:24:18.900
they can actually form their own teams.

460
00:24:18.900 --> 00:24:21.950
They can do just about everything
that they need to, okay?

461
00:24:21.950 --> 00:24:24.810
Now this one is as far as
the influence goes and

462
00:24:24.810 --> 00:24:27.180
what we're looking at
here moderate to high.

463
00:24:27.180 --> 00:24:29.490
They still have to report
to their department head,

464
00:24:29.490 --> 00:24:33.960
they still have resource availability cuz
they have the access to the resource pool,

465
00:24:33.960 --> 00:24:38.040
but now they control their own budget and
they're actually full time.

466
00:24:38.040 --> 00:24:41.000
And when we move to the projectized,
okay, and

467
00:24:41.000 --> 00:24:43.490
that's where we're
ultimately heading here.

468
00:24:43.490 --> 00:24:48.170
When we take a look now the entire
organization says what, departments,

469
00:24:48.170 --> 00:24:49.440
no way, okay.

470
00:24:49.440 --> 00:24:52.897
What we have essentially is that we
have multiple project managers and

471
00:24:52.897 --> 00:24:56.076
they function like departments,
but they have their own team.

472
00:24:56.076 --> 00:24:59.185
They usually have a set of their own
resources that they also depend on.

473
00:24:59.185 --> 00:25:00.820
They also share resources.

474
00:25:00.820 --> 00:25:04.450
You name it, everybody has
a project manager, a project team.

475
00:25:04.450 --> 00:25:06.160
You just work on projects.

476
00:25:06.160 --> 00:25:10.700
A projectized environment is where
you tend to see most things being

477
00:25:10.700 --> 00:25:15.700
done very agilely changing up when they
need to, doing some of the things.

478
00:25:15.700 --> 00:25:19.140
It doesn't matter about the reporting
structure as far as departments go,

479
00:25:19.140 --> 00:25:23.240
it's all about getting your project
members and project teams working.

480
00:25:23.240 --> 00:25:27.590
And this is where, of course, project
management becomes a little bit easier.

481
00:25:27.590 --> 00:25:30.730
High to total authority,
resource availability,

482
00:25:30.730 --> 00:25:33.640
high to total because they're
all working on the same thing.

483
00:25:33.640 --> 00:25:35.190
You manage your own budget.

484
00:25:35.190 --> 00:25:37.660
And, of course, your time is full time.

485
00:25:37.660 --> 00:25:40.830
Everybody that works on your team
is actually full time as well.

486
00:25:40.830 --> 00:25:44.080
It's prefect, right,
if you have a shared resource pool,

487
00:25:44.080 --> 00:25:47.590
then sometimes the administration
staff may not be full time.

488
00:25:47.590 --> 00:25:49.610
They may be working for others as well.

489
00:25:49.610 --> 00:25:52.712
But overall though, when you start
taking a look at some of these

490
00:25:52.712 --> 00:25:56.620
different organizational structures,
if you are actually working on a project

491
00:25:56.620 --> 00:25:59.684
management type of team,
you've gotta know where you fit in.

492
00:25:59.684 --> 00:26:02.870
You've gotta actually know where
your level of influence is.

493
00:26:02.870 --> 00:26:07.010
So take the time to go through,
do some reading on each of these.

494
00:26:07.010 --> 00:26:09.750
We kinda went through it in
a fairly fast fashion, here.

495
00:26:09.750 --> 00:26:13.570
But at the same time, it's something
that actually opens you up to realize

00:26:13.570 --> 00:26:17.040
that if you get hired on as a project
manager, what do you need to understand?

497
00:26:18.070 --> 00:26:20.700
Are we actually in that functional style?

498
00:26:20.700 --> 00:26:23.230
Is this organization
completely projectized?

499
00:26:23.230 --> 00:26:24.480
Or is it somewhere in between?

500
00:26:24.480 --> 00:26:27.430
And you work out what's
your authority going to be?

00:26:28.860 --> 00:26:31.320
What control do you have over the budget?

502
00:26:31.320 --> 00:26:35.260
How do I get my staff members,
how do I actually end up working in this?

503
00:26:35.260 --> 00:26:37.608
And then, at that point,
you choose, you know, whether or

00:26:37.608 --> 00:26:39.926
not you're actually going to work for

505
00:26:39.926 --> 00:26:44.980
>> Yeah, projectized actually reminds me
a lot of the special operations command.

506
00:26:44.980 --> 00:26:48.570
In the United States military we have the
Department of Defense and then it goes to

507
00:26:48.570 --> 00:26:51.920
the Department of the Army, Department
of the Navy, and so on and so forth.

508
00:26:51.920 --> 00:26:57.970
But SOCOM, the Special Operations Command,
they kinda do their own thing,

509
00:26:57.970 --> 00:27:02.140
and they even pull resources
from the others, and

510
00:27:02.140 --> 00:27:06.750
to create their own teams, but they're not
under their jurisdiction should it say.

511
00:27:06.750 --> 00:27:09.036
So it's very similar in that fashion.

512
00:27:09.036 --> 00:27:11.650
I like to projectize because
then you get your own team,

513
00:27:11.650 --> 00:27:14.420
you have your own resources,
you don't need

00:27:14.420 --> 00:27:18.180
to cannibalize somebody else really

515
00:27:18.180 --> 00:27:21.170
Everything is set aside for

516
00:27:21.170 --> 00:27:24.480
It's a whole lot easier and
it's probably as time goes on,

517
00:27:24.480 --> 00:27:26.870
it's gonna become the more
popular of the matrices.

518
00:27:26.870 --> 00:27:29.300
>> I think you're gonna see that more and
more often,

519
00:27:29.300 --> 00:27:34.140
because we are living in this day and
age in which the ability to change

520
00:27:34.140 --> 00:27:38.350
when we need to, right, very quickly,
is what's gonna be happening.

521
00:27:38.350 --> 00:27:41.890
In that functional type of style

522
00:27:41.890 --> 00:27:44.800
Very difficult to make a lot

523
00:27:44.800 --> 00:27:48.050
They tend to have to all

00:27:48.050 --> 00:27:51.060
And a lot of times the authority

00:27:51.060 --> 00:27:53.030

526
00:27:53.030 --> 00:27:56.110
In a projectized environment, because

00:27:56.110 --> 00:27:59.820

528
00:27:59.820 --> 00:28:01.530
And, with the agreement

00:28:01.530 --> 00:28:04.960
they know that they can shift the focus
and even the scope if they need to.

530
00:28:04.960 --> 00:28:07.620
As long as everything is addressed

531
00:28:07.620 --> 00:28:11.000
So these are some of those organizational
structures that you're likely seeing.

532
00:28:11.000 --> 00:28:13.200
I definitely will tell you
that according to CompTIA,

you're gonna see them on your Project+

00:28:17.090 --> 00:28:20.970
understand at least the nature and
the basics that we talked about here.

535
00:28:20.970 --> 00:28:24.090
But take a little bit more time,
do some research and some reading.

536
00:28:24.090 --> 00:28:29.140
Again, we do recommend the actual Sybex

00:28:29.140 --> 00:28:32.310
it's actually worth a read for

538
00:28:32.310 --> 00:28:34.810
very good explanations on

539
00:28:34.810 --> 00:28:39.051
But overall though just make
sure you take a few minutes.

540
00:28:39.051 --> 00:28:43.325
As a brand new project manager, it's
easier to sit there once somebody says,

541

we have an opening for project manager,
and you just apply for the job and

00:28:47.274 --> 00:28:50.094

Well you need to have your eyes opened and

a smarter decision about where your

546
00:29:01.892 --> 00:29:05.930
>> All right, well Ronnie thank you so
much for explaining these different

00:29:05.930 --> 00:29:10.210
organizational structures and how
the project manager's gonna fit into that,

548
00:29:10.210 --> 00:29:13.280
how it might work, and
types that you're gonna see in real life.

549
00:29:13.280 --> 00:29:16.940
So that when you encounter them, well,
you understand how they work, and

550
00:29:16.940 --> 00:29:20.070
you're able to integrate yourself
into them as a project manager.

551
00:29:20.070 --> 00:29:21.830
Thank you so much for that.

552
00:29:21.830 --> 00:29:24.970
It looks like we have come to the end of
yet another great episode here at ITProTV.

553
00:29:24.970 --> 00:29:27.050
Thank you guys for watching.

554
00:29:27.050 --> 00:29:29.230
We always enjoy your viewership.

555
00:29:29.230 --> 00:29:30.800
And we hope you get a lot
out of this episode.

556
00:29:30.800 --> 00:29:32.110
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

557
00:29:32.110 --> 00:29:34.290
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

558
00:29:34.290 --> 00:29:34.990
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

559
00:29:34.990 --> 00:29:36.607
>> We'll see you next time.

00:29:36.607 --> 00:29:42.318

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe how you create a scope management plan while project planning. They begin by going through the first of three major scope components which is the Scope Management Plan. They break the scope management plan down into its component documentation. Then they look at the inputs and the scope change process make allowances for scope deviation.
episodes.title: Prepare a Scope Management Plan

So we wanna take a look, then,

Now Daniel, let me go and

that, we're going to say unnamed, but

Well, things like that actually

The asides,

yes one more caveat we gotta do this as

Yeah, that tends to happen actually

what that scope statement is going to be.

501
00:26:37.680 --> 00:26:42.210
So you make sure you ask you take that in
the consideration, you also wanna make

502
00:26:42.210 --> 00:26:49.560
sure you understand that on your
project if it's really limited by time,

503
00:26:49.560 --> 00:26:54.110
you've gotta understand what impact
that that scope is gonna change.

504
00:26:54.110 --> 00:26:57.620
Or if you actually have a limited amount
of money or you have to produce so

505
00:26:57.620 --> 00:26:58.730
many of these things.

506
00:26:58.730 --> 00:27:03.360
Or whatever it might be, you have
to understand what impacts any time

507
00:27:03.360 --> 00:27:05.810
something in the overall scope changes.

508
00:27:05.810 --> 00:27:08.330
And are you willing to
live with that as well?

509
00:27:08.330 --> 00:27:12.740
So that means you at this point here,
have to consider all of the constraints

510
00:27:12.740 --> 00:27:17.100
that you have to be able to
deal with from your project.

511
00:27:17.100 --> 00:27:20.340
Are there actually additional
resources that will be available

512
00:27:20.340 --> 00:27:21.820
if you continue to add work?

513
00:27:21.820 --> 00:27:24.030
You might find out something, no, okay.

514
00:27:24.030 --> 00:27:27.380
Here it is, here's the limitation
of your team, and that's it.

00:27:27.380 --> 00:27:30.400
No matter what somebody else comes in,
you can say, look there's just not enough

things that we need to.

00:27:34.470 --> 00:27:37.560
And, of course, if there actually
is additional money involved,

00:27:37.560 --> 00:27:40.910
which there always is gonna be,
you continue to allow a scope to creep,

00:27:40.910 --> 00:27:43.170
it's gonna absolutely cost you more money.

00:27:43.170 --> 00:27:46.580
So how do you actually secure
additional funding for it or

00:27:46.580 --> 00:27:50.330

gratis to be able to do all this,

00:27:50.330 --> 00:27:52.680
in other words, work for
free for a bit of time.

523
00:27:52.680 --> 00:27:55.460
So, you'll probably also see that as well,
okay?

524
00:27:55.460 --> 00:28:01.846
Now, we do have a little bit more to
cover here, and even actually right here.

525
00:28:01.846 --> 00:28:05.340
I was trying to make sure I was saying
the right thing here, but here it is.

00:28:05.340 --> 00:28:08.440
This scope change process, I don't know
why I wasn't seeing that right here on my

00:28:08.440 --> 00:28:10.640
screen, it's probably cuz I
don't have my glasses on.

00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:14.590
But remember that what we want right
here right as far as the input,

00:28:14.590 --> 00:28:16.460
is that we wanna know, okay.

530
00:28:16.460 --> 00:28:21.500
We want as much as we can as
an input that we have some process

00:28:21.500 --> 00:28:24.690
that handles changes, okay.

00:28:24.690 --> 00:28:26.420
We don't wanna go into this blindly and
go,

00:28:26.420 --> 00:28:29.780
all right guys, let's figure out

00:28:29.780 --> 00:28:33.550
Take some structure in mind, whether it's

00:28:33.550 --> 00:28:37.590
here's how we manage changes formally,
okay, whether it's a template that

00:28:37.590 --> 00:28:41.930
you follow, whatever it is, you want to
make sure that you have some process.

00:28:41.930 --> 00:28:45.760
And here the recommendation from
CompTIA is at least that's right.

538
00:28:45.760 --> 00:28:50.390
At a minimum, make somebody fill out

00:28:50.390 --> 00:28:53.970
It doesn't mean you have to follow

So we described a change, reason for it,

00:29:07.420 --> 00:29:09.570
Daniel might have actually put

00:29:09.570 --> 00:29:13.700
this change better be in here or

00:29:13.700 --> 00:29:16.350
And even if the change didn't

00:29:16.350 --> 00:29:17.830
well why did the project fail?

00:29:17.830 --> 00:29:20.750
Somebody can do a thumb back through and

00:29:20.750 --> 00:29:24.160
Daniel said he wouldn't sign off on

00:29:24.160 --> 00:29:25.700
if he didn't have this

00:29:25.700 --> 00:29:26.710
>> Creates a paper trail.

551
00:29:26.710 --> 00:29:28.180
>> It does create a paper trail.

552

Yep, it surely does.

00:29:30.090 --> 00:29:30.650
Don't forget,

00:29:30.650 --> 00:29:35.350
you wanna make sure you also impact the

00:29:35.350 --> 00:29:40.820
And at the end of this, right, that there

00:29:40.820 --> 00:29:47.350

00:29:47.350 --> 00:29:50.960
Not somebody just scribbled a name on it,

In other words, it literally has

So there's no vaguery to it, right?

The very fact is that Daniel gets this

Well does that signature mean

We don't have a clue.

What does that signature really mean?

it means the formal project team

No.

Well, somebody signed it, but that doesn't

00:30:33.180 --> 00:30:39.330
So you want to make sure that there is

572
00:30:39.330 --> 00:30:40.770
approved or rejected.

573
00:30:40.770 --> 00:30:44.170
This is where the big red
stamps really do help, right?

574
00:30:44.170 --> 00:30:46.490
Approved, rejected whatever it might be.

575
00:30:46.490 --> 00:30:50.170
Make sure it's there, make sure it’s
signed, and we are ready to go.

576
00:30:50.170 --> 00:30:53.330
Also, of course, make sure that your
stakeholders understand that if a change

577

those changes if they do happen.

578
00:30:58.800 --> 00:31:01.340
And then, of course,
that we have a solid methodology for

come into existence for us, so

the scope or the actual management

581
00:31:10.880 --> 00:31:15.990
play when we start talking about planning

So all that's actually a part

But Daniel,

It's good stuff.

We wanna hear this stuff, and obviously

00:31:40.060 --> 00:31:43.643
we got another part two in our future, but

00:31:43.643 --> 00:31:44.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're great stuff.

00:31:44.780 --> 00:31:46.190
Ronnie, thank you for joining us today.

00:31:46.190 --> 00:31:48.210

00:31:48.210 --> 00:31:50.630
Looking forward to see you

Looking forward to see you

We're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel describe how you create a scope management plan while project planning. Here they pick back up by looking at the 2nd of the three major scope components which is the scope statement. Then they finish by scope statement validation to stakeholders.
episodes.title: Prepare a Scope Management Plan Part 2

Now, in this sense.

the difference between the management and

So before, when we talked about the scope

hey, what are the things in place

Now, we're not looking to nitpick on

00:04:50.800 --> 00:04:53.470
And that means we're actually

do we have on hand what is gonna be

What is actually gonna be

That we'll actually say that we've

that we wanna make sure

You might say, well how do we know that?

We haven't even begun the idea of managing

So, you do want to make sure

You got to make sure you have that

Because, that's how you

Secondly, we can also talk about the idea

the objectives, and

that's what the scope

00:06:25.070 --> 00:06:28.650
And the scope statement
should help to clarify

00:06:28.650 --> 00:06:33.160
as the project begins to move forward
here, any understanding, okay, and
