in to every little step that we have.

575
00:29:49.670 --> 00:29:52.440
>> We can break it down
into the very minutia but

576
00:29:52.440 --> 00:29:56.280
overall understanding that this is just
that it really is the beginning that we're

577
00:29:56.280 --> 00:30:01.650
planning for our project management
plan is gonna take place.

578
00:30:01.650 --> 00:30:02.910
This now sets that tone.

579
00:30:02.910 --> 00:30:05.770
It's pretty much the key and you want to
make sure that you understand that when

580
00:30:05.770 --> 00:30:08.290
you get ready to go and
face the exam as well.

581
00:30:08.290 --> 00:30:10.790
>> Well, excellent stuff Ronnie,
it's a really good stuff.

582
00:30:10.790 --> 00:30:13.860
We appreciate you stopping by and
explaining this to us.

583
00:30:13.860 --> 00:30:17.400
But again,
we have a lapsed our time together.

584
00:30:17.400 --> 00:30:21.338
Hopefully you guys have enjoyed it and
had a great time and learned something for

585
00:30:21.338 --> 00:30:25.711
that Project+ exam that you're preparing
for or just project management in general.

586
00:30:25.711 --> 00:30:28.256
We're going to sign off IT PRO TV.

587
00:30:28.256 --> 00:30:29.560
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

588
00:30:29.560 --> 00:30:30.320
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

589
00:30:30.320 --> 00:30:32.134
>> We'll see you next time.

590
00:30:32.134 --> 00:30:39.600
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the Work Breakdown Structure or WBS. They begin by explaining what a WBS is and its purpose as well as some of the benefits of using a WBS. Then they take you through the levels typically found in a WBS and wrap things up by identifying the planning processes that utilize a WBS as input. Also discussed is WBS dictionaries.
episodes.title: Explain Work Breakdown Structure
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.028 --> 00:00:10.028
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.588 --> 00:00:16.928
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.928 --> 00:00:18.540
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.540 --> 00:00:22.430
in today's episode we are continuing
on with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.430 --> 00:00:25.970
Joining me back in the studio today to
lend his expertise on that very topic

6
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:27.710
is our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:27.710 --> 00:00:29.040
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:32.520
>> Well, thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue to take a look

9
00:00:32.520 --> 00:00:35.480
at more of the CompTIA Project+.

10
00:00:35.480 --> 00:00:40.830
And we are moving into talking about what
a work breakdown structure actually is.

11
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:44.340
Now, this actually comes immediately
after, if you're following along in

12
00:00:44.340 --> 00:00:49.460
the series here, where we talked about the
planning out the project scope statement,

13
00:00:49.460 --> 00:00:53.000
as well as planning out
the management of the project scope.

14
00:00:53.000 --> 00:00:56.200
And one of those elements that actually
gets involved in that particular

15
00:00:56.200 --> 00:01:01.010
situation, of course, is gonna be what
we call a work breakdown structure.

16
00:01:01.010 --> 00:01:04.768
Now, everybody tends to actually use this
terminology a little bit differently.

17
00:01:04.768 --> 00:01:07.809
But it is an industry-wide
term that you tend

18
00:01:07.809 --> 00:01:12.970
to hear when you talk about the idea
of this work breakdown structure.

19
00:01:12.970 --> 00:01:16.837
So we wanna make sure we understand what's
actually involved in a work breakdown

20
00:01:16.837 --> 00:01:20.560
structure and why we need to actually use
it, and why this is actually something

21
00:01:20.560 --> 00:01:25.270
important for us as we actually move
in to the realm of project management.

22
00:01:25.270 --> 00:01:28.930
So, let's go ahead and
take a look at my screen as we begin here.

23
00:01:28.930 --> 00:01:31.950
And that way this will kind of
help us out when we take a look

24
00:01:31.950 --> 00:01:33.310
just a little bit more.

25
00:01:33.310 --> 00:01:38.838
So what in the world is the purpose of
that work breakdown structure or WBS?

26
00:01:38.838 --> 00:01:41.276
That's more than likely what
you'll hear people refer to it,

27
00:01:41.276 --> 00:01:42.934
not necessarily the idea work breakdown.

28
00:01:42.934 --> 00:01:45.222
And I was teasing with Daniel
right before the show,

29
00:01:45.222 --> 00:01:47.518
I know I'm gonna say work
break dance at some point.

30
00:01:47.518 --> 00:01:49.817
>> [LAUGH]
>> And everybody's gonna stop and pop and

31
00:01:49.817 --> 00:01:51.100
lock and do all that stuff.

32
00:01:51.100 --> 00:01:53.770
But it's not gonna happen today,
at least I don't think so.

33
00:01:53.770 --> 00:01:56.690
But this is what we're talking about here,
okay.

34
00:01:56.690 --> 00:01:59.750
Now, remember that if you take
a look at the previous show where

35
00:01:59.750 --> 00:02:04.390
we talked about that scope statement, as
well as the scope management plan, okay.

36
00:02:04.390 --> 00:02:05.520
We described that and

37
00:02:05.520 --> 00:02:09.260
we said that it needs to actually
be put down in written form.

38
00:02:09.260 --> 00:02:13.120
And that is pretty much
the key document for us.

39
00:02:13.120 --> 00:02:18.012
But when we start to actually try and
make work happen,

40
00:02:18.012 --> 00:02:21.010
right, what we need is something
a little bit more visual.

41
00:02:21.010 --> 00:02:23.870
In other words, we need to be able to
understand that it's not just a sentence

42
00:02:23.870 --> 00:02:24.930
we're looking at, but

43
00:02:24.930 --> 00:02:28.290
that this is something that we
are really gonna end up dealing with.

44
00:02:28.290 --> 00:02:33.066
And so a lot of the work breakdown
structure types of software that's out

45
00:02:33.066 --> 00:02:33.693
there and

46
00:02:33.693 --> 00:02:38.718
some of the ways that we tend to do this
is not by making gigantic paragraphs.

47
00:02:38.718 --> 00:02:43.073
But simply by making boxes if we need to
and then adding in the elements in there

48
00:02:43.073 --> 00:02:46.959
that show that we understand what
a work breakdown structure is, and

49
00:02:46.959 --> 00:02:49.210
what a work package is as well.

50
00:02:49.210 --> 00:02:50.370
So, first of all,

51
00:02:50.370 --> 00:02:55.240
it gives us a very graphic display of
the entirety of the project's scope.

52
00:02:55.240 --> 00:02:59.020
Now, when I say that, we actually
do see where we're saying that,

53
00:02:59.020 --> 00:03:03.480
hey, this graphic element does represent
the entire scope of the project, and

54
00:03:03.480 --> 00:03:06.810
actually really represents
the work of the project as well.

55
00:03:06.810 --> 00:03:09.710
And then we start actually
kind of analyzing that and

56
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:12.840
breaking them down into
smaller needs as well.

57
00:03:12.840 --> 00:03:16.830
The other reason that we also need to
create this work breakdown structure

58
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:19.720
is that what we're gonna see
during the remaining of our

59
00:03:19.720 --> 00:03:21.680
planning process here, right?

60
00:03:21.680 --> 00:03:25.300
Which is gonna be the longest of
the five phases that we spend in project

61
00:03:25.300 --> 00:03:26.390
management.

62
00:03:26.390 --> 00:03:31.150
Is that the work breakdown structure, as
far as the elements that we get out of it,

63
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:37.060
really help us to go into a whole bunch of
other processes that are actually there.

64
00:03:37.060 --> 00:03:39.180
So if you wanna talk about a key and

65
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:44.870
a pivotal element that you really need
to spend time creating, it's this.

66
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:47.470
Daniel, if you take a look here
I've got four different elements,

67
00:03:47.470 --> 00:03:51.080
at least four, and we might even see
more here, that we normally use.

68
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:54.380
And you tell me if these are important
elements or not, Daniel.

69
00:03:54.380 --> 00:03:56.476
So if I were to tell you that hey,

70
00:03:56.476 --> 00:04:01.548
I'm gonna actually need to create
the activity duration or a task duration.

71
00:04:01.548 --> 00:04:04.907
And one of the elements that I have to
have before I can do that is understanding

72
00:04:04.907 --> 00:04:06.368
the work package that's there.

73
00:04:06.368 --> 00:04:08.380
You would say that that's
an important element, right?

74
00:04:08.380 --> 00:04:09.750
>> Yeah,
that's definitely an important element.

75
00:04:09.750 --> 00:04:11.890
>> Yeah, so overall though,
if you think about it,

76
00:04:11.890 --> 00:04:14.500
right, we're saying that
really we can't accomplish

77
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:18.980
the estimation of even trying to figure
out how long a particular activity is.

78
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:20.670
We don't know the work
that's involved in it.

79
00:04:20.670 --> 00:04:23.480
And so that's why this is important.

80
00:04:23.480 --> 00:04:27.400
Also what we call about
Estimating Work Effort here.

81
00:04:27.400 --> 00:04:31.630
Now, work effort is when we do
end up kind of qualifying, right,

82
00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:35.160
the idea of whether a task
actually requires effort.

83
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:41.172
In other words, do more resources make
the actual task duration shorten?

84
00:04:41.172 --> 00:04:45.152
Or do adding in more resources
don't make the task shorten?

85
00:04:45.152 --> 00:04:47.664
Now you may have heard that
term before and you go, man,

86
00:04:47.664 --> 00:04:49.012
I know I've heard that term.

87
00:04:49.012 --> 00:04:51.645
CompTIA doesn't really
refer to it too often, but

88
00:04:51.645 --> 00:04:55.570
the idea of work effort is
something that's very important.

89
00:04:55.570 --> 00:04:57.940
So, let's kind of understand
something like this.

90
00:04:57.940 --> 00:05:02.283
Let's say that Daniel and
I were assigned to a brand new house and

91
00:05:02.283 --> 00:05:07.289
we actually need to put in the first
interior coat of a single room, okay.

92
00:05:07.289 --> 00:05:11.914
So here it is, we've got a dinning room
that we're supposed to slap paint up

93
00:05:11.914 --> 00:05:14.640
on in whatever the initial color is.

94
00:05:14.640 --> 00:05:18.090
Well, in that particular situation,
Daniel and

95
00:05:18.090 --> 00:05:22.120
I are assigned to it and let's say that
we're given three hours to do the work.

96
00:05:22.120 --> 00:05:25.940
And now we realize something, we've
only got an hour left to do the work.

97
00:05:25.940 --> 00:05:30.025
Well, would assigning a third person
help us to finish that room quicker,?

98
00:05:30.025 --> 00:05:34.200
Well, absolutely, the very fact is it
really would help because now we have

99
00:05:34.200 --> 00:05:36.620
three paint brushes
going at the same time.

100
00:05:36.620 --> 00:05:38.250
Each of us could take a wall and

101
00:05:38.250 --> 00:05:41.050
then all three of us could work
on that final wall together.

102
00:05:41.050 --> 00:05:44.530
It'd be up within that last hour
even if I didn't realize that.

103
00:05:44.530 --> 00:05:46.380
But that's the idea of work effort.

104
00:05:46.380 --> 00:05:48.208
But we've all seen this before too,
Daniel.

105
00:05:48.208 --> 00:05:50.746
You've probably seen that and
you've probably made the same,

106
00:05:50.746 --> 00:05:53.156
I say I don't want to be cliche and
I'm going to use a cliche.

107
00:05:53.156 --> 00:05:55.731
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay, so every episode I say that,

108
00:05:55.731 --> 00:05:58.520
I end up using a cliche, it's pretty bad.

109
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:01.210
But overall though,
when we take a look at this,

110
00:06:01.210 --> 00:06:04.600
especially construction that happens
on the side of the road, right?

111
00:06:04.600 --> 00:06:06.480
And traffic jams are going on.

112
00:06:06.480 --> 00:06:10.115
We've all made the comment before, and I'm
assuming it's gonna be true everywhere,

113
00:06:10.115 --> 00:06:11.930
not just here in the states.

114
00:06:11.930 --> 00:06:15.480
That you go, why is there one
guy down there digging, and

115
00:06:15.480 --> 00:06:18.400
12 guys are standing around,
and more people are coming in?

116
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:22.126
Well, it seems to actually not matter that
the more people that you add into that,

117
00:06:22.126 --> 00:06:25.270
the work's not actually being
accomplished any quicker.

118
00:06:25.270 --> 00:06:27.130
So even if there's 15
guys standing around,

119
00:06:27.130 --> 00:06:29.090
it's actually still 1
person doing the work.

120
00:06:29.090 --> 00:06:32.050
And the reason why is maybe that hole
that's actually there is only big enough

121
00:06:32.050 --> 00:06:33.750
for one person to be there.

122
00:06:33.750 --> 00:06:36.970
So you can only have one shovel at a time
but then there actually just handing it

123
00:06:36.970 --> 00:06:40.350
off from one after the other, but
they're still standing around.

124
00:06:40.350 --> 00:06:44.080
So when we talk about estimating
the idea of work effort, well,

125
00:06:44.080 --> 00:06:47.185
that's what we're talking about,
is that is really does go into this.

126
00:06:47.185 --> 00:06:49.740
When we need to actually have
that work breakdown structure,

127
00:06:49.740 --> 00:06:51.320
we need to actually be able
to figure out whether or

128
00:06:51.320 --> 00:06:54.300
not we need additional resources,
and we'll see that as well.

129
00:06:54.300 --> 00:06:57.500
And then,
how many resources do we end up assigning?

130
00:06:57.500 --> 00:07:01.732
So if we don't know what the packages are,
I can say well, Daniel,

131
00:07:01.732 --> 00:07:03.378
here is what a package is.

132
00:07:03.378 --> 00:07:04.965
And Daniel looks and goes,

133
00:07:04.965 --> 00:07:09.390
why do you have eight people assigned
to this one work package here?

134
00:07:09.390 --> 00:07:10.790
It doesn't make sense.

135
00:07:10.790 --> 00:07:14.030
Well, the reason why is that I have no
idea what the breakdown of the work

136
00:07:14.030 --> 00:07:15.020
is for that.

137
00:07:15.020 --> 00:07:18.200
So I just said it looked like
a good number that I could assign.

138
00:07:18.200 --> 00:07:21.290
But actually understanding what the work
is when we talk about a work breakdown,

139
00:07:21.290 --> 00:07:25.680
right, is actually assigning the work
itself and ultimately creating the budget.

140
00:07:25.680 --> 00:07:30.090
So when we go back to the terminology,
work breakdown, well,

141
00:07:30.090 --> 00:07:31.490
that's what we're really talking about.

142
00:07:31.490 --> 00:07:35.760
Is how do we take the actual
work that we need and

143
00:07:35.760 --> 00:07:39.350
being actually put it into
some manageable form.

144
00:07:39.350 --> 00:07:44.011
And that's what we talk about here
as far as the overall benefits

145
00:07:44.011 --> 00:07:48.598
that we get when we have this
work breakdown structure, okay?

146
00:07:48.598 --> 00:07:53.778
So, it is really key that there's a couple
of things that has to be done, okay?

147
00:07:53.778 --> 00:07:58.106
First and foremost, right, we have that
project scope statement where we do have

148
00:07:58.106 --> 00:08:02.244
A fairly high level overview, and then
if we include this in there, we now have

149
00:08:02.244 --> 00:08:06.410
a little bit of a detailed overview as
well, but at the highest levels, okay?

150
00:08:06.410 --> 00:08:09.571
Now notice what I have here,
the key element,

151
00:08:09.571 --> 00:08:13.641
the key benefit behind it,
is what we call decomposition.

152
00:08:13.641 --> 00:08:16.363
It allows us to do what
we absolutely need to do.

153
00:08:16.363 --> 00:08:22.878
We take the scope and we now break it
down into manageable work elements.

154
00:08:22.878 --> 00:08:26.393
Okay, or work chunks,
work components, whatever you want.

155
00:08:26.393 --> 00:08:28.742
And this is something that
is very difficult for

156
00:08:28.742 --> 00:08:32.692
the beginning project manager,
the novice project manager, to understand.

157
00:08:32.692 --> 00:08:37.570
He can take a look at the scope and
says, I think, I believe,

158
00:08:37.570 --> 00:08:41.701
I absolutely 100% agree
that this can be done.

159
00:08:41.701 --> 00:08:46.255
But because of a lack of experience
a lot of times he doesn't know what

160
00:08:46.255 --> 00:08:50.193
elements it actually breaks
down into to get that job done.

161
00:08:50.193 --> 00:08:52.048
He knows what needs to be done but

162
00:08:52.048 --> 00:08:55.020
he may not know how it
actually breaks down to do so.

163
00:08:55.020 --> 00:08:57.480
So trying to figure this
out is technically, and

164
00:08:57.480 --> 00:08:59.760
this is the word you want
to center in on here,

165
00:08:59.760 --> 00:09:03.120
is that term decomposition which
is really just breaking it down.

166
00:09:03.120 --> 00:09:06.640
>> Ronnie, is that what separates this,
or distinguishes it,

167
00:09:06.640 --> 00:09:11.430
maybe should I say, from something like
the scope statement or even the charter?

168
00:09:11.430 --> 00:09:13.920
>> Yes,
remember that both of those, right,

169
00:09:13.920 --> 00:09:18.640
at the actual scope statement level
itself as well as at the charter level,

170
00:09:18.640 --> 00:09:23.310
we're really getting a bird's eye view
of the entire project itself, okay?

171
00:09:23.310 --> 00:09:28.180
Now when you start asking manufacturing or
creating that scope statement itself.

172
00:09:28.180 --> 00:09:31.350
You even come down to the work
breakdown structure to show that

173
00:09:31.350 --> 00:09:36.120
you have an understanding of what needs to
be managed in very general chunks here.

174
00:09:36.120 --> 00:09:39.890
But when you start breaking this down for
actual planning, you really do,

175
00:09:39.890 --> 00:09:44.580
you're actually breaking it down into
very small and manageable chunks.

176
00:09:44.580 --> 00:09:48.760
And this again is where the project
manager has to stand back for a moment and

177
00:09:48.760 --> 00:09:53.490
not say, I know I can accomplish
this in three hours, okay?

178
00:09:53.490 --> 00:09:57.880
What he has to do is stand back and say,
what level do I need to manage this at?

179
00:09:57.880 --> 00:10:02.120
Or, at this point,
who do I need to get to manage it instead?

180
00:10:02.120 --> 00:10:05.660
So, the work breakdown structure is taking
that, it's taking the project scope and

181
00:10:05.660 --> 00:10:10.510
saying, what are the manageable
chunks of work that need to be done,

182
00:10:10.510 --> 00:10:14.980
and how do I actually manage that, or
who do I get to manage that for us?

183
00:10:14.980 --> 00:10:16.270
And that's what we're talking about.

184
00:10:16.270 --> 00:10:19.780
So, you'll hear in the way that
CompTIAt mentions this is,

185
00:10:19.780 --> 00:10:23.470
it breaks down the scope
down to work components.

186
00:10:23.470 --> 00:10:27.555
Now in the PMP world, right, the project
management professional world and so

187
00:10:27.555 --> 00:10:30.920
I'm gonna say that you might
see both terms on the exam,

188
00:10:30.920 --> 00:10:34.060
you might hear instead
the term work package.

189
00:10:34.060 --> 00:10:38.020
So when you hear that,
that's what also happens here too.

190
00:10:38.020 --> 00:10:40.600
Is that the work breakdown
takes the scope and

191
00:10:40.600 --> 00:10:43.380
breaks it down into
individual work packages.

192
00:10:43.380 --> 00:10:46.420
The work package itself
is actually designed

193
00:10:46.420 --> 00:10:49.060
to do a couple of things for us, right?

194
00:10:49.060 --> 00:10:52.850
It's a really a management term
more that anything else, okay?

195
00:10:52.850 --> 00:10:55.240
It allows us to be able to actually say,

196
00:10:55.240 --> 00:11:00.270
here's the amount of work we believe
that can be done in an estimated time.

197
00:11:00.270 --> 00:11:06.420
So if we say hey, it's gonna take Daniel
and Ronnie, let's say, six hours to paint

198
00:11:06.420 --> 00:11:11.250
the entire house, or we'll say, we'll give
them a day to paint the entire house.

199
00:11:11.250 --> 00:11:14.940
Well, then we're saying that
that's a manageable amount of time

200
00:11:14.940 --> 00:11:19.870
that we can say with some assurance and
some assumptions that Daniel and

201
00:11:19.870 --> 00:11:21.750
Ronnie can paint the house in a day, okay.

202
00:11:21.750 --> 00:11:25.530
Now I don't know who would ever actually
assign me to do something like that.

203

because everybody does it a little bit

426
00:23:05.550 --> 00:23:06.680
differently and

427
00:23:06.680 --> 00:23:11.290
different software breaks down these word
packages a little bit differently as well.

428
00:23:11.290 --> 00:23:15.350
So what happen is that you set up some
type of graphical way that you are wanna

429
00:23:15.350 --> 00:23:21.110
explain to anybody that walks by of what
is going to has occur in your project.

430
00:23:21.110 --> 00:23:23.020
So you might see something like
this hang up on the wall or

431
00:23:23.020 --> 00:23:25.460
you might see it in the form of software.

432
00:23:25.460 --> 00:23:29.170
During meeting you'll see it of course
as hand outs as you have this done.

433
00:23:29.170 --> 00:23:32.010
So let's take for an example
the project that I mentioned here.

434
00:23:32.010 --> 00:23:33.710
Okay, here it is.

435
00:23:33.710 --> 00:23:36.770
My project was migrating
users to thin clients,

436
00:23:36.770 --> 00:23:40.630
that was the ultimate goal on the project
to move people that were on regular

437
00:23:40.630 --> 00:23:43.850
desktop computers over
to those thin clients.

438
00:23:43.850 --> 00:23:49.717
So at this point I assign myself a number,
1.0, why?

439
00:23:49.717 --> 00:23:52.698
Because we didn't have any real
structure that we had to follow.

440
00:23:52.698 --> 00:23:55.588
So, I'm actually saying that
this is one project for me.

441
00:23:55.588 --> 00:24:01.180
And in this one project that is
my top level, WBS here, okay?

442
00:24:01.180 --> 00:24:03.900
So that is the overall project itself.

443
00:24:03.900 --> 00:24:07.690
I break down now what I believe
needs to be accomplished in the most

444
00:24:07.690 --> 00:24:11.350
major accomplishments that I
can as far as deliverables go.

445
00:24:11.350 --> 00:24:14.600
And I told you about the idea
of installing hardware.

446
00:24:14.600 --> 00:24:18.410
Notice that I started off with one but
here is my second level and

447
00:24:18.410 --> 00:24:21.870
this is normally how you see
it displayed is using decimal.

448
00:24:21.870 --> 00:24:24.040
Now sometimes you might see dashes.

449
00:24:24.040 --> 00:24:27.190
You can change this in
systems that you want to.

450
00:24:27.190 --> 00:24:31.290
If you do it in software you might have to
manually create your own numbering system

451
00:24:31.290 --> 00:24:34.630
which can be a little bit challenging at
times when you use something like this.

452
00:24:34.630 --> 00:24:38.760
But overall though you see where it says
1.1, and then I had system testing and

453
00:24:38.760 --> 00:24:41.460
it continuous on and on,
I just didn't draw the rest of it.

454
00:24:41.460 --> 00:24:44.280
But I could have broken each and
one of those down about what I meant for

455
00:24:44.280 --> 00:24:47.830
system testing and
all the owners that I add in there.

456
00:24:47.830 --> 00:24:50.580
And notice at the third level, notice
that there's actually three numbers,

457
00:24:50.580 --> 00:24:53.790
let me zoom in and make sure that we
could see that just a little bit more.

458
00:24:53.790 --> 00:24:55.490
So you can actually see now,

459
00:24:55.490 --> 00:25:00.780
the three numbers right there, it started
with servers going in to the racks,

460
00:25:00.780 --> 00:25:05.780
wiring installation for the building,
setting up the end-user thin clients here,

461
00:25:05.780 --> 00:25:10.600
and of course the actual setup
of monitors, keyboard, and mice.

462
00:25:10.600 --> 00:25:13.850
I could have broken it down in that
particular situation as far as work

463
00:25:13.850 --> 00:25:15.300
packages go.

464
00:25:15.300 --> 00:25:17.930
And now, those are now manageable for us.

465
00:25:17.930 --> 00:25:19.926
So when somebody says,
or when Daniel says,

466
00:25:19.926 --> 00:25:21.720
well what am I supposed to be working on?

467
00:25:21.720 --> 00:25:24.560
I'm gonna say, well which work
package were you assigned to?

468
00:25:24.560 --> 00:25:26.510
And that way we can actually do that.

469
00:25:26.510 --> 00:25:28.242
And Daniel can actually look and

470
00:25:28.242 --> 00:25:32.490
go, yeah, I'm suppose to be
working on 1.1.4 right now, yeah.

471
00:25:32.490 --> 00:25:34.825
I spent a couple days where
I didn't do anything.

472
00:25:34.825 --> 00:25:37.810
So, we update that and
we do whatever we need to.

473
00:25:37.810 --> 00:25:41.200
But this is really essential when you
do need that graphic way of being able

474
00:25:41.200 --> 00:25:45.680
to display the information that
we tend to have in our scope.

475
00:25:45.680 --> 00:25:48.900
And this is also great in
meetings because it does.

476
00:25:48.900 --> 00:25:51.660
Giving somebody a paper to read,
people like that.

477
00:25:51.660 --> 00:25:55.170
But you show them visually that hey,
here's what we've accomplished and

478
00:25:55.170 --> 00:25:58.550
you start marking these things off and
what we aren't accomplishing yet.

479
00:25:58.550 --> 00:26:02.352
They can kind of visually see, hey,
how far are you actually progressing and

480
00:26:02.352 --> 00:26:05.042
there's a lot more detail
that we can go into this but,

481
00:26:05.042 --> 00:26:08.875
at least at the WBS structure, this is
what we're normally taking a look at.

482
00:26:08.875 --> 00:26:13.790
>> And this also gives us the opportunity
to give a good critique of our WBS.

483
00:26:13.790 --> 00:26:16.360
Maybe we've made some mistakes here and
there.

484
00:26:16.360 --> 00:26:21.770
Having that good visual reference is gonna
give us a great place to go you know what?

485
00:26:21.770 --> 00:26:23.420
I need to merge these two things together.

486
00:26:23.420 --> 00:26:26.070
Or I need to separate
these two things out.

487
00:26:26.070 --> 00:26:28.180
And it really does a great job of that for
us as well.

488
00:26:28.180 --> 00:26:30.940
>> It really does and
that's exactly what you're doing right?

489
00:26:30.940 --> 00:26:34.420
When you take a look at this,
when you take a look at where you are, and

490
00:26:34.420 --> 00:26:37.730
there's a lot of times where you're
brought into the middle of a project and

491
00:26:37.730 --> 00:26:38.780
you just don't know.

492
00:26:38.780 --> 00:26:42.100
And now what you do is you take a look
at the work breakdown structure and

493
00:26:42.100 --> 00:26:45.300
you start seeing how the actual
work packages were assigned.

494
00:26:45.300 --> 00:26:47.810
And what they were doing,
it really is something like this.

495
00:26:47.810 --> 00:26:50.850
But you normally see in the work breakdown
structure, if you're critiquing it.

496
00:26:50.850 --> 00:26:53.030
You normally see a numbering system, okay.

497
00:26:53.030 --> 00:26:55.080
You normally see the top level.

498
00:26:55.080 --> 00:26:57.970
You normally see multiple levels at times.

499
00:26:57.970 --> 00:27:02.020
But remember, whatever that last level is,
that's what the project manager,

500
00:27:02.020 --> 00:27:06.210
and whoever's helping them to create
this believes is what is the work

501
00:27:06.210 --> 00:27:11.170
package itself in order to manage
a unit of work that has to be done.

502
00:27:11.170 --> 00:27:15.190
It's not trying to micromanage, it's just
saying that here's what we believe here

503
00:27:15.190 --> 00:27:18.200
is here's that manageable unit of work.

504
00:27:18.200 --> 00:27:22.870
Normally if you wanna take that
down to real time estimates,

505
00:27:22.870 --> 00:27:24.400
it's usually about a day's work.

506
00:27:24.400 --> 00:27:27.420
A day worth of work, and
in project management,

507
00:27:27.420 --> 00:27:30.240
you tend to equal that
out to about eight hours.

508
00:27:30.240 --> 00:27:32.510
Now not every day is always
eight hours of work,

509
00:27:32.510 --> 00:27:34.640
but that's the assumption
that you're making.

510
00:27:34.640 --> 00:27:38.950
And it's a general assumption because
normally workdays are eight hours long and

511
00:27:38.950 --> 00:27:41.540
you accomplish just so
much during that time.

512
00:27:41.540 --> 00:27:44.600
So usually if you need a rule of thumb,
right?

513
00:27:44.600 --> 00:27:45.950
If you go, work breakdown structure?

514
00:27:45.950 --> 00:27:49.750
I still have to manage it, but
I'm not gonna take the time to do this.

515
00:27:49.750 --> 00:27:53.350
What you wanna do is you wanna breakdown
the work to what's normally managed within

516
00:27:53.350 --> 00:27:54.660
about a day's time.

517
00:27:54.660 --> 00:27:56.680
So what are you gonna accomplish in a day?

518
00:27:56.680 --> 00:28:00.080
So even though I talked about installing
hardware, I could do it all in a day, but

519
00:28:00.080 --> 00:28:03.220
the very fact is I don't know how
much hardware needed installed.

520
00:28:03.220 --> 00:28:05.760
I don't know how detailed it actually
gets into installing servers and

521
00:28:05.760 --> 00:28:09.420
server racks, well I may not know
if I can accomplish that in a day.

522
00:28:09.420 --> 00:28:11.150
So I might break that down and go no.

523
00:28:11.150 --> 00:28:13.830
I'm gonna say that I'm gonna
give the servers a day.

524
00:28:13.830 --> 00:28:15.585
And you can kind of use
that as a guideline or

525
00:28:15.585 --> 00:28:18.610
a rule of thumb to kind
of help you out there.

526
00:28:18.610 --> 00:28:20.120
So that's where that breaks down.

527
00:28:20.120 --> 00:28:23.350
Now remember it doesn't mean
that you have to follow us.

528
00:28:23.350 --> 00:28:24.300
What are we trying to do here?

529
00:28:24.300 --> 00:28:27.210
Remember we're trying to actually give you
the best practices That you'll generally

530
00:28:27.210 --> 00:28:31.030
find by most project managers,
as well as getting ready for the exam.

531
00:28:31.030 --> 00:28:35.970
But in the end, PMI, right, the Project
Management Institute, the guys at CompTIA

532
00:28:35.970 --> 00:28:39.520
don't sit there and go, you have to
do your project management this way.

533
00:28:39.520 --> 00:28:41.600
You have to make sure that you do it all.

534
00:28:41.600 --> 00:28:42.790
You can do it however you want to.

535
00:28:42.790 --> 00:28:46.270
But they're saying, here's normally
what most project managers would end up

536
00:28:46.270 --> 00:28:49.280
breaking it down into, and
that's pretty much the key.

537
00:28:49.280 --> 00:28:50.400
>> Awesome stuff, Ronnie.

538
00:28:50.400 --> 00:28:51.880
Now, we've talked a lot about WBS,

539
00:28:51.880 --> 00:28:55.780
is there anything else that we need
to cover, in this episode at least?

540
00:28:55.780 --> 00:29:01.065
I know this probably, we can probably make
12 episodes of WBS and bore you to tears.

541
00:29:01.065 --> 00:29:02.835
But pertinent information,
anything else for

542
00:29:02.835 --> 00:29:04.195
this episode that we need to talk about?

543
00:29:04.195 --> 00:29:06.465
>> There's only one other thing
that we really need to get in here,

544
00:29:06.465 --> 00:29:09.885
which is what we call the WBS Dictionary.

545
00:29:09.885 --> 00:29:14.605
Now this is really more of a technical
side for us as we are getting ready for

546
00:29:14.605 --> 00:29:15.245
the exam.

547
00:29:15.245 --> 00:29:20.530
And this does happen to more formalized
project management situations here,

548
00:29:20.530 --> 00:29:23.640
but we normally need to create something
like this because remember where your

549
00:29:23.640 --> 00:29:25.480
project team maybe coming from.

550
00:29:25.480 --> 00:29:28.487
And you're saying, well where the heck
is my project team coming from,

551
00:29:28.487 --> 00:29:29.670
exactly, okay?

552
00:29:29.670 --> 00:29:30.820
You don't know, okay?

553
00:29:30.820 --> 00:29:32.500
So that's the key.

554
00:29:32.500 --> 00:29:36.660
So what has to happen is that
if you want somebody to try and

555
00:29:36.660 --> 00:29:39.860
fully understand the way you
created a work breakdown structure,

556
00:29:39.860 --> 00:29:42.380
you need a dictionary about
your work breakdown structure.

557
00:29:42.380 --> 00:29:46.130
In other words, to actually let them
understand the terms that you're using,

558
00:29:46.130 --> 00:29:47.790
cuz it may not actually be working for
them.

559
00:29:47.790 --> 00:29:50.290
They might go,
I don't know what that means or,

560
00:29:50.290 --> 00:29:53.100
that's not the way that I did
it in my last organization.

561
00:29:53.100 --> 00:29:57.710
So the idea of the work breakdown
structure dictionary, the WBS Dictionary,

562
00:29:57.710 --> 00:30:02.220
it goes ahead and it begins to formal
documentation of that work level.

563
00:30:02.220 --> 00:30:05.300
In other words,
it shows us that WBS structure and

564
00:30:05.300 --> 00:30:10.060
then it gives us descriptions of
the actual work packages themselves.

565
00:30:10.060 --> 00:30:14.690
Now normally it also includes a lot
of these other things that we see.

566
00:30:14.690 --> 00:30:18.230
Which is, how do we know that we're
actually accomplishing what we need to?

567
00:30:18.230 --> 00:30:21.030
So we have a list of every single
deliverable that we believe that's gonna

568
00:30:21.030 --> 00:30:22.670
be accomplished during our project.

569
00:30:22.670 --> 00:30:25.260
And that way,
we know that we're actually on track.

570
00:30:25.260 --> 00:30:28.400
It gives us that code
that we're talking about.

571
00:30:28.400 --> 00:30:35.344
So, if somebody's wondering,
what the heck is 4.1.2.3?

572
00:30:35.344 --> 00:30:39.268
It actually explains
how that code is there.

573
00:30:39.268 --> 00:30:42.810
A lot of times it is about
accounting more than anything else.

574
00:30:42.810 --> 00:30:46.950
When you turn in your work, and you
have that Project Management Accountant,

575
00:30:46.950 --> 00:30:48.690
he's not gonna know well,
where does this fit in?

576
00:30:48.690 --> 00:30:52.520
He wants that code that says hey, here's
where they actually bought the material,

577
00:30:52.520 --> 00:30:53.810
and here's where it actually goes into.

578
00:30:53.810 --> 00:30:55.500
And that way they can judge whether or

579
00:30:55.500 --> 00:30:59.820
not you've been over budget, under budget,
did what you needed to or not.

580
00:30:59.820 --> 00:31:03.900
Who's responsible for the work,
the actual resources, estimates,

581
00:31:03.900 --> 00:31:05.990
acceptance criteria, you name it.

582
00:31:05.990 --> 00:31:08.520
But remember that it's actually
used as a reference so

583
00:31:08.520 --> 00:31:11.497
that everybody can understand
that work breakdown structure.

584
00:31:11.497 --> 00:31:14.414
And you might go, well,
how important is this?

585
00:31:14.414 --> 00:31:16.230
It's insanely important, okay?

586
00:31:16.230 --> 00:31:17.447
When it comes down to it.

587
00:31:17.447 --> 00:31:20.136
If I start to talk, and
Daniel thinks he's talking, that I'm

588
00:31:20.136 --> 00:31:23.940
talking about the same thing he is, and
then Daniel starts describing them.

589
00:31:23.940 --> 00:31:25.230
I don't know what you're talking about,
Daniel.

590
00:31:25.230 --> 00:31:27.180
Well then we're on a different page.

591
00:31:27.180 --> 00:31:29.440
And Daniel may be working on
a totally different project,

592
00:31:29.440 --> 00:31:32.070
even though he thinks he's working
on the same project as I am.

593
00:31:32.070 --> 00:31:33.250
Not a good feeling to have.

594
00:31:33.250 --> 00:31:36.371
>> Yeah, I've actually had
that happen in practicality,

595
00:31:36.371 --> 00:31:39.816
maybe not on a grand scale, but
the boss told me, he always says

596
00:31:39.816 --> 00:31:44.317
I want you to delete a user because they
were, they left the company or something.

597
00:31:44.317 --> 00:31:47.706
But don't delete them from exchange.

598
00:31:47.706 --> 00:31:48.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> He said delete them

599
00:31:48.990 --> 00:31:51.420
from Active Directory but
don't delete them from exchange.

600
00:31:51.420 --> 00:31:53.590
Well I have an exchange
server as our email server.

601
00:31:53.590 --> 00:31:56.584
You have Active Directory server
obviously that holds all the users, and

602
00:31:56.584 --> 00:31:57.360
that's strange.

603
00:31:57.360 --> 00:32:02.450
Okay so, you want me to keep their mail
box around but not their user account,

604
00:32:02.450 --> 00:32:04.250
no problem, so I did that.

605
00:32:04.250 --> 00:32:07.020
Then one day he calls me up and
says why didn't you delete this user?

606
00:32:07.020 --> 00:32:10.670
I said I did, your email right here
says delete it from Active Directory and

607
00:32:10.670 --> 00:32:11.640
not Exchange.

608
00:32:11.640 --> 00:32:17.810
He said what I meant was don't do the
deletion from the Active Directory server,

609
00:32:17.810 --> 00:32:19.580
do it from the Exchange server.

610
00:32:19.580 --> 00:32:22.390
>> Yes.
>> Which would remove the account as well.

611
00:32:22.390 --> 00:32:27.450
So, as you can see, we weren't
jiving on what our terms were and

612
00:32:27.450 --> 00:32:29.960
then there was a disconnect and
the work didn't get done.

613
00:32:29.960 --> 00:32:34.870
So having a consistent terminology
that we can all look back to,

614
00:32:34.870 --> 00:32:36.380
very, very important.

615
00:32:36.380 --> 00:32:38.320
>> And that dictionary being open and
available for

616
00:32:38.320 --> 00:32:41.860
everyone will actually allow Daniel to
know that I didn't just change it at

617
00:32:41.860 --> 00:32:45.990
the moment cuz Daniel can say, no you
changed what you actually said to me now.

618
00:32:45.990 --> 00:32:47.480
Well going back to that dictionary,

619
00:32:47.480 --> 00:32:50.020
right, when we start working
on the entire project

620
00:32:50.020 --> 00:32:54.210
anybody should be able to access that
dictionary to understand what's going on.

621
00:32:54.210 --> 00:32:57.250
And if they can't that's when they
actually need more clarification.

622
00:32:57.250 --> 00:32:59.380
But that's why we have the dictionary,
it's so

623
00:32:59.380 --> 00:33:03.740
that we won't need that and everybody
will understand what I mean when I say,

624
00:33:03.740 --> 00:33:05.350
why aren't you doing your work package?

625
00:33:05.350 --> 00:33:08.550
Generally it's like,
well that's not my work package.

626
00:33:08.550 --> 00:33:11.820
Or that's not what I understand by
a work package, whatever it might be.

627
00:33:11.820 --> 00:33:15.190
So it's very clear that this is actually
one of the key elements that will

628
00:33:15.190 --> 00:33:20.300
really help us out when we start talking
about the beginnings of management, right?

629
00:33:20.300 --> 00:33:25.090
Of being able to manage the entire plan
of the entire scope of the project.

630
00:33:25.090 --> 00:33:27.810
This is, by far, one of the most
important elements we'll ever cover.

631
00:33:27.810 --> 00:33:28.810
>> Totally agreed, Ronnie.

632
00:33:28.810 --> 00:33:32.220
And excellent job in explaining this,
and why it's so important.

633
00:33:32.220 --> 00:33:35.830
Now hopefully, you guys are seeing it,
that this is going to help us

634
00:33:35.830 --> 00:33:40.170
be kind of our guiding star as we go
through the project planning, and

635
00:33:40.170 --> 00:33:41.640
even the project itself.

636
00:33:41.640 --> 00:33:45.040
Ronnie thank you so much for joining
us today, we appreciate your wisdom and

637
00:33:45.040 --> 00:33:49.120
knowledge to help us be better
prepared for our Project + exam and

638
00:33:49.120 --> 00:33:50.670
for our projects in real life.

639
00:33:50.670 --> 00:33:54.351
That being said, we thank you guys for
joining us, we're gonna go ahead and

640
00:33:54.351 --> 00:33:55.456
sign off for ITProTV.

641
00:33:55.456 --> 00:33:56.651
I've been your hose Daniel Lowrie.

642
00:33:56.651 --> 00:33:57.557
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

643
00:33:57.557 --> 00:33:58.590
>> And we'll see you next time.

644
00:34:00.296 --> 00:34:06.252
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into the exciting world of managing project changes. They begin by explaining what is meant by a project change and how you can go about formally requesting and documenting said changes. They will show you the forms needed, explain the approval process, and turnaround times; then walk you through document routing and communication flow to distribute the changes to project team members and stakeholders.
episodes.title: Manage Project Changes

WEBVTT

2
00:00:12.385 --> 00:00:16.691

Is it actually something that's done
by courier, is this actually a written

452
00:24:10.730 --> 00:24:15.030
documentation on paper that they have to
be able to read, can it be done by email,

453
00:24:15.030 --> 00:24:16.750
whatever it might be.

454
00:24:16.750 --> 00:24:19.970
We need a formal process that says
here's something that's gonna happen.

455
00:24:19.970 --> 00:24:23.410
And it normally also announces that
a meeting's gonna be taking place.

456
00:24:23.410 --> 00:24:26.080
Now also remember that the approval, or

457
00:24:26.080 --> 00:24:30.530
also of course the declining of this,
also needs to be addressed and

458
00:24:30.530 --> 00:24:33.950
distributed as well, and what
are the formal channels for that, okay?

459
00:24:33.950 --> 00:24:35.760
So you might found out that
the formal channel for

460
00:24:35.760 --> 00:24:37.990
the approval is Whatever it might be.

461
00:24:37.990 --> 00:24:40.270
Where it's announced to
the project manager.

462
00:24:40.270 --> 00:24:43.720
The project manager will then announce
that to whoever he wants to and

463
00:24:43.720 --> 00:24:45.260
they'll distribute it out.

464
00:24:45.260 --> 00:24:50.070
But usually though especially on
a decline of some sort it might be if it

465
00:24:50.070 --> 00:24:52.540
only effects that one department
you don't announce it to everybody.

466
00:24:52.540 --> 00:24:53.090
Okay?

467
00:24:53.090 --> 00:24:57.330
Now if it actually effects every
department, so let's say that Daniel for

468
00:24:57.330 --> 00:24:59.420
one reason or another,
got nominated to make this change and

469
00:24:59.420 --> 00:25:05.130
it's because it affected like six or
seven different steps in the project.

470
00:25:05.130 --> 00:25:08.340
And Daniel said,
yeah I'll submit that change, but

471
00:25:08.340 --> 00:25:13.260
now nobody else is willing to stand up and
say I approved that change.

472
00:25:13.260 --> 00:25:14.590
And Daniel is standing there,

473
00:25:14.590 --> 00:25:19.220
well normally that's why you
handle that idea of rejection.

474
00:25:19.220 --> 00:25:23.110
In private and you go "Daniel you know,
this is how it happens." But

475
00:25:23.110 --> 00:25:26.520
if you need to male a statement go
"alright we're not doing that change." And

476
00:25:26.520 --> 00:25:28.690
everybody gets it all at one time.

477
00:25:28.690 --> 00:25:31.360
You also have to start doing some team
building if you start doing something

478
00:25:31.360 --> 00:25:32.010
like that.

479
00:25:32.010 --> 00:25:34.980
Just kind of realize that document
routing is actually part of it.

480
00:25:34.980 --> 00:25:38.580
And last step step here of course
is that idea of communication flow.

481
00:25:38.580 --> 00:25:43.090
Now when we talk about It's
fairly difficult, right,

482
00:25:43.090 --> 00:25:47.570
to have great communication with a whole
bunch of people at the same time.

483
00:25:47.570 --> 00:25:50.220
Usually when that happens, right,
it's really one voice that goes over

484
00:25:50.220 --> 00:25:53.300
an intercom or
one email that's distributed to everybody.

485
00:25:53.300 --> 00:25:56.640
But there's no real great
feedback system that we have, and

486
00:25:56.640 --> 00:26:00.440
no real great communication system that
actually addresses everybody's needs.

487
00:26:00.440 --> 00:26:03.170
So we need to make sure that we
have some communication flow.

488
00:26:04.480 --> 00:26:06.050
From the very beginning, like I said.

489
00:26:06.050 --> 00:26:08.730
And this is the important thing, okay?

490
00:26:08.730 --> 00:26:11.070
How is that request to be made?

491
00:26:11.070 --> 00:26:12.990
Everybody needs to know, okay?

492
00:26:12.990 --> 00:26:16.250
It's not just that one say I
just send an email to whoever.

493
00:26:16.250 --> 00:26:20.760
Daniel though, actually types out
on a long form and types out or

494
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:22.420
he submits it electronically.

495
00:26:22.420 --> 00:26:24.830
We need everybody to actually
be able to agree to it.

496
00:26:24.830 --> 00:26:26.750
Whether it's oral, email, forms,

497
00:26:26.750 --> 00:26:31.160
whatever it is, we should have the idea
of what our communication channel is.

498
00:26:31.160 --> 00:26:34.582
And also we should have
that formalized process,

499
00:26:34.582 --> 00:26:39.070
as far as the result go and
how they're going to be communicated.

500
00:26:39.070 --> 00:26:42.000
The very fact is,
if you don't see it showing up.

501
00:26:42.000 --> 00:26:47.500
As a change in the actual work breakdown
structure then don't worry about it.

502
00:26:47.500 --> 00:26:49.100
But there has to be some process,

503
00:26:49.100 --> 00:26:53.780
there has to be some way that we can
manage the changes that do come along.

504
00:26:53.780 --> 00:26:56.420
You still won't get every single
change that ends up happening.

505
00:26:56.420 --> 00:26:59.170
It's just an impossibility, okay?

506
00:26:59.170 --> 00:27:04.190
Unless you can get everybody on
your side to understand that any

507
00:27:04.190 --> 00:27:06.070
change that anybody else requests,

508
00:27:06.070 --> 00:27:10.310
even other sponsors request,
has to go through this formal process.

509
00:27:10.310 --> 00:27:14.000
Somebody will still slip things in that
you don't realize a lot of times, and

510
00:27:14.000 --> 00:27:16.570
then you have to go back and
try and figure that out and try and

511
00:27:16.570 --> 00:27:20.990
figure out where you went over budget,
under budget, didn't have enough people.

512
00:27:20.990 --> 00:27:22.710
It all comes out in the end.

513
00:27:22.710 --> 00:27:25.900
Where that ends up happening, but
you'll never get a straight answer.

514
00:27:25.900 --> 00:27:29.890
But by having an understanding that every
change goes through the same process,

515
00:27:29.890 --> 00:27:31.060
it's uniform.

516
00:27:31.060 --> 00:27:32.190
It makes it easier for

517
00:27:32.190 --> 00:27:35.850
us to manage the entire project,
especially when changes come up.

518
00:27:35.850 --> 00:27:37.930
>> Excellent points, Ronnie, all of them.

519
00:27:37.930 --> 00:27:41.050
I know change requests
can be time-consuming,

520
00:27:41.050 --> 00:27:43.670
tedious, even frustrating at times.

521
00:27:43.670 --> 00:27:46.980
But hopefully at the end of this show,

522
00:27:46.980 --> 00:27:52.610
you are seeing the importance of it, how
it can work to your benefit in many cases.

523
00:27:52.610 --> 00:27:54.805
Especially when it comes
time to who did what wrong-

524
00:27:54.805 --> 00:27:55.540
>> [LAUGH]

525
00:27:55.540 --> 00:27:58.470
>> You're gonna love it at that point.

526
00:27:58.470 --> 00:27:59.590
That is that thing, right?

527
00:27:59.590 --> 00:28:01.710
It is an important thing,
we do need to engage in it.

528
00:28:01.710 --> 00:28:04.170
Ronnie's done a great job of explaining.

529
00:28:04.170 --> 00:28:08.280
Actually, all the major caveats and
benefits of how we use these things.

530
00:28:08.280 --> 00:28:09.790
We appreciate you doing that for us today.

531
00:28:09.790 --> 00:28:13.150
And we appreciate you guys watching,
but we have come to the end of yet

532
00:28:13.150 --> 00:28:13.930
another episode.

533
00:28:13.930 --> 00:28:15.010
Hopefully you've enjoyed it.

534
00:28:15.010 --> 00:28:17.660
We had a great time making it for
you, but signing off for ITProTV,

535
00:28:17.660 --> 00:28:19.480
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

536
00:28:19.480 --> 00:28:20.230
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

537
00:28:20.230 --> 00:28:20.929
>> We'll see you next time.

538
00:28:23.621 --> 00:28:31.470
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take you through developing a project schedule. They begin by looking at the inputs that will help define the schedule as well as working with a Project Management Information System. Then they define the different identity types such as Mandatory Dependencies, Discretionary Dependencies, and External Dependencies.
episodes.title: Develop a Project Schedule
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.018 --> 00:00:10.018
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.338 --> 00:00:14.141
All right, greetings, everyone,

3
00:00:14.141 --> 00:00:17.490
and welcome to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.490 --> 00:00:20.670
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are still moving

5
00:00:20.670 --> 00:00:25.390
forward with our Project+ series joining
us back in the studio again today to

6
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:29.300
lend his super brain in Project,
that is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:30.520
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

8
00:00:30.520 --> 00:00:31.620
>> Well, thank you very much.

9
00:00:31.620 --> 00:00:34.910
I don't have a super brain in Project but
I do know a little bit about it but

10
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:37.930
welcome to off course
the Comp IT ProTV show

11
00:00:37.930 --> 00:00:42.040
as we continue to make sure you
are ready not only for that exam,

12
00:00:42.040 --> 00:00:45.000
making sure you get all the knowledge
that you need there, but also if you

13
00:00:45.000 --> 00:00:48.350
are someone that is actually interested in
learning more about project management.

14
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:53.050
If you are actually trying to not only
get that project plus certification, but

15
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:55.680
of course if you actually are all ready in
project management you may want to learn

16
00:00:55.680 --> 00:00:57.840
more about the tools that
are available to you and

17
00:00:57.840 --> 00:01:00.030
that's what we'll be
taking a look at today.

18
00:01:00.030 --> 00:01:02.080
Now, we've already been
going through the series and

19
00:01:02.080 --> 00:01:06.680
we are really kind of starting to
get the ball rolling, the snowball

20
00:01:06.680 --> 00:01:11.150
rolling down the hill, the build up
of knowledge in terms of planning.

21
00:01:11.150 --> 00:01:15.650
So, in that planning stage, we've really
started taking a look, of course,

22
00:01:15.650 --> 00:01:20.920
at the project scope and managing that
project scope we also took an episode or

23
00:01:20.920 --> 00:01:26.590
so and took a look of course at how that
work break down structure ends up working

24
00:01:26.590 --> 00:01:30.950
for us and now we're beginning and we're
not gonna tell you we're covering every

25
00:01:30.950 --> 00:01:34.880
thing that there is but we're actually
getting in to really the heart and

26
00:01:34.880 --> 00:01:39.470
soul of the project management which
is the idea of scheduling, okay.

27
00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:43.520
Now when it comes down to scheduling the
automatic thing that we always think about

28
00:01:43.520 --> 00:01:48.750
is essentially calendar and time, and
that's really what we're focusing in on.

29
00:01:48.750 --> 00:01:53.070
But most of us understand how to keep
a calendar, right, you probably have one,

30
00:01:53.070 --> 00:01:56.190
I know Daniel probably has one
with little kittens up there.

31
00:01:56.190 --> 00:01:58.150
And you know you flip the months and.

32
00:01:58.150 --> 00:01:58.750
>> It's at my desk.

33
00:01:58.750 --> 00:02:00.070
>> Yeah, it's at your desk.

34
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:03.560
So that way you can actually keep
track of different things that happen.

35
00:02:03.560 --> 00:02:04.600
But overall though,

36
00:02:04.600 --> 00:02:08.860
right, that is actually a very important
element to the idea of project management.

37
00:02:08.860 --> 00:02:12.550
Because, remember that, every single
project is actually constrained by what

38
00:02:12.550 --> 00:02:14.430
we call our project constraints.

39
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:17.550
We talk about the idea of cost,
quality and

40
00:02:17.550 --> 00:02:22.350
time is what we really focus in around and
so a whole third of what you do as

41
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:28.060
a project manager is all about managing
the time that you have on that project.

42
00:02:28.060 --> 00:02:32.890
The time itself, if we overemphasize it,
ends up costing us in quality, or

43
00:02:32.890 --> 00:02:35.410
ends up costing us, of course, in money.

44
00:02:35.410 --> 00:02:38.870
And so we've gotta actually be very
good at actually understanding

45
00:02:38.870 --> 00:02:42.440
how in the world we manage time and
what goes into the elements

46
00:02:42.440 --> 00:02:45.750
of being able to manage the time
that we're given for our project.

47
00:02:45.750 --> 00:02:51.330
So when we start to take a look at
the idea here of managing time.

48
00:02:51.330 --> 00:02:54.230
Well we've gotta understand that there's
actually several things that we have

49
00:02:54.230 --> 00:02:56.820
to take into account
when we start doing this.

50
00:02:56.820 --> 00:02:59.730
One of course is,
how long does it take for

51
00:02:59.730 --> 00:03:05.020
a individual task to actually be
started and completed, as well, okay?

52
00:03:05.020 --> 00:03:09.280
So at that point, we might actually
accept some input then from our WBS,

53
00:03:09.280 --> 00:03:11.580
our work breakdown structure.

54
00:03:11.580 --> 00:03:15.470
We also of course make sure that we
are still lines up with the scope

55
00:03:15.470 --> 00:03:18.770
of the project as well,
there's nothing more disheartening for

56
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:23.800
a project manager than to go around and
now get updated reports and

57
00:03:23.800 --> 00:03:26.330
now you actually take a look
at one report that's kind of

58
00:03:26.330 --> 00:03:30.010
tweaked your eye a little bit, wondering
like what in the world has happened here.

59
00:03:30.010 --> 00:03:32.540
I don't remember this as
being part of the project.

60
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:35.540
And now you realize that a part of your
project team's working on something that's

61
00:03:35.540 --> 00:03:37.510
outside of the scope of your project.

62
00:03:37.510 --> 00:03:39.400
And you just didn't actually
take in the count for that.

63
00:03:39.400 --> 00:03:42.360
And that's a little bit of a sickening
feeling when you realize that all

64
00:03:42.360 --> 00:03:45.800
your resources right now we're
actually at a critical stage where

65
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:49.120
we need everybody working on the project,
not just part-time, but

66
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:50.670
everything that we need too.

67
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:56.320
And, of course, what requirements do we
have, as far as the usage of resources and

68
00:03:56.320 --> 00:03:58.460
all those other constraints
that we've talked about.

69
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:02.170
So those are kinda the basic
inputs that go into things

70
00:04:02.170 --> 00:04:05.240
when we have to consider
managing time in our project.

71
00:04:05.240 --> 00:04:07.380
If it's just about you scheduling
your day, it's no big deal.

72
00:04:07.380 --> 00:04:10.780
If you're like me you kind of open
up your Google calendar and go yeah,

73
00:04:10.780 --> 00:04:12.600
Daniel wants us to have
a meeting about this.

74
00:04:12.600 --> 00:04:14.900
And when do we like to have meetings,
during lunch.

75
00:04:14.900 --> 00:04:17.230
Cuz we get to eat and
talk at the same time.

76
00:04:17.230 --> 00:04:20.170
I know that that's when I would
schedule meetings, but overall though,

77
00:04:20.170 --> 00:04:21.690
that's something that's actually great.

78
00:04:21.690 --> 00:04:25.800
But when you start talking about managing
time and getting things scheduled for

79
00:04:25.800 --> 00:04:30.290
your project, though,
this takes a bit more consideration and

80
00:04:30.290 --> 00:04:32.570
a lot more elements need
to be considered here.

81
00:04:32.570 --> 00:04:36.200
And we go beyond the idea of
bringing a pen and a paper or

82
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:39.530
even just a calendar into the mix here.

83
00:04:39.530 --> 00:04:43.640
>> So Ronnie, we're talking more
of a formalization of the schedule

84
00:04:43.640 --> 00:04:47.650
to make sure that it is on lockdown
that we have try to account for

85
00:04:47.650 --> 00:04:52.390
every bit of the time that we're gonna
need for the project, put that in a, okay,

86
00:04:52.390 --> 00:04:56.490
from this date to this date we are gonna
be working on this part of the project,

87
00:04:56.490 --> 00:04:59.210
and then moving forward from there and
continue to account for

88
00:04:59.210 --> 00:05:00.440
those types of time.

89
00:05:00.440 --> 00:05:02.970
But that being said,
we're trying to formalize that.

90
00:05:02.970 --> 00:05:05.130
What is the best way to go about that?

91
00:05:05.130 --> 00:05:08.720
>> Well the best way to at least
get a general start to things

92
00:05:08.720 --> 00:05:12.430
especially when we start laying
things down for the progress.

93
00:05:12.430 --> 00:05:15.080
The over all things that we need to do so

94
00:05:15.080 --> 00:05:18.490
that we can have our project
be succesful at the end.

95
00:05:18.490 --> 00:05:21.140
Is to understand where do
we need to schedule to,

96
00:05:21.140 --> 00:05:24.050
in other words what's gonna be the length
and duration of our schedules and

97
00:05:24.050 --> 00:05:28.750
how do we know that we're actually marking
progress and in project management terms,

98
00:05:28.750 --> 00:05:32.620
what we do is we set up what we
call milestones along the way.

99
00:05:32.620 --> 00:05:37.500
And then we start trying, from those
milestones, to be able to put into,

100
00:05:37.500 --> 00:05:40.670
of course, the progress that
helps us to meet that milestone.

101
00:05:40.670 --> 00:05:45.840
So let's take, for an example,
let's just take a duration, right.

102
00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:48.670
Let's say that you know that you
have six months to complete whatever

103
00:05:48.670 --> 00:05:49.400
this project is.

104
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:52.380
I'm not even gonna make up something
that's gonna be fake cuz it's gonna sound

105
00:05:52.380 --> 00:05:53.055
fake if I do.

106
00:05:53.055 --> 00:05:56.240
[LAUGH] So let's say that you
have six months to finish.

107
00:05:56.240 --> 00:05:59.060
Well, if you know what your
project scope is, right,

108
00:05:59.060 --> 00:06:03.240
you know what the product is supposed
to be, then that means what you can do

109
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:06.670
is say, here's what the first
thing I know I need to accomplish.

110
00:06:06.670 --> 00:06:08.560
If I want this thing to
actually happen at the end.

111
00:06:08.560 --> 00:06:11.820
You might actually say, all right,
if I take six months of time,

112
00:06:11.820 --> 00:06:17.030
I know I'll have about six weeks, or
five weeks or so, in between this and

113
00:06:17.030 --> 00:06:21.410
the time that I actually finish here,
that I need to set up milestones.

114
00:06:21.410 --> 00:06:24.060
You might say that your first big
milestone is coming up with some type

115
00:06:24.060 --> 00:06:25.070
of prototype.

116
00:06:25.070 --> 00:06:26.730
So it might be six weeks from now.

117
00:06:26.730 --> 00:06:28.310
Then the second six weeks, you might say,

118
00:06:28.310 --> 00:06:32.360
I need to make sure that I'm not only
testing the prototype itself, but

119
00:06:32.360 --> 00:06:37.030
I'm actually starting to think
about testing, or beginning

120
00:06:37.030 --> 00:06:41.330
the software development of that,
since I have the prototype after that.

121
00:06:41.330 --> 00:06:45.680
And then that third milestone might
be testing both prototype and

122
00:06:45.680 --> 00:06:47.010
software together.

123
00:06:47.010 --> 00:06:51.090
And then, yes, you bring everything to
a close here or in the last six weeks.

124
00:06:51.090 --> 00:06:54.300
Try and make sure that you actually
wrap up any other things that you have.

125
00:06:54.300 --> 00:06:58.460
So when we talk about the idea
of milestones as far as project

126
00:06:58.460 --> 00:07:02.420
planning goes, you have to take in to
consideration then what you're planning.

127
00:07:02.420 --> 00:07:06.810
Milestones, essentially,
are markers inside of our entire schedule.

128
00:07:06.810 --> 00:07:08.980
Which we don't give any duration to.

129
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:12.790
In other words, it's just the idea
that we get to that point and

130
00:07:12.790 --> 00:07:15.950
now we actually are saying,
here is the milestone that we set so

131
00:07:15.950 --> 00:07:17.600
that we know that we're
actually going the right way.

132
00:07:17.600 --> 00:07:20.740
We're actually making progress
through our project here.

133
00:07:20.740 --> 00:07:24.140
So, normally when you start
talking about the basics here

134
00:07:24.140 --> 00:07:27.290
of just beginning to figure out
how to schedule It's not that

135
00:07:27.290 --> 00:07:30.880
you're trying to schedule every minute of
the day, but that becomes a micro manager.

136
00:07:30.880 --> 00:07:35.270
It's that you know that you have to
get to this point in so much time and

137

you didn't really have

the milestone itself doesn't

00:20:18.550 --> 00:20:22.420

00:20:22.420 --> 00:20:26.530

00:20:26.530 --> 00:20:30.210

00:20:49.540 --> 00:20:52.270
usually in that Gantt

00:21:37.980 --> 00:21:40.680
Now, for getting ready for, of course,

the CompTia project plus exam, you need

actually three generic types

I wanna make sure I told you them right.

You need to know about what is

00:21:54.060 --> 00:21:58.070
you also need to know about what is

00:21:58.070 --> 00:22:02.960
And then lastly what we call

00:22:02.960 --> 00:22:04.530
Now what is that dependency about?

00:22:04.530 --> 00:22:07.440
And then we'll go back and

When we start talking about the idea

okay, in the way that is

in what we see is that we're saying

one finishes.

Is that what we talk up task

00:23:47.880 --> 00:23:49.090
number one finishes.

Is that a mandatory dependency,

Well, this is how you tell the difference,

00:23:58.068 --> 00:24:01.178
A mandatory dependency is actually

In other words,

That the cookie dough has to kind of be

Well yeah, that actually sounds

00:24:25.170 --> 00:24:27.180

So what we're saying is if a process has

00:24:41.010 --> 00:24:42.560

Now this type of discretionary

00:29:53.960 --> 00:29:54.490

And

00:29:54.490 --> 00:29:58.490
when you start seeing things like this,

00:30:23.556 --> 00:30:25.250

And that way with this type of project

Maybe if you can, you might be able to

00:30:54.360 --> 00:30:59.490
