00:30:59.490 --> 00:31:04.280
But Daniel, there's a lot more to do
with what we call dependencies but

585
00:31:04.280 --> 00:31:07.900
you've let me talk a long time again,
which means I've exhausted my time.

586
00:31:07.900 --> 00:31:10.050
>> Yeah we've only got so
much time for show, and

587
00:31:10.050 --> 00:31:13.980
poor Ronnie he's got a whole lot more to
talk about as it comes to scheduling.

588
00:31:13.980 --> 00:31:15.790
So we're gonna have to
do a part two on this.

589
00:31:15.790 --> 00:31:16.450
I look forward to that.

590
00:31:16.450 --> 00:31:17.520
Hopefully you do as well.

591
00:31:17.520 --> 00:31:21.120
Ronnie, we look forward to see you in
that episode to finish this up and

592
00:31:21.120 --> 00:31:24.220
round out our knowledge, when it comes
to scheduling and project management.

593
00:31:24.220 --> 00:31:26.390
That being said, let's go ahead and
wrap up the show.

594
00:31:26.390 --> 00:31:29.770
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

595
00:31:29.770 --> 00:31:30.500
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

596
00:31:30.500 --> 00:31:32.638
>> And we'll see you next time.

597
00:31:32.638 --> 00:31:40.480
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish developing a project schedule, picking back up with task relationships. Then they show how to determine the critical path of a project schedule as well as how to establish schedule baselines.
episodes.title: Develop a Project Schedule Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.145 --> 00:00:14.176
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.240 --> 00:00:20.645
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we are continuing on with our

4
00:00:20.645 --> 00:00:25.160
Project+ series, actually moving into
another one of our famous part twos.

5
00:00:25.160 --> 00:00:28.570
Joining us back in the studio today to
help round that out is our good friend and

6
00:00:28.570 --> 00:00:30.310
mentor Mr Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:31.670
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

8
00:00:31.670 --> 00:00:32.230
>> Well thank you for

9
00:00:32.230 --> 00:00:36.310
having me back on the show as we continue
on taking a look at CompTIA's Project+.

10
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:39.740
Yes, another part two and you're probably
saying, man, they do that on purpose?

11
00:00:39.740 --> 00:00:43.890
Well sometimes we do but overall
though it's because one episode was so

12
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:47.280
jam packed with information on a lot of
great information that it did need to

13
00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:49.870
just overflow into another show or
I would continue to talk on.

14
00:00:49.870 --> 00:00:53.941
And that's never a great thing at times,
but now we're actually continuing on with

15
00:00:53.941 --> 00:00:57.053
that same episode where we'll
talk about project scheduling.

16
00:00:57.053 --> 00:01:02.518
And we were looking at the tool in one of
those PMISSD, I know it sounds strange,

17
00:01:02.518 --> 00:01:06.200
the Project Management Information System
things.

18
00:01:06.200 --> 00:01:09.590
And we were taking a look at
Microsoft Project to help us and

19
00:01:09.590 --> 00:01:11.080
to show you some of the utilities,

20
00:01:11.080 --> 00:01:15.750
at least one of the tools that you
might see used in project management.

21
00:01:15.750 --> 00:01:18.850
Now, when we were taking a look at
it from a previous episode here,

22
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:20.150
let's go ahead and
take a look at my screen,

23
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.630
that way we can kind of zoom in and
remind everyone briefly.

24
00:01:23.630 --> 00:01:26.540
As I pulled up this kind of
very generic project plan.

25
00:01:26.540 --> 00:01:30.950
And what we were talking about was
the idea of dependencies, right?

26
00:01:30.950 --> 00:01:33.740
That there are actually different
types of dependencies, like mandatory,

27
00:01:33.740 --> 00:01:37.680
discretionary, and even external
dependencies that we all have to take into

28
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:41.580
consideration when we start
creating these project plans.

29
00:01:41.580 --> 00:01:46.930
But once we have them in our project plan
then, we can actually go and line them up.

30
00:01:46.930 --> 00:01:50.530
The default way that Microsoft
works this is fairly simple.

31
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:53.100
We end up actually putting them
essentially one after the other.

32
00:01:53.100 --> 00:01:57.210
In other words, task number one
finishes before task number two begins.

33
00:01:57.210 --> 00:01:59.970
And then, of course, that means task
number two finishes before task number

34
00:01:59.970 --> 00:02:02.220
three begins, and that's a default.

35
00:02:02.220 --> 00:02:03.930
That's the way that it's done.

36
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:06.850
But they don't expect you
to leave it that way, okay?

37
00:02:06.850 --> 00:02:11.080
So a lot of times what you end up
realizing inside of a project plan,

38
00:02:11.080 --> 00:02:14.060
is that you'll take a look
at two different tasks.

39
00:02:14.060 --> 00:02:16.960
One that happens after the other, or
if you wanna do it the project manage way,

40
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:20.350
one that happens before the other
You kinda get the picture.

41
00:02:20.350 --> 00:02:24.040
It's six one way, half a dozen the other.

42
00:02:24.040 --> 00:02:26.650
And that's just one of those things
where you just have to get used to

43
00:02:26.650 --> 00:02:27.780
the terminology.

44
00:02:27.780 --> 00:02:31.400
But what you might end up finding
out is that even though one task

45
00:02:31.400 --> 00:02:36.370
can finish before the other one begins,
you can also find out that maybe I can

46
00:02:36.370 --> 00:02:39.890
start essentially both
tasks at the same time.

47
00:02:39.890 --> 00:02:43.440
Or both tasks can complete
at the same time,

48
00:02:43.440 --> 00:02:47.790
thereby shortening the duration
of the overall project schedule.

49
00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:51.670
Now we want to talk about that factor now,
so that we can take a look here.

50
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:54.440
So let's take a look here, here's
the default that I was talking about.

51
00:02:54.440 --> 00:02:56.960
If you take a look at this project plan.

52
00:02:56.960 --> 00:02:59.620
You can see where task number
one essentially goes ahead and

53
00:02:59.620 --> 00:03:03.820
completes, then task number two begins,
task number two completes and

54
00:03:03.820 --> 00:03:05.880
then task number three begins.

55
00:03:05.880 --> 00:03:10.200
And it continues to go on and on and on,
and right here at the last one there's no

56
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:13.480
linking to that task and
that's why we don't see that.

57
00:03:13.480 --> 00:03:14.970
Now, when we take a look at that,

58
00:03:14.970 --> 00:03:20.260
cuz that's actually to be announced
here If I select both of those tasks.

59
00:03:20.260 --> 00:03:22.150
Task seven and eight.

60
00:03:22.150 --> 00:03:22.830
I can then.

61
00:03:22.830 --> 00:03:24.570
Let me see if I can do this.

62
00:03:24.570 --> 00:03:29.910
I can actually right click and
then I can link them together.

63
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:31.830
If I can actually see it here.

64
00:03:31.830 --> 00:03:32.630
At some point.

65
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:33.400
>> Put your cheaters on.

66
00:03:33.400 --> 00:03:34.390
>> Let me see here.

67
00:03:34.390 --> 00:03:37.550
Yeah, let me see if I can
actually link that up.

68
00:03:37.550 --> 00:03:40.100
Here, in the correct way.

69
00:03:41.730 --> 00:03:45.840
So I can actually come down here and say
to task number twelve, and there we go.

70
00:03:45.840 --> 00:03:47.580
Now I've actually linked
those two together.

71
00:03:47.580 --> 00:03:50.180
Actually it looks like
i did the wrong one.

72
00:03:50.180 --> 00:03:50.990
That's what I need to do.

73
00:03:50.990 --> 00:03:55.520
See I even had the wrong one there, so
that actually links to task number eleven.

74
00:03:55.520 --> 00:03:56.100
Is what needs it.

75
00:03:56.100 --> 00:03:56.870
There we go.

76
00:03:56.870 --> 00:03:58.630
So notice how that particular task,

77
00:03:58.630 --> 00:04:02.110
if I can actually pull in a little bit,
you can now see where that pushed it out

78
00:04:02.110 --> 00:04:07.580
to the very end once again extending out
the overall duration of that project.

79
00:04:07.580 --> 00:04:10.060
So we can go ahead and
link those together and

80
00:04:10.060 --> 00:04:12.890
now Microsoft Project knows
how to deal with them,

81
00:04:12.890 --> 00:04:17.450
but what you have to worry about though is
the very fact that manually, you need to

82
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:21.450
understand how that works and what
happens there, so let me show you here.

83
00:04:21.450 --> 00:04:25.100
So let's say that what we have here
is a representation of the task

84
00:04:25.100 --> 00:04:28.370
on my Gantt chart and
the ways that we can link them together.

85
00:04:28.370 --> 00:04:31.920
Now this is you logically having to deal
with the different tasks that are actually

86
00:04:31.920 --> 00:04:33.860
in front of you, or work packages,

87
00:04:33.860 --> 00:04:36.900
whatever you want to call them and
so here is the standard ways.

88
00:04:36.900 --> 00:04:40.770
And there's actually four ways that you
might see that you might do this, okay.

89
00:04:40.770 --> 00:04:44.980
The default is this finish to start, and
the way that you can tell this inside of

90
00:04:44.980 --> 00:04:49.000
the Gantt chart is that over here on the
left hand side this represents the start

91
00:04:49.000 --> 00:04:53.120
of a task, over on the right hand
side it represents the finish or

92
00:04:53.120 --> 00:04:55.430
the completion of a task as well.

93
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:58.800
And this is the only one in which,
when you take a look at it,

94
00:04:58.800 --> 00:05:02.680
it actually finishes and then it links and
a lot of the time it links right here to

95
00:05:02.680 --> 00:05:04.820
the top of the task for
one reason or another.

96
00:05:04.820 --> 00:05:08.730
But inside of Microsoft Project,
you actually see this one right here,

97
00:05:08.730 --> 00:05:09.760
it's really tiny.

98
00:05:09.760 --> 00:05:11.870
I'll see if I can zoom in for us here.

99
00:05:11.870 --> 00:05:14.760
You can see even right there
where it actually does do it

100
00:05:14.760 --> 00:05:18.600
right at the very beginning, but notice
it links it really to the very top there.

101
00:05:18.600 --> 00:05:22.190
So you will see things like
that where you'll see that.

102
00:05:22.190 --> 00:05:24.780
And that's actually a visual
representation that lets you know that

103
00:05:24.780 --> 00:05:27.360
those two,
at least from the way that we have it,

104
00:05:27.360 --> 00:05:32.960
we're saying that task number one has to
finish before task number two begins.

105
00:05:32.960 --> 00:05:34.070
But remember what I said.

106
00:05:34.070 --> 00:05:37.780
You might end up finding out that
you have two tasks that are actually

107
00:05:37.780 --> 00:05:41.230
done sequentially this way
according to Microsoft Project but

108
00:05:41.230 --> 00:05:45.350
you realize then that they can
actually start at the time.

109
00:05:45.350 --> 00:05:48.270
So let's go back and
take our example of something like

110
00:05:48.270 --> 00:05:51.900
a finishing of the building of a house,
right.

111
00:05:51.900 --> 00:05:55.070
So let's say that we complete
the actual structure of the house and

112
00:05:55.070 --> 00:05:59.470
everything's ready to go, but there's
also landscaping that we want to do.

113
00:05:59.470 --> 00:06:04.440
And so what we might see in a regular
task in a project plan is that

114
00:06:04.440 --> 00:06:09.310
we finish the actual house and it's ready
to go, and then we start the landscaping.

115
00:06:09.310 --> 00:06:10.240
But in our reality,

116
00:06:10.240 --> 00:06:14.860
Daniel, if we think about it, couldn't
we possibly do one of two things here?

117
00:06:14.860 --> 00:06:18.030
Couldn't we actually say that
what we wanna do is that

118
00:06:18.030 --> 00:06:21.800
on the last week of that house finishing
up, before we turn over the key and

119
00:06:21.800 --> 00:06:24.330
everything else,
that we start landscaping.

120
00:06:24.330 --> 00:06:28.950
We could start them both at the same time
if we actually wanted to and say this.

121
00:06:28.950 --> 00:06:32.990
Even more logical would be say
the day that we turn over the key

122
00:06:32.990 --> 00:06:34.630
It's a day that we also finish.

123
00:06:34.630 --> 00:06:36.570
In other words, when we finish
building and constructing the house,

124
00:06:36.570 --> 00:06:40.650
turn the key over, is also the day
the landscaping finishes instead.

125
00:06:40.650 --> 00:06:44.830
So let's take a look at my diagram again.

126
00:06:44.830 --> 00:06:48.110
So either one of those is
actually two great possibilities.

127
00:06:48.110 --> 00:06:52.500
If I wanted to say that we finish, and
let's say, just painting the garage, or

128
00:06:52.500 --> 00:06:56.400
we start painting the garage on the same
day that we start the landscaping.

129
00:06:56.400 --> 00:06:57.430
We could do something like that.

130
00:06:57.430 --> 00:06:58.810
Makes it very easy.

131
00:06:58.810 --> 00:07:02.470
All you do is you actually go into Project
and you can actually change that link, but

132
00:07:02.470 --> 00:07:04.340
you have to understand
what it is you're doing.

133
00:07:04.340 --> 00:07:06.130
And that's why we're
showing it to you here.

134
00:07:06.130 --> 00:07:07.560
So this is the graphic
way you would do it.

135
00:07:07.560 --> 00:07:11.680
You would just simply draw an arrow
on the start and start side.

136
00:07:11.680 --> 00:07:15.000
If you wanna do what I talked about
earlier here where you're saying

137
00:07:15.000 --> 00:07:17.870
When we finish painting
the interior of the house,

138
00:07:17.870 --> 00:07:21.480
we wanna make sure that the landscaping
finishes at the same time.

139
00:07:21.480 --> 00:07:25.400
Notice that we're coming from the finish
side and we're linking those two together.

140
00:07:25.400 --> 00:07:27.700
Those two elements belong together.

141
00:07:27.700 --> 00:07:30.240
And so when you do that, instead of
actually having them stack end to end,

142
00:07:30.240 --> 00:07:33.000
which is what we see in
the finish to start,

143
00:07:33.000 --> 00:07:35.250
we now essentially shortened the duration.

144
00:07:35.250 --> 00:07:38.722
So you might find out that that
last bit of painting, let's say for

145
00:07:38.722 --> 00:07:43.256
example takes two days, but the landscape
is going to take, let's say, three days.

146
00:07:43.256 --> 00:07:48.741
So you might see something that is a
little bit funny as far as the bars go and

147
00:07:48.741 --> 00:07:52.653
representing the duration,
so you might see that.

148
00:07:52.653 --> 00:07:56.163
Now, the weirdest thing and,
at least to me,

149
00:07:56.163 --> 00:07:59.225
the most ironic thing, as one of these.

150
00:07:59.225 --> 00:08:02.995
You normally do not see
a dependency like this,

151
00:08:02.995 --> 00:08:06.360
in which you talk about a start to finish.

152
00:08:06.360 --> 00:08:08.640
Now I actually did this
a little bit backward here.

153
00:08:08.640 --> 00:08:10.500
So this was supposed to
link the start side.

154
00:08:10.500 --> 00:08:13.080
See, I did the arrows
backward is what I did.

155
00:08:13.080 --> 00:08:15.550
>> It's so counter-intuitive for you.

156
00:08:15.550 --> 00:08:17.570
>> It did not, yeah, it really is.

157
00:08:17.570 --> 00:08:21.060
So, let me see if I can relink
this the way that it needs to be.

158
00:08:21.060 --> 00:08:21.632
Which is here.

159
00:08:24.665 --> 00:08:26.560
Yeah, this is really fun.

160
00:08:26.560 --> 00:08:28.900
Let me see.
Let me try to regrab this.

161
00:08:28.900 --> 00:08:29.930
This is gonna be great fun.

162
00:08:31.560 --> 00:08:34.350
Look at that,
that actually keeps creating more.

163
00:08:34.350 --> 00:08:37.500
There we go, that's starting to get there.

164
00:08:37.500 --> 00:08:38.660
It takes a little bit more time.

165
00:08:41.024 --> 00:08:44.280
Man it's like-
>> It's just hideous.

166
00:08:44.280 --> 00:08:45.600
>> Yeah, I think that's actually bad.

167
00:08:45.600 --> 00:08:47.724
>> I think this train's
derailed there [LAUGH].

168
00:08:47.724 --> 00:08:50.550
>> It is, but it looks like I'm
finally gonna grab the last one.

169
00:08:50.550 --> 00:08:51.960
There we go, that is terrible.

170
00:08:51.960 --> 00:08:53.540
>> It ain't pretty but
it got the job done.

171
00:08:53.540 --> 00:08:55.880
>> It ain't pretty but there we go.

172
00:08:55.880 --> 00:08:59.440
So, you actually see where
now the start of one task,

173
00:08:59.440 --> 00:09:05.160
which is normally the predecessor, means
that the second task ended up finishing.

174
00:09:05.160 --> 00:09:08.110
Now you normally don't see
very much of this type.

175
00:09:08.110 --> 00:09:09.160
I'll tell you the truth,

176
00:09:09.160 --> 00:09:12.500
I don't think I've ever seen it in
an actual project plan before but

177
00:09:12.500 --> 00:09:16.850
it does give you that ability to say
that the start of the predecessor

178
00:09:17.850 --> 00:09:23.210
indicates that the dependent
task has actually finished.

179
00:09:23.210 --> 00:09:26.249
So go figure, you might actually
end up seeing something like that.

180
00:09:26.249 --> 00:09:30.070
I can't even tell you of
a great example of this.

181
00:09:30.070 --> 00:09:31.560
And you can go out and look for examples,

182
00:09:31.560 --> 00:09:36.820
but none of the examples that you normally
see even make any type of remote sense.

183
00:09:36.820 --> 00:09:38.470
So what you tend to deal
with a lot of times,

184
00:09:38.470 --> 00:09:40.520
I'm gonna say in all reality, right?

185
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:43.900
Finish to Start, Start to Start,
Finish to Finish.

186
00:09:43.900 --> 00:09:47.110
So when you do see this on a Gantt chart,
whether it's written out or whether you're

187
00:09:47.110 --> 00:09:51.700
seeing it inside of something like
Microsoft Project, Projectlibre, anything

188
00:09:51.700 --> 00:09:55.380
else, Primavera, whatever you might see
it in, what you're having to actually

189
00:09:55.380 --> 00:09:59.240
deal with is understanding how they are
actually linking these things together.

190
00:09:59.240 --> 00:10:02.410
The overall goal of changing
these dependencies is

191
00:10:02.410 --> 00:10:07.740
essentially to shorten the overall
duration of the project itself.

192
00:10:07.740 --> 00:10:10.350
And that's why we might choose
to do something like this.

193
00:10:10.350 --> 00:10:13.120
And to make sure that we
logically can actually

194
00:10:13.120 --> 00:10:16.750
see how things are actually
designed to be scheduled together.

195
00:10:16.750 --> 00:10:21.480
So now if you change it from a Finish
to Start, add to a Start to Start,

196
00:10:21.480 --> 00:10:24.450
you're realizing that means you
have to go and call the landscaper.

197
00:10:24.450 --> 00:10:27.790
And go whoa, wait a minute,
I know I had you starting on the 13th but

198
00:10:27.790 --> 00:10:30.840
it looks like you need to start on 9th and
see if they can do so.

199
00:10:30.840 --> 00:10:32.900
And you might even change
it if they say no.

200
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:33.630
So in other words,

201
00:10:33.630 --> 00:10:38.770
you might have realized you can't change
it because it's on scheduling and that's

202
00:10:38.770 --> 00:10:43.270
when we start going to outside types of
dependencies that we have to worry about.

203
00:10:43.270 --> 00:10:46.890
Or is this a discretionary dependency or
is it a mandatory, that's when you have to

204
00:10:46.890 --> 00:10:50.120
start trying to realize what is
actually gonna end up happening.

205
00:10:50.120 --> 00:10:54.570
So understanding at least the layout here,
besides this last one, in which I terribly

206
00:10:54.570 --> 00:10:59.420
mangled here like crazy, and I'm gonna
mangle it even more by doing this.

207
00:10:59.420 --> 00:11:04.270
But you can see that this is something
that you don't really want to

208
00:11:04.270 --> 00:11:07.710
ever see happen but
you do see it every once in awhile.

209
00:11:07.710 --> 00:11:10.180
But not in anything that
we would normally do.

210

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to choose the appropriate methods for estimating duration before completion. In other words, figure out how long the project will last before it's done. They go over the common tools and methods used to that end, tools like Expert Judgement, Parametric Estimate, Three-point Estimate, PERT formulas and Gantt charts.
episodes.title: Pick a Project Tool

Yes, okay.

00:28:23.260 --> 00:28:27.200
But I don't know why you would if
you have the chance to use software.

515
00:28:27.200 --> 00:28:31.910
Because by doing it by hand right, once
it's actually done, you make a mistake and

516
00:28:31.910 --> 00:28:36.170
a lot of eraser marks are ultimately
gonna drive you nuts at the end.

517
00:28:36.170 --> 00:28:37.690
So let me show you an example again,

518
00:28:37.690 --> 00:28:43.330
we've already taken a look at the same
one in a previous episode here.

519
00:28:43.330 --> 00:28:46.180
Let me see if I can zoom out
just a little here, there we go.

520
00:28:46.180 --> 00:28:50.530
The Gantt chart is actually one that gives
us details over here on the left side.

521
00:28:50.530 --> 00:28:54.900
As far as the actual model goes,
tells task duration, start and

522
00:28:54.900 --> 00:28:59.610
finishes, and then over on the right-hand
side a graphic model as well.

523
00:28:59.610 --> 00:29:01.480
Now the reason why this
is important is because,

524
00:29:01.480 --> 00:29:03.670
it actually includes in all the elements,
right.

525
00:29:03.670 --> 00:29:05.140
We get a calendar.

526
00:29:05.140 --> 00:29:08.160
We can even go ahead and
assign resources to it.

527
00:29:08.160 --> 00:29:10.740
We can even assign cost values to it.

528
00:29:10.740 --> 00:29:11.760
And using the software,

529
00:29:11.760 --> 00:29:14.620
it actually determines all
that stuff in the background.

530
00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:18.190
And then allows us to see
the whole thing graphically too.

531
00:29:18.190 --> 00:29:21.590
So today, if there's a method that
you're more than likely gonna choose,

532
00:29:21.590 --> 00:29:24.120
it's probably gonna be one of
these information systems.

533
00:29:24.120 --> 00:29:29.455
Now, this is actually done, if you need
to see it essentially graphically, all

534
00:29:29.455 --> 00:29:35.035
the other ones, if it's not a guess, it's
an estimate or based on some type of map.

535
00:29:35.035 --> 00:29:39.508
So depending on the result that you need,
you can choose any of these techniques

536
00:29:39.508 --> 00:29:43.980
that you need to give you what you're
actually taking a look at as well.

537
00:29:43.980 --> 00:29:47.570
So, just kinda realize that yeah,
picking the appropriate tool is

538
00:29:47.570 --> 00:29:50.770
something that's actually a part
of what a project manager does.

539
00:29:50.770 --> 00:29:55.210
And a lot of times today because you do
have a big team behind you a lot of times,

540
00:29:55.210 --> 00:29:56.010
you don't really have to do it.

541
00:29:56.010 --> 00:29:57.670
You can just say, here's what I need.

542
00:29:57.670 --> 00:29:58.693
And that person goes,

543
00:29:58.693 --> 00:30:01.400
I know what tool that I'm gonna
use here to figure this out.

544
00:30:01.400 --> 00:30:05.170
But more than likely, if you have some
type of information system like this,

545
00:30:05.170 --> 00:30:08.076
you plug in your numbers and
that's what happens, right?

546
00:30:08.076 --> 00:30:10.232
Somebody actually just goes ahead and
plugs in the numbers for

547
00:30:10.232 --> 00:30:12.950
the duration here on the left-hand
side of the third column.

548
00:30:12.950 --> 00:30:14.130
And then they just tell you.

549
00:30:14.130 --> 00:30:16.990
And your the project manager, you go,
I really need that take four days?

550
00:30:16.990 --> 00:30:18.990
Well, he just changed
that number to four days.

551
00:30:18.990 --> 00:30:22.840
And then you can actually see what
that does to the rest of your project.

552
00:30:22.840 --> 00:30:26.300
That's why this one is probably the most
comprehensive tool that we have and

553
00:30:26.300 --> 00:30:29.400
is not just an approximation,
not just an estimate.

554
00:30:29.400 --> 00:30:32.450
This is actually one that really you
can see and you can manipulate and

555
00:30:32.450 --> 00:30:33.680
see the rest of it.

556
00:30:33.680 --> 00:30:36.750
And that's why this tool is so
valuable and so amazing.

557
00:30:36.750 --> 00:30:41.350
>> Yeah, you can see why it is definitely
the preferred method of choice for

558
00:30:41.350 --> 00:30:43.490
probably most of your projects and

559
00:30:43.490 --> 00:30:46.880
your project managers out there too
to try to keep track of things and

560
00:30:46.880 --> 00:30:52.120
see what's going to take how long or other
durations as we're looking at them today.

561
00:30:52.120 --> 00:30:54.120
Ronnie, any other methods
that we need to go over?

562
00:30:54.120 --> 00:30:57.700
>> Well, there's at least several
other methods that we need to go over.

563
00:30:57.700 --> 00:30:59.910
But Daniel,
it looks like you let me talk too long,

564
00:30:59.910 --> 00:31:03.390
and that means we've got to take
this over into another episode.

565
00:31:03.390 --> 00:31:06.380
>> Well, hey, if we have to,
that's what we gotta do.

566
00:31:06.380 --> 00:31:08.720
The clock has ticked its last tock, so

567
00:31:08.720 --> 00:31:13.193
look forward to seeing you in the part
two of our little mini series here.

568
00:31:13.193 --> 00:31:14.360
Hopefully we'll see you there as well.

569
00:31:14.360 --> 00:31:16.290
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

570
00:31:16.290 --> 00:31:18.060
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

571
00:31:18.060 --> 00:31:18.740
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

572
00:31:18.740 --> 00:31:20.775
>> And we'll see you next time.

573
00:31:20.775 --> 00:31:27.788
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish exploring methods of calculating duration estimates. They round out the show with methods like Critical Path Method (CPM), Crashing, and Fast Tracking.
episodes.title: Pick a Project Tool Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.203 --> 00:00:17.031
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.031 --> 00:00:19.646
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and today's episode,

4
00:00:19.646 --> 00:00:21.882
we are continuing on
with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:21.882 --> 00:00:23.371
We're going to our Part two.

6
00:00:23.371 --> 00:00:27.260
I am picking a project tool for
estimating your duration activity.

7
00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:31.660
Joining us back to help ground that out
that little topic is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:31.660 --> 00:00:33.050
Ronnie, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:33.750
>> Thank you for having me.

10
00:00:33.750 --> 00:00:36.730
As we need to continue to take
a look at picking a project tool,

11
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:40.330
remember that we're in the middle of
our CompTIA Project+ series here,

12
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:43.997
and what we're doing is we're planning
for, of course, activity duration.

13
00:00:43.997 --> 00:00:46.130
We're trying to come up with estimates so

14
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:50.020
that we can take whatever we have,
as far as an activity goes, and

15
00:00:50.020 --> 00:00:53.590
say how long we believe it's gonna
take for us to accomplish that.

16
00:00:53.590 --> 00:00:56.960
Now, in a previous episode, we've already
taken a look at seven different methods.

17
00:00:56.960 --> 00:00:59.950
We've talked about
three-point estimations.

18
00:00:59.950 --> 00:01:03.930
We've also talked about parametric
estimations, expert judgments,

19
00:01:03.930 --> 00:01:07.840
as well as the idea here of just top-down.

20
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:12.840
We even took a look briefly at using
the PERT analysis to help us out

21
00:01:12.840 --> 00:01:16.110
to be able to give us
an expected value instead, and

22
00:01:16.110 --> 00:01:19.080
all of that actually works
the way that we want them to.

23
00:01:19.080 --> 00:01:21.340
But there's sometimes what
you also end up with,

24
00:01:21.340 --> 00:01:25.370
though, is that you need to
actually have a better estimate for

25
00:01:25.370 --> 00:01:31.010
the entire project plan, and
that's what you really also need as well.

26
00:01:31.010 --> 00:01:34.000
And one of the methods that
we can actually use here

27
00:01:34.000 --> 00:01:35.736
is the critical path method.

28
00:01:35.736 --> 00:01:39.970
Now, we've already taken a look
at one example of it, but

29
00:01:39.970 --> 00:01:44.190
we wanna take you through another
example to make sure that this does

30
00:01:44.190 --> 00:01:48.560
get down into your mind where it needs
to be, and you understand how to do

31
00:01:48.560 --> 00:01:52.790
the actual critical path method given
the data that you have in front of you.

32
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:55.560
It's important, especially if
you're preparing as a candidate for

33
00:01:55.560 --> 00:01:57.810
the Project+ Exam that you know and

34
00:01:57.810 --> 00:02:01.570
understand a forward pass as
well as a backward pass and

35
00:02:01.570 --> 00:02:06.440
how to determine the float that's actually
in your project, and not only off of one

36
00:02:06.440 --> 00:02:11.660
very simple diagram critical path
method like what we showed you before,

37
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.640
but now, actually, taking in a couple
of different instances in place, too.

38
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:17.920
I'm gonna show you another
one that we need, and

39
00:02:17.920 --> 00:02:21.080
that's what we're actually
gonna start off with right now.

40
00:02:21.080 --> 00:02:24.780
So when we start talking about using
the critical path, let's go ahead and

41
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:27.170
take a look at my diagram here.

42
00:02:27.170 --> 00:02:31.660
As we start off, remember that what we're
taking away at the entire rectangle that

43
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:36.600
you see over here on the left-hand side
represents a task or an activity, okay?

44
00:02:36.600 --> 00:02:41.890
So depending on who you talk to, remember
that those terms, they're interchangeable.

45
00:02:41.890 --> 00:02:45.200
So if you hear the term task,
you hear the term work package,

46
00:02:45.200 --> 00:02:49.340
you hear the term activity, they're
all gonna mean about the same thing.

47
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:53.590
And because we're talking about trying
to figure out the duration of tasks

48
00:02:53.590 --> 00:02:55.810
as well as the entire project,

49
00:02:55.810 --> 00:03:00.390
what you normally have are some different
elements involved in every task.

50
00:03:00.390 --> 00:03:03.700
You have ES over here,
which stands for Early Start.

51
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:08.850
What is the earliest this task can
start according to our project plan?

52
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:13.490
And then that means you also can
determine the early finish as well.

53
00:03:14.490 --> 00:03:18.400
Now, once you actually determine the early
starts and the early finishes for

54
00:03:18.400 --> 00:03:24.190
everything in your project plan,
that normally will give you the duration

55
00:03:24.190 --> 00:03:29.050
of the entire project that you have and
a couple of other things, too.

56
00:03:29.050 --> 00:03:32.140
But at least that's what
it normally gives you.

57
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:34.140
Now, the other thing
that you may determine,

58
00:03:34.140 --> 00:03:37.650
though, is there's a range
of numbers here, right?

59
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:41.990
And what we wanna determine at this
point as well is what we call the latest

60
00:03:41.990 --> 00:03:46.580
possible start and the latest possible
finish that we can have to that task as

61
00:03:46.580 --> 00:03:51.160
well to still keep us on track for
finishing our project, okay?

62
00:03:51.160 --> 00:03:51.890
And we'll do that.

63
00:03:51.890 --> 00:03:55.400
We'll actually do that in what
we call a backward pass, too.

64
00:03:55.400 --> 00:03:59.380
Now, a lot of times when you see it, it's
actually using this or something fairly

65
00:03:59.380 --> 00:04:03.170
similar to this, but it doesn't mean
that you'll see these boxes drawn out.

66
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:06.620
Most of the time, project manager
will simply write in the area, and

67
00:04:06.620 --> 00:04:08.260
that's pretty much the key.

68
00:04:08.260 --> 00:04:11.360
But if it's in the upper left-hand corner,
it's gonna be the early start.

69
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:13.302
Upper right-hand corner, the early finish.

70
00:04:13.302 --> 00:04:18.850
Lower left-hand corner, the late start,
and then the late finish.

71
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:23.910
In between the late start and
the late finish, you'll also

72
00:04:23.910 --> 00:04:26.990
see that there are probably gonna be
a number that's gonna be floating.

73
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:28.340
Sometimes you'll see it written down here.

74
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:32.360
Sometimes you'll actually see it kinda
written a little bit higher as well

75
00:04:32.360 --> 00:04:34.490
is the duration of that task.

76
00:04:34.490 --> 00:04:38.540
What is the expected duration, or
what is your estimate for that duration?

77
00:04:38.540 --> 00:04:39.930
And of course, the name.

78
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:43.140
Now, the name can be written
right here in the middle, okay?

79
00:04:43.140 --> 00:04:47.400
Sometimes you actually see it written on
top of each of these boxes as well, and

80
00:04:47.400 --> 00:04:50.780
then normally at the bottom,
you actually write what we call float.

81
00:04:50.780 --> 00:04:55.090
Float, for us, is actually also another
element that we're trying to determine,

82
00:04:55.090 --> 00:04:58.620
and that is essentially what we
call the free time that we have for

83
00:04:58.620 --> 00:05:04.790
that task to adjust either
early start to late start.

84
00:05:04.790 --> 00:05:08.680
You have that ability to actually adjust
that task to begin a little bit earlier,

85
00:05:08.680 --> 00:05:11.270
or to begin a little bit later,
or to finish earlier, or

86
00:05:11.270 --> 00:05:13.000
to finish later as well.

87
00:05:13.000 --> 00:05:15.110
So understanding those elements, right?

88
00:05:15.110 --> 00:05:18.340
We've already done one of these, but it's
something that we will end up determining

89
00:05:18.340 --> 00:05:23.050
again, because it's an essential part of
what a project manager will need to do for

90
00:05:23.050 --> 00:05:26.350
their project, and
they'll have to do this again if task and

91
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:30.162
if time changes for their project, too.

92
00:05:30.162 --> 00:05:33.930
So here's that basic
breakdown when you see this.

93
00:05:34.970 --> 00:05:38.740
So let's go ahead and
show you the critical path method here.

94
00:05:38.740 --> 00:05:40.710
It is what we want to begin with.

95
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:46.860
And you'll see that this particular
project begins at activity A,

96
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:50.750
and there's three possible
paths through this project.

97
00:05:50.750 --> 00:05:52.970
I was about to say two.

98
00:05:52.970 --> 00:06:00.593
But notice that I have the ability to
go from A to E to F to G to H to I,

99
00:06:00.593 --> 00:06:06.238
or I have the ability to go
from A to B to C to D to I,

100
00:06:06.238 --> 00:06:11.037
or I have the ability
to go from A to B to C,

101
00:06:11.037 --> 00:06:15.310
possibly up to G, H, and then to I.

102
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:19.240
Now, you may be wondering, why in the
world would something like this happen?

103
00:06:19.240 --> 00:06:23.980
Well, sometimes it does happen like that
where you end up realizing that hey,

104
00:06:23.980 --> 00:06:27.710
there's another possible way that we can
actually determine what we call that

105
00:06:27.710 --> 00:06:31.370
critical path, and that is the longest
uninterrupted path through

106
00:06:31.370 --> 00:06:35.440
my entire project,
one that doesn't have any float in it.

107
00:06:35.440 --> 00:06:38.320
And if there's no adjustment for
the float of whether I can actually

108
00:06:38.320 --> 00:06:43.180
adjust the start time or
the finish time to the particular task,

109
00:06:43.180 --> 00:06:47.330
that means that that particular task,
if somebody actually moves it along that

110
00:06:47.330 --> 00:06:52.990
path, it will overall affect
the end date of my project.

111
00:06:52.990 --> 00:06:56.710
And most of the time, it affects the end
date towards the adverse condition,

112
00:06:56.710 --> 00:07:00.370
not generally for my favor, so that's
why we're normally looking for that.

113
00:07:00.370 --> 00:07:04.710
So anytime along that we find there's a
critical path here, what we're looking for

114
00:07:04.710 --> 00:07:08.790
is that path that we know that if we
adjust anything along this path, and

115
00:07:08.790 --> 00:07:11.750
it affects the overall finish date, well,

116
00:07:11.750 --> 00:07:13.890
anything in there is
actually gonna do that.

117
00:07:13.890 --> 00:07:15.940
So that's what we need to determine.

118
00:07:15.940 --> 00:07:19.630
So let's make sure that we
understand how we begin, okay?

119
00:07:19.630 --> 00:07:22.060
So over here on task A, again.

120
00:07:23.350 --> 00:07:27.270
Notice that this duration
happens with a one day duration.

121
00:07:27.270 --> 00:07:29.330
And we'll just take it as one day.

122
00:07:29.330 --> 00:07:35.030
And so when I start that task,
my earliest start is on day one, okay?

123
00:07:35.030 --> 00:07:36.610
So we don't count day zero here.

124
00:07:36.610 --> 00:07:38.448
We'll start with day one.

125
00:07:38.448 --> 00:07:43.849
And if I have where that task starts
on day one and finishes on day one,

126
00:07:43.849 --> 00:07:49.548
well, that means my earliest finish
will be at the end of day one, okay?

127
00:07:49.548 --> 00:07:51.850
So now,
I'm beginning what we call the four pass.

128
00:07:51.850 --> 00:07:55.773
We're gonna take the top path and
then we'll do the bottom as well.

129
00:07:55.773 --> 00:07:59.486
Now, we can only do it partially and
then we'll have to kind of switch off and

130
00:07:59.486 --> 00:08:01.239
do something else here in a moment.

131
00:08:01.239 --> 00:08:03.619
So we'll take the top path.

132
00:08:03.619 --> 00:08:08.581
If the earliest finish that I
can have is day one, on task A,

133
00:08:08.581 --> 00:08:13.545
that means on task E,
the earliest start that I have is gonna

134
00:08:13.545 --> 00:08:18.530
be not at the end of day one,
but at the beginning of day two.

135
00:08:19.960 --> 00:08:27.680
So if day two is where I begin task E and
I have a one day duration on that task.

136
00:08:27.680 --> 00:08:32.660
That will mean that I will also finish
on day two of that task as well.

137
00:08:34.020 --> 00:08:35.990
Then for task F that

138
00:08:37.200 --> 00:08:41.100
means that the earliest start that I will
have is at the beginning of day three,

139
00:08:41.100 --> 00:08:45.940
right, because I ended on day two and
this now means day three.

140
00:08:45.940 --> 00:08:49.213
Here is another task that
lasts the entire day.

141
00:08:49.213 --> 00:08:51.740
So the earliest day that I
will finish here is three.

142
00:08:52.740 --> 00:08:57.720
Now I cannot determine this next one yet,
because there are actually two

143
00:08:57.720 --> 00:09:01.660
predecessors to task G
that I need to determine.

144
00:09:01.660 --> 00:09:07.520
So then I come back here to Task A, and
we do the same thing on this bottom path.

145
00:09:07.520 --> 00:09:12.710
So now at this particular point,
this means that the earliest

146
00:09:12.710 --> 00:09:17.300
finish here is day one and so
on task number two, my earliest start

147
00:09:17.300 --> 00:09:22.780
is day two and this is now a two
day task according to what we see.

148
00:09:22.780 --> 00:09:28.440
So we count all of day two, and we count
day three as being a two-day task.

149
00:09:28.440 --> 00:09:31.890
So the earliest finish here is day three,
right?

150
00:09:31.890 --> 00:09:33.570
Day two and day three.

151
00:09:33.570 --> 00:09:39.070
So that means for task C,
the earliest start that I will have here

152
00:09:39.070 --> 00:09:44.080
is going to be the beginning of
day four and here is today, so

153
00:09:44.080 --> 00:09:50.130
I count day four and day five, so
that my earliest finish here is day five.

154
00:09:50.130 --> 00:09:54.830
So now, this is where we actually
have a little bit of a conundrum.

155
00:09:54.830 --> 00:10:00.730
Notice that both of these will
affect when task G begins, okay.

156
00:10:00.730 --> 00:10:06.410
If I actually assume that this is day
four, for task G as early as start,

157
00:10:06.410 --> 00:10:11.690
well I discount that task C is
actually gonna be a predecessor.

158
00:10:12.740 --> 00:10:18.410
So I cannot actually use day four

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and practice of logical diagramming your projects. They take you through various diagramming methods like Precedence Diagramming Method(PDM), Arrow Diagramming Method(ADM), Conditional Diagramming Method(CDM), and Critical Chain Method(CCM). They also look at using Graphical Evaluation and Review Technique, or GERT, to account for looping activities.
episodes.title: Setup Logical Diagramming

the conditional diagramming method, might

Well, the very fact is you have

You can complete the entire

00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:41.260

It really did take the last 15% of my

So that way, you account for the duration

00:20:42.540 --> 00:20:43.640

Now, we know that we can use GERT

00:20:47.380 --> 00:20:51.100
There's going to be a repeatable

00:20:51.100 --> 00:20:53.080
Or if something comes up,

So you can go ahead and set up, let's say,

I gotta repeat that process over for

Well, this is why GERT and things like

this one also is linked around there,

And you have to keep that straight, and

00:22:24.370 --> 00:22:28.420
that straight as far as the duration go,

But there's an assumption

00:23:52.988 --> 00:23:56.715

00:23:56.715 --> 00:24:00.936

00:24:00.936 --> 00:24:05.447

You're just at this point,

Well, the one that most people focus

So what is best even now as you're

00:25:40.130 --> 00:25:43.660
So the way that they do it is they take

00:25:43.660 --> 00:25:48.070

00:25:48.070 --> 00:25:51.535
So what is the reality of the amount

00:25:51.535 --> 00:25:54.310
okay, and that's kind of key.

00:25:54.310 --> 00:25:58.010
Now the way that it works out is not

Okay, so when we take a look

So here, what we do is we focus in then

Now in this example,

Now when you take a look at this,

right, here's a regular work

With using the critical chain method

The critical chain here says look, what

tiny one right here is also task D, but

526
00:30:10.000 --> 00:30:11.020
much smaller.

527
00:30:11.020 --> 00:30:15.510
But now notice that on Tuesday and
Wednesday though, he's not over allocated.

528
00:30:15.510 --> 00:30:17.850
He's working his eight hour day.

529
00:30:17.850 --> 00:30:21.320
Now what about on Wednesday,
when we had task F up here?

530
00:30:21.320 --> 00:30:24.527
Well instead, what we do is we
move that now to Thursday, okay.

531
00:30:25.570 --> 00:30:30.170
Now when we do something like this, notice
that now Daniel's not over allocated,

532
00:30:30.170 --> 00:30:32.040
he's not getting overtime.

533
00:30:32.040 --> 00:30:35.710
But, we're actually now levelling his
resources to the constraint that we

534
00:30:35.710 --> 00:30:36.960
need them to be.

535
00:30:36.960 --> 00:30:39.770
But look at what happened to
the schedule though, okay?

536
00:30:39.770 --> 00:30:44.880
Whereas Daniel had it for the first
three days, where that's exactly,

537
00:30:44.880 --> 00:30:48.370
let's say that this represents a miniature
portion of a sub-project here,

538
00:30:48.370 --> 00:30:49.760
all the way through task F.

539
00:30:49.760 --> 00:30:52.190
He should have finished on Wednesday.

540
00:30:52.190 --> 00:30:55.010
Daniel, it looks like you're going
to have to work on Thursday instead.

541
00:30:55.010 --> 00:30:57.340
>> Well, as long as I'm already
scheduled to work on Thursday, and

542
00:30:57.340 --> 00:31:00.050
it's a nice even eight hour day,
I'm pretty happy about that.

543
00:31:00.050 --> 00:31:02.351
>> Yeah, and so a lot of times,
it may be that way.

544
00:31:02.351 --> 00:31:05.780
And so that's what you'll also end
up seeing is that the critical path

545
00:31:05.780 --> 00:31:09.820
tries to take that into account and
then says look, along with that,

546
00:31:09.820 --> 00:31:12.410
it's gonna push the schedule
out a little bit.

547
00:31:12.410 --> 00:31:16.210
And that's the reality of
actually planning this stuff out.

548
00:31:16.210 --> 00:31:18.720
When you take the critical path method and

549
00:31:18.720 --> 00:31:21.470
we're just focusing on this one second,
okay?

550
00:31:21.470 --> 00:31:25.350
It's your project schedule, right,
that's what you're actually relying on.

551
00:31:25.350 --> 00:31:28.300
But that is like you taking a sponge,
right, and

552
00:31:28.300 --> 00:31:32.720
you're wringing out every single
bit of water that you can.

553
00:31:32.720 --> 00:31:36.550
And once you do that, right,
it can soak up more, okay.

554
00:31:36.550 --> 00:31:39.760
And that's the key, right, is your
critical path method is doing that.

555
00:31:39.760 --> 00:31:42.830
It's saying, look,
no extra slack anywhere,

556
00:31:42.830 --> 00:31:46.910
no free time or float,
no float in between any activity.

557
00:31:46.910 --> 00:31:49.256
You're squeezing that schedule out, okay.

558
00:31:49.256 --> 00:31:51.879
Now you're not taking into
account anything, but

559
00:31:51.879 --> 00:31:55.539
now when I start adding in Daniel as
a a resource, myself as a resource,

560
00:31:55.539 --> 00:31:57.866
other people as a resource,
what am I doing?

561
00:31:57.866 --> 00:32:01.254
I'm now soaking that sponge up
a little bit more with the water,

562
00:32:01.254 --> 00:32:03.763
whatever it is that I'm
soaking up with it, and

563
00:32:03.763 --> 00:32:07.340
what's happening is that that
schedule is now expanding.

564
00:32:07.340 --> 00:32:11.050
Because now Daniel says,
I can't really do it on Thursday,

565
00:32:11.050 --> 00:32:12.930
I've got a chiropractor appointment.

566
00:32:12.930 --> 00:32:14.370
Can I push that to Friday?

567
00:32:14.370 --> 00:32:15.320
Well, that's a reality.

568
00:32:15.320 --> 00:32:17.010
It happens, right?

569
00:32:17.010 --> 00:32:21.230
And these are things that the critical
chain takes into account.

570
00:32:21.230 --> 00:32:23.510
And that's why when reality comes in,

571
00:32:23.510 --> 00:32:28.055
critical path is good when you actually go
all right, I'm a little bit delayed now.

572
00:32:28.055 --> 00:32:33.010
What else is actually gonna
be delayed if I do this?

573
00:32:33.010 --> 00:32:35.470
Well, then you actually soak that back in,
okay?

574
00:32:35.470 --> 00:32:39.683
But now, this is us taking reality into
account here, and when we do so, resource

575
00:32:39.683 --> 00:32:44.080
constraints and the critical path, again,
show us that what will end up happening is

576
00:32:44.080 --> 00:32:48.264
the majority of time, right, it will
expand our schedule out a little bit more.

577
00:32:48.264 --> 00:32:51.608
And this is a more realistic
view of our scheduling, and

578
00:32:51.608 --> 00:32:55.960
that's why it's actually very critical for
us to at least understand.

579
00:32:55.960 --> 00:32:57.850
Now, did we go through every method of it?

580
00:32:57.850 --> 00:33:01.040
No, okay, but
this is kind of a big general overview.

581
00:33:01.040 --> 00:33:03.760
So when you see something like that and
they talk about something like this

582
00:33:03.760 --> 00:33:06.360
that when you're dealing
with over-allocation, one

583
00:33:06.360 --> 00:33:11.322
of the methods that you can use is what we
call the idea here of resource levelling.

584
00:33:11.322 --> 00:33:14.390
Resource levelling, I don't know why
that doesn't sound right in my mind,

585
00:33:14.390 --> 00:33:15.230
but it is right.

586
00:33:15.230 --> 00:33:18.890
Resource levelling, okay, or
you can actually go ahead and just go,

587
00:33:18.890 --> 00:33:20.950
all right, Daniel, you're just
gonna be assigned the overtime.

588
00:33:20.950 --> 00:33:25.180
And that's fine with Daniel maybe,
and that may be fine with me.

589
00:33:25.180 --> 00:33:26.860
But you might find out that
you can't do that, and

590
00:33:26.860 --> 00:33:29.280
that means you have to use
something like the critical

591
00:33:29.280 --> 00:33:31.890
chain to see what now happens to
the rest of your schedule as well.

592
00:33:31.890 --> 00:33:33.600
So a lot of different methods there.

593
00:33:33.600 --> 00:33:39.180
>> Yeah, I can definitely see why
the chain method would be very,

594
00:33:39.180 --> 00:33:43.540
very highly recommended because it does
give you that more realistic approach to

595
00:33:43.540 --> 00:33:44.460
the time allocation.

596
00:33:44.460 --> 00:33:48.510
How long is this really gonna take,
instead of giving you some pie in the sky.

597
00:33:48.510 --> 00:33:51.543
Everything goes perfectly right,
we can get it done in three weeks,

598
00:33:51.543 --> 00:33:53.437
when it's really going to take six weeks.

599
00:33:53.437 --> 00:33:56.530
And then what happens is just
like what I talked about before.

600
00:33:56.530 --> 00:33:59.370
You say it’s going to take three weeks and
then now three weeks have come and

601
00:33:59.370 --> 00:34:02.500
gone, things have occurred,
delays of it has happened.

602
00:34:02.500 --> 00:34:04.420
And now you’re pushing it and
people think, wow,

603
00:34:04.420 --> 00:34:06.160
you told me it was going
to take three weeks.

604
00:34:06.160 --> 00:34:10.046
You have unsatisfied stakeholders in your
projects, and you’re going to have to

605
00:34:10.046 --> 00:34:13.330
resell them on well,
we didn't account for da da da da da.

606
00:34:13.330 --> 00:34:14.515
And now you look a little,

607
00:34:14.515 --> 00:34:18.090
you're probably not the best project
manager ever to walk the Earth.

608
00:34:18.090 --> 00:34:21.860
But Ronnie, really great resources
that you've shown us today and

609
00:34:21.860 --> 00:34:25.450
how we can figure out how
the project is gonna flow and

610
00:34:25.450 --> 00:34:30.540
then that way we can actually create
a schedule that is going to be realistic.

611
00:34:30.540 --> 00:34:33.860
Cuz these diagram methods are really
gonna come in handy for our projects.

612
00:34:33.860 --> 00:34:36.310
Anything else that we need to
talk about before we wrap it up?

613
00:34:36.310 --> 00:34:40.190
>> No, really remember that a lot of
us are gonna learn this in the field,

614
00:34:40.190 --> 00:34:41.150
is what it comes down to.

615
00:34:41.150 --> 00:34:43.960
We've shown you several examples
that will at least get you

616
00:34:43.960 --> 00:34:45.610
familiar with the concepts.

617
00:34:45.610 --> 00:34:47.990
Just don't be surprised
if you see any of them.

618
00:34:47.990 --> 00:34:51.800
It really does depend on the experience
of whatever project manager you end up

619
00:34:51.800 --> 00:34:52.891
working under.

620
00:34:52.891 --> 00:34:55.416
And they'll actually show you the ways
that they've also tweaked it.

621
00:34:55.416 --> 00:34:58.221
Remember everything about
project management, right,

622
00:34:58.221 --> 00:35:01.330
is not about doing it by the rules,
it's about best practices.

623
00:35:01.330 --> 00:35:04.885
And that means that hey,
not everything is gonna be as cut and

624
00:35:04.885 --> 00:35:06.715
dry as the way that you want to.

625
00:35:06.715 --> 00:35:09.225
It's always gonna be, well,
here's how I do it best.

626
00:35:09.225 --> 00:35:12.500
And you'll probably find that out
that as you manage a project,

627
00:35:12.500 --> 00:35:15.230
you'll kind of cut your corners
the way that you want to.

628
00:35:15.230 --> 00:35:16.770
And everybody else will just fall in line.

629
00:35:16.770 --> 00:35:18.890
And it's kind of a neat thing
about project management.

630
00:35:18.890 --> 00:35:20.750
it is not rule based.

631
00:35:20.750 --> 00:35:22.210
It's best practice based.

632
00:35:22.210 --> 00:35:24.150
And that means you do the best
that you can at times.

633
00:35:24.150 --> 00:35:24.680
>> That's right.

634
00:35:24.680 --> 00:35:29.230
And we try to be as practical as possible
in our project management and scheduling.

635
00:35:29.230 --> 00:35:32.490
Ronnie, thank you so much for joining us
today and explaining these concepts to us.

636
00:35:32.490 --> 00:35:36.470
Hopefully you guys get a lot out of that
but as for this episode goes, we are done.

637
00:35:36.470 --> 00:35:38.060
It is time to say sayonara.

638
00:35:38.060 --> 00:35:40.526
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

639
00:35:40.526 --> 00:35:41.448
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

640
00:35:41.448 --> 00:35:42.891
>> We'll see you next time.

641
00:35:42.891 --> 00:35:51.000
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to get the right information to the right people at the right time through developing a communications plan. They go through the key elements of a good communications plan starting with a Distribution List to identify those that need to be "in the loop". Then they go on to explain communications formats, the frequency of communication, as well as the common methods of information distribution.
episodes.title: Plan Project Communications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.038 --> 00:00:10.038
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.298 --> 00:00:16.430
All right, greetings everyone, and
welcome to another episode of IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.430 --> 00:00:20.820
I'm your host, Daniel Lowry, and today's
episode, well we are moving on with our

4
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:24.510
Project + series, joining us back in the
studio again today is our good friend and

5
00:00:24.510 --> 00:00:26.600
mentor Mr. Ronald Wong.

6
00:00:26.600 --> 00:00:27.970
Ronnie welcome back to the show, sir.

7
00:00:27.970 --> 00:00:31.190
>> Well thank you for having me back
on the show as we continue on to take

8
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:33.350
a look at more of the CompTIA Project +.

9
00:00:33.350 --> 00:00:36.530
And what we're actually doing
today is we're gonna talk about

10
00:00:36.530 --> 00:00:38.430
managing communications.

11
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:41.750
We're talking about the idea of
planning out our communications and

12
00:00:41.750 --> 00:00:46.190
we need to understand that communications
is by far one of the things that is very

13
00:00:46.190 --> 00:00:47.960
easy to get wrong.

14
00:00:47.960 --> 00:00:52.240
When we talk about communications, a lot
of times from the standpoint of a leader,

15
00:00:52.240 --> 00:00:55.690
what you end up understanding
is that leaders get information.

16
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:59.460
They don't tend to have to actually
express themselves too much on their own.

17
00:00:59.460 --> 00:01:03.690
Because what they say then is interpreted
by someone else, like a spokesperson.

18
00:01:03.690 --> 00:01:05.490
And then they actually
end up bringing that out.

19
00:01:05.490 --> 00:01:09.540
And now we actually get some type
of official message that comes out.

20
00:01:09.540 --> 00:01:12.610
Well, inside of project management,
we're not talking about

21
00:01:12.610 --> 00:01:15.740
basic communications even though
we could throw all that in there.

22
00:01:15.740 --> 00:01:18.740
We're talking about how we
manage communications and

23
00:01:18.740 --> 00:01:22.850
this is by far one of the most important
elements for a project manager

24
00:01:22.850 --> 00:01:27.560
to understand because Daniel, you and
I, we run in to situations and

25
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:32.870
issues where you simply talk to
someone and you have a conversation.

26
00:01:32.870 --> 00:01:36.820
And what ends up happening is that
you hear back from someone else,

27
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:39.650
that this is what you actually said.

28
00:01:39.650 --> 00:01:41.490
And Daniel, that doesn't feel good right?

29
00:01:41.490 --> 00:01:43.180
>> No and it can be frustrating.

30
00:01:43.180 --> 00:01:49.090
It can definitely break down the forward
momentum of any kind of project.

31
00:01:49.090 --> 00:01:52.530
I've literally told somebody something and
said.

32
00:01:52.530 --> 00:01:54.810
Well we need to do x, y, and z.

33
00:01:54.810 --> 00:01:57.040
And watch them walk across the room and

34
00:01:57.040 --> 00:02:01.210
explain it to somebody there and
completely have missed the mark.

35
00:02:01.210 --> 00:02:03.830
They didn't understand what
it was I was telling them and

36
00:02:03.830 --> 00:02:09.300
therefore as they communicated it to
somebody else, it started to break down.

37
00:02:09.300 --> 00:02:11.480
It's kind of the old phone game as a kid.

38
00:02:11.480 --> 00:02:14.840
You know, I whisper in Ronnie's ear and
ten other people later you get back and

39
00:02:14.840 --> 00:02:17.580
it's something completely
different than what you said.

40
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:19.970
So Ronnie, that being said,

41
00:02:19.970 --> 00:02:22.940
this is today you're gonna help us keep
that kind of thing from happening.

42
00:02:22.940 --> 00:02:27.970
You're gonna show us some ways to properly
communicate with everybody on the project

43
00:02:27.970 --> 00:02:30.840
so that everything is done
the way it's supposed to be done.

44
00:02:30.840 --> 00:02:33.480
>> Right, we're talking about
now how do we manage it best.

45
00:02:33.480 --> 00:02:36.730
So let me kind of show you an example of
why things can kind of get messed up in

46
00:02:36.730 --> 00:02:38.680
the way Daniel said it here.

47
00:02:38.680 --> 00:02:39.610
So here it is.

48
00:02:39.610 --> 00:02:43.540
I made a diagram for us to understand what
ends up happening a lot of times here,

49
00:02:43.540 --> 00:02:44.900
is let's say we have six people.

50
00:02:44.900 --> 00:02:48.210
And these are represented by
these squares right here.

51
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:51.440
And it looks like I should probably
have zoomed in just a little.

52
00:02:51.440 --> 00:02:54.920
So let me zoom in just a little
bit more and help us out.

53
00:02:54.920 --> 00:02:55.940
There we go.

54
00:02:55.940 --> 00:02:58.460
So we'll focus in on that model,
that diagram, and

55
00:02:58.460 --> 00:03:00.920
then we'll talk about how we
have these communications.

56
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:05.230
So let's say that there are six people
in this particular project, and

57
00:03:05.230 --> 00:03:08.320
one person actually does
the communication, right?

58
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:12.930
Now, if we're in a meeting of some sort
it seems like it works perfectly fine and

59
00:03:12.930 --> 00:03:17.430
what I believe that's actually happened is
that they've heard exactly what I said,

60
00:03:17.430 --> 00:03:19.120
all six people, okay?

61
00:03:19.120 --> 00:03:23.700
Well, that could be true, okay, that they
actually heard the words that I said, but

62
00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:29.590
then after the meeting disperses, okay,
after it actually is over the other five,

63
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:36.810
they go into the next room, and then they
say what did Ronnie really say about that?

64
00:03:36.810 --> 00:03:40.810
Now you essentially have another
communication form that actually goes on

65
00:03:40.810 --> 00:03:42.880
between those other five, and

66
00:03:42.880 --> 00:03:47.170
then they start interpreting what
might have really been said.

67
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:51.650
Each one essentially saying and
thinking and doing and

68
00:03:51.650 --> 00:03:54.790
repeating what they believe's
actually going on here.

69
00:03:54.790 --> 00:03:57.510
So in this particular type of model,

70
00:03:57.510 --> 00:04:02.640
then, you essentially have what we call
a full mesh communication theory, okay?

71
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:06.730
And that means that even though one
person might have spread the message

72
00:04:06.730 --> 00:04:10.540
It doesn't necessarily mean that the other
ones didn't spread a message that then it

73
00:04:10.540 --> 00:04:13.390
started denigrating and
continuing down as well.

74
00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:17.300
So whenever you have more than one
person you're communicating to, you've

75
00:04:17.300 --> 00:04:21.970
got to actually figure out the idea of
a communication model which actually says,

76
00:04:21.970 --> 00:04:25.320
look, everybody can communicate
with everybody else.

77
00:04:25.320 --> 00:04:29.470
And just like we as humans can actually
have misunderstandings between you.

78
00:04:29.470 --> 00:04:33.680
Let's say that you actually have
a very Maine type of accent.

79
00:04:33.680 --> 00:04:36.370
Here in the United States
you tend to drop the letter

80
00:04:36.370 --> 00:04:38.460
R a lot of times if you're from Maine.

81
00:04:38.460 --> 00:04:41.310
And then if you're like me,
where you're from the south,

82
00:04:41.310 --> 00:04:45.710
you tend to over exaggerate and
elongate your vowels a little bit.

83
00:04:45.710 --> 00:04:47.840
And you might not understand
exactly what we're talking about.

84
00:04:47.840 --> 00:04:50.080
So, it could be just
basic miscommunication.

85
00:04:50.080 --> 00:04:52.220
Or somebody could actually just
reinterpret what you have.

86
00:04:52.220 --> 00:04:55.330
And the reason why that's
important is because everybody can

87
00:04:55.330 --> 00:04:56.100
actually communicate.

88
00:04:56.100 --> 00:04:56.760
And so

89
00:04:56.760 --> 00:05:01.160
what you end up having to do is figure out
how many possible variations are there?

90
00:05:01.160 --> 00:05:04.090
How many possible
communications can be going on?

91
00:05:04.090 --> 00:05:05.800
In this model right here.

92
00:05:05.800 --> 00:05:07.960
You expand that out to your project and
you go,

93
00:05:07.960 --> 00:05:09.980
wait I've got 30 people, you're right.

94
00:05:09.980 --> 00:05:13.850
That means everybody has a potential of
communicating with everybody else and

95
00:05:13.850 --> 00:05:15.240
still getting the message wrong.

96
00:05:15.240 --> 00:05:17.170
That's what it breaks down to.

97
00:05:17.170 --> 00:05:21.830
So the way that we figure this out is,
we're given a group or a team you need to

98
00:05:21.830 --> 00:05:26.130
figure out what are the possibilities here
and it comes out to a basic formula and

99
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:29.310
that formula is right over
here on the left hand side,

100
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:32.830
I'm gonna highlight a little bit more
is something like this, it's n and

101
00:05:32.830 --> 00:05:37.800
then you actually end up multiplying
it by n minus 1 divided by 2, okay.

102
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:41.220
So you're trying to establish
every communication

103
00:05:41.220 --> 00:05:45.230
possibility between every other node so
let's say that my n is 6.

104
00:05:45.230 --> 00:05:46.130
Which is 6 people.

105
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:48.830
Which is what I showed you over
here on the right hand side.

106
00:05:48.830 --> 00:05:51.240
And now I go ahead and I convert that.

107
00:05:51.240 --> 00:05:54.990
You take 6 and
then you multiply it by 6 minus 1.

108
00:05:54.990 --> 00:05:58.250
Which essentially gives you 6 times 5.
