if Mike calls me up and

561
00:30:20.120 --> 00:30:23.200
goes, hey, is there a reason
why I'm not getting this?

562
00:30:23.200 --> 00:30:26.650
I can flip to this and go, well, you
should have actually received this type of

563
00:30:26.650 --> 00:30:29.930
communication and
it should have been weekly.

564
00:30:29.930 --> 00:30:32.780
And you may even keep another
document that shows that you did

565
00:30:32.780 --> 00:30:35.720
communicate with him on that
particular day, as well.

566
00:30:35.720 --> 00:30:40.720
So, you can use something like that and
we've actually created a template

567
00:30:40.720 --> 00:30:44.650
a while ago here where it actually
does something like this.

568
00:30:44.650 --> 00:30:49.600
So maybe if you want to print this out on
paper you can also communicate this way.

569
00:30:49.600 --> 00:30:51.730
The same type of information,

570
00:30:51.730 --> 00:30:54.650
this one of course should be
on a larger sheet of paper.

571
00:30:54.650 --> 00:30:57.890
But this one even has
assumptions that you're making,

572
00:30:57.890 --> 00:31:02.660
as well as even constraints that you
might actually communicate on too.

573
00:31:02.660 --> 00:31:08.000
And also, if you're using specific terms
that may need to be defined here, you

574
00:31:08.000 --> 00:31:12.310
wanna make sure that you add that in and
any other accompanying details as well.

575
00:31:12.310 --> 00:31:14.380
So you may go ahead and attach this.

576
00:31:14.380 --> 00:31:17.690
Now, you're probably saying when
the heck would I ever come up with this.

577
00:31:17.690 --> 00:31:21.810
Well you're gonna do it if you're
creating that communication plan.

578
00:31:21.810 --> 00:31:25.300
But you're also gonna put a copy of
this inside the project management

579
00:31:25.300 --> 00:31:29.610
portfolio book that you want to ensure
that the project management has a copy

580
00:31:29.610 --> 00:31:33.230
of what the actual plan was so
that you can use it.

581
00:31:33.230 --> 00:31:34.530
So it's the same way,

582
00:31:34.530 --> 00:31:38.670
just less graphic than the way
I had it on my diagram instead.

583
00:31:38.670 --> 00:31:42.760
But you can see why this is very helpful
when you do need to establish those

584
00:31:42.760 --> 00:31:47.685
formal communications or any type of
communication plan inside of your project.

585
00:31:47.685 --> 00:31:51.310
>> Ronnie lot's of good information there
on developing a communications plan for

586
00:31:51.310 --> 00:31:52.540
each one of our projects.

587
00:31:52.540 --> 00:31:56.650
All the steps necessary that are going
to help us keep the information flowing

588
00:31:56.650 --> 00:31:59.700
as necessary, keep that project
on the straight and narrow and

589
00:31:59.700 --> 00:32:00.860
that's what we like, right Ronnie?

590
00:32:00.860 --> 00:32:01.530
>> It is.

591
00:32:01.530 --> 00:32:03.680
>> All right, is there anything
else that we need to cover for

592
00:32:03.680 --> 00:32:05.560
this episode before we wrap things up?

593
00:32:05.560 --> 00:32:06.680
>> Not for this episode, but

594
00:32:06.680 --> 00:32:09.820
remember we're still in the midst
of the planning stage right?

595
00:32:09.820 --> 00:32:12.270
There's still a few elements
that we need to cover.

596
00:32:12.270 --> 00:32:15.435
In the project planning this is gonna be
the longest element that we talk about

597
00:32:15.435 --> 00:32:17.840
in overall project management.

598
00:32:17.840 --> 00:32:21.600
But it is a very important part
of something that we've got to be

599
00:32:21.600 --> 00:32:22.400
willing to do.

600
00:32:22.400 --> 00:32:25.205
If you're like me you really
don't like communicating,

601
00:32:25.205 --> 00:32:27.450
[LAUGH] well it still means you
have to learn how to do it.

602
00:32:27.450 --> 00:32:30.860
You still need to do it according
to some particular channels here

603
00:32:30.860 --> 00:32:33.500
to make sure that everybody's
on the same page.

604
00:32:33.500 --> 00:32:36.800
Getting the right information to
the right people at the right time

605
00:32:36.800 --> 00:32:40.910
will help you out tremendously
in your project management.

606
00:32:40.910 --> 00:32:45.920
If you can just get that information
down pat, you'll be ready to go.

607
00:32:45.920 --> 00:32:47.140
>> Excellent stuff, Ronnie.

608
00:32:47.140 --> 00:32:49.180
And as always, thank you so much for

609
00:32:49.180 --> 00:32:54.020
explaining these concepts to us, getting
us ready for either our Project+ exam or

610
00:32:54.020 --> 00:32:56.820
just to be better project
managers in general.

611
00:32:56.820 --> 00:32:59.163
That being said it look like we've come
to the end of another great episode.

612
00:32:59.163 --> 00:33:01.796
Hopefully you guys have learned a thing or
two.

613
00:33:01.796 --> 00:33:04.850
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

614
00:33:04.850 --> 00:33:05.740
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

615
00:33:05.740 --> 00:33:07.737
>> We'll see you next time.

616
00:33:07.737 --> 00:33:14.360
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie walk you through developing a plan for risk management. They begin by explaining the 3 major components of risk management plans, which include Identifying the Risks, Analyzing the Potential Impact, and Appropriate Responses to high risk areas with great impact. They break each one of these areas down in detail, giving you a solid foundational knowledge and tools to develop your risk management plan.
episodes.title: Plan for Risk Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.106 --> 00:00:10.106
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.306 --> 00:00:16.610
All right, greetings, everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.610 --> 00:00:19.456
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.456 --> 00:00:21.960
we are moving on with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:21.960 --> 00:00:23.550
Joining us back in the studio today,

6
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:27.230
to lend his gigantic wealth of
knowledge in project management.

7
00:00:27.230 --> 00:00:29.120
That is our good friend and
mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:31.310
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:31.310 --> 00:00:34.572
>> Well thank you, as we continue
on to actually take a look at

10
00:00:34.572 --> 00:00:39.110
CompTIA's Project+ as we're
getting ready for that exam.

11
00:00:39.110 --> 00:00:41.760
And we're also getting ready for
some project management.

12
00:00:41.760 --> 00:00:44.690
We're moving into the area
of more planning, right?

13
00:00:44.690 --> 00:00:47.660
We've just started taking
a looking at planning.

14
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:50.420
And we've talked about schedule
planning a little bit.

15
00:00:50.420 --> 00:00:55.170
We've also talked, of course, about the
idea here of scope planning a bit more.

16
00:00:55.170 --> 00:00:57.500
And now we're actually moving
into the realm of what we call,

17
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:00.870
of course, planning for risk management.

18
00:01:00.870 --> 00:01:04.400
Now remember, we're not actually
people that are trying to come in and

19
00:01:04.400 --> 00:01:09.010
understand the entirety and
the exhaustive nature of risk management.

20
00:01:09.010 --> 00:01:12.360
Believe it or not, you can actually
get PHDs in risk management.

21
00:01:12.360 --> 00:01:14.180
I am not a PHD in risk management.

22
00:01:14.180 --> 00:01:14.980
Let me put it that way.

23
00:01:14.980 --> 00:01:15.950
So-,
>> I know one.

24
00:01:15.950 --> 00:01:18.540
>> Yeah, and you actually know
one that's related to you.

25
00:01:18.540 --> 00:01:19.200
Right?

26
00:01:19.200 --> 00:01:24.790
So, but i'm not one that people, but I do
understand that the nature of risk, right?

27
00:01:24.790 --> 00:01:29.120
Is something that we all have to deal with
in our regular, everyday daily jobs, but

28
00:01:29.120 --> 00:01:33.990
on projects, right, because we
are constrained by time, by cost and

29
00:01:33.990 --> 00:01:39.340
by quality or requirements that we have to
actually be able to manage them much more.

30
00:01:39.340 --> 00:01:42.168
They have to actually be a little
bit more in focus for us and

31
00:01:42.168 --> 00:01:43.572
we do need to consider them.

32
00:01:43.572 --> 00:01:48.102
Every day that we're actually running
a project we need to think about

33
00:01:48.102 --> 00:01:50.710
the idea of risks that
we end up taking and

34
00:01:50.710 --> 00:01:55.422
make sure that we understand how to
deal with them is pretty much the key.

35
00:01:55.422 --> 00:01:59.395
So that's where we are going to begin,
and we're going to take a look and

36
00:01:59.395 --> 00:02:03.500
take our time to make sure we have at
least an understanding of how we plan for

37
00:02:03.500 --> 00:02:04.950
risk management itself.

38
00:02:05.950 --> 00:02:08.820
So I think that the key question though,
for us, Daniel,

39
00:02:08.820 --> 00:02:14.380
right at the very beginning is,
a lot of times, the term risk is used in,

40
00:02:14.380 --> 00:02:17.580
at least every time that I think about it,

41
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:23.030
is always used in a very adverse way,
that when I say I'm taking a risk on this,

42
00:02:23.030 --> 00:02:28.210
what I'm saying is, I have the potential
to lose on this particular battle.

43
00:02:28.210 --> 00:02:31.789
So, whatever it is,
when I say that I'm taking risks,

44
00:02:31.789 --> 00:02:36.598
there's always a potential for danger or
for loss that ends up happening.

45
00:02:36.598 --> 00:02:39.919
So that's what we're normally taking
a look at when we think about it.

46
00:02:39.919 --> 00:02:44.816
But in reality though,
risk itself can be, well, both, right?

47
00:02:44.816 --> 00:02:46.756
It can be something that's adverse, and

48
00:02:46.756 --> 00:02:49.807
it can be something that's actually
even positive on your side,

49
00:02:49.807 --> 00:02:53.140
if the risk is actually worth
the venture and that's the key, right?

50
00:02:53.140 --> 00:02:55.660
Is that you don't know which
way it's actually gonna go.

51
00:02:55.660 --> 00:02:57.850
But then for a project manager though,

52
00:02:57.850 --> 00:03:00.860
we need to be able to manage
those risks a little bit better.

53
00:03:00.860 --> 00:03:05.580
The idea here is trying to deal with
the uncertainty, and because we do

54
00:03:05.580 --> 00:03:10.490
have those constraints we need to
manage uncertainties as much as we can.

55
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:14.410
And the way that we do that is by coming
up with a way that we go ahead and

56
00:03:14.410 --> 00:03:16.790
we plan for the risk management.

57
00:03:16.790 --> 00:03:18.950
So when we start talking
about planning for

58
00:03:18.950 --> 00:03:23.780
risk management, there's really three
basic components to a risk management

59
00:03:23.780 --> 00:03:27.690
plan that should be included at
least at the conceptual level.

60
00:03:27.690 --> 00:03:30.870
And then we're gonna talk a little bit
about details on how we can actually see

61
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:32.730
some of this stuff if we need to.

62
00:03:32.730 --> 00:03:35.270
Now remember,
we're not actually doing risk management.

63
00:03:35.270 --> 00:03:40.180
We're saying, here's how we plan for
handling the risk that come about, but

64
00:03:40.180 --> 00:03:42.980
you still need to understand just
a little bit of those concepts.

65
00:03:42.980 --> 00:03:45.800
So let's go ahead and
start with an overview of

66
00:03:45.800 --> 00:03:49.730
what normally is going to be inside
of our risk management plans.

67
00:03:49.730 --> 00:03:53.160
When it comes down to it, let's go ahead
and take a look at my machine here.

68
00:03:53.160 --> 00:03:54.440
And then we'll see.

69
00:03:54.440 --> 00:03:59.190
So I've created this diagram that gives us
a list of bulletpoints of things we should

70
00:03:59.190 --> 00:04:00.090
consider.

71
00:04:00.090 --> 00:04:04.070
And we're gonna be walking through some of
these different considerations as well,

72
00:04:04.070 --> 00:04:05.770
little bit more in detail.

73
00:04:05.770 --> 00:04:09.910
The first and foremost idea that we
have to actually be able to understand

74
00:04:09.910 --> 00:04:12.010
is what is a risk to our project?

75
00:04:12.010 --> 00:04:14.370
But remember, it might not be a risk
to anybody else at this point.

76
00:04:14.370 --> 00:04:14.910
In other words,

77
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:19.060
our project actually has several risks
that we always have to keep in mind.

78
00:04:19.060 --> 00:04:20.930
When we take a look at
the project constraints,

79
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:24.230
those are kind of the constraining risks
that we have to worry about, right.

80
00:04:24.230 --> 00:04:27.530
That we go something like,
over budget at times.

81
00:04:27.530 --> 00:04:30.310
Or we don't have enough time
to complete the project and

82
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:33.540
we may be facing penalties of some sort,
or a project's

83
00:04:33.540 --> 00:04:37.960
not what the stakeholder actually
wanted and so that's a risk as well.

84
00:04:37.960 --> 00:04:40.390
But so the first thing that we need to do,
of course,

85
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:46.430
is be able to take our project and
identify as many risks as we can.

86
00:04:46.430 --> 00:04:49.040
Let's not go into the analysis yet, okay?

87
00:04:49.040 --> 00:04:50.660
Let's just say that what we wanna try and

88
00:04:50.660 --> 00:04:56.420
do is identify as many risks as we
can inside of our project, right?

89
00:04:56.420 --> 00:04:59.410
Because it's better to actually
be able to to get everything and

90
00:04:59.410 --> 00:05:04.610
then eliminate the things that really are
not as risky as we think that they are.

91
00:05:04.610 --> 00:05:10.440
Then to just actually center in and focus
in on one risk and miss the rest of it.

92
00:05:10.440 --> 00:05:14.170
So we’re going to talk about
that a bit more in detail.

93
00:05:14.170 --> 00:05:19.340
The other thing then, after we actually
identify as many possible risks as we can,

94
00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:22.620
we are going to analyze
the potential impact.

95
00:05:22.620 --> 00:05:24.390
Essentially, we're rating the risk.

96
00:05:24.390 --> 00:05:25.020
Right?

97
00:05:25.020 --> 00:05:28.290
There are some things that
are risky inside of our project.

98
00:05:28.290 --> 00:05:31.510
I don't assign enough
resources to finish a task.

99
00:05:31.510 --> 00:05:35.160
Well that means that it's going to blow up
at some point where I have to assign more

100
00:05:35.160 --> 00:05:38.780
resources or
it's not going to get finished at all.

101
00:05:38.780 --> 00:05:43.050
There could be a risk that somebody
leaves our project and that does happen.

102
00:05:43.050 --> 00:05:47.250
But it actually depends on what is
the impact of that to our project and so

103
00:05:47.250 --> 00:05:51.200
what we do is we take the risk and we
actually analyze them and we essentially

104
00:05:51.200 --> 00:05:55.405
rank them as what we'll end up doing here,
so that then we can add a value or or

105
00:05:55.405 --> 00:06:01.495
assign a value to it and see then what
our actual response is going to be.

106
00:06:01.495 --> 00:06:05.615
Now down here at the bottom, Daniel, I
know it's a little bit hard for us to see.

107
00:06:05.615 --> 00:06:08.545
Let me see if I can zoom
in just a little bit here.

108
00:06:08.545 --> 00:06:10.685
Now normally I like to try and

109
00:06:10.685 --> 00:06:14.035
keep everything equal as far as
on the grammatical side, right?

110
00:06:14.035 --> 00:06:18.635
So I had identify and analyze, and
then down here at the bottom I have

111
00:06:18.635 --> 00:06:21.760
appropriately responding to risk
I have no verb in that at all.

112
00:06:21.760 --> 00:06:24.600
So, you're probably like,
what the heck is going on there?

113
00:06:24.600 --> 00:06:28.990
Well, because there is no verb for
me to be able to say what I need to here,

114
00:06:28.990 --> 00:06:32.260
I'm gonna do this kind of
adverbial thing here which is,

115
00:06:32.260 --> 00:06:35.760
we need to appropriately
respond to the risk.

116
00:06:35.760 --> 00:06:39.920
Now you might say, why is that important?

117
00:06:39.920 --> 00:06:42.130
Because the emphasis is
on the appropriately.

118
00:06:42.130 --> 00:06:46.560
It's not on the action,
it's the appropriate response.

119
00:06:46.560 --> 00:06:48.480
So let me give you an example.

120
00:06:48.480 --> 00:06:55.350
If I accidentally spill, say, my beverage
here on the notes that I gave Daniel for

121
00:06:55.350 --> 00:06:59.680
the show, he might be a little bit upset
at that, and normally, what he does is, he

122
00:06:59.680 --> 00:07:04.230
just shakes the notes off, he kind of pats
it dry and that's an appropriate response.

123
00:07:04.230 --> 00:07:08.640
An inappropriate response to
that is Daniel goes ahead, and

124
00:07:08.640 --> 00:07:12.560
he crumples the notes up, and
then he punches me in the face, okay.

125
00:07:12.560 --> 00:07:14.300
Is that actually a response the risk?

126
00:07:14.300 --> 00:07:18.800
Yes, it is a response, okay, but
is it an appropriate response?

127
00:07:18.800 --> 00:07:22.120
Well, that's something that we as
project managers have to understand,

128
00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:25.410
that there are inappropriate
responses to risk and

129
00:07:25.410 --> 00:07:28.410
that there are appropriate
responses to the risk as well.

130
00:07:28.410 --> 00:07:31.360
>> I'm guessing anything that
facilitates a crime is gonna be one

131
00:07:31.360 --> 00:07:32.980
of those inappropriate responses.

132
00:07:32.980 --> 00:07:37.801
>> It normally is and just about
every legal jurisdiction there is on

133
00:07:37.801 --> 00:07:43.326
the planet out there But that's
something that we can under-emphasize,

134
00:07:43.326 --> 00:07:48.235
is that there has to be an appropriate
response to the risk itself,

135
00:07:48.235 --> 00:07:53.433
because over-response to the risk
can put our project in danger too.

136
00:07:53.433 --> 00:07:57.979
So we need to talk about this idea of
appropriately responding to the risk and

137
00:07:57.979 --> 00:08:02.606
that's why it doesn't make grammatical
equality there when we take a look.

138
00:08:02.606 --> 00:08:04.566
But overall though, that's what-
>> You work with what you got, Ronnie.

139
00:08:04.566 --> 00:08:06.766
>> Yeah, we can do what we can do here.

140
00:08:06.766 --> 00:08:10.206
But risks is a big part of
project management too, and

141
00:08:10.206 --> 00:08:14.488
as a project manager you do,
you need to be able to see that the risks

142
00:08:14.488 --> 00:08:17.260
are there and
they just have to be managed.

143
00:08:17.260 --> 00:08:20.350
Do you have to understand everything
there is to know about risks management?

144
00:08:20.350 --> 00:08:23.000
No, you don't have to understand
every single thing but

145
00:08:23.000 --> 00:08:26.180
you do need to know,
at least these three things,

146
00:08:26.180 --> 00:08:28.610
if you're going to actually be
dealing inside of project manager.

147
00:08:28.610 --> 00:08:31.730
And we're just going to take a look
at each of those three concepts

148
00:08:31.730 --> 00:08:33.540
as we kind of dive down into this.

149
00:08:33.540 --> 00:08:34.380
>> That's right.

150
00:08:34.380 --> 00:08:35.280
Ronny makes a great point.

151
00:08:35.280 --> 00:08:37.910
He's laid out a really good path for

152
00:08:37.910 --> 00:08:40.920
us to take in developing
our risk management plan.

153
00:08:40.920 --> 00:08:44.910
And I saw number one on that list, and
it is the most appropriate spot for it.

154
00:08:44.910 --> 00:08:49.470
Is that number one spot is
the idea of identifying the risks.

155
00:08:49.470 --> 00:08:51.750
Cuz it's kinda hard to plan for

156
00:08:51.750 --> 00:08:56.120
risks if you haven't even tried to
assess what those risks might be.

157
00:08:56.120 --> 00:09:01.080
How can I think of how do I make this
building fireproof if I didn't think,

158
00:09:01.080 --> 00:09:03.730
well, this building might
one day catch fire.

159
00:09:03.730 --> 00:09:07.150
That's the risk, cuz I'm gonna be
running electricity through it.

160
00:09:07.150 --> 00:09:09.750
I'm gonna have people inside of it.

161
00:09:09.750 --> 00:09:11.810
Maybe this is a restaurant.

162
00:09:11.810 --> 00:09:14.710
There's going to be open flame
at some point in this time, so

163
00:09:14.710 --> 00:09:18.400
the risk that it could
catch fire starts to rise.

164
00:09:18.400 --> 00:09:19.180
And, that's what we need to do.

165
00:09:19.180 --> 00:09:24.890
We need to assess what the risks are to

00:35:08.101 --> 00:35:10.920
if it does,
I can now have a pay out from it.

610
00:35:10.920 --> 00:35:13.400
So, that's the idea of transference and
believe it or

611
00:35:13.400 --> 00:35:18.170
not a lot of our risk planning, okay,
we handle it in doing transferring.

612
00:35:18.170 --> 00:35:19.360
Why?

613
00:35:19.360 --> 00:35:21.090
It does cost a bit, but

614
00:35:21.090 --> 00:35:24.840
it really does allow us to get on
the project as soon as we can, okay?

615
00:35:24.840 --> 00:35:28.060
Mitigation, of course,
is dealing with the risk itself.

616
00:35:28.060 --> 00:35:32.880
The idea of avoidance isn't really
dealing with the idea that the risk,

617
00:35:32.880 --> 00:35:35.220
we're just saying we're
just gonna get around it.

618
00:35:35.220 --> 00:35:38.120
Transference, again,
doesn't really get rid of the risk.

619
00:35:38.120 --> 00:35:41.500
Mitigation in theory should
get rid of the risk.

620
00:35:41.500 --> 00:35:44.439
Why?
Because we face it head on, and

621
00:35:44.439 --> 00:35:47.879
say alright, what can we do to
deal with the risks that I have?

622
00:35:48.960 --> 00:35:52.740
Problem is this takes a longest time, cuz
you don't know what factors actually deal

623
00:35:52.740 --> 00:35:56.650
with the risk that happens and you never
can actually judge what the overall

624
00:35:56.650 --> 00:36:00.190
impact to that risk is, so even though you
may deal with it immediately, you might

625
00:36:00.190 --> 00:36:04.580
find out something that whatever happened
here we can restructure something else.

626
00:36:04.580 --> 00:36:08.930
You may found out that your impact of
change in this actually affects a deal

627
00:36:08.930 --> 00:36:10.730
somewhere else so you don't know.

628
00:36:10.730 --> 00:36:12.740
Mitigations are a little bit strange.

629
00:36:12.740 --> 00:36:15.290
They take the longest time,
but in theory, they should

630
00:36:15.290 --> 00:36:18.760
be where you're actually handling
the risk and you're dealing with it.

631
00:36:18.760 --> 00:36:20.440
Of course, outright accepting it.

632
00:36:20.440 --> 00:36:22.000
Say, well look, risk is gonna happen.

633
00:36:22.000 --> 00:36:24.460
That's what ends up happening and
that's what you do.

634
00:36:24.460 --> 00:36:27.380
So you just go ahead and accept it,
deal with it, you pay for it.

635
00:36:27.380 --> 00:36:29.590
That's what goes on there.

636
00:36:29.590 --> 00:36:31.830
Now what if the risk is
actually something positive?

637
00:36:31.830 --> 00:36:35.170
Well again you have three
different opportunities here, too.

638
00:36:35.170 --> 00:36:37.080
Best and foremost,
we're going to exploit it.

639
00:36:37.080 --> 00:36:41.080
If this is something good we exploit the
heck out of it and we go ahead and we go,

640
00:36:41.080 --> 00:36:42.560
let's jump on this bandwagon.

641
00:36:42.560 --> 00:36:45.588
And we throw all of our resources
behind it and we can do that.

642
00:36:45.588 --> 00:36:48.570
If we believe that even
though this is a great thing,

643
00:36:48.570 --> 00:36:52.980
we wanna share this as well to be
able to spread out the workload

644
00:36:52.980 --> 00:36:56.910
as well as actually having to share
part of the benefits of it, too.

645
00:36:56.910 --> 00:36:59.720
And then, of course, if we believe that
this is something that can turn into

646
00:36:59.720 --> 00:37:03.080
something else, we're willing to enhance
it, invest more into it, as well.

647
00:37:03.080 --> 00:37:05.200
So those are also possibilities, too,

648
00:37:05.200 --> 00:37:08.770
if it's some type of opportunity,
risk opportunity.

649
00:37:08.770 --> 00:37:09.410
And lastly,

650
00:37:09.410 --> 00:37:13.380
we have to talk just briefly about
contingency is what we need to do, okay?

651
00:37:13.380 --> 00:37:17.060
Contingency is not what we like to say,
right?

652
00:37:17.060 --> 00:37:19.930
It’s not that we’re dealing with a risk
because we're not because a risk doesn’t

653
00:37:19.930 --> 00:37:20.790
actually exist.

654
00:37:20.790 --> 00:37:24.530
This is a probability of any risk
happening is what we’re taking a look at.

655
00:37:24.530 --> 00:37:28.080
Contingency planning is all about
the what if is what we're saying here.

656
00:37:28.080 --> 00:37:28.880
>> The backup plan.

657
00:37:28.880 --> 00:37:30.650
>> The backup plan exactly good.

658
00:37:30.650 --> 00:37:35.330
The backup plan, what do we think is
most likely to happen if it happens,

659
00:37:35.330 --> 00:37:40.120
and then we're coming up with
what we might do to deal with it.

660
00:37:40.120 --> 00:37:44.570
Most of the time we don't tend to
worry about contingencies too often,

661
00:37:44.570 --> 00:37:49.000
unless the probability is very high or

662
00:37:49.000 --> 00:37:52.910
the impact is very high, then we start
dealing with idea of contingencies.

663
00:37:52.910 --> 00:37:54.770
If it's just a normal everyday risk,

664
00:37:54.770 --> 00:37:57.980
we just try to mitigate it as it
comes along more than anything else.

665
00:37:57.980 --> 00:38:01.990
We don't tend to deal with contingencies
on a regular day to day, but we do say

666
00:38:01.990 --> 00:38:06.390
though, on these contingency or on these
basis here, we're at a high probability or

667
00:38:06.390 --> 00:38:10.790
a high impact, I need to have a plan
on hand just in case it happens.

668
00:38:10.790 --> 00:38:14.370
So, when you start talking about risk
management planning, you need to consider

669
00:38:14.370 --> 00:38:17.400
all of those different factors that
we really did talk about here.

670
00:38:18.530 --> 00:38:23.420
And when you do so, you will then come up
with your entire risk management plan.

671
00:38:24.480 --> 00:38:25.370
Let me see.
Yep, okay,

672
00:38:25.370 --> 00:38:29.960
your entire risk management plan that
will help you to actually realize and

673
00:38:29.960 --> 00:38:33.800
give your organization and
your stakeholders an idea that you have at

674
00:38:33.800 --> 00:38:37.880
least thought about the risks that can
actually take place in your project.

675
00:38:37.880 --> 00:38:41.120
When you can't see the risk
you're absolutely gonna end up

676
00:38:41.120 --> 00:38:42.780
having them hit you in the face.

677
00:38:42.780 --> 00:38:44.470
You don't know how to deal with them.

678
00:38:44.470 --> 00:38:46.330
Well, then that slows
your project down again.

679
00:38:46.330 --> 00:38:48.320
Something you don't want to have happen.

680
00:38:48.320 --> 00:38:52.550
So being able to actually manage risk,
a huge part of project management as well.

681
00:38:52.550 --> 00:38:55.130
>> Yes, definitely,
anytime you put together a project,

682
00:38:55.130 --> 00:38:56.660
there's always risks involved.

683
00:38:56.660 --> 00:38:58.575
We have to have a way to deal with those.

684
00:38:58.575 --> 00:39:03.290
Ronnie, you've done a great job of
showing us at least the Project+ way or

685
00:39:03.290 --> 00:39:05.950
CompTIAs way of helping
guide us through that.

686
00:39:05.950 --> 00:39:08.650
We have some sort of actionable
plan that we can take.

687
00:39:08.650 --> 00:39:11.290
And we understand the concepts within
them, did a great job on that,

688
00:39:11.290 --> 00:39:12.620
we really appreciate you stopping by.

689
00:39:12.620 --> 00:39:15.920
That being said, we have gone over
our time just a little bit, but

690
00:39:15.920 --> 00:39:17.530
we're gonna call it a day right here.

691
00:39:17.530 --> 00:39:20.150
Thanks again for you, Ronnie,
and thank you for watching.

692
00:39:20.150 --> 00:39:22.830
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

693
00:39:22.830 --> 00:39:23.600
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

694
00:39:23.600 --> 00:39:25.677
>> We'll see you next time.

695
00:39:25.677 --> 00:39:32.340
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concepts and tools used to aid in planning out your resource management. They begin by identifying existing resource availability, which may be in human, equipment, or material form. They then use tools like the Responsibility Assignment Matrix(RAM) and RACI chart (Responsible, Accountable, Consult, Inform) to figure out resource assignment and management.
episodes.title: Plan Resource Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:03.148
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.148 --> 00:00:12.168
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:12.168 --> 00:00:16.312
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:16.312 --> 00:00:17.860
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.860 --> 00:00:21.520
And in today's episode we are moving
on with our Project+ course.

6
00:00:21.520 --> 00:00:26.330
And joining us back in the studio again
today to lend his, well, his expertise and

7
00:00:26.330 --> 00:00:29.310
his knowledge on that very subject
is our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Long.

8
00:00:29.310 --> 00:00:30.660
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:30.660 --> 00:00:32.121
>> Well thank you having me on the show,

10
00:00:32.121 --> 00:00:34.399
as we continue on to take
a look at CompTia's Project+.

11
00:00:34.399 --> 00:00:37.071
We are now moving into the realm of, well,

12
00:00:37.071 --> 00:00:41.020
resource management is what
we're taking a look at here.

13
00:00:41.020 --> 00:00:45.250
Remember that, as a project manager it's
not really our responsibility to literally

14
00:00:45.250 --> 00:00:48.130
manage every single resource
that's actually out there.

15
00:00:48.130 --> 00:00:52.150
Our responsibility is to come up with a
plan in which we can actually manage those

16
00:00:52.150 --> 00:00:54.070
resources that we have available.

17
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:57.190
Resources are pretty much
the part of our project that

18
00:00:57.190 --> 00:01:01.150
may get overlooked a lot of times
because assumptions that are made.

19
00:01:01.150 --> 00:01:04.060
Some of the assumptions that's made
when you become a project manager is

20
00:01:04.060 --> 00:01:07.250
your project team is ready and
waiting to go.

21
00:01:07.250 --> 00:01:12.090
Every resource that you have need
of is ready and waiting to go.

22
00:01:12.090 --> 00:01:17.010
Everything that you think that you can
have ready to have accomplish that project

23
00:01:17.010 --> 00:01:19.520
is actually ready and willing to go.

24
00:01:19.520 --> 00:01:23.060
And the reality of that is that
none of that may actually exist.

25
00:01:23.060 --> 00:01:26.400
And one of the things that you have
to do then, as a project manager,

26
00:01:26.400 --> 00:01:31.310
is go ahead and begin to think about what
can we do to ensure that we come up with

27
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:35.230
some type of resource management
plan at a very high level overview.

28
00:01:35.230 --> 00:01:38.350
We're not gonna get into
the nitty gritty details because

29
00:01:38.350 --> 00:01:40.660
every single project
is gonna be different.

30
00:01:40.660 --> 00:01:42.868
If you're working building construction,

31
00:01:42.868 --> 00:01:46.360
it's gonna be different than if I'm
working on an IT project, right?

32
00:01:46.360 --> 00:01:47.840
You need different resources and

33
00:01:47.840 --> 00:01:52.130
different types of people working on
those particular types of resources.

34
00:01:52.130 --> 00:01:54.170
If you're working under water,
underground,

35
00:01:54.170 --> 00:01:57.820
versus you're actually building
a sky rise, it's gonna be different.

36
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:00.530
So we're not actually getting
into the nitty-grittys of exactly

37
00:02:00.530 --> 00:02:04.120
who needs to be hired and what needs
to be hired and human resources.

38
00:02:04.120 --> 00:02:08.010
We're not even going to that point
where I actually explain to Daniel that

39
00:02:08.010 --> 00:02:11.640
here's what I need and
he tells me what type of person I need.

40
00:02:11.640 --> 00:02:14.670
We're just talking about what
do we really need to understand

41
00:02:14.670 --> 00:02:18.530
about what has to be on our
project to at least make it work.

42
00:02:18.530 --> 00:02:22.770
Okay, so this is the 10,000 feet overview

43
00:02:22.770 --> 00:02:27.440
of what we call resource management
planning as what we're taking a look at.

44
00:02:27.440 --> 00:02:30.470
So, when we begin to start planning for

45
00:02:30.470 --> 00:02:34.990
our project and
now our resource management planning.

46
00:02:34.990 --> 00:02:38.940
We need to understand that all those
things that I just talked about may not

47
00:02:38.940 --> 00:02:40.930
actually be on hand yet.

48
00:02:40.930 --> 00:02:45.510
And that means I need to come up with
something that will help me to be able to

49
00:02:45.510 --> 00:02:49.880
identify the resources that I need and
to make sure that I can actually get them

50
00:02:49.880 --> 00:02:53.870
onto the project planning and that's what
we're actually going to take a look at.

51
00:02:53.870 --> 00:02:54.490
Okay?

52
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:58.320
So let's go ahead and
jump right in, and here it is.

53
00:02:58.320 --> 00:03:02.560
I've got my diagram up so
that we can take a look at resource

54
00:03:02.560 --> 00:03:05.050
management planning
components that we have.

55
00:03:05.050 --> 00:03:06.050
And the first.

56
00:03:06.050 --> 00:03:08.270
Oops, now that's a little bit unusual.

57
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:11.850
The first aspect of this that
we're gonna take a look at then

58
00:03:11.850 --> 00:03:17.300
is gonna be up here where it says,
identify existing resource availability.

59
00:03:17.300 --> 00:03:21.310
Now, when we start to talk about
something like that, right?

60
00:03:21.310 --> 00:03:26.140
The very fact is, as like what we said,
you can try and assume that

61
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:30.760
all this is gonna be ready by the time
that your project actually begins.

62
00:03:30.760 --> 00:03:34.410
But what you need to do is go ahead and
start planning out and figuring out

63
00:03:34.410 --> 00:03:39.090
whether or not that resource is in
existence right now and can you get it?

64
00:03:39.090 --> 00:03:42.010
Okay, and that is a key thing, right?

65
00:03:42.010 --> 00:03:45.920
If you're gonna start scheduling and start
trying to figure out how your project is

66
00:03:45.920 --> 00:03:49.320
gonna work, you need to make sure
that you have on hand what you need.

67
00:03:49.320 --> 00:03:53.180
And the first one that we always
talk about is just human resources.

68
00:03:53.180 --> 00:03:56.330
This one is, by far,
the one that can be very difficult for

69
00:03:56.330 --> 00:04:01.070
you to get or very easy, depending on
where you are located in the world.

70
00:04:01.070 --> 00:04:04.300
And it's easy enough to give

71
00:04:04.300 --> 00:04:08.020
We're here in Gainesville, Florida and
as we're here creating more and

72
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:12.170
more shows, we're starting to find
out from our members that hey,

73
00:04:12.170 --> 00:04:14.260
here's the shows that they want us to do.

74
00:04:14.260 --> 00:04:18.660
Well I hate to say it,
as brilliant as Daniel and

75
00:04:18.660 --> 00:04:21.995
I really are, and I'm kinda joking on
that to a point, but Daniel's brilliant.

76
00:04:21.995 --> 00:04:24.150
>> [LAUGH]
>> But as brilliant as he is,

77
00:04:24.150 --> 00:04:26.880
there are some topics that he's
not very comfortable with.

78
00:04:26.880 --> 00:04:29.210
There's a ton of topics
I'm not comfortable with.

79
00:04:29.210 --> 00:04:32.390
We're trying to find out best
subject matter experts that we can

80
00:04:32.390 --> 00:04:33.440
bring on the show.

81
00:04:33.440 --> 00:04:36.930
Daniel's actually got one coming up

82
00:04:36.930 --> 00:04:40.990
That we can find but sometimes you might
find out in the area that you live in

83
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:44.580
those experts are few and far in
between and so you'd have to be able to

84
00:04:44.580 --> 00:04:47.820
move outside of that particular
comfort zone of where you are.

85
00:04:47.820 --> 00:04:52.250
But if we were maybe in
a larger metropolitan area,

86
00:04:52.250 --> 00:04:56.904
in a larger city where those people did
really exist and tend to work towards,

87
00:04:56.904 --> 00:05:00.545
it might be a lot easier for us to get
those types of human resources, right?

88
00:05:00.545 --> 00:05:01.060
>> Mm-hm.

89
00:05:01.060 --> 00:05:03.920
>> So, availability is really important if
we're gonna start to actually trying to

90
00:05:03.920 --> 00:05:05.330
plan out for human resources, right?

91
00:05:05.330 --> 00:05:09.090
>> Yeah definitely, the larger
the population the more likely it is that

92
00:05:09.090 --> 00:05:12.140
you're gonna be able to find someone
with the skill sets necessary for

93
00:05:12.140 --> 00:05:14.380
you to lean on their expertise.

94
00:05:14.380 --> 00:05:18.620
That's just kind of statistical
analysis right there in your face.

95
00:05:18.620 --> 00:05:19.980
Not much you can do about that.

96
00:05:19.980 --> 00:05:23.820
When you go to a place where
there aren't very many people,

97
00:05:23.820 --> 00:05:27.800
well then the probability runs low that
you're gonna find that person that you

98
00:05:27.800 --> 00:05:30.510
need to be that expert for your project.

99
00:05:30.510 --> 00:05:33.030
But they are a great, great resource.

100
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:38.465
And probably one of the ones you
want to give emphasis to, right?

101
00:05:38.465 --> 00:05:40.310
>> Mm-hm.
>> You wanna make sure that you have

102
00:05:40.310 --> 00:05:43.080
experts in this field
guiding your decisions

103
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:45.850
in the project cuz it's really gonna
help the project move forward.

104
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:49.370
>> Yeah, and finding them available

105
00:05:49.370 --> 00:05:49.960
Don't just say,

106
00:05:49.960 --> 00:05:53.490
hey, I need you right now unless you
really need the person right now.

107
00:05:53.490 --> 00:05:56.995
You may need to go out and plan out with
them that what we'd like to do is actually

108
00:05:56.995 --> 00:06:01.110
get you on our project for,
beginning in July, okay.

109
00:06:01.110 --> 00:06:05.670
And even though right now it's March, and
the time that we're actually recording

110
00:06:05.670 --> 00:06:10.070
this episode, we may go ahead and say,
Look, we'd love to get you on in July.

111
00:06:10.070 --> 00:06:13.150
We're just trying to figure out
your availability right now.

112
00:06:13.150 --> 00:06:17.590
And that is part of understanding
that the person or the expert or

113
00:06:17.590 --> 00:06:20.140
whoever you're talking about
in terms of human resources.

114
00:06:20.140 --> 00:06:23.240
What if they're available now, but
they're not available in July?

115
00:06:23.240 --> 00:06:27.700
So trying to figure that out is a big
part of planning for human resources, is

116
00:06:27.700 --> 00:06:32.160
scheduling and coordinating, and figuring
out how that stuff is gonna get there.

117
00:06:32.160 --> 00:06:33.810
Are they the right expert?

118
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:39.660
Sometimes we can get a little bit
confused in this sense that we believe,

119
00:06:39.660 --> 00:06:43.040
we know exactly what expert
we think that we need, and

120
00:06:43.040 --> 00:06:45.670
then you start talking to them and
you realize something.

121
00:06:45.670 --> 00:06:49.130
That's not the expert that you need, and
then you have to go to someone else and

122
00:06:49.130 --> 00:06:50.850
that does happen sometimes.

123
00:06:50.850 --> 00:06:53.510
When you are actually trying
to build something you go,

124
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:54.660
here's the expert that I need.

125
00:06:54.660 --> 00:06:56.160
And then you talk to them on the phone for

126
00:06:56.160 --> 00:06:59.240
a half an hour and they kinda go,
yeah, you don't need me.

127
00:06:59.240 --> 00:07:01.230
You need this type of person.

128
00:07:01.230 --> 00:07:06.270
And that really did happen to use here at
ITProTV Studios is that we've had, and

129
00:07:06.270 --> 00:07:10.900
I don't wanna say issues, but we thought
that what we needed is this type of expert

130
00:07:10.900 --> 00:07:14.460
to help us out in making sure
that what we're doing looks good,

131
00:07:14.460 --> 00:07:16.280
sounds good, does everything that we need.

132
00:07:16.280 --> 00:07:19.980
And so, we essentially want to look for
that particular type of expert.

133
00:07:19.980 --> 00:07:24.300
Well, it actually took one of those
experts to say, what you're really looking

134
00:07:24.300 --> 00:07:27.600
for though, because you actually have a
lot of different systems that have to work

00:07:27.600 --> 00:07:31.500
together is what, is you're looking for

someone that can actually show you
how all that stuff comes together and

that was the last thing that

00:07:37.960 --> 00:07:42.240
And so where does that comes from, it
doesn't come from a lack of trying, right?

00:07:42.240 --> 00:07:45.237
It comes from at that point a lack

00:07:45.237 --> 00:07:48.462
here's this system, here's this system,
here's this system,

141
00:07:48.462 --> 00:07:51.649
we knew about those systems,

00:07:51.649 --> 00:07:53.456

00:07:53.456 --> 00:07:57.526

00:07:57.526 --> 00:08:00.578
here's how these things

00:08:00.578 --> 00:08:01.083
And so,

00:08:01.083 --> 00:08:05.648
you may actually find yourself having

00:08:05.648 --> 00:08:09.837
So as far as human resources go, we need

00:08:09.837 --> 00:08:12.774

the person with the right expertise and

00:08:12.774 --> 00:08:16.340

00:08:16.340 --> 00:08:20.060
If not, what are you willing to do

00:08:20.060 --> 00:08:21.050
Is there anything you can do?

00:08:21.050 --> 00:08:24.366
You might find out there's nothing you

00:08:24.366 --> 00:08:26.631
matter expert or

00:08:26.631 --> 00:08:30.880
But it may be that you just need another

00:08:30.880 --> 00:08:33.400
But you gotta figure out,
in terms of human resources,

00:08:33.400 --> 00:08:35.500
what is the availability that you have?

00:08:35.500 --> 00:08:36.910
Do you need more people?

What if you realize that for 10 weeks

00:08:41.350 --> 00:08:46.180

00:08:46.180 --> 00:08:49.480
You can't go a day without

00:08:49.480 --> 00:08:51.970
So you may find out that there's no way.

00:08:51.970 --> 00:08:56.258
In the area that you live in, you might be

00:08:56.258 --> 00:08:58.050
you needed 200 to make it work.

164
00:08:58.050 --> 00:09:01.110
Well, now you start having

00:09:01.110 --> 00:09:04.380
So dealing with human
resources is a big issue.

00:09:04.380 --> 00:09:07.030
Understanding that this is what

00:09:07.030 --> 00:09:08.560
their availability.

00:09:08.560 --> 00:09:12.020
The other one, of course,

00:09:12.020 --> 00:09:16.900
Now it's nice when you end up working for

need for a construction project.

00:09:21.510 --> 00:09:25.190
If they own it and

00:09:25.190 --> 00:09:29.610
But Daniel's worked in

00:09:29.610 --> 00:09:33.100
there isn't a possibility that two

Should I get two excavators

That's the kind of things

00:10:07.200 --> 00:10:08.752

00:10:08.752 --> 00:10:13.080
Again, going back to that

00:10:13.080 --> 00:10:14.600

00:10:14.600 --> 00:10:18.400
But as you grow in experience and you lean

00:10:21.850 --> 00:10:25.780

00:10:25.780 --> 00:10:27.510
But we all need equipment,

00:10:27.510 --> 00:10:30.330
otherwise we're not gonna get very

00:10:30.330 --> 00:10:32.460
>> Right, so

00:10:42.890 --> 00:10:44.680
I might need it on Monday, but

00:10:44.680 --> 00:10:48.020
what if that excavator's

00:10:48.020 --> 00:10:50.180
And it doesn't matter how

00:10:53.190 --> 00:10:56.700
In other words, we don't have the

00:10:56.700 --> 00:11:00.880
Well, now this is where you have to start

00:11:00.880 --> 00:11:04.810

00:11:04.810 --> 00:11:07.280
Do I need to go and look for

00:11:07.280 --> 00:11:10.240

00:11:10.240 --> 00:11:13.521
So when you start talking

00:11:13.521 --> 00:11:17.961

00:11:17.961 --> 00:11:21.442

00:11:21.442 --> 00:11:25.440

00:11:25.440 --> 00:11:29.188
My plan doesn't start or my project

00:11:29.188 --> 00:11:30.584

00:11:30.584 --> 00:11:33.340
And then sometimes you might be able to,

00:11:33.340 --> 00:11:36.900
but how do you know until that

00:11:36.900 --> 00:11:40.170

00:11:40.170 --> 00:11:43.540
So that's where you are managing now for
contingencies and

00:11:43.540 --> 00:11:47.820
things like that to happen,
to actually think about as well.

00:11:47.820 --> 00:11:49.730
The other one that we also wanna mention,

00:11:49.730 --> 00:11:54.000

Consumables and stuff like this are part

00:11:59.420 --> 00:12:02.400
because, once again,
when we actually do end up working for

00:12:02.400 --> 00:12:06.820

00:12:06.820 --> 00:12:10.480
we simply assume that those

00:12:10.480 --> 00:12:13.212
But remember that supplies that

00:12:13.212 --> 00:12:18.080

00:12:18.080 --> 00:12:21.590

00:12:21.590 --> 00:12:23.750

00:12:23.750 --> 00:12:27.790
So the idea here that I've put is just
regular supplies as you start thinking

00:12:27.790 --> 00:12:30.300
about it, things that you
just don't think about doing.

00:12:30.300 --> 00:12:33.590
So let's say that we go back

Even if I have that equipment

Well, I might realize that I don't have

Well, what am I supposed to do?

00:12:59.590 --> 00:13:03.290
So you need to make sure that if

00:13:03.290 --> 00:13:04.940

00:13:04.940 --> 00:13:07.855
If it tells you ten hours

To actually come to that point and

00:13:26.160 --> 00:13:29.110
And then when it comes out to addressing

00:13:39.990 --> 00:13:43.550
It says all resources go into

00:14:15.190 --> 00:14:18.070
And I remember being on

00:15:13.470 --> 00:15:17.986
Now the last couple of things we really

Now I didn't actually

But part of our management plan, though,

00:15:32.815 --> 00:15:34.648

00:15:34.648 --> 00:15:37.960

So you need to actually plan for that in

Are you actually gonna
take the time to do so, or

00:15:48.170 --> 00:15:50.120

00:15:50.120 --> 00:15:53.790
And it just depends on what

00:15:53.790 --> 00:15:57.500
If you're still in the planning stages and

set this up, that I knew that

00:16:00.550 --> 00:16:02.868
You go ahead and you set that up

You tell your team, here's two weeks of

00:16:06.785 --> 00:16:08.618

Well, then you go ahead and

00:16:10.218 --> 00:16:11.778
Or, and you may find out.

Here's a group of experts we can get in.

The cost is just about the same.

But these guys have done it before,

they're not learning it right after

00:16:20.610 --> 00:16:22.730
It just depends on what you also need.

00:16:22.730 --> 00:16:26.970
And of course, making sure that they have

00:16:26.970 --> 00:16:28.140
a look at here.

00:16:28.140 --> 00:16:33.160
So when you start to see stuff like this,

That you're actually

you're saying that you are considering

00:16:42.740 --> 00:16:46.900

00:16:53.930 --> 00:16:57.510
here, so that we can understand things,

00:16:57.510 --> 00:17:00.160
Daniel if you and
I ended up working on a project, and

let's say that we took a look at it and

And then I said all right Daniel,

Well that means that we may not

00:17:20.850 --> 00:17:22.560

00:17:22.560 --> 00:17:24.460
But that doesn't mean

00:17:24.460 --> 00:17:27.050
It means that there are tools

00:17:27.050 --> 00:17:30.060

00:17:30.060 --> 00:17:32.190
So, one of those tools

00:17:32.190 --> 00:17:34.480

Is what we call a RAM, okay.

Now, when we start talking about

Is that you may come up with

Let's say that Daniel and

00:19:12.510 --> 00:19:15.740
And at that point the key here is this, so

358
00:19:15.740 --> 00:19:18.520
that you can see it as you
start planning this out.

359
00:19:18.520 --> 00:19:22.360
And what we want to do is we want to
use this grid that we've made here, and

360
00:19:22.360 --> 00:19:26.400
we want the number of resources that we
believe we're gonna need per work package.

361
00:19:26.400 --> 00:19:30.450
So it might be on this first work package
here that we are really trying to set up

362
00:19:30.450 --> 00:19:31.280
the actual server.

363
00:19:31.280 --> 00:19:35.880
And so let's say that I know that I need
one person to work on the server, okay.

364
00:19:35.880 --> 00:19:38.200
And then at that point that might be all.

365
00:19:38.200 --> 00:19:41.860
So in that work package, it may just
be one person, okay, to set that up.

366
00:19:41.860 --> 00:19:44.290
But then as we continue on,

367
00:19:44.290 --> 00:19:49.240
I may realize that this particular
designer is, I may need,

368
00:19:49.240 --> 00:19:54.500
let's say, two different designers here
to work along with somebody in marketing.

369
00:19:54.500 --> 00:19:59.220
And then also, in copyrighting
at that particular point, okay.

370
00:19:59.220 --> 00:20:01.880
So, now when you start to
take a look at your project,

371
00:20:01.880 --> 00:20:04.130
notice what's starting to happen.

372
00:20:04.130 --> 00:20:09.890
I can start adding up how many resources
do I really need on my project.

373
00:20:09.890 --> 00:20:12.280
And at this point, it's human resources.

374
00:20:12.280 --> 00:20:16.210
You can continue to do this on with
other work materials that you have.

375
00:20:16.210 --> 00:20:21.241
But you're essentially just
going down through here and

376
00:20:21.241 --> 00:20:25.957
you're starting to realize
that you might need three

377
00:20:25.957 --> 00:20:30.586
programmers here and
then a user interface tester.

378
00:20:30.586 --> 00:20:33.220
And let's say that we need
to test a server again.

379
00:20:33.220 --> 00:20:34.930
That letter q's getting in the way.

380
00:20:34.930 --> 00:20:36.540
And so now you start adding it up.

381
00:20:36.540 --> 00:20:40.950
At the end of your project,
you have a general scope.

382
00:20:40.950 --> 00:20:43.700
I'm not telling you it's exact,
but you have at least a general

383
00:20:43.700 --> 00:20:48.400
idea that you're gonna need 15 people at
some point if you count up all of these.

384
00:20:48.400 --> 00:20:52.980
And some of them you'll reuse again, but
that way you can at least see as far

385
00:20:52.980 --> 00:20:57.910
as responsibilities go, how many resources
that you will need on your project.

386
00:20:57.910 --> 00:21:01.070
So, it's a great beginning, and
I'm not saying it's anything else.

387
00:21:01.070 --> 00:21:03.900
But, it's a great beginning for
you, though,

388
00:21:03.900 --> 00:21:09.060
to be able to plan out the resources
that you will need on your project.

389
00:21:09.060 --> 00:21:11.240
So, a starting point,
it's not really anything else,

390
00:21:11.240 --> 00:21:12.790
to give you detailed analysis.

391
00:21:12.790 --> 00:21:16.440
>> It just keeps you from throwing out the
wild guess of, how many people is it gonna

392
00:21:16.440 --> 00:21:20.360
take for us to build this website Well,
it could be 30 people and

393
00:21:20.360 --> 00:21:25.210
obviously from looking this, generally
that would probably be way too much.

394
00:21:25.210 --> 00:21:27.540
But if I said five that
would be way too little.

395
00:21:27.540 --> 00:21:31.990
If you don't have a good idea of where to
begin, using something like this is going

396
00:21:31.990 --> 00:21:34.990
to help you get that,
like Ronnie said, that starting point.

397
00:21:34.990 --> 00:21:38.890
It's a good place to start, and
then you can adjust as necessary.

398
00:21:38.890 --> 00:21:41.940
Ronnie, is there any other way that
we can accomplish the same goal?

399
00:21:41.940 --> 00:21:45.760
>> There really is, and this is actually
once you get into specifics, to actually

400
00:21:45.760 --> 00:21:50.190
figure out how many you're going to need,
maybe for a single work package as well.

401
00:21:50.190 --> 00:21:54.370
And there's something that we can actually
do that we call a RACI or a RACI or

402
00:21:54.370 --> 00:21:56.630
whatever you want to call it and
this stands for,

403
00:21:56.630 --> 00:22:00.080
like it says down here in my legend,
on the lower left-hand-corner.

404
00:22:00.080 --> 00:22:04.890
Responsible, Accountable,
Consult and Inform, okay.

405
00:22:04.890 --> 00:22:07.300
So when I have different people now,

406
00:22:07.300 --> 00:22:12.380
and let's say that here is my website
project development team for right now.

407
00:22:12.380 --> 00:22:16.140
Aaron, Rob, Tyler, Thomas, and
Angie, and they're actually there.

408
00:22:16.140 --> 00:22:20.980
And here are the actual different work
packages that I might have going on.

409
00:22:20.980 --> 00:22:24.360
Well, what I can do,
is now I can actually start to say,

410
00:22:24.360 --> 00:22:26.780
all right,
what work needs to be assigned here?

411
00:22:26.780 --> 00:22:30.850
And I can give a very generic term,
right, is what I can do.

412
00:22:30.850 --> 00:22:33.290
So R, of course, stands for responsible.

413
00:22:33.290 --> 00:22:36.720
The one who actually is going
to do the work that we need.

414
00:22:36.720 --> 00:22:40.810
And A is the one who actually signs
off on the work, the accountable here.

415
00:22:40.810 --> 00:22:43.530
The C on consulting is
the one who has input,

416
00:22:43.530 --> 00:22:47.310
maybe on making sure that that work
is done the way that it needs to.

417
00:22:47.310 --> 00:22:50.750
And, of course, the I is to inform and
this is the person that needs to be

418
00:22:50.750 --> 00:22:55.380
informed at the end of
the package that we have.

419
00:22:55.380 --> 00:22:58.560
So we might actually end up finding out
such as the SEO and marketing list,

420
00:22:58.560 --> 00:23:03.770
say that Erin is actually responsible
then for that particular package.

421
00:23:03.770 --> 00:23:06.930
And then, once we have that,
at this point,

422
00:23:06.930 --> 00:23:10.560
Erin watch his finished with the SEO and
the marketing of this site.

423
00:23:10.560 --> 00:23:14.100
We may say that, hey,
at this point, the accountability

424
00:23:14.100 --> 00:23:17.610
she's supposed to report to Rob,
this is what's gonna happen.

425
00:23:17.610 --> 00:23:22.300
And then Thomas is actually going
to be the consultant here, and

426
00:23:22.300 --> 00:23:27.410
then in the end here once
the work is about to be performed

427
00:23:28.800 --> 00:23:32.205
Angie is actually suppose
to be informed here.

428
00:23:32.205 --> 00:23:36.790
Yu're trying to figure out, okay so in
this work package of marketing and SEO, or

429
00:23:36.790 --> 00:23:39.000
whatever the job role,
is here's what has to happen.

430
00:23:39.000 --> 00:23:41.650
Erin's goes to be responsible for
doing the work.

431
00:23:41.650 --> 00:23:44.540
Angie is going to be told when
the work is actually going to be done.

432
00:23:44.540 --> 00:23:46.410
Rob going to be told when it's finished.

433
00:23:46.410 --> 00:23:49.340
Thomas is the one that Erin consults.

434
00:23:49.340 --> 00:23:51.180
Well this again,
is planning your resources.

435
00:23:51.180 --> 00:23:55.490
So, Erin doesn't say, well Daniel,
who am I suppose to ask about this?

436
00:23:55.490 --> 00:23:59.494
And Daniel's going, maybe, I don't know.

437
00:23:59.494 --> 00:24:02.945
In the end, he can now flip over
to something like this and say,

438
00:24:02.945 --> 00:24:05.746
well, from what I see is
that you are supposed to let

439
00:24:05.746 --> 00:24:10.006
Rob know when you're done with work,
but if you need help, consult Thomas.

440
00:24:10.006 --> 00:24:13.828
And so it makes it easier in any
of these for you to go down and

441
00:24:13.828 --> 00:24:17.970
make it even a little bit more manageable,
and this helps who?

442
00:24:17.970 --> 00:24:21.220
It helps the resource out,
the human resource, they go,

443
00:24:21.220 --> 00:24:23.600
whatever resource it is,
where it's supposed to go and

444
00:24:23.600 --> 00:24:27.790
what it's supposed to do, and
also lets them know what is the action?

445
00:24:27.790 --> 00:24:31.170
What is the plan that's gonna happen
when you start seeing a matrix like

446
00:24:31.170 --> 00:24:32.480
this as well?

447
00:24:32.480 --> 00:24:35.150
So understanding that this
stuff can really help you out.

448
00:24:35.150 --> 00:24:39.630
Especially when you're not exactly sure
about a package that needs to be done.

449
00:24:39.630 --> 00:24:42.870
You go and consult and
then you start making this work out here.

450
00:24:42.870 --> 00:24:45.890
And that way you as a project manager,
you're not just guessing.

451
00:24:45.890 --> 00:24:50.140
I think Aaron was supposed to tell
so-and-so, you know, who knows.

452
00:24:50.140 --> 00:24:52.470
But you can now should go and
flip through there and

453
00:24:52.470 --> 00:24:55.650
figure it out very easily,
part of actually understanding management.

454
00:24:55.650 --> 00:24:58.600
Last thing that I wanna say
about the idea of, especially

455
00:24:58.600 --> 00:25:02.390
of human resource management, is that you
don't have to get as detailed as I did,

456
00:25:02.390 --> 00:25:05.830
which is to list actual names of people.

457
00:25:05.830 --> 00:25:09.770
You can, but overall though what we're
really looking for is some job role,

458
00:25:09.770 --> 00:25:11.090
some job title.

459
00:25:11.090 --> 00:25:14.430
And that way you can switch them on and
off whoever you want to.

460
00:25:14.430 --> 00:25:17.140
In a small organization,
you'll probably list them by name.

461
00:25:17.140 --> 00:25:20.090
The reason why is I remember the names a
lot easier than I remember what their job

462
00:25:20.090 --> 00:25:23.690
titles so, but in a larger organization

463
00:25:23.690 --> 00:25:27.840
being able to actually say this is who you
report to and here's their job title, it's

464
00:25:27.840 --> 00:25:31.850
probably going to be a lot easier than
you trying to memorize everybody’s named.

465
00:25:31.850 --> 00:25:33.400
Is it a good thing to do, sure.

466
00:25:33.400 --> 00:25:34.610
Do you have the time to do it?

467
00:25:34.610 --> 00:25:36.030
You may, you may not.

468
00:25:36.030 --> 00:25:39.890
But overall though,
you don’t have to get super specific then.

469
00:25:39.890 --> 00:25:42.060
I just did because it was
a fairly small project.

470
00:25:42.060 --> 00:25:44.660
But just kind of realize
that human resource planning

471
00:25:44.660 --> 00:25:48.080
is a big part of all sets
of things that we do.

472
00:25:48.080 --> 00:25:50.110
When we actually now have
to start figuring out

473
00:25:50.110 --> 00:25:51.710
how many people are working
on our project.

474
00:25:51.710 --> 00:25:53.980
What are their jobs and
their responsibilities?

475
00:25:53.980 --> 00:25:55.530
We can work it out in this way.

476
00:25:55.530 --> 00:25:56.830
>> Ronnie I really like those tools.

477
00:25:56.830 --> 00:26:00.230
They are very, very valuable, especially
like when you said we don't have

478
00:26:00.230 --> 00:26:04.450
a great idea of where or how to start or
how to start moving our people around and

479
00:26:04.450 --> 00:26:08.390
allocating those resources in places where
they may be needed or may not be needed.

480
00:26:08.390 --> 00:26:12.140
They just give us at least some idea,
a start that we can tighten up later.

481
00:26:12.140 --> 00:26:16.470
This is always in flux, we can always
change these things as we see and

482
00:26:16.470 --> 00:26:18.830
as we need, as we go through our project.

483
00:26:18.830 --> 00:26:20.250
And Ronnie, you did a great job.

484
00:26:20.250 --> 00:26:24.750
This is something I will actually, I think
everyone will use regardless of whether or

485
00:26:24.750 --> 00:26:25.781
not they are taking Project +.

486
00:26:25.781 --> 00:26:26.438
It's great tools.

487
00:26:26.438 --> 00:26:28.392
Thank you so much for stopping by and

488
00:26:28.392 --> 00:26:31.520
filling our heads full of
great Project + knowledge.

489
00:26:31.520 --> 00:26:33.180
Hopefully you guys got a lot out of that.

490
00:26:33.180 --> 00:26:36.650
That being said though, we have come to

00:26:36.650 --> 00:26:38.080
Again, hopefully you got a lot out of it.

492
00:26:38.080 --> 00:26:40.692
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off though from IT Pro TV.

493
00:26:40.692 --> 00:26:41.911

00:26:41.911 --> 00:26:42.650
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

495
00:26:42.650 --> 00:26:44.446

00:26:44.446 --> 00:26:52.630

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie identify and discuss the components of a quality management plan. Specifically, they explain the Quality Assurance(QA) processes, the Quality Control(QC) processes, and then show you how to measure your quality by using different metrics.
episodes.title: Plan Quality Mangement
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.138 --> 00:00:16.665
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPRO.TV.

3
00:00:16.665 --> 00:00:19.678
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.678 --> 00:00:22.960
well we're continuing on
with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.960 --> 00:00:25.570
Joining us back in the studio
today to lend his expertise

6
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:28.830
on that very topic is our good friend and
mentor Mister Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:30.270
Ronnie welcome back to the show Sir.

8
00:00:30.270 --> 00:00:30.970
>> Well thank you for

9
00:00:30.970 --> 00:00:35.733
having me back on the show as we
continue on taking CompTIAs Project+.

10
00:00:35.733 --> 00:00:40.162
And today we're delving in to the realm
of what we call quality control or

11
00:00:40.162 --> 00:00:41.420
quality management.

12
00:00:41.420 --> 00:00:45.491
And what we're talking about is not
necessarily all the things that provide

13
00:00:45.491 --> 00:00:49.624
for that, but how do we tend to manage
this and how do we plan to actually manage

14
00:00:49.624 --> 00:00:53.966
our quality controls and our quality
assurances is what we're taking a look at.

15
00:00:53.966 --> 00:00:57.201
So it's something that's
actually very important for

16
00:00:57.201 --> 00:01:01.741
us especially when we start doing projects
because a project can be assigned to

17
00:01:01.741 --> 00:01:04.037
us and we know what the deliverable is.

18
00:01:04.037 --> 00:01:08.980
But remember that the deliverable,
if I can say it right, the deliverable,

19
00:01:08.980 --> 00:01:11.489
or the product of whatever the result is

20
00:01:11.489 --> 00:01:16.590
from that project needs to be able
to meet a certain level of standard.

21
00:01:16.590 --> 00:01:17.330
It's not enough, and

22
00:01:17.330 --> 00:01:21.480
we've actually done this throughout
our entire manufacturing history here

23
00:01:21.480 --> 00:01:26.660
on the planet, is that it's not enough
just to say that we've produced something.

24
00:01:26.660 --> 00:01:28.670
We have to actually be able to
produce something that meets

25
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:30.220
a particular standard.

26
00:01:30.220 --> 00:01:32.520
We might actually take a look,
let's say for an example,

27
00:01:32.520 --> 00:01:36.420
in the automobile industry
here in the United States.

28
00:01:36.420 --> 00:01:41.560
In which when we talk about putting
a car out onto the road with hundreds or

29
00:01:41.560 --> 00:01:46.310
thousands of other vehicles out there,
it shouldn't actually be of such poor

30
00:01:46.310 --> 00:01:51.340
quality that the wheels fall off every
time we make a right turn or a left turn.

31
00:01:51.340 --> 00:01:54.500
So, there is some manufacturing
quality standard that

32
00:01:54.500 --> 00:01:58.820
all these vehicles go by that run on
the roads here in the United States,

33
00:01:58.820 --> 00:02:00.820
in which they met a certain quality.

34
00:02:00.820 --> 00:02:04.760
And we all demand it even in
other products that we buy.

35
00:02:04.760 --> 00:02:09.300
Let's take for an example the idea
of something just like a laptop or

36
00:02:09.300 --> 00:02:11.310
a TV that you might buy.

37
00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:14.886
The very fact is Daniel if you spent
several hundred dollars on a TV,

38
00:02:14.886 --> 00:02:18.036
I'm pretty sure you're expecting
some level of quality.

39
00:02:18.036 --> 00:02:21.853
You're not expecting some particular box
that really isn't gonna meet up to your

40
00:02:21.853 --> 00:02:22.859
standards, right?

41
00:02:22.859 --> 00:02:26.130
>> Yeah, no, I expect if I spend
a certain amount of money,

42
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:29.330
to get a certain level of quality for
that money.

43
00:02:29.330 --> 00:02:32.050
If it's a high level of money well
then I expect a high level of quality.

44
00:02:32.050 --> 00:02:35.780
If it's a lower level of money [COUGH]
excuse me, well then I expect what?

45
00:02:35.780 --> 00:02:40.530
A lower level of quality because as the
old saying goes, you get what you pay for.

46
00:02:40.530 --> 00:02:43.970
Now when we come into it
as far as doing a project,

47
00:02:43.970 --> 00:02:46.990
we have to ascertain what is the level
of quality that is expected.

48
00:02:46.990 --> 00:02:48.880
And that's kinda what
we're diving in today.

49
00:02:48.880 --> 00:02:49.620
Right, Ronnie?

50
00:02:49.620 --> 00:02:50.240
>> It really is.

51
00:02:50.240 --> 00:02:53.140
The very fact that as we understand
something about the way that

52
00:02:53.140 --> 00:02:56.860
quality ends up working through
a manufacturing process.

53
00:02:56.860 --> 00:03:01.080
Quality can be lessened very easily,
when people take their eye off the ball.

54
00:03:01.080 --> 00:03:03.160
In other words, they don't know
what they're measuring for.

55
00:03:03.160 --> 00:03:07.620
All they look for is the end result and
they go look, it looks exactly like

56
00:03:07.620 --> 00:03:11.640
what it should be, but maybe all the
components inside aren't actually meeting

57
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:15.060
up to the standards in which they
were designed to actually be used in.

58
00:03:15.060 --> 00:03:19.140
So when you have something like that
you hate to pick on certain things but

59
00:03:19.140 --> 00:03:23.660
let's say that you go to one of those
wholesale tool outlet places, right?

60
00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:26.690
And you go and
you buy certain things from there.

61
00:03:26.690 --> 00:03:32.350
As long as you're probably gonna use them
once or twice or not on a regular basis,

62
00:03:32.350 --> 00:03:37.070
those types of tools will end up
probably serving you just fine.

63
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:41.300
But Daniel, if you and I were actually on
a construction site, and I were to hand

64
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:46.200
you, let's say like a one and a half inch
wrench, and I told you, hey this came

65
00:03:46.200 --> 00:03:50.120
from the discount tool quality here's
the one you're gonna be using each and

66
00:03:50.120 --> 00:03:56.000
every day to turn these gigantic,
this inch and a half nut, on everything.

67
00:03:56.000 --> 00:03:58.470
You'd probably look at me a little
bit strange, wouldn't you?

68
00:03:58.470 --> 00:04:02.364
>> Yeah I'm gonna say, Ronnie this is
probably not the best tool for this job.

69
00:04:02.364 --> 00:04:07.490
Cuz as I start to torque down
those giant sized nuts and

70
00:04:07.490 --> 00:04:11.360
bolts whats gonna happen, well that wrench
is probably gonna break on me because its

71
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:13.789
quality isn't up to the job, right.

72
00:04:13.789 --> 00:04:17.850
I need something that's going to
be durable and gonna last me for

73
00:04:17.850 --> 00:04:20.890
more than just a few turns
of just a few bolts.

74
00:04:20.890 --> 00:04:24.330
It's great, like Ronny said, basically
you're kind of, you're paying a lot less

75
00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:28.530
money to get something that you're
basically renting for five or

76
00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:30.115
six times that you get to use it.

77
00:04:30.115 --> 00:04:31.180
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or however many times it

78
00:04:31.180 --> 00:04:33.330
goes beyond that, you really got a deal.
