00:28:32.885 --> 00:28:36.697
You have to be checking your
progress as you go for that quality,

524
00:28:36.697 --> 00:28:39.570
that it's meeting a certain standard.

525
00:28:39.570 --> 00:28:43.040
Or by the time it gets to the last
person that's inspecting it, suddenly,

526
00:28:43.040 --> 00:28:45.250
they're gonna go, this is horrible.

527
00:28:45.250 --> 00:28:46.700
Nobody checked anything on this.

528
00:28:46.700 --> 00:28:48.970
I'm going back to
the example of the guitars.

529
00:28:48.970 --> 00:28:52.700
I was watching a factory tour of them
building guitars and their process.

530
00:28:52.700 --> 00:28:55.080
They said that every person
that handles the guitar.

531
00:28:55.080 --> 00:28:57.335
So I go from sanding the bodies down.

532
00:28:57.335 --> 00:29:00.910
Well, the guy that's gonna stain the body,
he inspects the guy that sanded it

533
00:29:00.910 --> 00:29:03.170
to make sure that it was sanded
to the correct specifications.

534
00:29:03.170 --> 00:29:05.240
If it doesn't,
he sends it back to the sander.

535
00:29:05.240 --> 00:29:08.590
And when it comes back, he inspects
it again and then he stains it.

536
00:29:08.590 --> 00:29:11.210
Well then, he sends that onto
the guy that puts the clear coat,

537
00:29:11.210 --> 00:29:12.354
the top coat on top of it.

538
00:29:12.354 --> 00:29:15.264
Well that guy is gonna inspect the
standard to make sure that the staining

539
00:29:15.264 --> 00:29:16.462
process was done correctly.

540
00:29:16.462 --> 00:29:20.390
If there's any light spots or
too dark or whatever, he sends it back.

541
00:29:20.390 --> 00:29:23.700
There's that quality control all
the way through the process.

542
00:29:23.700 --> 00:29:27.200
So by the time it gets to that exiter,
he's looking at this thing going,

543
00:29:27.200 --> 00:29:28.410
man my job is easy.

544
00:29:28.410 --> 00:29:32.545
Everything's been inspected so
many times that this is a fine instrument.

545
00:29:32.545 --> 00:29:35.140
It should have no quality issues.

546
00:29:35.140 --> 00:29:37.810
But he's still there,
he still has a job to check and

547
00:29:37.810 --> 00:29:40.350
verify like we always used to say, right?

548
00:29:40.350 --> 00:29:41.786
Trust, yet verify everything.

549
00:29:41.786 --> 00:29:43.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> Is done correctly.

550
00:29:43.740 --> 00:29:47.230
Ronnie, lots of cool stuff when it comes
to quality, something that we wanna pay

551
00:29:47.230 --> 00:29:50.900
attention to because we don't wanna
put our name on a bad product or

552
00:29:50.900 --> 00:29:55.170
a bad project that creates a bad product,
so something we wanna pay attention to.

553
00:29:55.170 --> 00:29:58.620
Thank you so much for explaining the
different ways in which we can do that.

554
00:29:58.620 --> 00:30:02.190
All the cool metrics that are out
there and the tools available for

555
00:30:02.190 --> 00:30:06.150
us to measure and
judge to make sure these things are right.

556
00:30:06.150 --> 00:30:07.582
And that being said,
we thank you for watching us.

557
00:30:07.582 --> 00:30:10.380
Well, looks like we've come to
the end of another great episode.

558
00:30:10.380 --> 00:30:12.930
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie

559
00:30:12.930 --> 00:30:13.710
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

560
00:30:13.710 --> 00:30:15.661
>> We'll see you next time.

561
00:30:15.661 --> 00:30:23.760
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie identify and discuss the components of a cost management plan. They begin by explaining Control Limits and Cost Estimates. Then they explain how to create a project budget. Finally they take a look at the idea of a Cost Baseline to measure and track actual project spending.
episodes.title: Plan Cost Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.097 --> 00:00:10.097
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.193 --> 00:00:14.064
>> All right, greetings everyone and

3
00:00:14.064 --> 00:00:16.690
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:18.740
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:18.740 --> 00:00:21.870
In today's episode,
we are moving on with our Project+ series.

6
00:00:21.870 --> 00:00:25.400
Joining us back in the studio again
today to help us out with a little bit

7
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:28.580
of cost management is our good friend and
mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

8
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:29.950
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

9
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:33.200
>> Well, thank you again for having me
back on the show as we continue on to take

10
00:00:33.200 --> 00:00:37.430
a look at more of
the Project+ from CompTIA.

11
00:00:37.430 --> 00:00:40.970
And today, we are actually
talking more about planning.

12
00:00:40.970 --> 00:00:43.050
So we've already said it before,
and I'll say it again,

13
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:46.260
now that we're a little bit
further into the series here.

14
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:48.440
The idea of planning for projects,

15
00:00:48.440 --> 00:00:51.870
right, is pretty much the longest
process that we do have.

16
00:00:51.870 --> 00:00:55.580
And it's by far the most
important thing that we do

17
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:58.990
is make sure that we plan these things
out before we ever spend a dollar.

18
00:00:58.990 --> 00:00:59.870
And so, this way,

19
00:00:59.870 --> 00:01:03.750
we absolutely can say that we've tried to
consider every thing that needs to go on.

20
00:01:03.750 --> 00:01:05.100
And try and keep an eye on it.

21
00:01:05.100 --> 00:01:09.460
And, of course, one of the most important
ideas here is gonna be planning out

22
00:01:09.460 --> 00:01:14.580
cost management, which is a big part
that we also need to do as a project.

23
00:01:14.580 --> 00:01:17.490
Remember that when we talk about
the triple constraints of a project, we're

24
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:22.630
normally constrained by time, by cost and,
of course, by the actual requirements.

25
00:01:22.630 --> 00:01:23.590
Now, in the previous episode,

26
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:26.940
we talked about the requirements a little
bit when we talked about planning for

27
00:01:26.940 --> 00:01:31.150
things like quality control or
quality management there.

28
00:01:31.150 --> 00:01:34.270
We also talked about time when we
talked about planning for scheduling.

29
00:01:34.270 --> 00:01:38.450
And so now we're hitting that row
third kind of overall constraint,

30
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:40.930
where we now talk about
the idea of planning for

31
00:01:40.930 --> 00:01:45.500
cost management, which is a big one for
us as well, okay.

32
00:01:45.500 --> 00:01:50.130
Now in this particular series,
right, as we go through, we're not

33
00:01:50.130 --> 00:01:53.750
really diving in to everything that
there is to know about cost management.

34
00:01:53.750 --> 00:01:55.150
I'm not an accountant.

35
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:59.430
I can't actually claim that I
do very well with my own funds.

36
00:01:59.430 --> 00:02:00.300
>> I'm no CPA.

37
00:02:00.300 --> 00:02:01.330
>> That's right, no CPA.

38
00:02:01.330 --> 00:02:04.040
I can't tell you that I manage it,
like I said.

39
00:02:04.040 --> 00:02:07.940
Heck, I don't even have ten dollars in my
wallet right now, and the reason is that,

40
00:02:07.940 --> 00:02:10.650
I can' even tell you where other
ten might have actually gone.

41
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:13.800
At some point, but what I can tell you,
though, as a project manager,

42
00:02:13.800 --> 00:02:16.430
is one of the key things that we need
to make sure that we understand and

43
00:02:16.430 --> 00:02:19.980
that we keep in control and
that we do plan for, of course,

44
00:02:19.980 --> 00:02:24.980
is the idea of spending money and how
is that money spent, where is it spent?

45
00:02:24.980 --> 00:02:26.670
Because all that has to be accounted for

46
00:02:26.670 --> 00:02:29.950
at the end of the project so
that what we can actually learn is,

47
00:02:29.950 --> 00:02:34.220
is the overall product that we created,
result, situation, issue,

48
00:02:34.220 --> 00:02:37.740
whatever it is that we created, was it
worth the money that we put into it.

49
00:02:37.740 --> 00:02:41.280
So, we really need to make sure that we
understand that everything that we do,

50
00:02:41.280 --> 00:02:44.360
especially in planning here,
and especially with the cost.

51
00:02:44.360 --> 00:02:47.040
We need to make sure that
we keep some account of it.

52
00:02:47.040 --> 00:02:51.650
So, depending on your level of experience,
and also depending on where

53
00:02:51.650 --> 00:02:55.970
you tend to work, some of this
is gonna be fairly easy for you.

54
00:02:55.970 --> 00:03:00.435
If you work for a larger company, that
already has a project management office

55
00:03:00.435 --> 00:03:04.760
setup, more than likely your project
is gonna be assigned an accountant, and

56
00:03:04.760 --> 00:03:08.330
they are pretty much going to say,
all right, here's the budget that's set.

57
00:03:08.330 --> 00:03:12.490
You and I need to sit down along with
the major stakeholders here and try and

58
00:03:12.490 --> 00:03:14.980
make sure that we put these
into the right locations,

59
00:03:14.980 --> 00:03:18.460
and make sure that everything's actually
divvied out the way that we need to.

60
00:03:18.460 --> 00:03:21.470
And make sure we get the authorization for
spending that we need to and

61
00:03:21.470 --> 00:03:22.300
everything else.

62
00:03:22.300 --> 00:03:25.130
And you're gonna do fine
with some of that happens.

63
00:03:25.130 --> 00:03:29.590
I know that this sounds almost fun Daniel,
but scary at the same time,

64
00:03:29.590 --> 00:03:35.120
is instead when some eye look at you goes,
here's $25,000 for the project.

65
00:03:35.120 --> 00:03:36.780
Make sure you spend it well.

66
00:03:36.780 --> 00:03:40.860
And then, you look back, and go, okay.

67
00:03:40.860 --> 00:03:42.925
And, the first thing on my mind, new car.

68
00:03:42.925 --> 00:03:44.580
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, and that shouldn't be.

69
00:03:44.580 --> 00:03:45.600
I'm joking with that.

70
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:48.820
But you kinda, get the idea that it
can be a little bit more daunting to,

71
00:03:48.820 --> 00:03:53.550
essentially, just say, here's the amount
of money, and just make sure you spend it

72
00:03:53.550 --> 00:03:56.400
on the project, and make sure you
account for it And don't get me wrong.

73
00:03:56.400 --> 00:03:58.300
There's a lot of projects
that are done that way and

74
00:03:58.300 --> 00:04:00.830
people are really good at
keeping track of a lot of that.

75
00:04:00.830 --> 00:04:02.490
But if you're actually on these major,

76
00:04:02.490 --> 00:04:05.760
gigantic projects where you're not talking
about just, let's say, $5,000 or $20,000.

77
00:04:05.760 --> 00:04:09.990
You're now starting to talk about
hundreds of thousands of dollars.

78
00:04:09.990 --> 00:04:13.190
Somebody at some accountant firm somewhere

79
00:04:13.190 --> 00:04:15.490
is gonna want you to be able
to keep account of that.

80
00:04:15.490 --> 00:04:16.810
And so we're just gonna go through and

81
00:04:16.810 --> 00:04:19.340
we're gonna talk about some of
the planning processes that we have to

82
00:04:19.340 --> 00:04:20.310
think about.

83
00:04:20.310 --> 00:04:23.670
When we actually start doing this, and
understand some of the major components

84
00:04:23.670 --> 00:04:29.790
inside of cost management plans that
we need to be able to identify as well.

85
00:04:29.790 --> 00:04:31.900
So, let's go ahead and take a look then.

86
00:04:31.900 --> 00:04:35.880
One of the very first components
that we need to think about overall

87
00:04:35.880 --> 00:04:37.630
is what we call control limits.

88
00:04:37.630 --> 00:04:39.770
Now that's a CompTIA term for

89
00:04:39.770 --> 00:04:43.260
CompTIA's Project+ that you need
to make sure that you know.

90
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:44.270
If you are getting ready for

91
00:04:44.270 --> 00:04:47.140
your PMP, you might hear the term
instead control thresholds.

92
00:04:47.140 --> 00:04:50.630
I wanna throw both of them out there,
cuz you never know on the exam which

93
00:04:50.630 --> 00:04:55.370
one they're ever actually going to
mention, and you might go, well why not?

94
00:04:55.370 --> 00:04:59.930
Well, because, remember that as the exam
continues on in its age, as they

95
00:04:59.930 --> 00:05:03.960
actually develop new questions and add
them into the pool of questions here, you

96
00:05:03.960 --> 00:05:07.575
don't know weather or not they're going to
use an older term, like the control limits

97
00:05:07.575 --> 00:05:10.606
that were actually around when
the first objectives were made.

98
00:05:10.606 --> 00:05:13.550
Or whether they're gonna say,
hey we want this to line up more and

99
00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:14.410
more with the PMP.

100
00:05:14.410 --> 00:05:17.240
So you might use the term
control thresholds.

101
00:05:17.240 --> 00:05:18.460
Both of those are actually going

102
00:05:18.460 --> 00:05:21.340
to be valid terms in what
we're talking about here.

103
00:05:21.340 --> 00:05:24.230
Now what does this really mean when
we start talking about the idea of

104
00:05:24.230 --> 00:05:26.700
control limits for our costs?

105
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:29.950
What we're really talking
about is what I have here.

106
00:05:29.950 --> 00:05:32.720
The percentage deviation
from the baseline costs.

107
00:05:32.720 --> 00:05:35.640
Now when you start mentioning
the idea of baseline costs,

108
00:05:35.640 --> 00:05:38.930
this is our major assumption,
our planned assumption.

109
00:05:38.930 --> 00:05:42.940
Of what we believe the project
is going to cost us, okay?

110
00:05:42.940 --> 00:05:48.000
We know that we understand or at least we
believe that what will end up happening,

111
00:05:48.000 --> 00:05:50.910
here is the baseline here is
the general amount of money

112
00:05:50.910 --> 00:05:53.190
that we're gonna spend on our project.

113
00:05:53.190 --> 00:05:55.930
But it's really kind of
an estimate at that point and

114
00:05:55.930 --> 00:05:58.530
what we're now talking about
is what can it deviate.

115
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:01.830
Okay, what are the limits
that we have on either side?

116
00:06:01.830 --> 00:06:05.320
We need to be able to understand that
there are certain limits that we can go

117
00:06:05.320 --> 00:06:07.650
beyond without having to worry about it,
and

118
00:06:07.650 --> 00:06:10.630
then there's certain limits that we
shouldn't go beyond without having to ask

119
00:06:10.630 --> 00:06:14.090
for some permission to go beyond that,
and that's what we have.

120
00:06:14.090 --> 00:06:18.990
If you have a control limit in place in
terms of your project plan, what you're

121
00:06:18.990 --> 00:06:24.660
saying is that this is an agreed upon
variance, based on the performance

122
00:06:24.660 --> 00:06:29.480
that hey, here's what's gonna happen
before anything else needs to take place.

123
00:06:29.480 --> 00:06:33.180
Before some other action that brings
everything back into control takes place.

124
00:06:33.180 --> 00:06:35.110
So you're saying give me this leeway.

125
00:06:35.110 --> 00:06:37.610
That's what you're essentially
saying is that I need for

126
00:06:37.610 --> 00:06:40.730
my baseline here to have a leeway of 5% or

127
00:06:40.730 --> 00:06:46.820
10% of the budget of what we're
actually planning for as a leeway.

128
00:06:46.820 --> 00:06:48.160
Until somebody else steps in and

129
00:06:48.160 --> 00:06:52.880
says Ronnie, you spent too much money,
you don't have any more money to spend.

130
00:06:52.880 --> 00:06:54.790
Here is the variance that we have.

131
00:06:54.790 --> 00:06:57.310
And the reason why you have to do
that now is because you don't know.

132
00:06:57.310 --> 00:06:59.580
You haven't spent a single dime.

133
00:06:59.580 --> 00:07:03.380
You don't have a clue even
based on any real data at all.

134
00:07:03.380 --> 00:07:06.900
That your project is gonna come out
to be exactly what the baseline cost

135
00:07:06.900 --> 00:07:08.270
is going to be.

136
00:07:08.270 --> 00:07:12.050
So what you do is you set up your estimate
here, about what you believe the entire

137
00:07:12.050 --> 00:07:15.840
project's gonna cost, and then you
essentially sit down and you try and

138
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.200
figure out what this
control limit is gonna be.

139
00:07:19.200 --> 00:07:22.640
Now you may do this on every phase of
your project, or you may do it for

140
00:07:22.640 --> 00:07:25.090
the overall project schedule itself.

141
00:07:25.090 --> 00:07:27.750
You may end up finding out that you have
to do it on certain work packages and

142
00:07:27.750 --> 00:07:30.380
you don't have to do it on
other work packages here.

143
00:07:30.380 --> 00:07:33.820
And the reason happens to be,
of course, more uncertainty, or

144
00:07:33.820 --> 00:07:37.490
the idea of risk is another thing
that we have to worry about,

145
00:07:37.490 --> 00:07:40.040
especially when we start
talking about control limits.

146
00:07:40.040 --> 00:07:43.170
That there may be a certain
amount of risk even if you're

147
00:07:43.170 --> 00:07:45.900
risk adverse that you may say look,
here it is.

148
00:07:45.900 --> 00:07:49.818
We're willing to say that you have
to be within this range here.

149
00:07:49.818 --> 00:07:54.433
We'd really like you to be here, but we're
willing to go 10% above that if we need to

150
00:07:54.433 --> 00:07:57.532
without having to worry about
stopping the whole thing and

151
00:07:57.532 --> 00:07:59.448
then getting more approval for it.

152
00:07:59.448 --> 00:08:04.553
So you gotta know what your control limits
are gonna be inside of that initial

153
00:08:04.553 --> 00:08:10.830
planning, if you're going to set up to do
this for your project as well, all right?

154
00:08:10.830 --> 00:08:14.690
So that's kind of one of the key
elements that needs to be there.

155
00:08:14.690 --> 00:08:19.280
Most of the time what we end up doing
right here is something that's really bad.

156
00:08:19.280 --> 00:08:20.030
Okay?

157
00:08:20.030 --> 00:08:22.320
Is that we give an estimate and

158
00:08:22.320 --> 00:08:26.530
we sound so
confident in our estimate at this point,

159
00:08:26.530 --> 00:08:32.240
that all of our project stakeholders
assume that to be fact and true.

160
00:08:32.240 --> 00:08:35.630
And then because we haven't spent
a single dime, we don't know.

161
00:08:35.630 --> 00:08:38.930
And then when it comes down to spending
more money, somebody says, well,

162
00:08:38.930 --> 00:08:43.880
Ronnie that's not the amount you quoted us
on when we started working on the budget.

163
00:08:43.880 --> 00:08:47.760
And so, you wanna make sure that
you set a clear expectation here.

164
00:08:47.760 --> 00:08:51.050
Now here's the control limits that we
need to set up right at the beginning.

165
00:08:51.050 --> 00:08:54.820
It may not always happen, but
you at least have to make sure that

166
00:08:54.820 --> 00:08:57.260
you get something like
this in our project plan.

167
00:08:57.260 --> 00:08:57.900
>> That's right.

168
00:08:57.900 --> 00:09:01.810
And that comes down to the idea
of estimating the cost.

169
00:09:01.810 --> 00:09:03.920
It's just a, it's exactly what it is.

170
00:09:03.920 --> 00:09:05.930
Like Ronnie said it's an estimation.

171
00:09:05.930 --> 00:09:09.570
Now we base that based
off our expertise and

172
00:09:09.570 --> 00:09:13.790
our experience that we have and
our project management careers.

173
00:09:13.790 --> 00:09:17.290
And it's probably going to be around that,
but sometimes things happen and

174
00:09:17.290 --> 00:09:21.550
you can't account for them and now you
need more money if the stake holders

175
00:09:21.550 --> 00:09:25.676
believe that you've given the gospel
of Paul as far as the estimate goes.

176
00:09:25.676 --> 00:09:26.860
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

177
00:09:26.860 --> 00:09:30.510
you come in with a higher estimate now,
they're gonna start questioning your

178
00:09:30.510 --> 00:09:33.840
integrity maybe,
you're just looking for more money or

179
00:09:33.840 --> 00:09:37.530
you're not good at project management when
really you need to set the expectation for

180
00:09:37.530 --> 00:09:41.845
them that this is just
a very loose estimation.

181
00:09:41.845 --> 00:09:45.195
Like we always like to say,
we like to under-promise and over-deliver,

182
00:09:45.195 --> 00:09:48.800
so if you think the estimate's gonna
be 50,000 dollars, ask them for 75.

183

00:22:01.840 --> 00:22:06.560
you're just trying to get a general
figure parametric will do for you.

406
00:22:06.560 --> 00:22:10.366
So you wanna make sure that everybody
that's gonna help you in planning this,

407
00:22:10.366 --> 00:22:12.910
at least understand
those three methods and

408
00:22:12.910 --> 00:22:16.660
a lot of times at least make sure you
go through part of your project, with

409
00:22:16.660 --> 00:22:20.550
all three of the methods to figure out
which one you're gonna determined as well.

410
00:22:20.550 --> 00:22:23.500
Most of the time, you're probably gonna
end up doing this first two if you don't

411
00:22:23.500 --> 00:22:27.660
really have any data at all as long as you
actually have somebody that's really good

412
00:22:27.660 --> 00:22:30.560
at actually working out everything,
keeping track of that

413
00:22:30.560 --> 00:22:33.830
project management information system,
that bottom-up is probably going to give

414
00:22:33.830 --> 00:22:37.720
you as close of an accurate
estimate as you possibly can here.

415
00:22:37.720 --> 00:22:41.320
>> Yeah Ronnie, that bottom up approach is
definitely the most precise and the best

416
00:22:41.320 --> 00:22:44.310
way to go if you can get away with it
that's where you want to go because.

417
00:22:44.310 --> 00:22:45.420
It's gonna save you a lot of time,

418
00:22:45.420 --> 00:22:48.970
a lot of effort on the back
end as the output comes.

419
00:22:48.970 --> 00:22:52.930
It does take a lot more
effort on the front end, but

420
00:22:52.930 --> 00:22:57.160
it's totally worth it for
the return on that time investment.

421
00:22:57.160 --> 00:23:01.920
And that being said Ronnie, we'd be remiss
if we didn't discuss the budget, right?

422
00:23:01.920 --> 00:23:05.100
That's gonna come down to budget
meetings are always so much fun.

423
00:23:05.100 --> 00:23:06.280
I've been a part of plenty of them.

424
00:23:06.280 --> 00:23:08.420
And where are we gonna allocate funds?

425
00:23:08.420 --> 00:23:11.170
How much do we need to
allocate to this and to that?

426
00:23:11.170 --> 00:23:14.080
They're just part of any
cost management plan, and

427
00:23:14.080 --> 00:23:15.840
any budgeting plan that you're gonna have.

428
00:23:15.840 --> 00:23:17.440
All projects have this.

429
00:23:17.440 --> 00:23:20.570
>> They do, and
you're a better man that I am to sit in on

430
00:23:20.570 --> 00:23:23.900
on a lot of these different ones' that
are actually out there and available but

431
00:23:23.900 --> 00:23:26.990
budgeting is where really
it comes down to, right?

432
00:23:26.990 --> 00:23:30.260
Having the estimate, in order words,
getting what you believe is the proper

433
00:23:30.260 --> 00:23:34.700
amount of funding that you need for your
project is based on those estimates but

434
00:23:34.700 --> 00:23:38.110
this is where we talked about at the very
beginning of the episode, right?

435
00:23:38.110 --> 00:23:40.920
If I am told I have $25,000

436
00:23:40.920 --> 00:23:45.630
I need to make sure that I assign
the appropriate amount of money,

437
00:23:45.630 --> 00:23:50.740
of resources, whatever it is, to every
task to insure that those tasks get done.

438
00:23:50.740 --> 00:23:53.798
A budget essentially helps us
to do those two things right?

439
00:23:53.798 --> 00:23:55.708
Actually helps to do two things,
excuse me.

440
00:23:55.708 --> 00:23:59.698
One of course is assign a cost to
whatever activity that we have, okay?

441
00:23:59.698 --> 00:24:02.884
So we're actually saying hey, we believe
that this is gonna cost us this much, and

442
00:24:02.884 --> 00:24:04.670
we go ahead and we assign that.

443
00:24:04.670 --> 00:24:07.470
Secondly, a budget actually
gives us the authorization, or

444
00:24:07.470 --> 00:24:09.460
actually provides authorization for
us, too.

445
00:24:09.460 --> 00:24:12.960
And that sets that idea of control limits
that we were talking about at the very

446
00:24:12.960 --> 00:24:14.400
beginning, as well.

447
00:24:14.400 --> 00:24:18.000
So let's say that what ends up happening
here is that Daniel is gonna work on

448
00:24:18.000 --> 00:24:21.630
the networking clause, just as an example.

449
00:24:21.630 --> 00:24:25.538
And we set aside the budget for that
particular phase of the project to be,

450
00:24:25.538 --> 00:24:28.330
let's say $5,000.

451
00:24:28.330 --> 00:24:31.830
Perfectly fine if we do that.

452
00:24:31.830 --> 00:24:35.390
Now, when I do that,
I'm kind of saying here it is, okay.

453
00:24:35.390 --> 00:24:39.970
Daniel is actually now authorized,
once the budget actually gets accepted and

454
00:24:39.970 --> 00:24:41.030
everything else.

455
00:24:41.030 --> 00:24:41.810
He's authorized to be

456
00:24:41.810 --> 00:24:44.720
able to spend that without having
to come to me again as well.

457
00:24:44.720 --> 00:24:48.600
So that's why it actually provides
not only the assignment of cost

458
00:24:48.600 --> 00:24:53.250
to that activity, it also now assigns
the ability to authorize that he

459
00:24:53.250 --> 00:24:56.240
can do that without having to worry
about coming back to us as well.

460
00:24:56.240 --> 00:24:59.420
The other thing that it also does,
of course, when we start talking about

461
00:24:59.420 --> 00:25:05.040
the idea of the budget, is it helps us
to go ahead and create a cost baseline.

462
00:25:05.040 --> 00:25:08.290
So let me show you my
diagram here to try and

463
00:25:08.290 --> 00:25:11.750
help keep us on track
a little bit more too, okay?

464
00:25:11.750 --> 00:25:14.940
So, there we are, we're talking about
the very top down, the project budget.

465
00:25:14.940 --> 00:25:16.320
It really does help us do that.

466
00:25:16.320 --> 00:25:21.180
The idea of assigning cost and
then helping us to create a baseline

467
00:25:21.180 --> 00:25:25.100
type of cost for the entire project.

468
00:25:25.100 --> 00:25:29.440
That way we can see everything and we now
see where it breaks down and it goes.

469
00:25:29.440 --> 00:25:33.320
The other thing that we also normally
need, especially in a budget here,

470
00:25:33.320 --> 00:25:37.830
when you're working with an accountant is,
more than likely, the accountant is going

471
00:25:37.830 --> 00:25:43.330
to tell you how we wanna break
this down for accounting measures.

472
00:25:43.330 --> 00:25:44.278
Most of the time,

473
00:25:44.278 --> 00:25:48.022
the accountant actually may provide
some type of accounting number.

474
00:25:48.022 --> 00:25:52.860
And if you have a very formal project
management office, you also see that a lot

475
00:25:52.860 --> 00:25:57.844
of times, this breaks down into your WBS
numbers as well, where every WBS number

476
00:25:57.844 --> 00:26:02.714
is actually going to be assigned as being
a part of that accounting procedure.

477
00:26:02.714 --> 00:26:07.609
So that when Daniel actually does put
in for release of funds for this and

478
00:26:07.609 --> 00:26:11.650
that, it actually gets tied
to that number as well.

479
00:26:11.650 --> 00:26:14.650
And that way, you're not actually
having to write down, this is for

480
00:26:14.650 --> 00:26:16.990
Daniel's project, or this work breakdown.

481
00:26:16.990 --> 00:26:20.310
You just assign that number to it, and
it makes it easier for the accountant

482
00:26:20.310 --> 00:26:23.330
to go ahead and be able to match those
checks up to do what we need to for

483
00:26:23.330 --> 00:26:24.545
every expense category.

484
00:26:24.545 --> 00:26:27.120
We'll have that available for us.

485
00:26:27.120 --> 00:26:30.670
So it makes it easy to track the money
by doing something like this.

486
00:26:30.670 --> 00:26:32.215
It makes it easy for us to go ahead and

487
00:26:32.215 --> 00:26:35.500
authorize spending without having
to do it for every single time.

488
00:26:35.500 --> 00:26:38.470
Gives a clear baseline
of where we need to be.

489
00:26:38.470 --> 00:26:41.900
Now along with that, once you actually
have all of those things assigned,

490
00:26:41.900 --> 00:26:46.340
there are two other components that we
tend to actually have to worry about,

491
00:26:46.340 --> 00:26:50.958
which is what we call our contingency and
our management reserve.

492
00:26:50.958 --> 00:26:55.450
Now In reality, a lot of projects and

493
00:26:55.450 --> 00:26:59.340
a lot of project managers will see these
as actually being synonymous here.

494
00:26:59.340 --> 00:27:04.600
Contingency reserve, management reserve,
that they are one and the same.

495
00:27:04.600 --> 00:27:08.350
In the CompTia Project Plus,
they are not one and the same.

496
00:27:08.350 --> 00:27:11.380
So we need to make sure that we
separate out what the difference

497
00:27:11.380 --> 00:27:12.380
is between these two.

498
00:27:12.380 --> 00:27:15.650
And I've tried to delineate this for
us so that we can keep this in our mind.

499
00:27:16.700 --> 00:27:20.780
When you start talking about
a contingency reserve,

500
00:27:20.780 --> 00:27:25.670
what you're saying here, is that
funds that are set aside to cover for

501
00:27:25.670 --> 00:27:28.760
unplanned expenses to the project itself.

502
00:27:28.760 --> 00:27:33.850
Now, that doesn't actually mean for
anything that we want it to.

503
00:27:33.850 --> 00:27:38.730
The contingency is not set
there because now at the end,

504
00:27:38.730 --> 00:27:41.880
I've still got,
let's say $10,000 in the contingency.

505
00:27:41.880 --> 00:27:45.760
It's now time for
me to think about a big blow out party for

506
00:27:45.760 --> 00:27:46.840
the entire project team.

507
00:27:46.840 --> 00:27:49.120
That's not what the contingency's about.

508
00:27:49.120 --> 00:27:50.460
Can people use it for that?

509
00:27:50.460 --> 00:27:51.140
Do people?

510
00:27:51.140 --> 00:27:53.790
Probably, but
that's not what we're talking about.

511
00:27:53.790 --> 00:27:56.100
So usually what ends up happening here,

512
00:27:56.100 --> 00:28:00.380
is that it's not really supposed to be
a source of extra money for the project.

513
00:28:00.380 --> 00:28:04.890
It is for those unplanned expenses that
end up happening to every single project

514
00:28:04.890 --> 00:28:09.540
here, that we just don't have
any way to actually go look.

515
00:28:09.540 --> 00:28:13.070
We didn't know that it was gonna
cost this, to help us out.

516
00:28:13.070 --> 00:28:17.260
Now, the nice thing about it is that
the authorization of the spending list

517
00:28:17.260 --> 00:28:19.390
comes directly from the project manager.

518
00:28:19.390 --> 00:28:25.630
So he actually has put aside a set of the
funds here, a certain amount of funding.

519
00:28:25.630 --> 00:28:30.370
Usually it's a percentage of
the overall project cost, say,

520
00:28:30.370 --> 00:28:34.070
this is actually set aside for
things that we cannot plan for.

521
00:28:35.090 --> 00:28:37.450
You just have to set that aside.

522
00:28:37.450 --> 00:28:39.360
Now, do you have to use it?

523
00:28:39.360 --> 00:28:42.690
No, but if you don't use it,
it's not again, free money.

524
00:28:42.690 --> 00:28:44.900
It doesn't mean I'll just use it here.

525
00:28:44.900 --> 00:28:45.530
I'll just use it here.

526
00:28:45.530 --> 00:28:50.240
It is up to the discretion of the project
manager, but whatever you actually earmark

527
00:28:50.240 --> 00:28:54.170
that contingency to be, whether it's
emergencies only, and you can do that.

528
00:28:54.170 --> 00:28:55.000
>> It's an insurance policy.

529
00:28:55.000 --> 00:28:56.710
>> Yeah, it is an insurance policy, yeah.

530
00:28:56.710 --> 00:28:59.800
And so whatever you actually set up,
that's perfectly fine.

531
00:28:59.800 --> 00:29:02.930
But notice they actually have
management reserve down here instead.

532
00:29:04.030 --> 00:29:07.910
Funds set aside to cover for
unforseen situations.

533
00:29:07.910 --> 00:29:10.670
Now the first one I talked
about is unplanned expenses.

534
00:29:10.670 --> 00:29:13.390
Now there's things we
just didn't plan for.

535
00:29:13.390 --> 00:29:15.820
But unforseen things is more

536
00:29:15.820 --> 00:29:19.790
kind of the very basics of
the insurance policy, again.

537
00:29:19.790 --> 00:29:23.342
But this one, though,
is a little bit different.

538
00:29:23.342 --> 00:29:27.426
It's different in this way, in that even
though the project manager knows it's

539
00:29:27.426 --> 00:29:31.585
there and it's a percentage of the overall
total cost, he doesn't get to use it.

540
00:29:31.585 --> 00:29:33.340
He doesn't get to.

541
00:29:33.340 --> 00:29:36.320
He gets to request the use of this.

542
00:29:37.340 --> 00:29:40.790
If he happens to actually go beyond
what he thinks is gonna happen.

543
00:29:40.790 --> 00:29:42.620
Something unplanned happened here, and

544
00:29:42.620 --> 00:29:45.510
it's not inside of his
budget at this point.

545
00:29:45.510 --> 00:29:47.500
He can then go to management and

546
00:29:47.500 --> 00:29:52.740
actually request access to the management
reserve here for his project,

547
00:29:52.740 --> 00:29:55.680
but he has to get authorization and
approval for that as well.

548
00:29:56.760 --> 00:30:01.920
So a lot of times the management reserve
is not actually part of the budget itself,

549
00:30:01.920 --> 00:30:05.390
whereas the contingency reserve
is a part of the budget.

550
00:30:05.390 --> 00:30:08.380
But this is actually kind
of the key difference here.

551
00:30:08.380 --> 00:30:12.140
Is one, the project manager is not in
control of the management reserve.

552
00:30:12.140 --> 00:30:15.820
He has to request it and he has to be
authorized to be able to spend it here.

553
00:30:15.820 --> 00:30:18.590
And then,
this is not a part of the budget.

554
00:30:18.590 --> 00:30:21.710
Contingency, though,
unforseen things happen,

555
00:30:21.710 --> 00:30:24.530
things cost more than we
expected them to happen.

556
00:30:24.530 --> 00:30:28.110
The project manager has at his
discretion whatever that contingency is

557
00:30:28.110 --> 00:30:29.950
to be able to cover for those things.

558
00:30:29.950 --> 00:30:32.330
He does not have it as the ability to go,

559
00:30:32.330 --> 00:30:35.540
let me just add this onto
the project because I felt like it.

560
00:30:35.540 --> 00:30:37.930
At least,
that's the way it's supposed to be.

561
00:30:37.930 --> 00:30:41.240
In reality, most project managers would
probably consider both of them as being

562
00:30:41.240 --> 00:30:42.350
one in the same.

563
00:30:42.350 --> 00:30:43.860
But that's the big difference here.

564
00:30:43.860 --> 00:30:46.560
Who authorizes it and
who doesn't get authorization for it?

565
00:30:46.560 --> 00:30:48.480
And what is its intended purpose?

566
00:30:48.480 --> 00:30:53.722
So that's also gonna be a part of
planning for your budget as well.

567
00:30:53.722 --> 00:30:57.684
And then the last thing that we wanna
mention here is the idea of the baselines.

568
00:30:57.684 --> 00:31:02.353
Let me scroll this down, and I guess I can
actually increase the font, just a little

569
00:31:02.353 --> 00:31:07.600
bit more, so that we can see it here, is
that cost baseline that we talked about.

570
00:31:07.600 --> 00:31:09.930
Remember that we just need to make
sure that we understand that there is

571
00:31:09.930 --> 00:31:13.600
a baseline that we've gotta set up
before any of this stuff happens.

572
00:31:13.600 --> 00:31:18.010
So total approved expected cost should
be set before any work is ever done.

573
00:31:18.010 --> 00:31:20.170
We don't start it without
this cost baseline.

574
00:31:20.170 --> 00:31:21.470
You don't do that.

575
00:31:21.470 --> 00:31:24.660
Even when you actually begin to
make your project management

576
00:31:24.660 --> 00:31:26.470
plan inside of your project
information system.

577
00:31:26.470 --> 00:31:29.560
One of the early things you might
set up is the cost baseline,

578
00:31:29.560 --> 00:31:30.740
what you actually believe.

579
00:31:30.740 --> 00:31:33.810
And then we'll start actually
reducing the amount of money and

580
00:31:33.810 --> 00:31:35.990
actually show you where
you are in your budget.

581
00:31:35.990 --> 00:31:38.750
You also wanna make sure that
you include any variances and

582
00:31:38.750 --> 00:31:42.580
expenses, because that all will be
measured against that cost baseline.

583
00:31:42.580 --> 00:31:46.460
And this one will actually tell you
again where it's tracked in comparison.

584
00:31:46.460 --> 00:31:49.280
So let's show you when the money's
actually released as well,

585
00:31:49.280 --> 00:31:50.670
against that baseline.

586
00:31:50.670 --> 00:31:55.630
So this is our first major kind
of milestone type of point for

587
00:31:55.630 --> 00:31:57.100
cost that we have, and

588
00:31:57.100 --> 00:32:02.150
it needs to be set up before anything ever
happens on our budget planning as well.

589
00:32:02.150 --> 00:32:06.310
So when we start taking a look at
the components of a project cost

590
00:32:06.310 --> 00:32:10.980
management plan, those are the major
components that you have to deal with.

591
00:32:10.980 --> 00:32:15.160
Is there much more in-depth information
on this stuff you should go to?

592
00:32:15.160 --> 00:32:15.920
Beyond, right?

593
00:32:15.920 --> 00:32:19.410
You can take full accounting courses,
and of course, budget and

594
00:32:19.410 --> 00:32:23.600
management courses that will
just take you to the nth degree.

595
00:32:23.600 --> 00:32:26.360
We just did a high level review, wanna
make sure that you knew what was normally

596
00:32:26.360 --> 00:32:28.690
involved inside of the project plan here.

597
00:32:28.690 --> 00:32:31.850
>> Well Ronnie, I think if I learned
anything from today's episode,

598
00:32:31.850 --> 00:32:36.094
it's that cost management and creating a
cost management plan is not child's play.

599
00:32:36.094 --> 00:32:36.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

600
00:32:36.790 --> 00:32:39.420
it's extremely important to the project.

601
00:32:39.420 --> 00:32:41.210
Why?
Well this is the money right?

602
00:32:41.210 --> 00:32:43.530
This is really what it comes down to,
the brass tacks,

603
00:32:43.530 --> 00:32:45.570
as we like to say here in the US.

604
00:32:45.570 --> 00:32:47.960
What is it gonna cost me
to get this thing up and

605
00:32:47.960 --> 00:32:49.882
running, off the ground and wheels up?

606
00:32:49.882 --> 00:32:51.940
Ronnie, but
you've done a great job, I believe,

607
00:32:51.940 --> 00:32:56.790
of explaining at least, like you said, the
general overview of how we can do this and

608
00:32:56.790 --> 00:33:00.190
what goes into setting up
that cost management plan.

609
00:33:00.190 --> 00:33:01.150
And we really appreciate it.

610
00:33:01.150 --> 00:33:04.430
Thank you for stopping by, and everybody
out there, thank you for watching.

611
00:33:04.430 --> 00:33:06.190
We hope you got a lot out
of today's episode, but

612
00:33:06.190 --> 00:33:08.110
as of right now we're gonna go ahead and
sign off.

613
00:33:08.110 --> 00:33:10.411
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

614
00:33:10.411 --> 00:33:11.236
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

615
00:33:11.236 --> 00:33:13.335
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:33:13.335 --> 00:33:21.350
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the process of procurement when your project goals are outside your companies current capabilities. They take you through assessing areas that may require procurement of service through techniques like Requests For Information/Quote/Proposal(RFI/RFQ/RFP) as well as assessing and selecting a contractor or vendor. Finally, they discuss contract development.
episodes.title: Plan Project Procurement
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.080 --> 00:00:14.360
All right, greetings, everyone, and

3
00:00:14.360 --> 00:00:17.010
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:18.482
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

5
00:00:18.482 --> 00:00:21.439
in today's episode we are continuing
on with our Project+ series.

6
00:00:21.439 --> 00:00:24.893
Joining us back in the studio again today
is none other than Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:24.893 --> 00:00:26.420
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:26.420 --> 00:00:26.970
>> Well, thank you for

9
00:00:26.970 --> 00:00:31.430
having me back on the show as we continue
on to take a look at CompTIA's Project+.

10
00:00:31.430 --> 00:00:34.660
What we're actually doing today is we're
gonna be taking a look at what we call

11
00:00:34.660 --> 00:00:38.500
planning project procurement on,
of course, Project+,

12
00:00:38.500 --> 00:00:41.630
which is a lot of P's we were making
a little bit of a joke about that.

13
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:44.720
My alliteration was not
exactly the best thing today.

14
00:00:44.720 --> 00:00:48.540
But we are taking a look at what
we call planning for procurement.

15
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:52.089
Now when we start talking about
the idea of project procurement,

16
00:00:52.089 --> 00:00:55.713
what are we really trying to figure
out and what are we trying to do?

17
00:00:55.713 --> 00:00:58.400
Well, just like it says,
it talks about procurement here.

18
00:00:58.400 --> 00:01:02.624
But what we're talking about really is
what happens outside of our organization

19
00:01:02.624 --> 00:01:04.747
when we need to pull those resources in.

20
00:01:04.747 --> 00:01:09.030
Well, we need to have some standard way
to actually procure those resources.

21
00:01:09.030 --> 00:01:13.230
I know that it seems like a great
way to work when you watch TV and

22
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:15.770
somebody says, this is what we need done.

23
00:01:15.770 --> 00:01:18.810
And the guy just looks over and
goes, I know a guy, okay?

24
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:20.980
I know a guy and he can get it done.

25
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:26.020
And it's amazing and wonderful that on
TV when he does that, everything's done,

26
00:01:26.020 --> 00:01:29.440
there's never any question about how
it gets done, how much money it cost,

27
00:01:29.440 --> 00:01:33.580
what contracts are there, how do they
make that selection to be appropriate.

28
00:01:33.580 --> 00:01:36.850
It just happens and it's wonderful.

29
00:01:36.850 --> 00:01:41.780
In the real world of project management,
though, it's seldom that easy.

30
00:01:41.780 --> 00:01:43.340
Even the decision of whether or

31
00:01:43.340 --> 00:01:48.865
not to actually procure some type of
service from outside is not that easy.

32
00:01:48.865 --> 00:01:51.643
So usually there's two questions
we have to ask of whether or

33
00:01:51.643 --> 00:01:54.212
not we actually need
a Project Procurement Plan or not.

34
00:01:54.212 --> 00:01:58.651
But let's go ahead and look at my slide
here and my diagram, my simple diagram,

35
00:01:58.651 --> 00:02:02.210
and let's make sure we
understand those two questions.

36
00:02:02.210 --> 00:02:07.300
How in the world do I know if I
need a Project Procurement Plan?

37
00:02:07.300 --> 00:02:11.980
If my organization or my project team
cannot do what needs to be done on

38
00:02:11.980 --> 00:02:17.200
my project, more than likely I
have to get it done somehow.

39
00:02:17.200 --> 00:02:21.070
And that normally means I'm going
to either outsource the actual

40
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:25.990
project itself or that work package, or
I'm going to actually provide training for

41
00:02:25.990 --> 00:02:29.410
that so
that somebody can actually get it done.

42
00:02:29.410 --> 00:02:34.030
So if I realize something, that if I
try and do the training for this, and

43
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:37.290
it's gonna actually take another four
weeks in addition to what I have

44
00:02:37.290 --> 00:02:41.430
planned for that to be done,
I may realize something, that I cannot

45
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:44.960
lose that valuable time of those four
weeks for the additional training.

46
00:02:44.960 --> 00:02:47.720
What I need to do is consider
some type of outsourcing,

47
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:52.160
some type of expert to come in and
be able to do that.

48
00:02:52.160 --> 00:02:56.300
Now if you absolutely realize that that's
what's gonna have to happen at times

49
00:02:56.300 --> 00:03:01.322
on your project, then yes,
you need a Project Procurement Plan.

50
00:03:01.322 --> 00:03:05.530
Inside of your organization, though,
if you have all the resources that

51
00:03:05.530 --> 00:03:09.930
are available for you that absolutely
can do everything on your project,

52
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:12.730
then you don't need
a Project Procurement Plan.

53
00:03:12.730 --> 00:03:16.250
If you're willing to spend
the extra money to go ahead and

54
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:19.440
get additional training for everybody
internal to do what they need to,

55
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:23.370
you don't have to actually go outside
to get the Project Procurement Plan.

56
00:03:23.370 --> 00:03:28.050
And this is for the idea of human
resources more than anything else.

57
00:03:28.050 --> 00:03:32.040
The other thing that may also end up
happening, and this has happened on

58
00:03:32.040 --> 00:03:35.849
several projects before,
not on any one that I've ever worked on.

59
00:03:35.849 --> 00:03:40.541
But on several projects that I've
actually read about here in which you

60
00:03:40.541 --> 00:03:43.070
have to ask this question.

61
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:46.960
Do I choose to make it or
do I choose to buy it?

62
00:03:46.960 --> 00:03:51.156
You might find out as you work on
a particular project that here's

63
00:03:51.156 --> 00:03:55.490
something that is not in
existence in this hemisphere.

64
00:03:55.490 --> 00:03:59.390
And that stuff does happen
where they literally go, yeah,

65
00:03:59.390 --> 00:04:04.210
the only one that's actually in existence
is over in Southeast Asia right now.

66
00:04:04.210 --> 00:04:08.970
And so you have this chance to ask these
two questions here, whatever the product

67
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:13.970
is, whatever it might be, that is there
a possibility that I can get that, or

68
00:04:13.970 --> 00:04:16.959
I can buy that product and
get it over here for my project?

69
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:21.040
Or can I make it?

70
00:04:21.040 --> 00:04:24.430
So it is very possible that you
might be able to spend the time and

71
00:04:24.430 --> 00:04:28.070
the resources to literally make
the product that doesn't exist so

72
00:04:28.070 --> 00:04:31.688
that you can get your project done,
or are you going to buy it?

73
00:04:31.688 --> 00:04:35.930
Well, if you choose to buy it, it means
you need a Project Procurement Plan.

74
00:04:35.930 --> 00:04:37.170
So think about it in this way.

75
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:42.140
Any time you reach outside of your
organization to procure services or

76
00:04:42.140 --> 00:04:46.660
resources so
that you can get your project done,

77
00:04:46.660 --> 00:04:50.010
you're gonna need some type
of Project Procurement Plan,

78
00:04:50.010 --> 00:04:54.020
is what you're gonna absolutely
need to make sure that you do.

79
00:04:54.020 --> 00:04:59.100
Now the problem that we have again is,
how do we go about doing that

80
00:04:59.100 --> 00:05:04.540
in a way that absolutely doesn't violate
laws in the place that you're in and

81
00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:08.915
doesn't seem like you actually only giving
the contract to your brother-in-law?

82
00:05:08.915 --> 00:05:12.020
[LAUGH] Nepotism is what
we’re talking about.

83
00:05:12.020 --> 00:05:16.240
That you're only doing that,
which people absolutely frown upon.

84
00:05:16.240 --> 00:05:19.020
Well, the way that you do that
is you come up with a plan and

85
00:05:19.020 --> 00:05:20.760
a process that seems what?

86
00:05:20.760 --> 00:05:24.190
Equal, fair,
objective as much as possible,

87
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:27.720
to everybody that's actually
looking at your project.

88
00:05:27.720 --> 00:05:30.210
And the way that that comes
about a lot of times,

89
00:05:30.210 --> 00:05:33.060
then, is by actually
opening up the process.

90
00:05:33.060 --> 00:05:35.740
You might have heard about it,
the idea of considering bids for

91
00:05:35.740 --> 00:05:39.570
your project, having some type of bidder
conference, whatever it might be.

92
00:05:39.570 --> 00:05:41.623
But everybody uses these terms
a little bit differently.

93
00:05:41.623 --> 00:05:46.040
You might hear the acronyms RFI, RFQ, RFP.

94
00:05:47.310 --> 00:05:48.960
Now what do each of those stand for?

95
00:05:48.960 --> 00:05:54.426
Well, RFI stands for
request for the information.

96
00:05:54.426 --> 00:05:58.020
I wanted to say inquiry, but
it's request for information.

97
00:05:58.020 --> 00:06:00.630
And then RFQ is a request for a quote.

98
00:06:00.630 --> 00:06:05.220
RFP is a request for a proposal, is what
we're normally taking a look at when

99
00:06:05.220 --> 00:06:09.380
we start to talk about those
different ones that you see.

100
00:06:09.380 --> 00:06:13.132
So when we start talking about that,
this is what might happen,

101
00:06:13.132 --> 00:06:17.242
is that you do submit some type of
request out there in that community.

102
00:06:17.242 --> 00:06:21.420
You might do it through the trade papers
that are actually out there and available.

103
00:06:21.420 --> 00:06:26.220
You might actually do it just
advertising on the radio, on TV,

104
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:27.580
or whatever it might be.

105
00:06:27.580 --> 00:06:30.690
But you normally go through some type
of channel in which you actually

106
00:06:30.690 --> 00:06:33.210
put it out there in the community
that you're looking for

107
00:06:33.210 --> 00:06:37.070
someone to be able to do
what you have them to do.

108
00:06:37.070 --> 00:06:41.972
You're essentially putting out a request
for anyone that would like to consider

109
00:06:41.972 --> 00:06:46.741
this to come and see whether or not that
you're gonna procure their services.

110
00:06:46.741 --> 00:06:48.265
>> Ronnie, quick question.

111
00:06:48.265 --> 00:06:52.852
The RFI, the RFQ, and the RFP, are they
considered synonymous, or are they really

112
00:06:52.852 --> 00:06:57.256
separate things and they all kinda have
a pointed tip to them that's different?

113
00:06:57.256 --> 00:07:00.040
>> [LAUGH] It depends on
the industry that you're in.

114
00:07:00.040 --> 00:07:01.470
That's the key, right?

115
00:07:01.470 --> 00:07:04.640
So in a very generic sense,
they all really mean the same thing, but

116
00:07:04.640 --> 00:07:07.670
every industry actually kind of
calls it something differently.

117
00:07:07.670 --> 00:07:12.490
So you might see in certain places
where they say an RFI is this, and

118
00:07:12.490 --> 00:07:14.710
that's a formal thing for
something like this.

119
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:17.360
And they may say a request for a quote is
a little bit different, and a request for

120
00:07:17.360 --> 00:07:19.320
a proposal is different as well.

121
00:07:19.320 --> 00:07:22.270
So it might be the quote is
actually dealing with just money.

122
00:07:22.270 --> 00:07:26.570
It might be an information,
just to see if you actually are out there.

123
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:27.545
It's sort of like fishing.

124
00:07:27.545 --> 00:07:30.776
You kind of put a little bit of bait and
see if anybody bites, is the request for

125
00:07:30.776 --> 00:07:31.730
information.

126
00:07:31.730 --> 00:07:34.300
The quote is actually saying all right,
here it is,

127
00:07:34.300 --> 00:07:35.980
I'm willing to give this
much money to do it.

128
00:07:35.980 --> 00:07:38.360
The proposal is to say
I wanna see the layout,

129
00:07:38.360 --> 00:07:40.830
I wanna see the outline of
everything that you have.

130
00:07:40.830 --> 00:07:45.518
But a lot of times they can be synonymous,
depending on the industry that you're in.

131
00:07:45.518 --> 00:07:48.654
So in each of these you might
end up including, of course,

132
00:07:48.654 --> 00:07:52.174
your statement of work for
whatever it is that they are to look at,

133
00:07:52.174 --> 00:07:54.610
whoever is actually out
there is looking at.

134
00:07:54.610 --> 00:07:56.968
You wanna make sure that
they understand the scope.

135
00:07:56.968 --> 00:07:59.278
Of work that's actually to be done.

136
00:07:59.278 --> 00:08:03.277
They also need to be submitted in
a process that will be fairly uniform for

137
00:08:03.277 --> 00:08:08.132
everybody that's actually going to submit
for this, there's a reason behind that and

138
00:08:08.132 --> 00:08:10.510
we'll talk about that in a moment, okay.

139
00:08:10.510 --> 00:08:14.000
So when I talk about how responses
are to be formatted you may indicate

140
00:08:14.000 --> 00:08:19.340
a particular template that they are to
follow period, is what they're to do.

141
00:08:19.340 --> 00:08:23.300
And then, a deadline for
when the response is to come in.

142
00:08:23.300 --> 00:08:28.790
You may even indicate whether or not a
formal presentation is to be made or not.

143
00:08:28.790 --> 00:08:32.210
And maybe even indicate a bid for
whatever that is.

144
00:08:32.210 --> 00:08:34.030
Now, you may not do that
all at the same time.

145
00:08:34.030 --> 00:08:35.190
What you may actually go ahead and

146
00:08:35.190 --> 00:08:37.800
do like we talked about here
Is at the very beginning.

147
00:08:37.800 --> 00:08:39.750
We do a request for information.

148
00:08:40.950 --> 00:08:42.740
Who actually wants to bid on this?

149
00:08:42.740 --> 00:08:46.750
And then you ask for more information
like how big is your company?

150
00:08:46.750 --> 00:08:51.400
Cuz if I actually have a project that
actually requires you to have let's say 4,

151
00:08:51.400 --> 00:08:54.390
500 people, and
your particular construction team says,

152
00:08:54.390 --> 00:08:57.280
well, I've got three Well,
I know something.

153
00:08:57.280 --> 00:08:59.350
That, even though you say,
I think I can do this work,

154
00:08:59.350 --> 00:09:01.400
I know I can get enough subcontractors.

155
00:09:01.400 --> 00:09:04.130
I may not have the time to wait and
see if you can do it.

156
00:09:04.130 --> 00:09:08.090
I may just go well, absolutely I'm not
gonna actually accept this at all.

157
00:09:08.090 --> 00:09:10.470
And that weeds that
particular process out.

158
00:09:10.470 --> 00:09:12.570
But you gotta actually
figure this out too.

159
00:09:12.570 --> 00:09:17.140
Now, if the organization is normally
public funded a lot of times,

160
00:09:17.140 --> 00:09:20.200
in other words, by the government,
you're not suppose to actually be,

161
00:09:20.200 --> 00:09:22.950
you know, in other words Daniel and
I are not supposed to that

162
00:09:22.950 --> 00:09:25.860
I love this company let me mark this for
special inner marketer.

163
00:09:25.860 --> 00:09:27.920
So the idea of actually
formatting it the same.

164
00:09:27.920 --> 00:09:30.370
We don't want to try and
get everybody get dizzy here.

165
00:09:30.370 --> 00:09:34.320
The idea of actually formatting it exactly
the same makes what more difficult for

166
00:09:34.320 --> 00:09:38.280
somebody just look never decide here's
to come Daniel want me to look at for

167
00:09:38.280 --> 00:09:40.420
they literally have to read the name or

168
00:09:40.420 --> 00:09:43.730
they may even submit it
under a bid number, right.

169
00:09:43.730 --> 00:09:47.170
An actual unique ID number,
that whoever the company, and

170
00:09:47.170 --> 00:09:50.210
whoever's making the decisions is
requiring, is that he just looks at that.

171
00:09:50.210 --> 00:09:51.640
He doesn't even look at the name.

172
00:09:51.640 --> 00:09:55.460
He just says bid number 412,
or ID number 412 on this

173
00:09:55.460 --> 00:09:59.060
proposal is the one that looks the best,
hands it over to another one.

174
00:09:59.060 --> 00:10:02.900
And they go 412 looks the best and
it doesn't matter if Daniel actually

175
00:10:02.900 --> 00:10:06.950
likes the company or not, but if they're
all formatted the same and they'll

176
00:10:06.950 --> 00:10:10.610
all have to make that identification, well
then the people that are deciding this

177
00:10:10.610 --> 00:10:14.240
don't they get to choose it based on
the merits of what's being presented.

178
00:10:14.240 --> 00:10:18.930
So these are actually part of that
process of getting everything in line.

179
00:10:18.930 --> 00:10:22.150
Of who's actually going to be suitable for

180
00:10:22.150 --> 00:10:26.420
what we're actually trying to procure and
that's the the key behind this as well.

181
00:10:26.420 --> 00:10:28.990
You want to make sure they
have the deadline and

182
00:10:28.990 --> 00:10:31.890
that you're not making
the decision before that deadline.

183
00:10:31.890 --> 00:10:34.230
If you're asking for
a formal presentation,

184
00:10:34.230 --> 00:10:36.910
well that now can skew
things a little bit more.

185
00:10:36.910 --> 00:10:40.420
You again outline the structure of what
the presentation should include and

186
00:10:40.420 --> 00:10:43.120
what it shouldn't,
when is it gonna happen.

187
00:10:43.120 --> 00:10:46.020
And then, that way they can actually
do everything that you need.

188
00:10:46.020 --> 00:10:47.690
But not every process is the same.

189
00:10:47.690 --> 00:10:51.380
But just kind of realize that at least
when you start talking about procurement,

190
00:10:51.380 --> 00:10:53.260
a lot of time some countries and

191
00:10:53.260 --> 00:10:57.620
depending on laws there, you may find
out it's stricter than you think.

192
00:10:57.620 --> 00:10:58.560
And you go, no,

193
00:10:58.560 --> 00:11:02.220
I just gave it to cousin Larry cuz he
didn't have a job doing right now, and

194
00:11:02.220 --> 00:11:05.910
it might as well be my cousin instead
of somebody, a stranger, I don't know.

195
00:11:05.910 --> 00:11:08.530
Well, all of a sudden you might find
out that other people come in and

196
00:11:08.530 --> 00:11:13.010
say, that's not actually part of the way
that we do bidding processes around here.

197
00:11:13.010 --> 00:11:15.230
You gotta follow those laws as well.

198
00:11:15.230 --> 00:11:19.270
So this procurement process here,
may be a little bit more formalized and

199
00:11:19.270 --> 00:11:22.020
regulated than you realize,
a lot of times, so

200
00:11:22.020 --> 00:11:27.870
just be aware of that as you continue on
in your project wherever you are, okay.

201
00:11:27.870 --> 00:11:31.200
Now, once you get all that information in,

202
00:11:31.200 --> 00:11:36.340
that's where we talk about evaluating
the actual seller response here.

203
00:11:36.340 --> 00:11:41.160
Remember that this is not supposed to be
based on fancy colors or who you know,

204
00:11:41.160 --> 00:11:42.640
nepotism of some sort.

205
00:11:42.640 --> 00:11:48.270
But, it should be based on whatever
criteria that we absolutely set up

206
00:11:48.270 --> 00:11:50.050
for making decision.

207
00:11:50.050 --> 00:11:53.780
Just like I said, if the company says,
I've got a great construction company.

208
00:11:53.780 --> 00:11:56.850
We've been around for 15 years but
I only have five people working for me.

209
00:11:56.850 --> 00:12:01.200
You need a construction company
that can absolutely do 500 people.

210
00:12:01.200 --> 00:12:02.910
Well, it need you can't set it up.

211
00:12:02.910 --> 00:12:04.460
They don't need the criteria.

212
00:12:04.460 --> 00:12:09.870
Don't even add them into that market to
do something like that as well, okay.

213
00:12:09.870 --> 00:12:13.460
You also need to be careful about who
actually isn't part of this selection.

214
00:12:13.460 --> 00:12:16.740
So before you get everything in,
you go ahead and

215
00:12:16.740 --> 00:12:21.610
you decide who's gonna be part of this
selection team that evaluates the actual

216
00:12:23.740 --> 00:12:27.210
bidder information that
you're gonna have on hand.

217
00:12:27.210 --> 00:12:30.740
And that way you're not loading
it on one way or the other.

218
00:12:30.740 --> 00:12:31.860
You're just saying,

219
00:12:31.860 --> 00:12:35.470
this is who's going to be on it and
here's what we're going to do.

220
00:12:35.470 --> 00:12:36.490
Here's our evaluation and

221
00:12:36.490 --> 00:12:40.860
here's our criteria to absolutely
get us to this point that we need.

222
00:12:40.860 --> 00:12:42.660
So having that on hand, right,

223
00:12:42.660 --> 00:12:46.750
is actually a big part of understanding
that it's not just that simple.

224
00:12:46.750 --> 00:12:50.480
It's not just saying, we need somebody to
go and just get us one because, remember,

225
00:12:50.480 --> 00:12:53.120
they still have to do all of the other
things that are required in our project.

226
00:12:53.120 --> 00:12:56.070
We want to make sure we get the right one,
get the right bang for

227
00:12:56.070 --> 00:12:57.020
the buck that we have.

228
00:12:57.020 --> 00:12:59.890
>> So, Ronnie, I'm taking a look at
the information you're giving us here and

229
00:12:59.890 --> 00:13:05.210
is it more common for
the closed bid kind of environment or

230
00:13:05.210 --> 00:13:10.000
do we see a lot more of it's not what
you know but who you know kind of thing?

231
00:13:10.000 --> 00:13:13.700
>> I am hoping that it's actually more
common for it to be a closed bid,

232
00:13:13.700 --> 00:13:15.370
