the buyer, minimal risk for the seller.

460
00:24:47.850 --> 00:24:50.560
It's kind of the middle ground
that we talk about here.

461
00:24:50.560 --> 00:24:55.210
But the problem is you now have
an unlimited cost ceiling, okay?

462
00:24:55.210 --> 00:24:59.760
The very fact is, you just don't
know how much this is actually gonna

463
00:24:59.760 --> 00:25:01.270
drive up things that you have.

464
00:25:01.270 --> 00:25:03.980
So you've gotta realize that
there's always trade-offs

465
00:25:03.980 --> 00:25:05.670
to these types of contracts.

466
00:25:05.670 --> 00:25:09.350
Then we start getting into property
rights and intellectual property and

467
00:25:09.350 --> 00:25:12.780
stuff like that, even more and
more contracts have to appear.

468
00:25:12.780 --> 00:25:18.860
But in that sense it's not something that
you can manage as a project manager.

469
00:25:18.860 --> 00:25:20.510
These are the ones that we can manage.

470
00:25:20.510 --> 00:25:24.820
We can absolutely say well, Daniel, we
don't have any more to reimburse you on,

471
00:25:24.820 --> 00:25:26.380
or do we, okay?

472
00:25:26.380 --> 00:25:30.660
You agreed on this price, I can now as a
project manager say here's what you agreed

473
00:25:30.660 --> 00:25:34.690
to do, you gotta get it done, and
this is the way it's gonna be.

474
00:25:34.690 --> 00:25:36.360
But in terms of intellectual rights,

475
00:25:36.360 --> 00:25:39.840
that's where you send it to legal team,
let them deal with it as well.

476
00:25:39.840 --> 00:25:41.600
But this is all part of that procurement,
and

477
00:25:41.600 --> 00:25:45.230
once we start doing it,
this is kinda the basic breakdown.

478
00:25:45.230 --> 00:25:46.440
Is it anything in detail?

479
00:25:46.440 --> 00:25:49.210
No way, I'm not gonna ever
get into anything like that.

480
00:25:49.210 --> 00:25:49.980
I'm gonna leave that for

481
00:25:49.980 --> 00:25:52.450
the people that go to law school-
>> [LAUGH]

482
00:25:52.450 --> 00:25:53.350
>> To actually deal with

483
00:25:53.350 --> 00:25:54.620
more than anything else.

484
00:25:54.620 --> 00:25:56.760
But right here though,
is at least a basis,

485
00:25:56.760 --> 00:25:59.420
if you're actually starting
to plan out for your project.

486
00:25:59.420 --> 00:26:01.800
If you know that there's a possibility
you're gonna reach out for

487
00:26:01.800 --> 00:26:05.660
anybody on the outside of your project,
essentially outsourcing it,

488
00:26:05.660 --> 00:26:08.620
you gotta actually come up with
some kind of procurement plan.

489
00:26:08.620 --> 00:26:10.200
>> Excellent explanation Ronnie.

490
00:26:10.200 --> 00:26:14.000
This is something that we're all gonna
have to deal with as project managers.

491
00:26:14.000 --> 00:26:17.330
So you just gonna start
working your way into that.

492
00:26:17.330 --> 00:26:19.820
Go over this episode a few time,
cuz this is setting up

493
00:26:19.820 --> 00:26:22.620
a really good foundational set
of knowledge for you on that.

494
00:26:22.620 --> 00:26:26.590
So that when it comes to okay, do we need
to outsource this, or is this something we

495
00:26:26.590 --> 00:26:30.800
can do in-house, you start filling
in the gaps of whatever goes outside

496
00:26:30.800 --> 00:26:34.430
of the capabilities of your current
situation, your current environment.

497
00:26:34.430 --> 00:26:38.120
Now you can bring those resources in,
get the work done necessary, and

498
00:26:38.120 --> 00:26:40.020
complete your projects
as you need them to.

499
00:26:40.020 --> 00:26:43.030
Ronnie, is there anything else we need to
cover for this episode before we wrap up?

500
00:26:43.030 --> 00:26:45.420
>> Not really for
the idea of any type of planning for

501
00:26:45.420 --> 00:26:48.240
procurement when we start
taking a look here.

502
00:26:48.240 --> 00:26:51.160
But just realize that we
have a foundational level.

503
00:26:51.160 --> 00:26:55.650
If you want more and more information on
this, you might wanna check out the itself

504
00:26:55.650 --> 00:26:59.260
and of course, our series on PNP
to actually give you a little

505
00:26:59.260 --> 00:27:02.600
bit more of a solid foundation there,
a little bit more in depth knowledge.

506
00:27:02.600 --> 00:27:05.610
But here is the general stuff
that normally goes into

507
00:27:05.610 --> 00:27:07.760
basic project procurement planning.

508
00:27:07.760 --> 00:27:10.910
>> Excellent stuff, thanks again for
joining us today Ronnie, and thank you for

509
00:27:10.910 --> 00:27:12.920
watching, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off.

510
00:27:12.920 --> 00:27:15.580
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

511
00:27:15.580 --> 00:27:16.340
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

512
00:27:16.340 --> 00:27:18.381
>> And we'll see you next time.

513
00:27:18.381 --> 00:27:25.250
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the purpose and common components of a transition plan. Transition management components covered include Ownership, Transition Dates, Training, Extended Support, and Warranties.
episodes.title: Plan Transition Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.258 --> 00:00:16.830
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.830 --> 00:00:18.940
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.940 --> 00:00:21.590
we are continuing on with
our Project Plus series.

5
00:00:21.590 --> 00:00:24.910
Joining us back in the studio again today
is none other than our good friend and

6
00:00:24.910 --> 00:00:25.820
mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:25.820 --> 00:00:27.070
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

8
00:00:27.070 --> 00:00:28.420
>> Well thank you for
having me on the show.

9
00:00:28.420 --> 00:00:32.072
As we continue to take a look
at CompTIA's Project+ and

10
00:00:32.072 --> 00:00:36.010
we are continuing to move
through our planning phase.

11
00:00:36.010 --> 00:00:38.282
And today, we actually get to do
something that's actually a little

12
00:00:38.282 --> 00:00:38.958
bit unusual for us.

13
00:00:38.958 --> 00:00:44.640
In the past, well lots of episodes, we've
really been stuck in the planning phase.

14
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:48.690
Today, we're transitioning
out of that planning phase.

15
00:00:48.690 --> 00:00:52.180
And so there's one more element that
we need to talk about of course,

16
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:53.860
which is the idea of planning for

17
00:00:53.860 --> 00:00:57.970
transition management is what
we're actually talking about.

18
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:01.740
So the good thing is, I've kind
of made myself a deal even during

19
00:01:01.740 --> 00:01:06.030
the pre project set up or
the initiation phase.

20
00:01:06.030 --> 00:01:11.440
We went through the phases of project
management almost in every single episode.

21
00:01:11.440 --> 00:01:15.550
During the plan, I'm not gonna do that
to everybody on every single episode.

22
00:01:15.550 --> 00:01:19.470
But now that we've actually gotten a lot
of episodes in and really just about to

23
00:01:19.470 --> 00:01:23.720
finish that planning phase,
this is a great point and reminder for us.

24
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:26.460
And then I wanna show you where
the transition phase fits in

25
00:01:26.460 --> 00:01:29.080
here with the transition plan fits in.

26
00:01:29.080 --> 00:01:32.480
So let's go ahead and
take a look at my diagram here.

27
00:01:32.480 --> 00:01:37.420
And that will help reminds us of some of
the things that we are looking at as well.

28
00:01:37.420 --> 00:01:40.650
So when we start to do what
we call project management.

29
00:01:40.650 --> 00:01:44.459
Remember that if all projects go
through five different phases and

30
00:01:44.459 --> 00:01:48.404
even though we tend to be able to
talk about them in sequential order,

31
00:01:48.404 --> 00:01:50.528
they don't really happen that way.

32
00:01:50.528 --> 00:01:53.380
In reality it tends to
be this way instead.

33
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:57.750
We talk about the idea of the initiation
of the pre-project set up and

34
00:01:57.750 --> 00:02:02.980
this is where we have the basic idea
of the project coming on board and

35
00:02:02.980 --> 00:02:04.648
we don't really have anything else yet.

36
00:02:04.648 --> 00:02:07.920
But we wanna make sure that we get
everything started to set up for

37
00:02:07.920 --> 00:02:09.140
our project.

38
00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:13.716
The initial outcome of that
is gonna end up being for

39
00:02:13.716 --> 00:02:17.448
us of course, then the project charter.

40
00:02:17.448 --> 00:02:22.377
The project charter is essentially a nice
big summary of everything we believe

41
00:02:22.377 --> 00:02:25.450
we're gonna accomplish on the project.

42
00:02:25.450 --> 00:02:30.257
But ultimately, the most important
element of that project charter is

43
00:02:30.257 --> 00:02:35.063
that project sponsor signing off,
authorizing us to go ahead and say,

44
00:02:35.063 --> 00:02:38.767
this project can now get
started is what we're doing.

45
00:02:38.767 --> 00:02:43.772
Then what we've been doing is right
here in the planning phase and

46
00:02:43.772 --> 00:02:48.520
in the planning we've taken
a lot of time multiple elements.

47
00:02:48.520 --> 00:02:52.710
We've talked about the idea of
planning out the work packages.

48
00:02:52.710 --> 00:02:57.140
We've talked about the scheduling
of our project as well.

49
00:02:57.140 --> 00:03:00.440
We've also talked about cost management,
quality management,

50
00:03:00.440 --> 00:03:03.210
we've taken a look at a lot
of different things too.

51
00:03:03.210 --> 00:03:06.230
Procurement, human resource management,
resource management.

52
00:03:06.230 --> 00:03:09.580
You name it, we've taken a look
at a lot of different plans and

53
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:12.890
some of the things that we have
to consider as project managers.

54
00:03:12.890 --> 00:03:14.529
And so we're about to move in,

55
00:03:14.529 --> 00:03:18.388
especially as the episodes start
that we're about to begin recording.

56
00:03:18.388 --> 00:03:24.380
We're really moving into the execution
phase is where we're moving into.

57
00:03:24.380 --> 00:03:27.357
And then after that of course,
will be monitoring and controlling and

58
00:03:27.357 --> 00:03:28.018
then closing.

59
00:03:28.018 --> 00:03:32.269
And so when you look at the way that it's
normally lined up as a linear line most of

60
00:03:32.269 --> 00:03:36.458
the time, where you see initiation,
planning, execution, monitoring and

61
00:03:36.458 --> 00:03:38.440
controlling, and closing.

62
00:03:38.440 --> 00:03:42.490
Well we realized something here that
what happens is as you execute,

63
00:03:42.490 --> 00:03:46.780
your also doing monitoring and
controlling in reality at the same time.

64
00:03:46.780 --> 00:03:50.710
And then you're probably finishing both
of them up about the same time and

65
00:03:50.710 --> 00:03:54.470
then turning it over to closing, which
is closing out of the entire project.

66
00:03:54.470 --> 00:03:58.760
So those are kind of the basic
phases that we're talking about

67
00:03:58.760 --> 00:04:02.470
when we actually start to look at
the overall project management.

68
00:04:02.470 --> 00:04:07.248
Also as a great point in time for us to
be reminded of the project constraints.

69
00:04:07.248 --> 00:04:11.644
And we'll be dealing more with project
constraints especially in the execution

70
00:04:11.644 --> 00:04:14.250
phase as we try and balance all three.

71
00:04:14.250 --> 00:04:17.220
Remember that what we are always
trying to do here is make sure that

72
00:04:17.220 --> 00:04:22.520
the requirements, the scheduling, and
the budget are all actually in balance,

73
00:04:22.520 --> 00:04:25.880
and that's actually a very good thing for
us on the project.

74
00:04:25.880 --> 00:04:29.100
Any time we emphasize
one over the other ones,

75
00:04:29.100 --> 00:04:31.240
the other two will end up suffering here.

76
00:04:31.240 --> 00:04:36.131
So if we say that we need something to be
fast, well what ends up happening then is

77
00:04:36.131 --> 00:04:40.738
that puts more of a burden on the idea
of meeting the project requirements.

78
00:04:40.738 --> 00:04:43.856
In other words, we may cut short
on those requirements, and

79
00:04:43.856 --> 00:04:46.320
we end up costing a lot more as well.

80
00:04:46.320 --> 00:04:49.540
So remember that there's usually
a cliche that's also involved here.

81
00:04:49.540 --> 00:04:52.490
We always talk about this idea that
everybody wants everything good,

82
00:04:52.490 --> 00:04:53.810
fast, and cheap.

83
00:04:53.810 --> 00:04:57.120
Well, we can give you two out of
the three the majority of the times.

84
00:04:57.120 --> 00:05:00.798
But you can't actually take all three and
say, I want all of them.

85
00:05:00.798 --> 00:05:04.449
What you would normally have to do is
actually figure out a balance between them

86
00:05:04.449 --> 00:05:07.390
as much as you can and
not weigh one more than the other.

87
00:05:07.390 --> 00:05:10.740
So that's the key here in
getting a project done.

88
00:05:10.740 --> 00:05:14.700
And that's why we go through the planning
is so that this can actually happen

89
00:05:14.700 --> 00:05:18.680
during the time we're really starting
to get work done for our project.

90
00:05:19.760 --> 00:05:24.620
Now, even though we're now really at the
end and finish of our planning, and we're

91
00:05:24.620 --> 00:05:29.148
not really creating a ton of other plans
that we have to worry about and look at.

92
00:05:29.148 --> 00:05:33.730
We do need to actually create what
we call a project transition plan.

93
00:05:33.730 --> 00:05:39.170
And the project transition plan for
us works on multiple levels.

94
00:05:39.170 --> 00:05:43.380
So let me show you where a project
transition plan would normally fit in

95
00:05:43.380 --> 00:05:44.500
to the overall scheme.

96
00:05:44.500 --> 00:05:46.540
So I'm gonna go back to this diagram.

97
00:05:46.540 --> 00:05:50.900
Down here, let me go ahead and
add in the other word here.

98
00:05:50.900 --> 00:05:54.988
I put transition but
let me talk about transition plan here.

99
00:05:54.988 --> 00:05:57.849
If we wanted to talk
about transition plans,

100
00:05:57.849 --> 00:06:03.280
well normally we have a transition plan
just for every phases in our project.

101
00:06:03.280 --> 00:06:08.561
As I'm moving out of the initiation
going into the project planning,

102
00:06:08.561 --> 00:06:13.228
I don't have an official plan
that's normally written out.

103
00:06:13.228 --> 00:06:17.651
But once I actually get a project charter,
that now authorizes me to go ahead and

104
00:06:17.651 --> 00:06:21.480
begin, so that is kind of an add ad
hoc transition plan that is to say,

105
00:06:21.480 --> 00:06:23.210
here is a go no go at this point.

106
00:06:23.210 --> 00:06:25.698
I get it signed, we're ready to move on.

107
00:06:25.698 --> 00:06:29.631
At the end of the planning phase
as I move in from planning,

108
00:06:29.631 --> 00:06:32.845
in other words getting
all my plans together and

109
00:06:32.845 --> 00:06:37.940
we're about to move in to transition
of execution of my project.

110
00:06:37.940 --> 00:06:42.550
I can also have a transition phase right
there, and I might need a plan for that.

111
00:06:42.550 --> 00:06:46.208
In other words, do wanna have
all of those plans ready to go?

112
00:06:46.208 --> 00:06:49.956
Do they need to be reviewed or, do they
need that actually take a look at some

113
00:06:49.956 --> 00:06:52.578
other things that are going
on before we begin this?

114
00:06:52.578 --> 00:06:56.574
Is there anything else that we need
to do as we now turn it over to,

115
00:06:56.574 --> 00:07:02.160
well the actual functional managers that
are now gonna be carrying out the work?

116
00:07:02.160 --> 00:07:06.452
So I can come out with a plan for all of
my different phases in the execution to

117
00:07:06.452 --> 00:07:09.808
say, here's how this stuff
is going to transition over.

118
00:07:09.808 --> 00:07:12.109
Who do I hand these plans off to?

119
00:07:12.109 --> 00:07:13.920
How do I actually get this thing going?

120
00:07:15.190 --> 00:07:16.840
So we can have that too.

121
00:07:16.840 --> 00:07:18.840
And then of course ultimately,

122
00:07:18.840 --> 00:07:24.910
when everything is done as far as work
goes on the entire project itself,

123
00:07:24.910 --> 00:07:31.030
now we can talk about the hand
off to whoever our customer is.

124
00:07:31.030 --> 00:07:33.780
Now, remember our customer can
be internal to our company,

125
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:36.460
it can be external to our company as well.

126
00:07:36.460 --> 00:07:39.952
So what you're starting to see
here is the same cycles that we

127
00:07:39.952 --> 00:07:44.548
talked about at the beginning of the
planning phase that everything has a plan.

128
00:07:44.548 --> 00:07:48.166
So even though we talked about
moving into the planning cycle for

129
00:07:48.166 --> 00:07:52.990
the overall project itself, as we start
actually breaking down into work packages,

130
00:07:52.990 --> 00:07:57.630
I can assign that work package to them and
say Dan, start planning this out for me.

131
00:07:57.630 --> 00:08:02.173
Dan works through all the plans that
he needs to for his work package and

132
00:08:02.173 --> 00:08:04.406
then at the end, he might go, so.

133
00:08:04.406 --> 00:08:07.794
Who in the world after I've
finished my work package,

134
00:08:07.794 --> 00:08:11.720
where does that product go or
what does the next step?

135
00:08:11.720 --> 00:08:14.720
And then I tell them,
you're supposed to hand that off to Mike.

136
00:08:14.720 --> 00:08:16.600
Well, what are those procedures?

137
00:08:16.600 --> 00:08:18.680
That's where that
transition phase comes in.

138
00:08:18.680 --> 00:08:21.520
The procedures that need to be
done then to hand it off to Mike.

139
00:08:21.520 --> 00:08:23.760
So you can see why everything that we do,

140
00:08:23.760 --> 00:08:27.320
even though this is the overall
process at a major scale,

141
00:08:27.320 --> 00:08:31.290
you can see how that actually continues
to break down level by level.

142
00:08:31.290 --> 00:08:33.690
So that everything we're
doing is at process.

143
00:08:33.690 --> 00:08:36.220
And you might say why is so
important we follow that?

144
00:08:36.220 --> 00:08:39.300
Because this is about project management,
right?

145
00:08:39.300 --> 00:08:41.970
The ability for us to manage everything

146
00:08:41.970 --> 00:08:46.040
actually breaks down that way where
we do have it at every single level.

147
00:08:46.040 --> 00:08:47.190
And so we turn that over so

148
00:08:47.190 --> 00:08:51.030
I'm not micromanaging Daniel's
particular work package.

149
00:08:51.030 --> 00:08:54.620
Daniel's not having to go and
micromanage somebody else's.

150
00:08:54.620 --> 00:08:58.350
He just goes ahead and says look, make
sure sure you follow this process through.

151
00:08:58.350 --> 00:08:59.710
And we start seeing that.

152
00:08:59.710 --> 00:09:03.050
So that's where you also will
see transition management

153
00:09:03.050 --> 00:09:05.250
overall when you start seeing that.

154
00:09:05.250 --> 00:09:07.360
So everybody has their transitions.

155
00:09:07.360 --> 00:09:10.150
And we all have to work with them cuz
we're working with people a lot of times.

156
00:09:10.150 --> 00:09:12.470
And we have to actually make
sure they're coordinated,

157
00:09:12.470 --> 00:09:14.920
that they fit into
the overall project itself.

158
00:09:14.920 --> 00:09:17.050
>> Now Ronnie when it comes
to transition management and

159
00:09:17.050 --> 00:09:20.750
creating that plan,
how do you know who is that owner?

160
00:09:20.750 --> 00:09:23.890
Does that come back to what
we did in our pre-planning or

161
00:09:23.890 --> 00:09:25.960
during our planning phases itself?

162
00:09:25.960 --> 00:09:27.170
>> It really can, right?

163
00:09:27.170 --> 00:09:29.960
So when you actually go all
the way back to pre-planning,

164
00:09:29.960 --> 00:09:33.060
you may actually know who is
actually gonna be the owner.

165
00:09:33.060 --> 00:09:35.900
So we take a look at the grand
scale which is what we're gonna do.

166
00:09:35.900 --> 00:09:40.210
What are some of the elements that we
include inside of this project plan?

167
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:45.350
One of that, one of those elements then,
is that depending on where we are, right?

168
00:09:45.350 --> 00:09:48.320
When we are finished let's
say with the overall project,

169
00:09:48.320 --> 00:09:52.990
we need something that absolutely
says who is now the owner, okay?

170
00:09:52.990 --> 00:09:55.400
Now that sounds a little bit unusual.

171

I have nothing else to do with it,

399
00:21:39.100 --> 00:21:40.540
the project's done.

400
00:21:40.540 --> 00:21:43.790
Your particular company may
offer a warranty to say,

401
00:21:43.790 --> 00:21:47.830
we are still gonna be responsible for
some of the things.

402
00:21:47.830 --> 00:21:51.790
So let's say, if it's a design flaw,
we'll be responsible for it.

403
00:21:51.790 --> 00:21:58.219
Let's say, if it's a process flaw,
something that we did, yes.

404
00:21:58.219 --> 00:22:03.080
But if it's an installation thing, we may
not actually do support for that, okay?

405
00:22:03.080 --> 00:22:06.070
Or if you've abused a product,
that's the one I normally see, right?

406
00:22:06.070 --> 00:22:10.190
If you've used this in any other way
besides what it was designed for,

407
00:22:10.190 --> 00:22:14.300
then you can't actually ask us to
do warranty work for that as well.

408
00:22:14.300 --> 00:22:15.520
Now can you pay somebody to do it?

409
00:22:15.520 --> 00:22:18.790
Probably, but remember,
that's not gonna come under warranty.

410
00:22:18.790 --> 00:22:21.040
Warranty is about who is responsible for
paying for

411
00:22:21.040 --> 00:22:24.480
that work, not about just
who's doing the work itself.

412
00:22:24.480 --> 00:22:27.100
So just kind of realize that happens too,
and

413
00:22:27.100 --> 00:22:31.770
you can even include in a bit of service
level agreement in that warranty and

414
00:22:31.770 --> 00:22:33.910
make sure those are clearly delineated.

415
00:22:33.910 --> 00:22:37.300
But all that comes in that transition
phase, when we start taking it and

416
00:22:37.300 --> 00:22:40.670
looking at it from the overall
project itself toward the end.

417
00:22:40.670 --> 00:22:41.910
Is that part of planning?

418
00:22:41.910 --> 00:22:44.890
It is a part of planning itself, right?

419

They don't really consider it
a transition plan per se, but

420
00:22:48.680 --> 00:22:50.560
it is something that we
do need to think about.

421
00:22:50.560 --> 00:22:54.200
That when we finish a project,
what is done with it?

422
00:22:54.200 --> 00:22:57.850
We don't just get a lot of times,
I'm gonna say this in all honesty.

423
00:22:57.850 --> 00:23:01.810
You don't just get to say, I'm done,
I walk away, and you disappear.

424
00:23:01.810 --> 00:23:04.890
You normally do have to stand
behind your work some way, somehow.

425
00:23:04.890 --> 00:23:07.850
The transition phase,
make sure that everybody's in agreement of

426
00:23:07.850 --> 00:23:12.080
who's gonna be responsible for it, who's
gonna pay for it, how long is it gonna be.

427
00:23:12.080 --> 00:23:15.240
And that way everybody knows and
can actually accept it, and

428
00:23:15.240 --> 00:23:16.870
move on from that point.

429
00:23:16.870 --> 00:23:20.850
But it is a very important part of
actually finishing up the idea of planning

430
00:23:20.850 --> 00:23:21.970
as well.

431
00:23:21.970 --> 00:23:26.020
So once you have that in hand,
now you can feel with confidence that,

00:23:26.020 --> 00:23:29.460
as you hand this product off

00:23:32.854 --> 00:23:35.352
And that you feel good about it as well,
that you don't just go,

435
00:23:35.352 --> 00:23:40.960
let me leave as quietly as I can and
disappear so they can't find me again.

436
00:23:40.960 --> 00:23:43.770
So the transition is really a great
element that we need to include.

437
00:23:43.770 --> 00:23:45.485
>> That's right, and
that's really what it's all about.

438
00:23:45.485 --> 00:23:48.628
Is trying to get the product
after the project is over

00:23:48.628 --> 00:23:53.500
from your hands into the customer, and

440
00:23:53.500 --> 00:23:57.779
And then your extended level of
interaction with them as well,

441
00:23:57.779 --> 00:23:59.967
as necessary, after the fact.

442
00:23:59.967 --> 00:24:02.405
And that's what we do here, and
we're almost done with the planning.

443

So you got to put that into your plan.

444
00:24:04.042 --> 00:24:04.598

>> So that when the project is

447

Ronnie is there anything else we need to

448
00:24:15.660 --> 00:24:17.250
>> No, not so
much the idea of transitioning,

00:24:17.250 --> 00:24:21.220
but remember closing out of

The project plan itself

As you've actually seen in the previous

in other episodes that we've had.

00:24:30.100 --> 00:24:33.740
It actually includes a lot of small

that we can actually have the ability

455

to understand and
how to manage the entire project.

456
00:24:40.760 --> 00:24:44.375
So when you take a look at all the things

And whether we're talking about cost

00:24:48.001 --> 00:24:49.030

459
00:24:49.030 --> 00:24:50.970
Whatever it may be, right?

460
00:24:50.970 --> 00:24:55.090
All that is now actually,
what we're saying here in the transition,

461
00:24:55.090 --> 00:24:59.010
from this into the execution

462
00:24:59.010 --> 00:25:01.870
Okay, that we are completely

00:25:01.870 --> 00:25:04.880
now we're ready to move

So that is the goal and idea behind

00:25:08.070 --> 00:25:12.300

00:25:12.300 --> 00:25:14.880
So what we're saying then,
right, is if we get to this

point where we're now doing
the transition and everything is done.

468
00:25:18.540 --> 00:25:22.820
We are saying that as far as project
managers go that we are confident that we

469
00:25:22.820 --> 00:25:26.460
can move on from this project, if we're
actually closing on the entire project.

470
00:25:26.460 --> 00:25:29.880
Or we're confident that we can

471
00:25:29.880 --> 00:25:34.370

controlling phase, as well.

472
00:25:34.370 --> 00:25:34.950
Okay?

473
00:25:34.950 --> 00:25:38.760
So this is a big part of what we have

474
00:25:38.760 --> 00:25:39.960
It's easy to sit down and

when you haven't spent a dime yet.

476

When you can dream big and
do everything and

even though it's a headache at times,
it's easy to do that.

478

Now we're gonna move into the point

of those plans that we created and

480
00:25:57.560 --> 00:26:00.660
actually giving them the work,
we're actually gonna start building stuff.

00:26:00.660 --> 00:26:01.870
Is what we're taking or

00:26:01.870 --> 00:26:05.210
figuring out how to manage, while stuff

483
00:26:05.210 --> 00:26:09.370
>> Well we look very forward to that and
thank you so much Ronnie for

Your veritable wealth of knowledge.

>> When it comes to project planning.

Hopefully you guys out there, you got

Like, hopefully.

[LAUGH] Having a great time here.

>> Enjoyed having Ronnie on the show we

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the process of coordinating human resources to assemble a project team, build cohesiveness and perform individual appraisals. They cover the 5 phases of team development; Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing, and Adjourning. Then they explore team building through formal and informal activities.
episodes.title: Coordinate Human Resources
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

And welcome to another

We're moving from the planning phase

So we're gonna begin really right here

The problem that we have is fairly simple.

Is that as we start assembling our team of

We start to realize something

always a lot of different

Let's take for

You might find out that even though you

The other thing of course

Remember that even in that instance in

people, that actually go well I

And you can see why that doesn't

You can even of course have
the difference between technical versus

And of course temporary roles and

You name it, there is actually

So, one of the things that talked about

What actually has to happen here and

And that's what we're gonna be

Now if you're going man I've been through

But remember you're preparing for

But everything that you've gone through,

But let's learn their terminology and

So if we have to overcome a lot of

So we're gonna take a look at how

00:04:27.650 --> 00:04:31.140
So let's go ahead and take a look

this will help us out just

So when we start taking a look here

We want to make sure that we

We'll see that the term's forming,

But when we start talking about forming,

The reason why is right at the beginning,

And don't get me wrong

What really is important is that we are

So we wanna make sure that

Is that we give them that

>> Yeah if you're talking about forming

00:06:51.260 --> 00:06:56.050
Then, what you're gonna see from that

So you don't want the person, excuse me,

So, normally in these types of situations

But it's the idea of actually

know is gonna need to happen

If great communication

And it's about the idea of coordination or

You do things that actually allow them

So you can come up with a ton of

If you want them just to muddle along,

But if you really actually

00:22:11.480 --> 00:22:14.740
is gonna be one of the fastest ways

what do I hang on to

Okay?

Now, once you get that done, right?

It doesn't mean that throughout

So you'll see this more

You guys have to get together.

You have to build up the communication.

It's always about communication.

I know exactly where

Help relieve some of that stress.

Things like that can be a big help

Ronnie, I'm looking at our clock.

>> Well, let's go ahead and

[LAUGH] And then we'll end up doing.

00:25:14.300 --> 00:25:16.730
So what else does have to happen then?

00:25:16.730 --> 00:25:19.910
Okay, it's great to have
a team that feels cohesive.

00:25:19.910 --> 00:25:24.068
It's great to actually have the team
understand well, a couple of things.

495
00:25:24.068 --> 00:25:25.690
We want them to be effective.

496
00:25:25.690 --> 00:25:27.840
We want them to be able to perform.

497
00:25:27.840 --> 00:25:31.080
We want to encourage them to do that
as a project manager that's really our

498
00:25:31.080 --> 00:25:32.280
job and our goal.

499
00:25:32.280 --> 00:25:34.810
Because we know something,
if they're actually working as a team and

500
00:25:34.810 --> 00:25:39.400
they're being effective and productive,
well then we know that there's more than

501
00:25:39.400 --> 00:25:42.680
a likely chance that our
project is gonna get done

502
00:25:42.680 --> 00:25:45.970
in the manner that we want it done and
on time that we want it done as well.

503
00:25:46.980 --> 00:25:51.760
But, there's always a but to it,
we have to make sure that we can actually

504
00:25:51.760 --> 00:25:56.420
monitor the progress and of course,
the performance of our team members too.

505
00:25:56.420 --> 00:26:01.009
Now the reason why we want to, right,
is that Daniel actually just mentioned it,

506
00:26:01.009 --> 00:26:03.083
that the idea here is fairly simple.

00:26:03.083 --> 00:26:07.850
When there is a visible note from

00:26:07.850 --> 00:26:12.780
hey, Ronnie is really struggling
with this and having a bad time.

509
00:26:12.780 --> 00:26:15.113
And he takes it on himself to say,
let me just take Ronnie out to lunch.

00:26:15.113 --> 00:26:17.500
And maybe we kind of let the steam off and
do that.

511
00:26:17.500 --> 00:26:19.180
That's perfectly fine.

512
00:26:19.180 --> 00:26:20.730
But the problem is this.

00:26:20.730 --> 00:26:24.680
During that time, you don't know how far
Ronnie's performance may have dropped.

514
00:26:24.680 --> 00:26:25.860
It can happen.

515
00:26:25.860 --> 00:26:30.080
So what you need to do then is to have
some structure in place that actually

516
00:26:30.080 --> 00:26:35.420
gives you this ability to monitor
the team in several different ways.

517
00:26:35.420 --> 00:26:37.970
So one of the things that you want to make
sure that you understand when we start

518
00:26:37.970 --> 00:26:43.120
talking about the idea of monitoring
here is that a project manager allows

519
00:26:43.120 --> 00:26:47.790

of choice in a lot of things that they do,

520
00:26:47.790 --> 00:26:50.050
so they don't do over micromanage things.

521
00:26:50.050 --> 00:26:55.200
But at the same time, it has to also
be able to explain to the team member

522
00:26:55.200 --> 00:26:58.640
like Ronnie that may be falling behind,
that you still expect productivity.

523
00:26:58.640 --> 00:27:01.840
And the way that you actually
clarify that, believe it or not,

524
00:27:01.840 --> 00:27:07.540
is actually having a good performance
monitoring in place, okay?

525
00:27:07.540 --> 00:27:11.390
In this type of performance monitoring,
whether it's somebody walking around,

526
00:27:11.390 --> 00:27:14.460
whether it's actually daily
reports that come in,

527
00:27:14.460 --> 00:27:18.510
whatever it is,
you want to make sure that any time

528
00:27:18.510 --> 00:27:22.560
that you are trying to do the performance
mantra, that everything is clear here.

529
00:27:22.560 --> 00:27:25.750
You wanna make sure that everybody
understands what the expectations are.

530
00:27:25.750 --> 00:27:29.720
If this is a daily expectation, make sure
you tell them, it's a daily expectation.

531
00:27:29.720 --> 00:27:32.760
So for example,
we put a daily expectation ourselves at

532
00:27:32.760 --> 00:27:35.200
we're gonna produce three shows a day,
at least, okay.

533
00:27:35.200 --> 00:27:38.110
You may produce four sometimes
which is really great.

534
00:27:38.110 --> 00:27:39.820
But it's should be at least three.

535
00:27:39.820 --> 00:27:42.530
When I don't produce three,
I don't feel good about that day.

536
00:27:42.530 --> 00:27:45.210
And then I try and look for
ways I can make that up, okay?

537
00:27:45.210 --> 00:27:48.300
So you wanna make sure that
the performance expectations are there.

538
00:27:48.300 --> 00:27:51.850
You also need a way that
clearly marks this point here,

539
00:27:51.850 --> 00:27:56.000
where you actually start seeing
the inadequate performance behaviors.

540
00:27:56.000 --> 00:27:58.920
Well, for
us on the show it makes it very easy for

541
00:27:58.920 --> 00:28:03.080
us here, which is, we didn't get three,
well why didn't we?

542
00:28:03.080 --> 00:28:06.000
And try and figure out what it is,
what areas are actually lacking.

543
00:28:06.000 --> 00:28:09.770
Is it me not getting up there on time,
getting ready to go?

544
00:28:09.770 --> 00:28:12.720
Or is it something else that's actually
preventing us from doing that.

545
00:28:12.720 --> 00:28:14.830
So there has to be a way
that we can measure that,

546
00:28:14.830 --> 00:28:16.190
that we can actually look at it.

547
00:28:16.190 --> 00:28:18.200
As a project manager you do too.

548
00:28:18.200 --> 00:28:22.760
You need to have a way that you can say,
this is actually a performance problem,

549
00:28:22.760 --> 00:28:26.400
it's not a defect problem,
it's not a problem with missing equipment.

550
00:28:26.400 --> 00:28:29.660
This is a performance issue
that ends up happening and so

551
00:28:29.660 --> 00:28:32.500
you will also got to be doing that too.

552
00:28:32.500 --> 00:28:35.650
The other things of course,
talk about rewards as well as,

553
00:28:35.650 --> 00:28:38.370
of course, reprimands, okay?

554
00:28:38.370 --> 00:28:41.340
Now when you talk about the idea of
rewards especially if the performance

555
00:28:41.340 --> 00:28:46.860
is superior, the recommendation here
is of course that these rewards can be,

556
00:28:46.860 --> 00:28:50.140
and a lot of times maybe should be
done publicly in front of their peers

557
00:28:50.140 --> 00:28:55.120
to let them know that yes, I do recognize
that as being superior performance.

558
00:28:55.120 --> 00:28:57.690
But they don't recommend that for
reprimands.

559
00:28:57.690 --> 00:29:02.120
In other words, reprimands that are done
publicly usually are not ever taken well,

560
00:29:02.120 --> 00:29:03.500
as far as I know.

561
00:29:03.500 --> 00:29:08.140
I know I've never actually taken
anything like that very well at all.

562
00:29:08.140 --> 00:29:12.660
But the idea of doing this privately
actually shows what, well, kind of

563
00:29:12.660 --> 00:29:17.100
a compassion here that you understand that
that person is not performing as well.

564
00:29:17.100 --> 00:29:20.250
But you're also saying what I
need you to perform well, and

565
00:29:20.250 --> 00:29:22.510
let's get this back online here, okay.

566
00:29:22.510 --> 00:29:26.060
But you're not doing it in front of
everybody to actually provide more

567
00:29:26.060 --> 00:29:28.290
heaping on their shoulders
than they can handle.

568
00:29:28.290 --> 00:29:30.250
And sometimes you just don't know,

569
00:29:30.250 --> 00:29:33.620
especially when you think everything is
on your shoulders as project manager.

570
00:29:33.620 --> 00:29:36.280
>> Yeah,
plus when you reward people in public,

571
00:29:36.280 --> 00:29:38.400
what does it do to the rest of the team?

572
00:29:38.400 --> 00:29:41.520
It builds them up,
they think wow man, if we

00:29:41.520 --> 00:29:45.880

574
00:29:45.880 --> 00:29:49.170
There's an incentive and they're

00:29:49.170 --> 00:29:51.065
If you reprimand someone

00:29:51.065 --> 00:29:52.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> You're

577
00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:56.280
gonna feel the tension in the room
get super thick, super quick.

578
00:29:56.280 --> 00:29:57.285
And that is not what you want.

579
00:29:57.285 --> 00:30:00.990
And everybody's production
is actually gonna hinder it,

580
00:30:00.990 --> 00:30:03.960
cuz even though they feel like I'm
sticking my nose to the grindstone, in

581
00:30:03.960 --> 00:30:07.560
the back of their head they're constantly
worrying, their anxieties go up.

582
00:30:07.560 --> 00:30:10.400
And then the cohesion of the team
starts to break down, because

583
00:30:10.400 --> 00:30:13.470
now all they worry about is getting
what they're supposed to do done and

584
00:30:13.470 --> 00:30:17.570
not interacting with their team members,
helping them, everybody working together.

585
00:30:17.570 --> 00:30:20.180
Communication breaks down,
everything breaks down.

586
00:30:20.180 --> 00:30:21.460
Productivity drops.

587
00:30:21.460 --> 00:30:22.250
Bad case scenario.

588
00:30:22.250 --> 00:30:24.970
Do the reprimanding
behind closed doors and

589
00:30:24.970 --> 00:30:27.800
then try to build everybody
up in front of everyone.

590
00:30:27.800 --> 00:30:31.500
>> And Daniel, you bring up a great point
here about the communication break down.

591
00:30:31.500 --> 00:30:34.110
The problem is,
if that person is performing poorly,

592
00:30:34.110 --> 00:30:36.170
he isn't gonna communicate
the way that he needs to.

593
00:30:36.170 --> 00:30:39.250
And so the rest of your team is
also gonna suffer some performance,

594
00:30:39.250 --> 00:30:41.570
especially if he's an integral
part of that team.

595
00:30:41.570 --> 00:30:44.660
But even worse for
you as a project manager is this,

596
00:30:44.660 --> 00:30:48.570
is your communication now,
you stop actually getting communication.

597
00:30:48.570 --> 00:30:52.720
The person that gets reprimanded publicly
doesn't feel like communicating with

598
00:30:52.720 --> 00:30:54.247
the person that reprimanded them.

599
00:30:54.247 --> 00:30:57.560
And so a lot of times where you might
have actually gotten a steady stream of

600
00:30:57.560 --> 00:31:00.700
good information on the performance
of your work package or

601
00:31:00.700 --> 00:31:02.110
whatever it is at that point.

602
00:31:02.110 --> 00:31:04.380
You might find that now you get zero.

603
00:31:04.380 --> 00:31:08.330
You get nothing, you know,
as any type of indication and so

604
00:31:08.330 --> 00:31:10.490
now you actually come in and

605
00:31:10.490 --> 00:31:15.200
now you start to do more micro-managing
than you though you should need to.

606
00:31:15.200 --> 00:31:17.490
But you believe that that's
the only way to accomplish that.

607
00:31:17.490 --> 00:31:20.165
When what might have actually been
a little bit easier is simple,

608
00:31:20.165 --> 00:31:24.590
is to understand that in this process of
monitoring here, that even a reprimand

609
00:31:24.590 --> 00:31:27.510
actually need to take into
consideration who you're reprimanding.

610
00:31:27.510 --> 00:31:30.520
And a lot of times doing that in
private is gonna be more productive

611
00:31:30.520 --> 00:31:33.630
than ever doing it publicly
is the other one too.

612
00:31:33.630 --> 00:31:37.178
Also, you need to let people know that
there are consequences to their choices

613
00:31:37.178 --> 00:31:38.830
for their performance as well.

614
00:31:38.830 --> 00:31:40.240
Okay, the very fact is,

615
00:31:40.240 --> 00:31:43.450
sometimes there are people that say,
I'll do my bare minimum.

616
00:31:43.450 --> 00:31:46.338
And you can tell them,
you need to tell them as project manager,

617
00:31:46.338 --> 00:31:47.258
that is not enough.

618
00:31:47.258 --> 00:31:52.118
At this stage in our project, we need
everybody to actually perform better or

619
00:31:52.118 --> 00:31:55.798
to actually perform more than
they've ever done before.

620
00:31:55.798 --> 00:31:59.683
But somebody that's willing just to glide
along at whatever level they're willing to

621
00:31:59.683 --> 00:32:00.328
glide along.

622
00:32:00.328 --> 00:32:04.358
If it's not because they
can't do any better, okay?

623
00:32:04.358 --> 00:32:07.998
If they're actually just dragging their
feet because they feel like they need easy

624
00:32:07.998 --> 00:32:09.506
time, well, at this point here,

625
00:32:09.506 --> 00:32:13.060
you need to let them know that there
are consequences to their choices.

626
00:32:13.060 --> 00:32:14.480
And you don't have to let them know,
again, in public.

627
00:32:14.480 --> 00:32:15.472
You kinda let them know,

628
00:32:15.472 --> 00:32:18.940
I don't know why you're just doing this
cuz you know it can be done better.

629
00:32:18.940 --> 00:32:21.430
You need to actually go,
here's what's gonna happen here.

630
00:32:21.430 --> 00:32:25.526
We're not gonna make this deadline and
that's gonna be dire straits for us, okay?

631
00:32:25.526 --> 00:32:29.505
And of course, any time that you're doing
this, whether you're doing it with regular

632
00:32:29.505 --> 00:32:33.113
performance monitoring where you actually
give yearly performance reviews,

633
00:32:33.113 --> 00:32:35.608
monthly performance reviews,
whatever it might be.

634
00:32:35.608 --> 00:32:38.713
Make sure you provide timely feedback,
okay.

635
00:32:38.713 --> 00:32:43.554
The idea of giving people performance
reviews on projects, great idea, okay,

636
00:32:43.554 --> 00:32:46.600
really a great idea, and should be done.

637
00:32:46.600 --> 00:32:49.030
But the idea of saying,
I'm gonna do a performance review, and

638
00:32:49.030 --> 00:32:52.290
then never do it, not a great idea, okay.

639
00:32:52.290 --> 00:32:55.916
Because people really, a lot of people,
really want, I'm not gonna say everybody.

640
00:32:55.916 --> 00:32:58.940
I always keep saying everybody and
then somebody, I don't want one of those.

641
00:32:58.940 --> 00:33:01.370
But a lot of people, right,
they wanna know whether or

642
00:33:01.370 --> 00:33:04.320
not they're doing the job that they
believe that they're doing well.

643
00:33:04.320 --> 00:33:07.018
Especially if they believe that they're
doing well, and now you're the project

644
00:33:07.018 --> 00:33:09.380
manager that comes in and goes,
we're gonna do a performance review.

645
00:33:09.380 --> 00:33:12.320
We're gonna talk about here's where we
believe are great things that you do,

646
00:33:12.320 --> 00:33:15.750
and here's what you do that
are poor things, or not as great.

647
00:33:15.750 --> 00:33:17.750
And then you never actually come
through and you tell them that,

648
00:33:17.750 --> 00:33:20.060
and so they don't know.

649
00:33:20.060 --> 00:33:22.850
And they kinda get stuck in
limbo cuz they're wondering,

650
00:33:22.850 --> 00:33:24.490
is this actually tied to something else?

651
00:33:24.490 --> 00:33:25.980
What else is going on here?

652
00:33:25.980 --> 00:33:27.849
So make sure that you,
as a project manager,

653
00:33:27.849 --> 00:33:30.752
when you start talking about the idea
of monitoring for performance,

654
00:33:30.752 --> 00:33:33.771
give timely feedback if you're
actually gonna do something like that.

655
00:33:33.771 --> 00:33:37.726
Don't sit there and go, I'll decide
that day after day, later on, later on,

656
00:33:37.726 --> 00:33:38.270
later on.

657
00:33:38.270 --> 00:33:41.470
If you actually tell somebody you're
gonna make a decision, make sure you make

658
00:33:41.470 --> 00:33:45.690
a decision, cuz that's part of how they're
gonna actually start performing, as well.

659
00:33:45.690 --> 00:33:48.350
Longer that you wait to do that,
the more that their performance is gonna

660
00:33:48.350 --> 00:33:52.030
continue to dive downhill and
they're not gonna get things done.

661
00:33:52.030 --> 00:33:55.850
So we do need to make sure that we
understand at least this process here.

662
00:33:55.850 --> 00:33:58.960
That it does involve a lot, right,
when you start building a team.

663
00:33:58.960 --> 00:34:02.020
You gotta know how the team really
does come together psychologically,

664
00:34:02.020 --> 00:34:03.460
which is what we talked about.

665
00:34:03.460 --> 00:34:05.330
What are ways we can build that team.

666
00:34:05.330 --> 00:34:09.050
And also, how do we actually start
measuring the performance of that team.

667
00:34:09.050 --> 00:34:12.070
And that way we can keep
them on track as a team too.

668
00:34:12.070 --> 00:34:16.425
>> That's it, wise words from our
lovely sage here, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

669
00:34:16.425 --> 00:34:19.231
That being said,
we have plenty more topics to cover, but

670
00:34:19.231 --> 00:34:20.730
no time in which to cover them.

671
00:34:20.730 --> 00:34:22.675
>> [LAUGH]
>> At least in this episode.

672
00:34:22.675 --> 00:34:24.400
We got plenty of time in another episode,

673
00:34:24.400 --> 00:34:26.965
hopefully we'll see you
there in the part two.

674
00:34:26.965 --> 00:34:29.535
Ronnie, thanks for dropping by,
we'll see you there as well.

675
00:34:29.535 --> 00:34:32.755
Everybody here, thanks for watching,
we're gonna go ahead sign off for ITProTV.

676
00:34:32.755 --> 00:34:34.362
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

677
00:34:34.362 --> 00:34:35.244
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

678
00:34:35.244 --> 00:34:37.368
>> And we'll see you next time.

679
00:34:37.368 --> 00:34:45.449
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue explaining how to coordinate human resources to assemble a project team and building team cohesiveness, starting with getting proper training for your team. Then they take on the topic of conflict detection and resolution techniques, specific techniques being Smoothing, Forcing, Compromise, Confronting, Avoiding, and Negotiating.
episodes.title: Coordinate Human Resources Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.044 --> 00:00:10.044
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.239 --> 00:00:16.540
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:18.300
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:18.300 --> 00:00:21.798
in today's episode we're actually
continuing on with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:21.798 --> 00:00:25.780
We're going in to part two, joining
us back into the studio again today

6
00:00:25.780 --> 00:00:28.527
is none other than our good friend and
our leader, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:28.527 --> 00:00:30.660
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:30.660 --> 00:00:31.690
>> Well thank you again for

9
00:00:31.690 --> 00:00:35.330
having me back on the show as we
continue on with CompTIA's Project+.

10
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:39.010
We are taking a look at part two in
coordinating our human resources to try

11
00:00:39.010 --> 00:00:42.950
and get the most that we can out of them
without actually making them our slaves,

12
00:00:42.950 --> 00:00:44.680
I guess, more than anything else.

13
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:47.530
We really can't,
we can't demand that they actually

14
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:49.830
do what we really want them
to in this day and age.

15
00:00:49.830 --> 00:00:51.497
I guess we could if we
force some type of slavery.

16
00:00:51.497 --> 00:00:52.830
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we're not gonna do that.

17
00:00:52.830 --> 00:00:53.500
>> Indentured servitude?

18
00:00:53.500 --> 00:00:56.640
>> Indentured servitude,
something that we might choose to do, but

19
00:00:56.640 --> 00:01:01.190
in our ability here as project managers,
we shouldn't have to resort to that.

20
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.420
What we should actually be able
to do of course is take a look at

21
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:08.330
what we can do and we've already talked
about these in a previous episode here.

22
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:10.370
We talked about the idea
of team building and

23
00:01:10.370 --> 00:01:14.595
of course understanding how teams
really do end up getting developed.

24
00:01:14.595 --> 00:01:17.560
And focus around the psychology
of that team and

25
00:01:17.560 --> 00:01:21.410
what has to happen there but we did take a
look at that as well as some performance.

26
00:01:21.410 --> 00:01:25.970
But one of the other things that we
can also do to help provide some

27
00:01:25.970 --> 00:01:30.810
team cohesiveness here, is to make
sure that we provide adequate and

28
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:36.810
proper training for what our team needs
to be able to accomplish as well.

29
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:39.560
Now when we start talking about this idea,

30
00:01:39.560 --> 00:01:43.850
training is a big part of what
really does bring a team together.

31
00:01:43.850 --> 00:01:46.973
If you can train them together, if you
can actually give them what they need,

32
00:01:46.973 --> 00:01:49.038
it allows them to have the tool
sets that they need so

33
00:01:49.038 --> 00:01:52.830
that they can make decisions without
having to come to you each and every time.

34
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:55.290
So when we start talking about
the idea of team training,

35
00:01:55.290 --> 00:01:58.120
there are several elements we need
to consider, and let's go ahead and

36
00:01:58.120 --> 00:02:01.120
take a look at my diagram
that will help us out here

37
00:02:01.120 --> 00:02:06.650
to focus in on some of the understanding
and issues that we need to take a look at.

38
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:10.310
First and foremost,
as you provide team training,

39
00:02:10.310 --> 00:02:15.120
what you wanna make sure that you do is
you understand the team member skill sets.

40
00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:19.000
There are some people that you're
gonna provide training for

41
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:20.500
that really don't need the training.

42
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:22.550
There are some people you
need to provide training for

43
00:02:22.550 --> 00:02:24.780
that absolutely do need the training.

44
00:02:24.780 --> 00:02:28.680
It doesn't necessarily mean that
you have to all lump them together.

45
00:02:28.680 --> 00:02:31.720
You might actually take
a little bit more time and

46
00:02:31.720 --> 00:02:35.120
do some type of evaluation that allows you

47
00:02:35.120 --> 00:02:38.398
to actually know where the training
should be done and what needs to be done.

48
00:02:38.398 --> 00:02:41.510
And everybody feels like they
are getting the training that they need

49
00:02:41.510 --> 00:02:43.210
that's adequate for them.

50
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:46.110
All of us have done this before, where
we've had to sit through training just

51
00:02:46.110 --> 00:02:48.350
because we had to sit
through the training.

52
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:51.480
Why, because everybody else was sitting
through the training and that can be just

53
00:02:51.480 --> 00:02:54.820
as frustrating as the person that
really is enjoying the training and

54
00:02:54.820 --> 00:02:57.980
your just sitting there kind of
mouthing off or doing whatever you

55
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:01.560
think you're doing and not being
a distraction, when you really are.

56
00:03:01.560 --> 00:03:06.560
So you actually want to take into
account the idea of member skill sets,

57
00:03:06.560 --> 00:03:09.710
to see whether or not there is
training that needs to be done.

58
00:03:09.710 --> 00:03:12.860
The majority of times,
especially on a brand new project

59
00:03:12.860 --> 00:03:15.640
when you do know that people
are coming from different areas,

60
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:21.540
providing training is a very good concept
for us to focus in on in team building.

61
00:03:21.540 --> 00:03:25.810
The other thing of course, it makes sure
that it focuses on the skills needed for

62
00:03:25.810 --> 00:03:27.160
the project.

63
00:03:27.160 --> 00:03:31.740
Now, we've already talked about
this before in several other areas,

64
00:03:31.740 --> 00:03:35.970
you can actually get very distracted
here when you provide for training.

65
00:03:35.970 --> 00:03:39.300
Somebody says, we also need to have
this training, we need to have that.

66
00:03:39.300 --> 00:03:43.280
And now instead of actually doing what
really does help you on your project,

67
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:45.100
you end up providing
every other training but

68
00:03:45.100 --> 00:03:48.750
the training that really is gonna help
people out on their project as well.

69
00:03:49.800 --> 00:03:52.380
Now sometimes you may have to
provide specialized training and

70
00:03:52.380 --> 00:03:55.470
if you do, make sure you provide that.

71
00:03:55.470 --> 00:04:00.240
It never, I shouldn't say never,
what tends to actually drive a team

72
00:04:00.240 --> 00:04:04.476
apart a little bit more is when you end up
with a team member that feels like he's

73
00:04:04.476 --> 00:04:09.090
inadequately prepared for
whatever is his been assigned, and he has

74
00:04:09.090 --> 00:04:13.740
no recourse to get the information that he
needs and so he struggles through that.

75
00:04:13.740 --> 00:04:17.180
And other people may try
to help out if they can but

76
00:04:17.180 --> 00:04:21.370
they may not have any better understanding
as well, so you wanna make sure that you

77
00:04:21.370 --> 00:04:24.790
provide everything that you can so
that they can be successful.

78
00:04:24.790 --> 00:04:28.350
Our boss has that saying, that he says,

79
00:04:28.350 --> 00:04:31.600
Ronnie what is it that's gonna
make you perform your best?

80
00:04:31.600 --> 00:04:33.770
And he tries to provide that for us.

81
00:04:33.770 --> 00:04:35.410
He says, my goal and

82
00:04:35.410 --> 00:04:39.950
my job is fairly simple, is that I remove
any obstacles to your performance, Ronnie.

83
00:04:39.950 --> 00:04:42.640
That's what he says, so
he provides for us the equipment.

84
00:04:42.640 --> 00:04:45.530
He provides for us the training
that we need, whatever it is.

85
00:04:45.530 --> 00:04:48.650
He says, let's go ahead and do that so
that you can do your job, and

86
00:04:48.650 --> 00:04:51.910
that you really have no excuse to under
perform, is what it comes down to.

87
00:04:51.910 --> 00:04:54.890
And so
that's a great attitude to actually have.

88
00:04:54.890 --> 00:04:56.410
And so
when you have something like this, and

89
00:04:56.410 --> 00:04:59.470
you have the ability,
that's what you want to do, as well.

90
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:03.110
If somebody is saying I just don't know,
then let's find out what we can do,

91
00:05:03.110 --> 00:05:06.320
and training is usually
a big part of that too.

92
00:05:06.320 --> 00:05:08.620
Also, you may find out something.

93
00:05:08.620 --> 00:05:11.214
Training may just be to
ensure that team members,

94
00:05:11.214 --> 00:05:13.500
what they are actually to be able to use.

95
00:05:13.500 --> 00:05:15.470
Now what does that mean?

96
00:05:15.470 --> 00:05:18.920
Remember that the ends
don't justify the means.

97
00:05:18.920 --> 00:05:22.120
So the idea of actually just
creating a project is not enough,

98
00:05:22.120 --> 00:05:25.660
you might find out that they have to go
through some type of process training.

99
00:05:25.660 --> 00:05:29.500
So whatever the standard methodology
is that they're to do here,

100
00:05:29.500 --> 00:05:34.380
even though they might know another way
to do it, you go, I can't accept that.

101
00:05:34.380 --> 00:05:36.750
You provide that standard
methodology of training so

102
00:05:36.750 --> 00:05:39.660
they know the proper way to do it,
and that's what has to be done.

103
00:05:39.660 --> 00:05:41.560
You also do the same thing on tools.

104
00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:44.700
You don't let somebody drive an excavator

105
00:05:44.700 --> 00:05:48.975
that's only driven the Isuzu pick
up truck to go and pick up parts.

106
00:05:48.975 --> 00:05:50.345
Now can you, yeah, of course you can.

107
00:05:50.345 --> 00:05:53.976
But if they don't have the training for
it, no you don't let them drive the big

108
00:05:53.976 --> 00:05:57.718
excavator around and you don't tell they
to try and park it in the parking space,

109
00:05:57.718 --> 00:05:59.223
or do parallel parking with it.

110
00:05:59.223 --> 00:06:00.129
You don't do that.

111
00:06:00.129 --> 00:06:00.972
>> It would be fun.

112
00:06:00.972 --> 00:06:02.155
>> [LAUGH] It would be fun.

113
00:06:02.155 --> 00:06:03.125
>> [LAUGH] Not productive though.

114
00:06:03.125 --> 00:06:04.499
>> Yeah, not very good.

115
00:06:04.499 --> 00:06:06.405
But that's what we're talking about,
right.

116
00:06:06.405 --> 00:06:10.100
Make sure that you do provide the training
that's necessary for them, for

117
00:06:10.100 --> 00:06:11.600
whatever skills that are there.

118
00:06:11.600 --> 00:06:14.250
And even other templates
that you may have on hand

Both sides end up losing as

But remember that if you're

Just like the Solomon-

They didn't just say, well I'm yeah,

I just like Ronnie's beard so

No here is your argument,

00:27:34.400 --> 00:27:38.690
So what can happen is Daniel can present

time together on just a couple of things.

567
00:28:52.370 --> 00:28:55.850
One, there is really only one
resolution method that works here,

568
00:28:55.850 --> 00:28:58.300
okay, which is confrontation.

569
00:28:58.300 --> 00:29:03.320
Now, this is not the idea of you
meeting in a gladiator arena-

570
00:29:03.320 --> 00:29:04.100
>> Michael Buffer.

571
00:29:04.100 --> 00:29:05.120
>> And beating each other.

572
00:29:05.120 --> 00:29:06.280
Yeah, Michael Buffer.

573
00:29:06.280 --> 00:29:11.650
You can but just kinda remember
that here the key is what?

574
00:29:11.650 --> 00:29:15.170
Is that we're trying to actually
solve the problem at this point.

575
00:29:15.170 --> 00:29:18.430
And it is, it is by far the best
way to resolve the problem.

576
00:29:18.430 --> 00:29:19.930
Now will people get heated?

577
00:29:19.930 --> 00:29:23.410
At times, yes, but what you do is you
base this around some fact finding.

578
00:29:23.410 --> 00:29:27.540
In other words, it's not based on
what I feel or what he did to me.

579
00:29:27.540 --> 00:29:31.760
You take a look at the facts that are
actually presented here, okay, and then

580
00:29:31.760 --> 00:29:35.400
you make sure that both sides understand
the facts that you've actually seen.

581
00:29:35.400 --> 00:29:39.210
And that whatever decision is
made through this confrontation,

582
00:29:39.210 --> 00:29:41.920
that this is to be a clear resolution, and

583
00:29:41.920 --> 00:29:47.250
both sides are to agree that here's what
will resolve the problem itself, okay.

584
00:29:47.250 --> 00:29:51.100
So being able to come through that
confrontation is gonna be key.

585
00:29:51.100 --> 00:29:53.932
Now, when you do that, right,
it can be a long process.

586
00:29:53.932 --> 00:29:57.420
And so you're not going to be able
to solve this over night sometimes.

587
00:29:57.420 --> 00:29:59.000
Can it?
Yes.

588
00:29:59.000 --> 00:30:01.480
Okay.
Can it be resolved over a fit fight?

589
00:30:01.480 --> 00:30:05.680
Yes it could if you want to, but just
realize that what you want is that both

590
00:30:05.680 --> 00:30:09.340
sides agree that this is the only
way to really solve this.

591
00:30:09.340 --> 00:30:13.510
Let's get all the facts in front of both
sides, make sure they agree to the facts,

592
00:30:13.510 --> 00:30:16.820
and if they agree to the facts of
whatever it is they're presenting,

593
00:30:16.820 --> 00:30:19.220
then there is no conflict anymore, okay?

594
00:30:19.220 --> 00:30:20.500
And then you can say,
well what about this?

595
00:30:20.500 --> 00:30:21.900
And I'll say, that's personal, okay?

596
00:30:21.900 --> 00:30:26.320
That's not having anything to do with
what the conflict is about right now, but

597
00:30:26.320 --> 00:30:28.820
make sure that they both know what
they're actually fighting for,

598
00:30:28.820 --> 00:30:30.780
make sure they agree on the facts here.

599
00:30:30.780 --> 00:30:33.040
And once you do,
you've actually resolved that conflict.

600
00:30:33.040 --> 00:30:37.670
So, that takes a little bit more
off of you to try and go you know,

601
00:30:37.670 --> 00:30:40.040
I've known this guy longer,
I've known this guy longer.

602
00:30:40.040 --> 00:30:42.870
You actually are basing your
particular resolution on

603
00:30:42.870 --> 00:30:45.150
what's actually been
presented there as facts.

604
00:30:45.150 --> 00:30:47.020
But you do have to take
the time to do fact-finding.

605
00:30:47.020 --> 00:30:47.850
>> That's right.

606
00:30:47.850 --> 00:30:51.740
It never hurts to have a good set
of factual data in front of you.

607
00:30:51.740 --> 00:30:57.040
That is exactly what Ronnie says is going
help alleviate any of that opinionation

608
00:30:57.040 --> 00:30:58.570
from behind the argument.

609
00:30:58.570 --> 00:31:00.120
We want to stick with the facts.

610
00:31:00.120 --> 00:31:03.140
And let them be our guiding star
when it comes to what should we do,

611
00:31:03.140 --> 00:31:07.440
what should we not do in a project, and
that will help alleviate that conflict.

612
00:31:07.440 --> 00:31:13.570
And Ronnie, there's always caveats,
right, addendums, asides, special cases.

613
00:31:13.570 --> 00:31:15.240
You got a couple for us to help.

614
00:31:15.240 --> 00:31:16.390
Now help us go through those.

615
00:31:16.390 --> 00:31:18.870
>> When it comes down to special cases,
right,

616
00:31:18.870 --> 00:31:22.680
we're not really talking about some
particular conflict that exists with

617
00:31:22.680 --> 00:31:26.010
the project itself or
how things are actually done.

618
00:31:26.010 --> 00:31:27.910
We're talking about dealing with people.

619
00:31:27.910 --> 00:31:33.450
And that means personalities and of course
personal issues that may end up arising.

620
00:31:33.450 --> 00:31:35.310
And when we start talking
about dealing with this,

621
00:31:35.310 --> 00:31:39.110
there's a couple of special
cases that we need to deal with.

622
00:31:39.110 --> 00:31:40.350
Now let's take a look here.

623
00:31:40.350 --> 00:31:44.135
And I've went ahead and enumerated them
for us just a little bit, or listed them.

624
00:31:44.135 --> 00:31:48.580
Team member disputes, when you have
two team members, essentially,

625
00:31:48.580 --> 00:31:51.409
going after each other,
for whatever it is.

626
00:31:51.409 --> 00:31:53.121
Remember that patience is the key,

627
00:31:53.121 --> 00:31:55.695
fact-finding is pretty much
what we want to do here.

628
00:31:55.695 --> 00:32:00.420
Now when you do have this situation and
they agree on the facts, that's fine.

629
00:32:00.420 --> 00:32:05.323
But if you do have now where this dispute
is not gonna be carried on, your best bet,

630
00:32:05.323 --> 00:32:07.383
okay, at this point here, okay,

631
00:32:07.383 --> 00:32:11.720
is to make sure it doesn't
devolve into personal issues.

632
00:32:11.720 --> 00:32:15.720
Once it devolves into personal issues,
you need to take yourself out of it.

633
00:32:15.720 --> 00:32:18.060
And this now becomes an HR problem.

634
00:32:18.060 --> 00:32:22.200
Okay, you, and you want to follow those
standards and guidelines by the T.

635
00:32:22.200 --> 00:32:27.150
You do not want it actually situated
in there, where they tell HR that no,

636
00:32:27.150 --> 00:32:30.320
he said that I wouldn't ever
face any consequences from this.

637
00:32:30.320 --> 00:32:32.260
No, you simply go,

638
00:32:32.260 --> 00:32:36.390
this has now devolved into personal
issues where you're doing this.

639
00:32:36.390 --> 00:32:38.640
And this is a Human Resource problem and

640
00:32:38.640 --> 00:32:41.030
we need to deal with it
according to those facts.

641
00:32:41.030 --> 00:32:43.650
You definitely want to make
sure you stand by the policy.

642
00:32:43.650 --> 00:32:45.340
You don't deviate at all.

643
00:32:45.340 --> 00:32:48.850
The reason why is it can become
a legal issue very quickly if you do.

644
00:32:49.850 --> 00:32:53.170
You stood in my fair process of
getting this done the way I needed to.

645
00:32:53.170 --> 00:32:54.020
No I didn't.
Yes, you did,

646
00:32:54.020 --> 00:32:55.770
when you told me to do this instead.

647
00:32:55.770 --> 00:32:57.390
Nope, make sure that you do that.

648
00:32:57.390 --> 00:33:02.300
If it devolves beyond whatever that
team member issue is that you can't, and

649
00:33:02.300 --> 00:33:05.150
now it becomes personal,
you're done, okay?

650
00:33:05.150 --> 00:33:08.050
You do not want to
actually go beyond that.

651
00:33:08.050 --> 00:33:11.760
Now, it could be that the resolution ends
up being training for the person, right?

652
00:33:11.760 --> 00:33:13.000
And this stuff happens, right?

653
00:33:13.000 --> 00:33:17.240
If it's some type of sexual harassment
thing, you send them to training, but

654
00:33:17.240 --> 00:33:18.800
again HR will decide that.

655
00:33:18.800 --> 00:33:20.740
Whether it's actually gonna
be training that they get or

656
00:33:20.740 --> 00:33:23.650
whether it's gonna be dismissal
at some point, right?

657
00:33:23.650 --> 00:33:25.730
Disciplinary action could be mediation,

658
00:33:25.730 --> 00:33:29.590
could be the idea of absolutely outright
relieving them of their job duties.

659
00:33:29.590 --> 00:33:32.820
But just realize that if it's a dispute
like this, where it devolves and

660
00:33:32.820 --> 00:33:34.470
that's this special issue, right?

661
00:33:34.470 --> 00:33:37.490
it's not that there can't be disputes,
not that there can't be conflicts, but

662
00:33:37.490 --> 00:33:41.670
if it now turns into personal issues where
they say, I just can't work with that guy.

663
00:33:41.670 --> 00:33:45.910
You go, okay, I'm done with this,
because I can no longer,

664
00:33:45.910 --> 00:33:46.900
there's nothing that I can do.

665
00:33:46.900 --> 00:33:49.030
The main thing that we've talked
about that's going to work.

666
00:33:49.030 --> 00:33:51.118
>> That right the human
factor is just that.

667
00:33:51.118 --> 00:33:55.390
Is a factor, you've got to take it into
account, and sometimes that is going

668
00:33:55.390 --> 00:34:00.010
to be the deciding vote on whether or not
someone continues to work on a project or

669
00:34:00.010 --> 00:34:02.300
not and
maybe you might have to replace them.

670
00:34:02.300 --> 00:34:06.310
>> Yeah, the other one, of course, is just
a regular disgruntled team member and

671
00:34:06.310 --> 00:34:09.340
this can actually happen very easily.

672
00:34:09.340 --> 00:34:15.630
If this happens you want to try and deal
with this privately as much as you can.

673
00:34:15.630 --> 00:34:18.930
If you can find out the reason for

674
00:34:18.930 --> 00:34:21.960
their disgruntlement,
whatever it might be, right?

675
00:34:21.960 --> 00:34:26.960
Make sure you listen but
make sure you stick to the facts, okay?

676
00:34:26.960 --> 00:34:29.790
Do not ask them about how they,
I know that sounds strange, but

677
00:34:29.790 --> 00:34:31.430
don't ask them about how they feel.

678
00:34:31.430 --> 00:34:34.000
But say, what is the actual issue and

679
00:34:34.000 --> 00:34:39.470
problem here that you can try and
address and get figured out here, okay?

680
00:34:39.470 --> 00:34:43.380
Any negative statements that they make
towards you, towards a project, towards

681
00:34:43.380 --> 00:34:48.610
whatever it is, make sure they clarify
by giving you not, this is how I feel.

682
00:34:48.610 --> 00:34:52.497
But pointing out actual things
that have happened to them or

683
00:34:52.497 --> 00:34:55.460
that they've actually noticed.

684
00:34:55.460 --> 00:35:01.900
Don't sit there and go, well, that's just
how Ronnie is, he's just a loudmouth.

685
00:35:01.900 --> 00:35:03.420
That's not enough, right?

686
00:35:03.420 --> 00:35:07.970
You wanna actually go,
can you give me an actual example?

687
00:35:07.970 --> 00:35:13.080
Did you have a conversation with
Ronnie that absolutely said this?

688
00:35:13.080 --> 00:35:15.210
Can you tell me a time and
date that that happened?

689
00:35:15.210 --> 00:35:17.730
Make sure you get those facts there.

690
00:35:17.730 --> 00:35:20.740
What you might find out is, there's
nothing that you can do to resolve this.

691
00:35:20.740 --> 00:35:24.310
You can't do anything else,
while at that point,

692
00:35:24.310 --> 00:35:26.900
make sure whatever you actually
have to do, whether it's dismissal,

693
00:35:26.900 --> 00:35:30.650
whether it's anything else,
that you do it as quickly as possible.

694
00:35:30.650 --> 00:35:32.110
Being somebody that's disgruntled and

695
00:35:32.110 --> 00:35:34.490
they just get to work on
the project is never good.

696
00:35:34.490 --> 00:35:37.900
It is like that festering
wound that doesn't close.

697
00:35:37.900 --> 00:35:41.980
I had a friend that worked on
an oil rig about 20 years ago, and

698
00:35:41.980 --> 00:35:44.070
this is one of the things that he told me.

699
00:35:44.070 --> 00:35:48.720
He said, they fly people out there, and
you're essentially stuck on that rig for

700
00:35:48.720 --> 00:35:50.110
six to nine months.

701
00:35:50.110 --> 00:35:53.830
And he said the first thing that ends up
happening is that when a fight happens,

702
00:35:53.830 --> 00:35:57.970
they throw you both into a locked room for
overnight.

703
00:35:57.970 --> 00:36:00.220
And you deal with it however you can.

704
00:36:00.220 --> 00:36:02.850
The next day they come out and
they ask if it's been resolved.

705
00:36:02.850 --> 00:36:06.410
If it's not been resolved,
they call a helicopter out and

706
00:36:06.410 --> 00:36:10.140
they get those two people off
the rig the following day.

707
00:36:10.140 --> 00:36:12.230
They get them off the rig, why?

708
00:36:12.230 --> 00:36:14.450
Because what happens if you
leave those two on that rig?

709
00:36:14.450 --> 00:36:18.400
It will continue to denigrate
the entire working processes.

710
00:36:18.400 --> 00:36:22.400
You can imagine what it does when you're
under time constraints, money constraints,

711
00:36:22.400 --> 00:36:27.090
and requirement constraints,
how quickly this can devolve.

712
00:36:27.090 --> 00:36:30.610
So make sure you actually do whatever
you do very quickly here and

713
00:36:30.610 --> 00:36:34.370
get that resolved as quickly as possible
when it's some type of disgruntlement.

714
00:36:34.370 --> 00:36:38.070
>> Yeah, you may even be liable for some
sort of criminal negligence if it devolves

715
00:36:38.070 --> 00:36:41.450
to something like assault, or
dare I say, even a murder charge.

716
00:36:41.450 --> 00:36:43.440
People do kill people, it does happen.

717
00:36:43.440 --> 00:36:45.600
And they usually do that because
they're angry with them.

718
00:36:45.600 --> 00:36:49.210
So, we gotta look out for those things and
that's a really great policy for

719
00:36:49.210 --> 00:36:53.760
when you have people in
a confined closed space and

720
00:36:53.760 --> 00:36:55.570
they have no way to get
away from each other.

721
00:36:55.570 --> 00:36:58.153
Sometimes you just have to go,
you know what, we're gonna cut our loses,

722
00:36:58.153 --> 00:37:00.531
thanks for helping us out you guys,
but you are no longer necessary,

723
00:37:00.531 --> 00:37:01.688
it's time to get you out of here.

724
00:37:01.688 --> 00:37:05.311
That is a great way to relieve
that conflict, just separate them.

725
00:37:05.311 --> 00:37:10.540
All right Ronnie, we have gone
through a lot of conflict resolution.

726
00:37:10.540 --> 00:37:13.100
A lot of how we can look at conflicts in

727
00:37:13.100 --> 00:37:16.320
any parting words of wisdom
before we wrap up the show?

728
00:37:16.320 --> 00:37:17.625
>> This is gonna be important, right?

729
00:37:17.625 --> 00:37:19.190
Because we deal with people every day.

730
00:37:19.190 --> 00:37:22.340
If you're gonna be a project manager,
they're looking to you to lead.

731
00:37:22.340 --> 00:37:26.700
If you now lead and you deal with conflict
resolution by avoiding it, guess what?

732
00:37:26.700 --> 00:37:30.300
It's not gonna be a very powerful team
that works for you on your project.

733
00:37:30.300 --> 00:37:33.660
So make sure you take a look
about managing these things, and

734
00:37:33.660 --> 00:37:36.030
understand at least
the basic processes here.

735
00:37:36.030 --> 00:37:38.900
Get a little bit more study if you're
actually gonna be managing a big team,

736
00:37:38.900 --> 00:37:40.880
because this stuff will end up happening.

737
00:37:40.880 --> 00:37:44.460
But overall though, if you're taking a
look at this and go man, this sounds like

738
00:37:44.460 --> 00:37:47.890
something I want to get into,
do a little bit more training on your own.

739
00:37:47.890 --> 00:37:52.260
And make sure you understand a little
bit better, cuz it does get beyond

740
00:37:52.260 --> 00:37:56.550
the kind of little easy cartwheels or
leapfrog that I just showed you here.

741
00:37:56.550 --> 00:37:59.370
It can get into some convoluted stuff, so

742
00:37:59.370 --> 00:38:02.310
just make sure you actually
pay attention to your team.

743
00:38:02.310 --> 00:38:05.050
Build them up, make sure you
understand and resolve their conflicts.

744
00:38:05.050 --> 00:38:05.750
>> All right.

745
00:38:05.750 --> 00:38:07.530
Thank you so much, Ronnie,
for dropping by and

746
00:38:07.530 --> 00:38:09.400
explaining these awesome concepts to us.

747
00:38:09.400 --> 00:38:14.170
So we can resolve conflicts when we find
them and use these techniques to do so.

748
00:38:14.170 --> 00:38:16.600
That being said, it looks like we've
wrapped up yet another great episode.

749
00:38:16.600 --> 00:38:18.780
Hopefully you guys enjoyed it and
learned something.

750
00:38:18.780 --> 00:38:21.570
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

751
00:38:21.570 --> 00:38:22.350
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

752
00:38:22.350 --> 00:38:23.273
>> We'll see you next time.

753
00:38:23.273 --> 00:38:31.940
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Daniel explain the importance of a project kickoff meeting and outline common activities that are performed during this meeting. They begin by explaining how a kickoff meeting is a perfect time to communicate the purpose of the project and set the tone and goals. Also, you can use the kickoff meeting to introduce team members, management, timelines, budgets, and team expectations. It also provides a platform for Q&A.
episodes.title: Have a Project Kickoff Meeting
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.947 --> 00:00:16.819
All right, greeting everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.819 --> 00:00:19.592
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.592 --> 00:00:21.990
we are continuing on
with our Project+ series.

5
00:00:21.990 --> 00:00:25.040
Joining us back in the studio
again today to help

6
00:00:25.040 --> 00:00:29.080
further us on in that endeavor is our
good friend and mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:29.080 --> 00:00:29.757
Ronnie, welcome back, sir.

8
00:00:29.757 --> 00:00:31.003
How you doing?
>> Well, thank you for

9
00:00:31.003 --> 00:00:32.130
having me back on the show.

10
00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:37.310
It's great to be here again as we pick
up on the idea of CompTIA's Project+.

11
00:00:37.310 --> 00:00:40.900
We're moving on into
the execution phase now, and

12
00:00:40.900 --> 00:00:45.560
what we're actually taking a look at today
of course is how in the world do we begin?

13
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:50.070
What do we need to do to ensure that we
can move from the planning into the realm

14
00:00:50.070 --> 00:00:54.620
of execution, and ensure that everybody is
on the same page, is on the right foot,

15
00:00:54.620 --> 00:00:59.780
is whatever cliche you want to give to it,
is ready to go as we start the project.

16
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:01.880
Well, one of things that what
we want to actually consider and

17
00:01:01.880 --> 00:01:04.460
one thing you should absolutely consider.

18
00:01:04.460 --> 00:01:08.610
Is the idea of starting with what
we call a project kick-off meeting.

19
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:13.560
Now, lot of times when you say that
in a company where people aren't talk

20
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:16.980
about project management,
they immediately go to the word party,

21
00:01:16.980 --> 00:01:18.580
is what they think about, right?

22
00:01:18.580 --> 00:01:20.470
Cuz we say project kickoff, and for

23
00:01:20.470 --> 00:01:25.470
some reason kickoff sounds like it's
a Super Bowl party or something like that,

24
00:01:25.470 --> 00:01:28.450
a dance that you're about to start,
something that you're actually having.

25
00:01:28.450 --> 00:01:31.230
And don't get me wrong,
you can actually do that if you choose to,

26
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:35.380
if that's the tone that you wanna set,
but you wanna consider this because

27
00:01:35.380 --> 00:01:39.840
this is actually one of these great
activities that will really allow

28
00:01:39.840 --> 00:01:45.030
you to begin your project in
the way that you choose to begin.

29
00:01:45.030 --> 00:01:47.950
So we wanna take a look at the elements
that are normally involved

30
00:01:47.950 --> 00:01:50.530
of this idea of a project kickoff meeting.

31
00:01:50.530 --> 00:01:53.620
So when you start to take
a look at something like this,

32
00:01:53.620 --> 00:01:58.960
if you wanted to set it up as a party,
a very relaxed atmosphere, not a big deal.

33
00:01:58.960 --> 00:02:03.180
You can do so as long as you realize
that in this particular party,

34
