episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and purpose of organizational governance during a project's execution. They begin by describing what organizational governance is and how it can affect you as a team member. Then they look at common compliances implemented in organizational governance. This includes Standards compliance, Internal Process compliance, Decision Oversight, and Phase Gate Approval.
episodes.title: Work with Organizational Governance

something that they have to watch out for.

244
00:13:36.220 --> 00:13:39.800
So, things like borrowing equipment is
not done in the way that we would like to

245
00:13:39.800 --> 00:13:41.700
which is hey, just let me use that.

246
00:13:41.700 --> 00:13:44.610
A lot of times there has to be
that requisition that shows that

247
00:13:44.610 --> 00:13:47.950
there is a transfer of authority
from one location to another and

248
00:13:47.950 --> 00:13:51.010
that's because there's cost associated
with it, there's value associated with it.

249
00:13:51.010 --> 00:13:55.440
There's time in which that equipment
has to actually be accounted for and so

250
00:13:55.440 --> 00:13:57.810
we have to have things like audit trails.

251
00:13:57.810 --> 00:14:00.890
The other thing that we also have to do
is the idea of what we call retention

252
00:14:00.890 --> 00:14:02.070
policies as well.

253
00:14:03.090 --> 00:14:06.080
When you are actually
working on a project you

254
00:14:06.080 --> 00:14:09.640
might end up over your lifetime
working on very many projects.

255
00:14:09.640 --> 00:14:11.820
But you might also find
yourself working for

256
00:14:11.820 --> 00:14:17.810
an organization that says we retain these
records and your work records here,

257
00:14:17.810 --> 00:14:21.580
for a certain number of years or
months after the project is done.

258
00:14:21.580 --> 00:14:25.910
So they can go back and they can find
that information if they need to again.

259
00:14:25.910 --> 00:14:27.270
If warranty work needs to be done,

260
00:14:27.270 --> 00:14:30.030
if anything else needs to be done,
they can find it.

261
00:14:30.030 --> 00:14:34.960
It's easy to think, cuz I remember doing
this when I first kind of lived on my

262
00:14:34.960 --> 00:14:38.790
own essentially right after college, is
I'll throw away everything and then first

263
00:14:38.790 --> 00:14:42.590
time I started doing that, I essentially
go, I shouldn't have thrown that away.

264
00:14:42.590 --> 00:14:45.860
And I find out, and then I've just
become a hoarder since I point instead,

265
00:14:45.860 --> 00:14:46.630
no I'm joking.

266
00:14:46.630 --> 00:14:47.830
It's somewhere in between that.

267
00:14:47.830 --> 00:14:50.430
But you tend to actually retain things for
so long.

268
00:14:50.430 --> 00:14:53.460
And so you might find that your
organization has a particular

269
00:14:53.460 --> 00:14:57.700
retention policy and this is something
you have got to pay attention to.

270
00:14:57.700 --> 00:15:01.600
The idea of you just saying well,
I won't worry about it.

271
00:15:01.600 --> 00:15:04.360
And you throw that away when they come and
do an audit, right.

272
00:15:04.360 --> 00:15:05.520
They're gonna ask for those records.

273
00:15:05.520 --> 00:15:08.940
And if those records aren't there,
that's when you're gonna have a problem.

274
00:15:08.940 --> 00:15:13.030
So make sure you know where you're
retaining them, your particular records,

275
00:15:13.030 --> 00:15:15.670
and make sure you know
how long the organization

276
00:15:15.670 --> 00:15:19.080
expects you to also retain
those records as well.

277
00:15:19.080 --> 00:15:21.840
The other one is the idea of
what we call version control,

278
00:15:21.840 --> 00:15:24.150
which is a big one for us, too.

279
00:15:24.150 --> 00:15:27.570
Whenever you start looking at
this idea of version control,

280
00:15:27.570 --> 00:15:31.620
we know that our project may
end up changing over time.

281
00:15:31.620 --> 00:15:33.060
But the problem that we have is simple.

282
00:15:33.060 --> 00:15:36.710
It's not that it changes over time,
but what did it change from and

283
00:15:36.710 --> 00:15:38.600
what did it change to?

284
00:15:38.600 --> 00:15:42.180
We don't just simply need to actually
know that one day when we got up,

285
00:15:42.180 --> 00:15:43.888
that the project scope changed.

286
00:15:43.888 --> 00:15:48.787
And the only thing that you could tell is
that it changed, but you don't know why,

287
00:15:48.787 --> 00:15:50.148
you don't know when.

288
00:15:50.148 --> 00:15:54.179
So there's always what we call version
control that essentially says Here was

289
00:15:54.179 --> 00:15:58.211
the project's original versionm here's
what the revision versions are up in

290
00:15:58.211 --> 00:15:58.896
this point.

291
00:15:58.896 --> 00:16:02.556
And that way you can increment and
see when these things have changed and

292
00:16:02.556 --> 00:16:04.738
what has changed over that time.

293
00:16:04.738 --> 00:16:09.070
Just saying in the project is now this
instead of this is no longer good enough.

294
00:16:09.070 --> 00:16:11.907
We need to maintain that
historical record for

295
00:16:11.907 --> 00:16:16.705
us, because our internal process says we
need to know why this project ended up

296
00:16:16.705 --> 00:16:20.217
costing us $50,000 more
than it originally did.

297
00:16:20.217 --> 00:16:23.226
And when you know when that
actually ended up happening, so

298
00:16:23.226 --> 00:16:27.271
they can use that as historical data for
new projects that come on board as well.

299
00:16:27.271 --> 00:16:30.623
So just kinda realize that there's
also those internal process

300
00:16:30.623 --> 00:16:33.488
compliance things that we
have to worry about as well.

301
00:16:33.488 --> 00:16:38.159
So we have Standards Compliance that are
a part of the organizational governance,

302
00:16:38.159 --> 00:16:40.428
we have Internal Process Compliance and

303
00:16:40.428 --> 00:16:43.580
then we of course have what
we call Decision Oversight.

304
00:16:43.580 --> 00:16:48.467
Decision Oversight for us means that
the project manager is not an all

305
00:16:48.467 --> 00:16:51.594
powerful omnipotent being on the project.

306
00:16:51.594 --> 00:16:53.313
I know it sounds fun, okay?

307
00:16:53.313 --> 00:16:55.147
But it's not, okay?

308
00:16:55.147 --> 00:17:00.108
He has to have some oversight and a lot
of times those recite decisions come from

309
00:17:00.108 --> 00:17:04.693
the people that are really actually
the sponsors, the stakeholders and

310
00:17:04.693 --> 00:17:09.984
that organization that has given him the
authority to manage that project as well.

311
00:17:09.984 --> 00:17:14.271
So, when there are things that the project
manager can directly change but

312
00:17:14.271 --> 00:17:17.741
should actually let the entire
organization know about it,

313
00:17:17.741 --> 00:17:21.844
we normally have what we call decision
oversights that need to be done.

314
00:17:21.844 --> 00:17:25.714
And normally in this particular one this
is probably one of the most detailed

315
00:17:25.714 --> 00:17:27.829
processes that we can
spend our time in and

316
00:17:27.829 --> 00:17:31.648
that has to do with what we call change
management more than anything else.

317
00:17:31.648 --> 00:17:35.224
If you wanna know about a great
example of organizational governance.

318
00:17:35.224 --> 00:17:39.532
It might be that the entire organization
says, here is how we manage change and

319
00:17:39.532 --> 00:17:43.906
our projects will also go through that
same particular process to ensure that we

320
00:17:43.906 --> 00:17:48.477
understand what the changes are, and the
changes are actually done in a way that's

321
00:17:48.477 --> 00:17:52.034
not gonna affect the overall
functioning of the organization.

322
00:17:52.034 --> 00:17:54.129
Nor is it gonna be harmful
to human beings, nor

323
00:17:54.129 --> 00:17:55.651
is it gonna be doing this or that.

324
00:17:55.651 --> 00:18:00.416
But we have to have some type of oversight
in the decision making that needs to go on

325
00:18:00.416 --> 00:18:02.184
when you start taking a look.

326
00:18:02.184 --> 00:18:06.501
So when you start seeing stuff like that,
it really is to ensure that

327
00:18:06.501 --> 00:18:11.141
the project manager doesn't just
become a dictator on his own project.

328
00:18:11.141 --> 00:18:12.650
>> Yeah, as much as they would
love to do that, I'm sure.

329
00:18:12.650 --> 00:18:14.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean, who wouldn't?

330
00:18:14.020 --> 00:18:15.370
Let's be honest, right?

331
00:18:15.370 --> 00:18:19.130
You feel like, this is my project,
I'm gonna run it to where I wanna run it,

332
00:18:19.130 --> 00:18:22.070
but we have to,
that never really works out.

333
00:18:22.070 --> 00:18:23.187
I mean, look at the large scale, right?.

334
00:18:23.187 --> 00:18:26.043
Dictatorships usually aren't
the best type of governance systems.

335
00:18:26.043 --> 00:18:28.344
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because it all comes down to

336
00:18:28.344 --> 00:18:32.681
the decisions of one person, and
they can be highly emotionally driven, or

337
00:18:32.681 --> 00:18:34.194
idealistically driven.

338
00:18:34.194 --> 00:18:37.535
And if thee's any deviation,
they just get rid of that person and

339
00:18:37.535 --> 00:18:39.374
bring in someone that believes in.

340
00:18:39.374 --> 00:18:44.027
It's never a good idea, I've always said
I never want, if I'm a project manager,

341
00:18:44.027 --> 00:18:46.190
I don't want a group of yes men.

342
00:18:46.190 --> 00:18:50.340
I want people to say yes to the right
things and no to the wrong things.

343
00:18:50.340 --> 00:18:52.007
And that's the type of,
and you need that, and

344
00:18:52.007 --> 00:18:54.885
that's what we're talking about here is
having that governance, you got people

345
00:18:54.885 --> 00:18:57.660
that are over you that are watching
what's going on and going, you know what?

346
00:18:57.660 --> 00:19:00.880
I see what you're doing there but I think
this is gonna be the better way to go.

347
00:19:00.880 --> 00:19:04.490
So you need to listen to all the guidance
that everyone around you that's a part of

348
00:19:04.490 --> 00:19:09.030
the project, that's going to have, and
there are those that have the ability,

349
00:19:09.030 --> 00:19:11.270
like I was telling in my anecdote, right?

350
00:19:11.270 --> 00:19:13.140
Who was watching my change, right?

351
00:19:13.140 --> 00:19:13.980
My boss wasn't.

352
00:19:13.980 --> 00:19:18.940
It was his boss that was going,
why isn't Daniel doing this correctly and

353
00:19:18.940 --> 00:19:20.280
now he had to pull me in and

354
00:19:20.280 --> 00:19:23.650
say, here's where you're not doing this
correctly and then we make that change.

355
00:19:23.650 --> 00:19:25.908
So there's always somebody over
you taking a look at things and

356
00:19:25.908 --> 00:19:27.835
making sure everything's
getting done correctly.

357
00:19:27.835 --> 00:19:28.909
Ronnie, that being said,

358
00:19:28.909 --> 00:19:31.721
is there anything else that we need
to know about the specific process?

359
00:19:31.721 --> 00:19:35.565
>> There is one other thing that we need
to actually be concerned about when we

360
00:19:35.565 --> 00:19:39.038
take a look at organizational
governance according to CompTIA and

361
00:19:39.038 --> 00:19:41.220
that is what we call Phase Gate Approval.

362
00:19:41.220 --> 00:19:44.010
So let's go ahead and take a look
at all four of these again here,

363
00:19:44.010 --> 00:19:46.040
at least let me see if I
can zoom out a little bit.

364
00:19:46.040 --> 00:19:46.730
There we go.

365
00:19:46.730 --> 00:19:49.570
Okay, so we have standards compliance,
which we already talked about.

366
00:19:49.570 --> 00:19:51.620
We have the internal process compliant.

367
00:19:51.620 --> 00:19:55.030
We just mentioned decision
oversight as well.

368
00:19:55.030 --> 00:19:58.420
And this last one right here,
let me make sure I can zoom in there,

369
00:19:58.420 --> 00:20:01.800
Phase Gate Approval is
what we're talking about.

370
00:20:01.800 --> 00:20:03.670
This particular terminology,

371
00:20:03.670 --> 00:20:06.050
this is the only place where
I find it which is CompTIA.

372
00:20:06.050 --> 00:20:08.630
A lot of other places
you may hear the terms,

373
00:20:08.630 --> 00:20:10.340
let me make sure I mention them correctly.

374
00:20:10.340 --> 00:20:13.800
Okay, Toll Gate Approval,
you may hear that term.

375
00:20:13.800 --> 00:20:18.470
You may hear the idea of
Project Phase Transition.

376
00:20:18.470 --> 00:20:21.271
Or my favorite is Go,
No-Go decisions, right?

377
00:20:21.271 --> 00:20:25.318
So remember that your project may actually
proceed with the approval, right?

378
00:20:25.318 --> 00:20:29.839
With your project charter, you proceed
essentially with the pre-project planning

379
00:20:29.839 --> 00:20:33.981
and then you're actually now got the
charter, which gives you that authority

380
00:20:33.981 --> 00:20:38.081
to move through that planning stage and
then of course even in the execution.

381
00:20:38.081 --> 00:20:41.596
But along with that,
what also ends up happening to ensure

382
00:20:41.596 --> 00:20:44.478
that the project is not
going to get out of hand.

383
00:20:44.478 --> 00:20:49.103
Is that you may find yourself actually
marking the actual phases here, to say,

384
00:20:49.103 --> 00:20:53.659
all right, at the end of the pre-project,
in other words, the initiation,

385
00:20:53.659 --> 00:20:56.419
if I can get the project charter,
that means for

386
00:20:56.419 --> 00:20:59.411
me to able to move onto
the next phase of my project.

387
00:20:59.411 --> 00:21:03.296
So let's say that what we actually end
up finding out is that a realistic

388
00:21:03.296 --> 00:21:04.604
project gate, right?

389
00:21:04.604 --> 00:21:09.587
A phase gate here is that I can't
get any sponsor to sign off on

390
00:21:09.587 --> 00:21:11.748
the pre-project setup.

391
00:21:11.748 --> 00:21:16.318
If I can't then that is definitely a no-go
decision, and that might not be mine,

392
00:21:16.318 --> 00:21:19.100
that might be the organization that says,
look,

393
00:21:19.100 --> 00:21:22.168
you've presented this
project as a project manager.

394
00:21:22.168 --> 00:21:24.464
Now you need to get charter approval,

395
00:21:24.464 --> 00:21:28.934
you cannot find anybody that will sign
off on this that this is a good idea.

396
00:21:28.934 --> 00:21:31.478
So, if you can't that's
definitely a no-go.

397
00:21:31.478 --> 00:21:35.388
But, let's say we get through that
process and we've now done our planning.

398
00:21:35.388 --> 00:21:39.339
And even after the examination,
the planning and bringing it together with

399
00:21:39.339 --> 00:21:43.229
stakeholders, we might actually go
ahead and now with the organization,

400
00:21:43.229 --> 00:21:46.461
with the stakeholder,
with the project management office.

401
00:21:46.461 --> 00:21:51.017
We might look at it and go, this was a lot
more complicated than we believed that it

402
00:21:51.017 --> 00:21:55.113
would be and we need to make a decision
now before we spend any more money.

403
00:21:55.113 --> 00:21:57.993
We've already spent this much
on just the planning phase,

404
00:21:57.993 --> 00:22:01.174
before we spend any more money
that we are gonna continue onward.

405
00:22:01.174 --> 00:22:03.840
And it might be a vote,
but it might be, again,

406
00:22:03.840 --> 00:22:08.243
just decisions that are made based on what
we thought the time period might be or

407
00:22:08.243 --> 00:22:10.950
can it actually fit into the schedule.

408
00:22:10.950 --> 00:22:11.960
We might find out something,

409
00:22:11.960 --> 00:22:14.265
which is one of the heartbreakers
that end up happening.

410
00:22:14.265 --> 00:22:19.482
It's that organization, it says yes,
there is a go, no-go decision right now.

411
00:22:19.482 --> 00:22:24.220
We wanna say yes to it, but in the time
that you actually requested for

412
00:22:24.220 --> 00:22:27.960
this project to start, we've already
got five other projects going and

413
00:22:27.960 --> 00:22:30.980
we just can't afford to take
on another one right now.

414
00:22:30.980 --> 00:22:34.670
If you can put this off for
six months to a year, then we can do it.

415
00:22:34.670 --> 00:22:38.600
Well, what if in six months to a year
you don't really know if you're gonna be

416
00:22:38.600 --> 00:22:40.920
a project manager right then or not.

417
00:22:40.920 --> 00:22:45.234
I know even within organizations you might
move from being a project manager on one

418
00:22:45.234 --> 00:22:48.434
particular part of the company
to another particular part.

419
00:22:48.434 --> 00:22:51.508
You might go, I don't know,
in six months I really applu,

420
00:22:51.508 --> 00:22:55.462
you know that you might have applied
to be a project manager somewhere else.

421
00:22:55.462 --> 00:22:58.997
So you might go, well,
let's just do a no-go right now and

422
00:22:58.997 --> 00:23:03.044
they can use the project plan later on and
see if they want to do this.

423
00:23:03.044 --> 00:23:05.831
But you gotta realize that those
are things that may also happen.

424
00:23:05.831 --> 00:23:08.995
So a lot of times it's not up to
the project manager just to say,

425
00:23:08.995 --> 00:23:11.761
I don't care how complicated it is,
we're gonna go.

426
00:23:11.761 --> 00:23:15.379
So these decisions on governance,
organizational governance,

427
00:23:15.379 --> 00:23:19.705
and I say this is out of the hands of the
project manager, he's got a vote in it but

428
00:23:19.705 --> 00:23:23.404
we all have to decide whether or
not we believe it's gonna proceed.

429
00:23:23.404 --> 00:23:25.116
And even in the execution phase,

430
00:23:25.116 --> 00:23:29.090
we may find out that we may go and say
here's how we know we're gonna proceed,

431
00:23:29.090 --> 00:23:33.154
did we produce the original prototype,
if that's what we're doing, okay?

432
00:23:33.154 --> 00:23:36.802
In the first eight weeks like we
said we're gonna do, if we don't,

433
00:23:36.802 --> 00:23:38.082
we come to a milestone.

434
00:23:38.082 --> 00:23:42.747
And at that point, we may say, let's go
ahead and do a go-no go decision here,

435
00:23:42.747 --> 00:23:45.271
after looking at that product prototype.

436
00:23:45.271 --> 00:23:48.993
If the prototype doesn't exist,
it's a no-go and we cancel it and

437
00:23:48.993 --> 00:23:51.094
we start all over at some other point.

438
00:23:51.094 --> 00:23:54.952
So, you may find that out, that there
maybe a ready procedures in place

439
00:23:54.952 --> 00:23:57.921
to do that,
because the organization has set that up.

440
00:23:57.921 --> 00:24:02.123
Or in maybe a meeting, something, like
maybe even in the change management board,

441
00:24:02.123 --> 00:24:06.344
or whoever your project sponsor is and
your stakeholders, and they come together.

442
00:24:06.344 --> 00:24:09.171
And they say look, this is what it is,
you can't have it.

443
00:24:09.171 --> 00:24:13.467
But you do need to actually understand
that usually the decision to proceed on

444
00:24:13.467 --> 00:24:16.454
with the project is not in
the project manager alone.

445
00:24:16.454 --> 00:24:21.109
It does come from the organizational
governance that has to also happen

446
00:24:21.109 --> 00:24:25.231
as oversight for the project and
the project manager himself.

447
00:24:25.231 --> 00:24:29.666
>> Well, Ronnie you've done a great job of
explaining why organizational governance

448
00:24:29.666 --> 00:24:31.488
might be a bit of a hindrance to us.

449
00:24:31.488 --> 00:24:35.231
But it is also usually
a very necessary hindrance.

450
00:24:35.231 --> 00:24:37.294
It's good for us, and
we need it, and we rely on it.

451
00:24:37.294 --> 00:24:40.158
It helps things move in the way that
we need them to move so that we are A,

452
00:24:40.158 --> 00:24:40.887
Compliant and B,

453
00:24:40.887 --> 00:24:43.817
that people aren't just doing whatever
the heck they feel like doing.

454
00:24:43.817 --> 00:24:45.903
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're following some sort

455
00:24:45.903 --> 00:24:49.883
of structured procedure to verify that
those things are being done in that way.

456
00:24:49.883 --> 00:24:53.846
Thanks again, Ronnie, for stopping by and
lending your expertise on this topic,

457
00:24:53.846 --> 00:24:55.165
we appreciate that.

458
00:24:55.165 --> 00:24:56.765
We also appreciate you guys watching.

459
00:24:56.765 --> 00:24:59.825
I hope you got a lot out of this and
learned something, and for

460
00:24:59.825 --> 00:25:01.845
our budding young project managers.

461
00:25:01.845 --> 00:25:03.705
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

462
00:25:03.705 --> 00:25:05.495
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

463
00:25:05.495 --> 00:25:06.315
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

464
00:25:06.315 --> 00:25:07.990
>> And we'll see you next time.

465
00:25:07.990 --> 00:25:13.379
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie begin exploring the scenarios in which components of a project plan can be affected and what actions should be taken when that occurs. Specific components covered here include: Risk Register, Communications Plan, Issues Log, Change Management Forms, and Quality Management Metrics.
episodes.title: Execute the Project Plan

447
00:23:29.330 --> 00:23:33.940
And they have a certain level of quality
that they expected to see before they

448
00:23:33.940 --> 00:23:39.110
would approve any vehicular use
of said area of the bridge.

449
00:23:39.110 --> 00:23:42.850
Now, if it hit 5,000 pounds, they're gonna
say, okay, we have a bit of an issue.

450
00:23:42.850 --> 00:23:46.960
That concrete is not gonna work and
we need to either go back and take all

451
00:23:46.960 --> 00:23:51.800
that old concrete out and put new,
good concrete in, or hey, you know what?

452
00:23:51.800 --> 00:23:56.180
You hit that 10,000 or 20,000 pound
limit now that concrete is good to go,

453
00:23:56.180 --> 00:23:57.880
you can start putting vehicles on it.

454
00:23:57.880 --> 00:24:01.360
So a good thing to have is
definitely quality management.

455
00:24:01.360 --> 00:24:02.910
Make sure that those things are,

456
00:24:02.910 --> 00:24:06.140
they're working the way in which
you would hope that they would.

457
00:24:06.140 --> 00:24:08.840
Ronnie is there anything else we need
to cover when it comes to this stuff?

458
00:24:08.840 --> 00:24:11.750
>> Well, not as far as what
we just talked about, right?

459
00:24:11.750 --> 00:24:14.700
Don't get me wrong, you know,
we could talk on these things in much

460
00:24:14.700 --> 00:24:19.290
more detail and continue to,
to wax eloquent on a lot of this stuff.

461
00:24:19.290 --> 00:24:22.300
But overall, though, just realizing
that these are kind of the basic

462
00:24:22.300 --> 00:24:25.250
scenarios that you're normally
looking at when you're talking about

463
00:24:25.250 --> 00:24:30.510
what am I doing when I'm using my project
plan to manage my project here, okay?

464
00:24:30.510 --> 00:24:32.100
So when you start seeing that, right, and

465
00:24:32.100 --> 00:24:35.900
you start implementing everything, okay,
you're gonna find out that a lot of times

466
00:24:35.900 --> 00:24:38.800
things will go exactly the way you
planned, hopefully that they will.

467
00:24:38.800 --> 00:24:42.410
But if they don't you need to know
what component is going to be

468
00:24:42.410 --> 00:24:45.340
your source of information,
gonna give you also your

469
00:24:45.340 --> 00:24:48.640
plan of action to be able to
implement what you need to as well.

470
00:24:48.640 --> 00:24:51.860
And then what you need to call on
if changes need to be done as well.

471
00:24:51.860 --> 00:24:56.140
And we still got several more to go over,
but we're gonna save that for a part two.

472
00:24:56.140 --> 00:24:57.570
I thought trying to go over like ten or

473
00:24:57.570 --> 00:25:00.650
15 of these In one episode
would be a little bit too much.

474
00:25:00.650 --> 00:25:02.145
>> Like drinking from a fire hose.

475
00:25:02.145 --> 00:25:03.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's always fun.

476
00:25:03.300 --> 00:25:06.500
The information overload is never a good
thing, so we're gonna give you these five,

477
00:25:06.500 --> 00:25:09.590
let you sit on them, stew on them,
think about them, learn about them.

478
00:25:09.590 --> 00:25:13.410
Get them put in the old brain so
that you can pass that Project+ exam and

479
00:25:13.410 --> 00:25:15.930
we'll come back for
a part two and give you the rest.

480
00:25:15.930 --> 00:25:17.490
So, we'll see you then hopefully.

481
00:25:17.490 --> 00:25:20.370
Ronnie, thank you so much for
stopping by and explaining these five.

482
00:25:20.370 --> 00:25:22.380
We look forward to seeing
you in the next episode.

483
00:25:22.380 --> 00:25:23.980
Again we thank you you guys for watching.

484
00:25:23.980 --> 00:25:25.570
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

485
00:25:25.570 --> 00:25:27.400
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

486
00:25:27.400 --> 00:25:28.000
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

487
00:25:28.000 --> 00:25:30.199
>> We'll see you next time.

488
00:25:30.199 --> 00:25:36.712
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring the scenarios in which components of a project plan can be affected and what actions should be taken when that occurs. Specific components covered here include: Project Schedule, WBS, Budget, Resource Requirements, and Scope Statements.
episodes.title: Execute the Project Plan Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:10.025
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.545 --> 00:00:16.486
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.486 --> 00:00:19.525
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode well,

4
00:00:19.525 --> 00:00:22.110
we're continuing on with
our Project+ series.

5
00:00:22.110 --> 00:00:25.570
Joining us back in the studio again today
to lend his expertise on that very topic

6
00:00:25.570 --> 00:00:27.290
is our mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:27.290 --> 00:00:28.560
Ronnie, welcome back to the show.

8
00:00:28.560 --> 00:00:29.390
>> Well thanks for having me.

9
00:00:29.390 --> 00:00:33.110
As we continue on to take
a look at CompTIA's Project+

10
00:00:33.110 --> 00:00:36.690
we're still taking a look at some of the
different scenarios that we're going to

11
00:00:36.690 --> 00:00:40.670
end up seeing our project plan coming on
when we start talking about managing and

12
00:00:40.670 --> 00:00:43.660
executing our particular project as well.

13
00:00:43.660 --> 00:00:46.900
And what we're really looking at are just
several different scenarios that we

14
00:00:46.900 --> 00:00:50.770
need to understand that, when we bring out
our project plan we talked about managing,

15
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:52.330
what is it that's gonna be affected and

16
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:56.510
then what actions are we really
taking when we do that as well.

17
00:00:56.510 --> 00:00:59.120
So the good thing is we've already
looked at several of them and

18
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:03.100
we wanna just kind of finish up our round
of some of the different ones that we

19
00:01:03.100 --> 00:01:06.500
want to actually make sure
that we understand as well.

20
00:01:06.500 --> 00:01:10.070
So one of the last things we
looked at at the end of our

21
00:01:10.070 --> 00:01:13.580
previous episode here was some of
the things that we have to worry about,

22
00:01:13.580 --> 00:01:16.020
such as issues and change managements.

23
00:01:16.020 --> 00:01:17.780
And what we're actually now doing,
of course,

24
00:01:17.780 --> 00:01:21.380
is moving on towards a little bit
more on our scheduling side as well.

25
00:01:21.380 --> 00:01:25.050
So we're just gonna pick right on up
there when we start to take a look.

26
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:29.670
Sometimes what ends up happening is
as we begin our project execution,

27
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:34.030
we wanna be able to see if our project
is actually, well, progressing.

28
00:01:34.030 --> 00:01:38.210
It's kind of strange that we
think about it in that way.

29
00:01:38.210 --> 00:01:39.320
It's easy.
You go well,

30
00:01:39.320 --> 00:01:43.340
I know if people are working on the
project, that it's actually progressing.

31
00:01:43.340 --> 00:01:47.800
But as a project manager you
really do not know that.

32
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:51.080
And the reason why you don't know
that is because nobody's actually

33
00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:52.490
reporting to you.

34
00:01:52.490 --> 00:01:55.450
In this sense, let's say that you're
working in the same building with your

35
00:01:55.450 --> 00:01:59.410
project as the actual functional
teams are working as well.

36
00:01:59.410 --> 00:02:02.510
Well how do you know that those people
are actually on your project and

37
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:05.080
doing the work of your
project versus the work of

38
00:02:05.080 --> 00:02:08.260
what actually is going on
inside of the building as well?

39
00:02:08.260 --> 00:02:11.110
And the reason why you don't know it
is cuz you can't tell just by watching

40
00:02:11.110 --> 00:02:13.660
somebody work whether or
not they're doing that.

41
00:02:13.660 --> 00:02:16.490
So a lot of times that you have
to do this as a project manager,

42
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:21.170
though, is to essentially go ahead and
start scheduling meetings.

43
00:02:21.170 --> 00:02:24.590
Now, I don't like meetings if I
don't have to be in meetings and

44
00:02:24.590 --> 00:02:27.340
the reason why is that there's
usually not a lot that gets

45
00:02:27.340 --> 00:02:29.740
accomplished in the meetings
that you go to.

46
00:02:29.740 --> 00:02:33.440
It's usually most people expressing,
yeah, here's stuff that needs to be done.

47
00:02:33.440 --> 00:02:34.390
Well, who's gonna do it?

48
00:02:34.390 --> 00:02:36.240
I don't know, but it needs to be done.

49
00:02:36.240 --> 00:02:40.220
But in project management, though,
meetings are very important.

50
00:02:40.220 --> 00:02:42.820
And things like project
status meetings are of

51
00:02:42.820 --> 00:02:44.830
utmost important to the project manager.

52
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:48.640
And they're important to the project
manager because, without those,

53
00:02:48.640 --> 00:02:55.150
he cannot be able to tell if the project
is making any progress at all, okay.

54
00:02:55.150 --> 00:03:00.588
So meetings or scheduled meetings are very
important to the project manager.

55
00:03:00.588 --> 00:03:03.160
If you're like me and
you don't really like to attend meetings,

56
00:03:03.160 --> 00:03:07.820
you try to push meetings off into
the last possible issue and thing.

57
00:03:07.820 --> 00:03:11.340
And what you're doing at that point,
right, is you're making the assumption

58
00:03:11.340 --> 00:03:15.880
that as long as you feel like work is
going on, that it's really going on.

59
00:03:15.880 --> 00:03:20.320
But the problem that you have as a project
manager is that you are limited by those

60
00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:24.880
constraints of time,
of cost, right, money, and

61
00:03:24.880 --> 00:03:27.450
of the requirement or the project scope.

62
00:03:27.450 --> 00:03:30.740
And you cannot do that,
as far as a manager goes,

63
00:03:30.740 --> 00:03:32.580
if you don't have any information.

64
00:03:32.580 --> 00:03:36.620
And your main source of information is
normally gonna be through these meetings

65
00:03:36.620 --> 00:03:37.420
with people.

66
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:38.280
>> That's right.

67
00:03:38.280 --> 00:03:42.160
As fun as meetings tend to be,
they are a great way to assess whether or

68
00:03:42.160 --> 00:03:45.449
not everybody is on schedule and
moving on their task.

69
00:03:45.449 --> 00:03:50.255
Just like Ronnie said, you can't kind of
take a bird's eye view of your people and

70
00:03:50.255 --> 00:03:54.700
of your team and say they seem to be
working, because, one of my favorite

71
00:03:54.700 --> 00:03:57.545
things I've always heard is,
if you want to look busy, look annoyed.

72
00:03:57.545 --> 00:03:59.950
>> [LAUGH] So
you just sit around going, Hmm.

73
00:04:01.250 --> 00:04:03.570
You think, man, Daniel's working.

74
00:04:03.570 --> 00:04:04.370
He is really working.

75
00:04:04.370 --> 00:04:05.490
I'm playing Free Cell.

76
00:04:05.490 --> 00:04:06.670
They don't know that.
>> [LAUGH]

77
00:04:06.670 --> 00:04:08.631
>> I'm not winning, right?

78
00:04:08.631 --> 00:04:11.750
You don't know what's going on, so
you call a meeting and you say,

79
00:04:11.750 --> 00:04:14.560
okay, Ronnie how are things progressing?

80
00:04:14.560 --> 00:04:16.150
How much progress have you made?

81
00:04:16.150 --> 00:04:18.420
Do you think you're going
to hit the time budget?

82
00:04:18.420 --> 00:04:20.860
Is everything moving accordingly and
let's see where you at and

83
00:04:20.860 --> 00:04:25.090
then you can assess if the time
is being managed properly.

84
00:04:25.090 --> 00:04:28.821
If not, I'm gonna say Ronnie, you're kinda
slacking, you need to tighten things up,

85
00:04:28.821 --> 00:04:29.781
make sure you move on.

86
00:04:29.781 --> 00:04:33.124
You're gonna have to play a little catch
up because you're behind on schedule but

87
00:04:33.124 --> 00:04:34.976
once you do,
let's stay on pace after that.

88
00:04:34.976 --> 00:04:37.435
And that's the only real
way to get a gauge of that.

89
00:04:37.435 --> 00:04:40.415
So this is a really good way to do that.

90
00:04:40.415 --> 00:04:43.148
>> It really is,
once you have these meetings, right,

91
00:04:43.148 --> 00:04:47.280
you can then update the project schedule
to show whether or not the project in that

92
00:04:47.280 --> 00:04:51.190
particular action or those actions
are really progressing along.

93
00:04:51.190 --> 00:04:53.980
Without those meetings,
you're just making those assumptions and

94
00:04:53.980 --> 00:04:55.980
it's just not going to help you out.

95
00:04:55.980 --> 00:04:59.900
So when you start seeing that, when you
start realizing that you need more and

96
00:04:59.900 --> 00:05:03.701
more information, that's the time for
you to actually call meetings.

97
00:05:03.701 --> 00:05:08.250
And if you're actually a great project
manager, you'll schedule these meetings

98
00:05:08.250 --> 00:05:12.310
in a regular and very periodic basis so
that people can update you.

99
00:05:12.310 --> 00:05:14.735
There's gonna be times in which
those people that are working,

100
00:05:14.735 --> 00:05:17.880
they're gonna say I don't really have
an update except that we're working.

101
00:05:17.880 --> 00:05:19.920
And what you need to tell them, right,

102
00:05:19.920 --> 00:05:24.120
is that you need to find out if they can't
report to you like how it's progressing,

103
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:28.090
at least how much work
has been accomplished.

104
00:05:28.090 --> 00:05:30.690
And you might actually ask for
this in terms of work hours,

105
00:05:30.690 --> 00:05:35.520
if you need to, or the amount of resources
that they've consumed on their project.

106
00:05:35.520 --> 00:05:38.630
That means that what they can do, and
hopefully that's what they're also

107
00:05:38.630 --> 00:05:42.136
monitoring, is that it means you're
not requiring any analysis of them,

108
00:05:42.136 --> 00:05:47.360
of whether they're 55% complete with it or
60 or 65%, right?

109
00:05:48.390 --> 00:05:49.592
When somebody normally asks that,

110
00:05:49.592 --> 00:05:51.642
well just give me a percentage
on how much you're complete.

111
00:05:51.642 --> 00:05:53.402
A lot of times I don't know.

112
00:05:53.402 --> 00:05:59.300
I generally just go it's either
gonna be 25%, 50%, 75 or 100.

113
00:05:59.300 --> 00:06:01.870
That's my kinda standard operating,
if I don't know.

114
00:06:01.870 --> 00:06:05.390
But a lot of times when people
get pushed to their point

115
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:07.950
they're gonna say I think I'm
about 60% complete on this.

116
00:06:07.950 --> 00:06:12.625
And what they really mean is I think I'm
halfway through, but I don't really know,

117
00:06:12.625 --> 00:06:14.260
but to push them that.

118
00:06:14.260 --> 00:06:17.550
But if you can at least get work
hours out of this right, and

119
00:06:17.550 --> 00:06:21.080
the number of days that they've already
worked on it, you can go ahead and

120
00:06:21.080 --> 00:06:24.590
start doing some estimates, and we're
gonna get into formulas in a later date.

121
00:06:24.590 --> 00:06:27.080
But you can actually at
least start working that.

122
00:06:27.080 --> 00:06:31.280
And that way you can update the actual
progress on your project schedule and

123
00:06:31.280 --> 00:06:34.450
know whether or not you do need
to assign more resources or

124
00:06:34.450 --> 00:06:37.090
not to actually figure this out.

125
00:06:37.090 --> 00:06:39.840
So using those scheduled
meetings is a big part.

126
00:06:39.840 --> 00:06:43.660
Making sure your project
schedule is also up to date.

127
00:06:43.660 --> 00:06:45.805
Is gonna give you
a graphical representation,

128
00:06:45.805 --> 00:06:49.410
is gonna allow your stakeholder to
know there is progress on this too.

129
00:06:49.410 --> 00:06:55.470
Now the other thing that we also need to
be able to tell, as a project manager,

130
00:06:55.470 --> 00:07:02.030
is when our project may be lacking some
of the resources that we have going on.

131
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:04.540
Now this is a little bit more difficult,
right.

132
00:07:04.540 --> 00:07:05.810
Work can progress.

133
00:07:05.810 --> 00:07:08.370
And there are people that can
actually work with very little.

134
00:07:08.370 --> 00:07:10.830
There's people that can't
actually work with anything but

135
00:07:10.830 --> 00:07:13.080
everything that can be done.

136
00:07:13.080 --> 00:07:14.680
And I know people like that, right.

137
00:07:14.680 --> 00:07:16.961
There's sometimes where
you'll give somebody some,

138
00:07:16.961 --> 00:07:19.130
and I wanna pull the MacGyver out here,
right?

139
00:07:19.130 --> 00:07:20.290
You give them a paperclip.

140
00:07:20.290 --> 00:07:21.990
You give them some duct tape.

141
00:07:21.990 --> 00:07:23.253
And they can work miracles.

142
00:07:23.253 --> 00:07:26.410
But then there's other
people that I know that,

143
00:07:26.410 --> 00:07:31.660
man, they will not lift a finger,
okay, until they feel like what?

144
00:07:31.660 --> 00:07:37.160
Everything is in it's proper place and
they have every element on hand.

145
00:07:37.160 --> 00:07:41.660
And then they'll pick everything up and
then they'll start working as well.

146
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:45.640
Well, both of those scenarios you know
can end up happening on a project.

147
00:07:45.640 --> 00:07:49.052
But what if your project
is now progressing?

148
00:07:49.052 --> 00:07:53.090
And yes, you actually do have multiple
work packages now actually working out.

149
00:07:53.090 --> 00:07:57.758
But how do you actually know when you have
one work package that may be suffering

150
00:07:57.758 --> 00:08:00.516
with a dearth of materials or
consumables, or

151
00:08:00.516 --> 00:08:04.548
even another person in need And
another one has too much, okay, and

152
00:08:04.548 --> 00:08:08.470
what are we taking a look at
there when we start seeing it?

153
00:08:08.470 --> 00:08:12.110
Well what you're actually now looking for
when you have something like that

154
00:08:12.110 --> 00:08:17.060
is that you have to go beyond the idea
of progress in your project here.

155
00:08:17.060 --> 00:08:19.940
And you now have to actually
start to demand some

156
00:08:19.940 --> 00:08:22.660
performance data is what
you're looking for.

157
00:08:22.660 --> 00:08:24.565
Okay, so even though we can ask for

158
00:08:24.565 --> 00:08:27.930
performance in terms of
completion by percentage, right?

159
00:08:27.930 --> 00:08:31.380
In other words the idea of progress,
but what we're now looking for

160
00:08:31.380 --> 00:08:32.738
is actual performance.

161
00:08:32.738 --> 00:08:36.020
And even though I told you that on the
originally if you can't do anything else

162
00:08:36.020 --> 00:08:37.820
at least get some performance here.

163
00:08:37.820 --> 00:08:41.370
You're actually gonna now take that
performance stuff and then try and

164
00:08:41.370 --> 00:08:46.130
see why one work package, right,
might be falling behind schedule and

165
00:08:46.130 --> 00:08:50.170
you might actually be able to find that
out by taking a look at those hours and

166
00:08:50.170 --> 00:08:52.540
seeing what materials I've
actually been consumed.

167
00:08:52.540 --> 00:08:54.955
And then you might go, man this is why,

168
00:08:54.955 --> 00:08:58.040
cuz they don't have enough people working
on this and that's why they're falling

169
00:08:58.040 --> 00:09:01.630
behind While this other project
has three or four people.

170
00:09:01.630 --> 00:09:05.410
And what we're realizing is
that they're progressing but

171
00:09:05.410 --> 00:09:07.700
the cost is actually insanely large.

172
00:09:07.700 --> 00:09:10.740
And that means that there's not
enough people working on that or

173
00:09:10.740 --> 00:09:12.530
too many people on that one.

174
00:09:12.530 --> 00:09:14.690
So you might end up finding that out.

175
00:09:14.690 --> 00:09:18.850
And when you start seeing that usually
you're gonna find that in the WBS itself,

176
00:09:18.850 --> 00:09:22.320
the work breakdown schedule structure for
you.

177
00:09:22.320 --> 00:09:25.960
Where you can take that one work package
and see what resources have been assigned

178
00:09:25.960 --> 00:09:28.940
and you do, you want to start demanding
some performance information or

179
00:09:28.940 --> 00:09:32.620
receiving, I should say,
performance information on that.

180
00:09:32.620 --> 00:09:35.930
So then you can take a look at
