But every project ends up being either
more, okay, than they thought it would be,

403
00:21:21.920 --> 00:21:25.580
and that's because you
didn't consider everything.

404
00:21:25.580 --> 00:21:27.980
And it's not easy, right?

405
00:21:27.980 --> 00:21:32.690
As a novice project manager, a lot of
times it's easy to see the big picture,

406
00:21:32.690 --> 00:21:35.730
but it's not easy to see how
to get to the big picture.

407
00:21:35.730 --> 00:21:36.250
So that means,

408
00:21:36.250 --> 00:21:40.870
you tend to make overwhelming assumptions
on projects that you go, no, I think

409
00:21:40.870 --> 00:21:44.800
I can do that in three weeks when it's in
reality five is what you'll end up with.

410
00:21:44.800 --> 00:21:46.225
And that's because you do.

411
00:21:46.225 --> 00:21:48.250
You see the end product.

412
00:21:48.250 --> 00:21:51.430
You believe what the team that you have,
they can accomplish it in this way.

413
00:21:51.430 --> 00:21:53.950
Reality kicks in with all
the different things and

414
00:21:53.950 --> 00:21:56.110
it becomes larger than you think.

415
00:21:56.110 --> 00:21:58.730
Or you might find out that the way
that you thought it could be done,

416
00:21:58.730 --> 00:22:00.500
it's not gonna be done that way.

417
00:22:00.500 --> 00:22:05.040
And this is true of anything that I've
ever really worked on the first time,

418
00:22:05.040 --> 00:22:05.740
you know?

419
00:22:05.740 --> 00:22:08.290
I assume that I know what
the end product looks like and

420
00:22:08.290 --> 00:22:11.150
I assume I have a road map
that actually leads us there.

421
00:22:11.150 --> 00:22:13.750
And then there's some point that
somebody says, you know Ronnie,

422
00:22:13.750 --> 00:22:15.560
you can't do it that way.

423
00:22:15.560 --> 00:22:17.020
And I go, well, why not?

424
00:22:17.020 --> 00:22:19.690
And they start explaining
what would have to be done

425
00:22:19.690 --> 00:22:22.980
if I were to do it the way that
I need to do it and go, whoa.

426
00:22:22.980 --> 00:22:26.300
Obviously, that's not the right way to go.

427
00:22:26.300 --> 00:22:30.140
And then I have to start asking for
suggestions cuz I didn't realize it.

428
00:22:30.140 --> 00:22:34.210
And then I have to bring that suggestion
to change management and say obviously,

429
00:22:34.210 --> 00:22:37.750
I couldn't do it that way, but
here is the way we should do it.

430
00:22:37.750 --> 00:22:41.700
Is that an okay that we can go ahead and
start working that way instead?

431
00:22:41.700 --> 00:22:43.280
So sometimes you will see that.

432
00:22:43.280 --> 00:22:47.260
When you're young and you're new, let
me not put, when you're new [LAUGH] and

433
00:22:47.260 --> 00:22:50.940
you're a novice at this [LAUGH], then
>> Could be 80 years old,

434
00:22:50.940 --> 00:22:52.810
you'd start at a project manager, Ron.

435
00:22:52.810 --> 00:22:55.110
>> Don't know why I said that,
want to remove that caveat.

436
00:22:55.110 --> 00:22:56.200
>> Ronnie's ageism [LAUGH].

437
00:22:56.200 --> 00:22:57.890
>> I know, tell me about it.

438
00:22:57.890 --> 00:23:00.050
So when this happens, right?

439
00:23:00.050 --> 00:23:02.590
It's easy to assume too much.

440
00:23:02.590 --> 00:23:06.330
So you gotta keep your eye on that
project scope as well, because if not,

441
00:23:06.330 --> 00:23:08.380
the project scope will eat you, okay?

442
00:23:08.380 --> 00:23:10.970
It will absolutely push your boundaries,

443
00:23:10.970 --> 00:23:13.470
cuz everybody makes a recommendation,
right?

444
00:23:13.470 --> 00:23:16.850
Your stakeholders will say,
hey, can you add this in here?

445
00:23:16.850 --> 00:23:20.080
And somebody on your team's gonna say,
yeah, I don't see why not, okay?

446
00:23:20.080 --> 00:23:23.630
And then you're gonna have internal people
that say, here's what needs to be done.

447
00:23:23.630 --> 00:23:26.190
And somebody's gonna say, yeah,
we should do it that way.

448
00:23:26.190 --> 00:23:28.010
And somebody forgets to update you.

449
00:23:28.010 --> 00:23:30.640
And then, you're gonna always see
that all of a sudden here it is.

450
00:23:30.640 --> 00:23:32.425
It's much bigger than you
thought it was gonna be.

451
00:23:32.425 --> 00:23:35.820
Keeping your eye on means
more than anything, right?

452
00:23:35.820 --> 00:23:38.970
Keeping on top of everything else
that we really talked about and

453
00:23:38.970 --> 00:23:43.000
keeping on top of that scope statement is
also what we're taking a look at as well.

454
00:23:43.000 --> 00:23:47.040
It's easy if people will follow
that change process, right?

455
00:23:47.040 --> 00:23:49.610
As long as you actually
keep on top of that,

456
00:23:49.610 --> 00:23:53.970
then when people say changes
are to be done, you make it clear.

457
00:23:53.970 --> 00:23:58.960
Changes can be done to the project, but
only through the official change process.

458
00:23:58.960 --> 00:24:00.940
It's not gonna be done at a whim.

459
00:24:00.940 --> 00:24:02.780
That's not gonna be done
because you hear it.

460
00:24:02.780 --> 00:24:05.710
It has to be done according
to that change process.

461
00:24:05.710 --> 00:24:09.640
And that way, it doesn't get out of
your scope and you don't realize

462
00:24:09.640 --> 00:24:11.840
that if somebody adds something in
that you didn't even account for.

463
00:24:11.840 --> 00:24:14.390
And that means you don't have anybody to
work on it, you don't have any money to

464
00:24:14.390 --> 00:24:16.690
work on it, you don't have
any resources to work on it.

465
00:24:16.690 --> 00:24:20.300
If they add it into scope statement,
that means we actually authorize.

466
00:24:20.300 --> 00:24:22.130
All the accounts, all the money, and

467
00:24:22.130 --> 00:24:25.770
all the resources to actually add that
into your project, and that's why you

468
00:24:25.770 --> 00:24:30.670
wanna actually keep on top of these things
to make sure that you're managing it well.

469
00:24:30.670 --> 00:24:34.840
The day that you as a project manager
decide that the reports aren't worth it,

470
00:24:34.840 --> 00:24:37.780
the meetings that we talked
about aren't worth it.

471
00:24:37.780 --> 00:24:41.680
The idea of tracking
the budget is not important.

472
00:24:41.680 --> 00:24:45.250
As you as the project manager, when you
decide that you're not gonna do that,

473
00:24:45.250 --> 00:24:49.980
that's the day that this gonna get be
on due and you're not gonna catch up.

474
00:24:49.980 --> 00:24:53.730
So, being a good project
manager means good vigilance.

475
00:24:53.730 --> 00:24:54.330
Right?

476
00:24:54.330 --> 00:24:57.870
And maintaining this reports and
giving the information that you need,

477
00:24:57.870 --> 00:25:01.320
to know exactly where your
project is at any point in time.

478
00:25:01.320 --> 00:25:04.580
So make sure you take a look
at these examples again.

479
00:25:04.580 --> 00:25:09.270
That you're gonna find from the comp t
exam objectives, and try and figure those

480
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:13.510
out, and try and put yourself in those
scenarios about what you would look to

481
00:25:13.510 --> 00:25:16.760
if you needed to update something, or
if you needed more information about it.

482
00:25:16.760 --> 00:25:18.580
It's always gonna be in your project plan,
but

483
00:25:18.580 --> 00:25:21.050
just in one of those
little sub-plans instead.

484
00:25:21.050 --> 00:25:24.290
So make sure you actually realize
what some of those are and

485
00:25:24.290 --> 00:25:28.140
what actions you're actually doing when
you work with those particular components.

486
00:25:28.140 --> 00:25:31.350
>> Well, Ronnie, it is a lot of
information, that is for sure.

487
00:25:31.350 --> 00:25:33.230
It's a good thing we broke
this up into two parts,

488
00:25:33.230 --> 00:25:37.220
cuz like I said before information
overload can easily occur here.

489
00:25:37.220 --> 00:25:39.860
So walk through these
episodes a few times.

490
00:25:39.860 --> 00:25:43.020
Make sure you understand each one of those
concepts, each one of the terms, each

491
00:25:43.020 --> 00:25:47.890
one of those different components, so that
you are prepared for that Project+ exam.

492
00:25:47.890 --> 00:25:52.150
Ronnie, Thank you for so faithfully
explaining these concepts to us and

493
00:25:52.150 --> 00:25:53.520
these different components.

494
00:25:53.520 --> 00:25:56.090
But, it looks like we've come to the end
of yet another excellent episode.

495
00:25:56.090 --> 00:25:57.310
Hopefully, you guys have enjoyed it.

496
00:25:57.310 --> 00:25:58.820
We've got a lot of great
information out of it.

497
00:25:58.820 --> 00:26:02.540
We're gonna go ahead and sign off for IT
Pro TV, I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

498
00:26:02.540 --> 00:26:03.180
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

499
00:26:03.180 --> 00:26:07.115
>> And we'll see you next time.

500
00:26:07.115 --> 00:26:13.340
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to implement proper change management procedures; in other words manage change management. They begin by looking at identifying necessary changes and officially documenting it. Next they detail the importance of performing an impact analysis and then coordinating the appropriate course of action with stakeholders. Finally, they discuss how the project plan should be appropriately updated.
episodes.title: Manage Project Changes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.921 --> 00:00:16.001
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPROTV.

3
00:00:16.001 --> 00:00:19.920
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we are moving on with our Project+

4
00:00:19.920 --> 00:00:23.572
series Joining us back in the studio again
today to lend his expertise on that very

5
00:00:23.572 --> 00:00:26.121
topic, our good friend and
mentor, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

6
00:00:26.121 --> 00:00:27.530
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

7
00:00:27.530 --> 00:00:30.050
>> Thank you for having me back on
the show as we continue on with

8
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:32.050
CompTIA's Project+.

9
00:00:32.050 --> 00:00:36.870
Today we're taking a look at the idea
of the change process that has to go on

10
00:00:36.870 --> 00:00:38.380
within projects.

11
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:41.709
Now, when we start talking about it,
the idea of change management is one of

12
00:00:41.709 --> 00:00:44.519
the most important things that we
can do during our execution and

13
00:00:44.519 --> 00:00:47.120
our monitoring and
controlling of the project.

14
00:00:47.120 --> 00:00:51.460
So even when we plan everything out, we're
actually also still supposed to be able to

15
00:00:51.460 --> 00:00:54.080
use this, especially when
changes do hit our project,

16
00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:56.770
and it's very important
that we understand that.

17
00:00:56.770 --> 00:01:01.150
Right before the show as we were talking a
little bit and getting ready for this, one

18
00:01:01.150 --> 00:01:04.930
of the hardest things to do when we start
talking, especially about the process of

19
00:01:04.930 --> 00:01:09.850
change management here, is the management
part of the change management.

20
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:15.040
I know that sounds strange, but remember
that it's easy to talk about changes and

21
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:17.540
what we really need to do
in terms of the process,

22
00:01:17.540 --> 00:01:21.560
it's much harder to talk about the
management of the change process itself,

23
00:01:21.560 --> 00:01:25.080
which is what we really need to
focus in on on our show today,

24
00:01:25.080 --> 00:01:29.500
because that's where we come at it from
the actual project management standpoint.

25
00:01:29.500 --> 00:01:31.750
It's not that changes
are bad to your project.

26
00:01:31.750 --> 00:01:33.690
Changes will happen in your project,

27
00:01:33.690 --> 00:01:37.040
sometimes on a daily basis
because of things that go on.

28
00:01:37.040 --> 00:01:40.420
Sometimes though,
the very fact is changes happen, and

29
00:01:40.420 --> 00:01:43.910
we don't know that they've happened,
that's when it's a bad process.

30
00:01:43.910 --> 00:01:47.900
And that means that what we want to do,
before anything happens here, right, is to

31
00:01:47.900 --> 00:01:53.690
make sure that we have a good solid plan
that helps us to manage when changes do

32
00:01:53.690 --> 00:01:57.910
end up getting requested for our project,
and then be able to manage them so that we

33
00:01:57.910 --> 00:02:01.820
see them all the way through the way that
they need to be able to be seen through.

34
00:02:01.820 --> 00:02:05.310
If not, these changes are gonna affect
our entire project whether it's

35
00:02:05.310 --> 00:02:08.070
actually the schedule and
it ends up being late, or

36
00:02:08.070 --> 00:02:11.250
whether the project's gonna
cost us too much money, or

37
00:02:11.250 --> 00:02:14.750
whether it's gonna affect the over all
quality of our project, or the actual

38
00:02:14.750 --> 00:02:18.620
end requirements of our project,
that's what we have to worry about.

39
00:02:18.620 --> 00:02:23.250
So, what we're gonna focusing on today, of
course then, is to take a look at multiple

40
00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:28.420
scenarios that will help us to understand
on what we have to do as project managers

41
00:02:28.420 --> 00:02:31.960
and what we have to make sure that we
get set in place as project managers, so

42
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:35.480
that we can manage
the change process itself.

43
00:02:35.480 --> 00:02:36.200
>> Yes, Ronnie,

44
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:40.120
we were having a good time talking
about this before the show started.

45
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:44.460
It's not about actually doing the change
that we're talking today, even though

46
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:47.370
you're going to do the change, it's
gonna be a part of it, it's more about

47
00:02:47.370 --> 00:02:52.198
managing the process and implementations
that go along with Change Management.

48
00:02:52.198 --> 00:02:53.188
>> [LAUGH].

49
00:02:53.188 --> 00:02:55.160
>> It can seem very confusing but

50
00:02:55.160 --> 00:02:59.300
hopefully we will remove the veil and
clear the fog and

51
00:02:59.300 --> 00:03:02.860
everything will look a little more
clear by the end of this episode.

52
00:03:02.860 --> 00:03:04.680
That being said Ronnie, where do we begin,

53
00:03:04.680 --> 00:03:07.410
how do we start to implement
proper change procedures?

54
00:03:07.410 --> 00:03:09.480
>> Well see in that,
that's the hard part we're talking about.

55
00:03:09.480 --> 00:03:12.940
The very fact it's fun to actually talk
about the change process especially when

56
00:03:12.940 --> 00:03:14.530
go through it with people and

57
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:16.980
they've actually been a part
of change management process.

58
00:03:16.980 --> 00:03:19.910
It lets you understand the logic
behind it a little bit better but

59
00:03:19.910 --> 00:03:23.730
it's much more difficult when you have
to now start talking about the idea

60
00:03:23.730 --> 00:03:28.140
of procedures, and documents, and
different things that we're gonna use as

61
00:03:28.140 --> 00:03:31.220
project managers to insure that
we know what's going on and

62
00:03:31.220 --> 00:03:35.560
to make sure that we have a nice uniform
coverage of every change that happens.

63
00:03:35.560 --> 00:03:38.980
So the end result of what our process is,
right, and when we talk about

64
00:03:38.980 --> 00:03:43.800
the management of change process here,
is to ensure that we as a project manager

65
00:03:43.800 --> 00:03:47.510
understand that any changes that come on
board, that they're gonna be handled in

66
00:03:47.510 --> 00:03:51.240
the professional way that we need them
handled, and they're gonna be treated in

67
00:03:51.240 --> 00:03:55.470
the manner that's really gonna actually
make us focus in on the project better.

68
00:03:55.470 --> 00:03:59.070
What we don't want is any change
to go on without our knowledge.

69
00:03:59.070 --> 00:04:02.170
So how do we ensure something
like that happens so

70
00:04:02.170 --> 00:04:06.090
that we can continue to actually
understand and be able to manage changes?

71
00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:08.660
It really breaks down into
four different components

72
00:04:08.660 --> 00:04:10.520
of the change management process.

73
00:04:10.520 --> 00:04:14.440
Let's take a look at those components in
an overview, and then we'll back and we'll

74
00:04:14.440 --> 00:04:17.870
hit them a little bit more in detail and
we'll talk about some of the scenarios.

75
00:04:17.870 --> 00:04:22.800
So, on my computer here I went ahead and
created a small kinda diagram here for

76
00:04:22.800 --> 00:04:24.330
us to help us out here or a list.

77
00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:25.830
So the first thing that we need to do,

78
00:04:25.830 --> 00:04:30.000
is we need to talk about the idea of
identifying the change, and then we'll

79
00:04:30.000 --> 00:04:35.710
talk about of course, performing an impact
analysis and where that also comes from.

80
00:04:35.710 --> 00:04:39.490
And then we coordinate with team members
and stakeholders to select a proper course

81
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:43.380
of action, now that we have the fact that
we might have a change that we need to do.

82
00:04:43.380 --> 00:04:46.980
And then lastly we need to also make sure
that we understand that updating that

83
00:04:46.980 --> 00:04:51.075
project plan is actually gonna be a part
of the change management process.

84
00:04:51.075 --> 00:04:55.416
It's one of those unusual things
where you we leave it as last, but

85
00:04:55.416 --> 00:04:58.390
it's probably something that's
actually very important as more and

86
00:04:58.390 --> 00:05:01.520
more changes come on board
when we get requested or

87
00:05:01.520 --> 00:05:04.130
we're not gonna know whether or
not a change has been done.

88
00:05:04.130 --> 00:05:07.640
So let's go ahead and
start back here at the beginning.

89
00:05:07.640 --> 00:05:10.830
When we start talking about something
that's actually very easy for us and

90
00:05:10.830 --> 00:05:16.710
very intuitive here, that if we are going
to manage the changes, what we want

91
00:05:16.710 --> 00:05:20.940
to do of course is be able to actually
have a way of identifying the change.

92
00:05:20.940 --> 00:05:23.070
Now when we start talking
about identifying the change,

93
00:05:23.070 --> 00:05:25.760
you might just say yeah,
when a change needs to be done,

94
00:05:25.760 --> 00:05:31.060
somebody just needs to let somebody
know that a change is done, and

95
00:05:31.060 --> 00:05:37.140
that is really kinda the very kernel of
the truth of that idea of identification,

96
00:05:37.140 --> 00:05:40.010
but the problem is,
how do you manage that?

97
00:05:40.010 --> 00:05:43.220
How do you manage the fact
that I told Daniel that,

98
00:05:43.220 --> 00:05:45.240
Daniel we need to have this change?

99
00:05:45.240 --> 00:05:49.570
So let's take for an example here as a
scenario that we can actually use here in

100
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:54.550
an instance is to sit and go this,
that I notice that a piece

101
00:05:54.550 --> 00:05:59.900
of equipment that we are constantly using
Daniel on our project, it keeps failing.

102
00:05:59.900 --> 00:06:03.890
We fix it, it works for a couple days, it
fails again, we fit it again, it works for

103
00:06:03.890 --> 00:06:06.410
a day then we continue to do that.

104
00:06:06.410 --> 00:06:09.160
Well, I just sit there, and
I mention to Daniel, Daniel,

105
00:06:09.160 --> 00:06:11.440
we need to replace this machine, okay?

106
00:06:11.440 --> 00:06:15.740
Now, in my mind, okay,
what am I essentially telling Daniel?

107
00:06:15.740 --> 00:06:19.370
That I believe that the machine
needs to be replaced, and

108
00:06:19.370 --> 00:06:23.660
therefore, that could now become
a change that happens in our project.

109
00:06:23.660 --> 00:06:27.830
Daniel, though, hears it and says he
just agrees, it's just an agreement.

110
00:06:27.830 --> 00:06:31.150
We've talked about the idea that we were
arguing a little bit before on logic.

111
00:06:31.150 --> 00:06:34.150
The idea is how is it heard, right?

112
00:06:34.150 --> 00:06:34.990
What I-
>> The perception.

113
00:06:34.990 --> 00:06:37.920
>> Yeah, the perception of it
is what ends up happening.

114
00:06:37.920 --> 00:06:42.910
Well you can't manage perception, nor
can I manage perception, so what ends up

115
00:06:42.910 --> 00:06:47.090
happening is that Daniel hears one thing,
and I said one thing, right?

116
00:06:47.090 --> 00:06:49.600
I said that machine needs to be changed.

117
00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:50.870
Daniel agrees.

118
00:06:50.870 --> 00:06:55.320
Three days later, I look at Daniel and go,
Daniel, why is that machine still here,

119
00:06:55.320 --> 00:06:58.120
why didn't we actually change it out for
a new one?

120
00:06:58.120 --> 00:07:00.840
And Daniel says, well,
you didn't tell me to change it.

121
00:07:00.840 --> 00:07:05.020
We didn't actually have any process in
change here, so how do we know that it's

122
00:07:05.020 --> 00:07:10.090
actually gonna be something that in our
project can actually get managed and

123
00:07:10.090 --> 00:07:13.750
then can actually have something done
about it, okay, is what we need to do.

124
00:07:13.750 --> 00:07:20.310
So the first part is to figure out, how do
we identify when a change has to happen.

125
00:07:20.310 --> 00:07:22.900
Not just identify that there is a problem,
but

126
00:07:22.900 --> 00:07:26.020
how do we actually begin to identify
that a change has happened?

127
00:07:26.020 --> 00:07:30.230
Well, there's two particular methods that
we can actually use here to do so, and

128
00:07:30.230 --> 00:07:34.130
they really do revolve around
something that we joke about it, but

129
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:37.400
it's very important,
especially on a very tight budget here,

130
00:07:37.400 --> 00:07:42.060
on a very tight schedule, is to actually
do the idea of documentation, right?

131
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:45.373
So let's talk about the two that we can
actually take a look at here, okay?

132
00:07:45.373 --> 00:07:50.056
So when you as a project manager and
somebody actually brings you something,

133
00:07:50.056 --> 00:07:53.944
one of the first things that you
want to do is you wanna go ahead and

134
00:07:53.944 --> 00:07:57.565
market in what we call a request log,
a Change Request Log.

135
00:07:57.565 --> 00:08:00.891
Let me see if I can bring
up an example of this

136
00:08:00.891 --> 00:08:01.819
>> Yeah, there we go.

137
00:08:01.819 --> 00:08:07.070
And let me zoom back out just a little
bit, and we'll take a look at this one.

138
00:08:07.070 --> 00:08:10.840
Now, this particular request log is part
of what you might have in your project

139
00:08:10.840 --> 00:08:15.050
management plan that allows you, and
you might have sheets of these, right?

140
00:08:15.050 --> 00:08:18.160
So, let's say that I've actually
got this on an electronic document,

141
00:08:18.160 --> 00:08:19.720
which is perfectly fine.

142
00:08:19.720 --> 00:08:20.240
So up here,

143
00:08:20.240 --> 00:08:24.510
you would simply write in, you'd print
this out, you'd write in your name and

144
00:08:24.510 --> 00:08:27.970
your project manager or your project name,
and then who the project manager is.

145
00:08:27.970 --> 00:08:30.520
You can include dates in there,
but that’s not so important for

146
00:08:30.520 --> 00:08:33.910
this as far as the entire log goes.

147
00:08:33.910 --> 00:08:37.420
But when you take look at the way
that this is done as far as logging,

148
00:08:37.420 --> 00:08:41.500
let’s say that what we do is we go ahead
and assign it an identification number.

149
00:08:41.500 --> 00:08:45.240
And this is important when we talk about
assigning an identification number.

150
00:08:45.240 --> 00:08:49.030
The reason why is that, even though
this is for me to keep track of,

151
00:08:49.030 --> 00:08:52.876
what I would end up giving to someone
that is making the request itself.

152
00:08:52.876 --> 00:08:56.680
Did I close that, apparently I
closed that other document out here.

153
00:08:57.720 --> 00:09:00.690
Is that I would give them
a change request form, okay?

154
00:09:00.690 --> 00:09:02.410
Now, if I give them a change request form,

155
00:09:02.410 --> 00:09:04.880
this number's also going
to be on that form so

156
00:09:04.880 --> 00:09:08.680
that there's a tracking or an audit
that we can follow all the way through.

157
00:09:08.680 --> 00:09:10.680
So I go in and assign this here.

158
00:09:10.680 --> 00:09:13.780
And then, on that change request,
I go and mark that number down and

159
00:09:13.780 --> 00:09:16.610
I hand it Daniel, or I hand it to
whoever's actually making this.

160
00:09:16.610 --> 00:09:18.560
So, let's say that Daniel went in and
submitted an assignment.

161
00:09:18.560 --> 00:09:23.180
I know I kinda pre-dated it here, next
week at some point, right, on the 14th,

162
00:09:23.180 --> 00:09:24.720
on the Monday.

163
00:09:24.720 --> 00:09:27.220
And the description here is
that he's telling me that,

164
00:09:27.220 --> 00:09:31.610
look, I realized something, I'm gonna
fall behind on my particular work package

165
00:09:31.610 --> 00:09:34.660
if I don't get enough help
in the following week.

166
00:09:34.660 --> 00:09:37.870
So, what he's done is he's asked for
an additional person on his project for

167
00:09:37.870 --> 00:09:39.290
one week.

168
00:09:39.290 --> 00:09:40.700
And there's the requester.

169
00:09:40.700 --> 00:09:43.470
And at this point here,
this is where I would keep track.

170
00:09:43.470 --> 00:09:46.157
Now, I may just have that
information up to this point, okay?

171
00:09:46.157 --> 00:09:48.090
I may not have anything else.

172
00:09:48.090 --> 00:09:51.692
But during that point,
if that was actually now submitted, and

173
00:09:51.692 --> 00:09:55.050
I submitted it to the change control
board, which is what CCB stands for,

174
00:09:55.050 --> 00:09:59.390
change control board, then I can
get a decision back from them and

175
00:09:59.390 --> 00:10:03.030
they can tell me whether if it's been
approved or not, and I can close that out,

176
00:10:03.030 --> 00:10:08.070
which actually indicates that now Daniel
has actually gotten his official response

177
00:10:08.070 --> 00:10:10.920
from what that change is suppose to be.

178
00:10:10.920 --> 00:10:14.064
So, one of these things right here
is actually kinda the key, right?

179
00:10:14.064 --> 00:10:18.520
That you can keep track of it as the
information starts going back and forth.

180
00:10:18.520 --> 00:10:20.280
The other one is that change request doc.

181
00:10:20.280 --> 00:10:23.170
And let me see if I can actually pull
that one up here, which is this one.

182
00:10:24.720 --> 00:10:26.480
And this is what we would give to Daniel.

183
00:10:26.480 --> 00:10:27.300
And this right here,

184
00:10:27.300 --> 00:10:31.660
notice the change number that you see,
or we could call it ID number, again.

185
00:10:31.660 --> 00:10:34.560
You just write that up as you're
actually the project manager.

186
00:10:34.560 --> 00:10:37.870
Or if this is in your project management
office, they can go there and

187
00:10:37.870 --> 00:10:39.590
they'll assign a number here.

188
00:10:39.590 --> 00:10:43.580
And from that point, it just depends on
how detailed your project wants to be.

189
00:10:43.580 --> 00:10:46.952
You can see where it actually lists
the categories of change, and

190
00:10:46.952 --> 00:10:50.750
whether it's scope, quality, requirements,
cost, schedule, documentation.

191
00:10:50.750 --> 00:10:52.310
Whatever it is, you go ahead and

192
00:10:52.310 --> 00:10:55.400
you submit that right there
by simply check-marking it.

193
00:10:55.400 --> 00:10:57.380
Add in your other details, as well.

194
00:10:57.380 --> 00:10:59.930
And these are normally handwritten
unless you do have an electronic

195
00:10:59.930 --> 00:11:01.470
template of some sort.

196
00:11:01.470 --> 00:11:03.080
Justification.

197
00:11:03.080 --> 00:11:07.540
And then, you also need to include the
impact that you think it's gonna cause.

198
00:11:07.540 --> 00:11:10.950
Now, we're gonna talk about impact and
risk management a little bit later on, and

199
00:11:10.950 --> 00:11:12.050
managing that.

200
00:11:12.050 --> 00:11:15.430
But what we're supposed to know is,
is this change really gonna impact me?

201
00:11:15.430 --> 00:11:17.350
Well, I can at least let them know,

202
00:11:17.350 --> 00:11:21.590
yes, it will help keep my work
package on schedule, okay?

203
00:11:21.590 --> 00:11:23.140
I could do something like that.

204
00:11:23.140 --> 00:11:25.950
Or, if I don't have it,
I could actually indicate that.

205
00:11:25.950 --> 00:11:29.230
Here's why the change is actually needed,
too.

206
00:11:29.230 --> 00:11:33.630
So, you can actually see that and whether
it's the scope, the grid, requirements,

207
00:11:33.630 --> 00:11:37.120
cost, you can add in all that
information that's gonna be relevant.

208
00:11:37.120 --> 00:11:41.170
Additional comments,
if you choose to, and justification.

209
00:11:41.170 --> 00:11:44.450
And this particular point right here,
right, on the disposition, that's for

210
00:11:44.450 --> 00:11:48.300
that change of management board to go
ahead and take a look at and to tell us

211
00:11:48.300 --> 00:11:52.550
whether they've approved it, deferred it
or actually rejected it at this point.

212
00:11:52.550 --> 00:11:53.760
And why is that important?

213
00:11:53.760 --> 00:11:57.760
Because, in change management, right,
in the idea of following the process of

214
00:11:57.760 --> 00:12:01.860
change, we're no longer talking
about Daniel's perception here.

215
00:12:01.860 --> 00:12:02.530
Okay?

216
00:12:02.530 --> 00:12:03.720
What can I do now?

217
00:12:03.720 --> 00:12:07.130
I can show Daniel that
the change that he requested,

218
00:12:07.130 --> 00:12:09.810
it's actually been logged, okay?

219
00:12:09.810 --> 00:12:11.760
He submitted it in writing.

220
00:12:11.760 --> 00:12:15.850
I've taken that document and actually
submitted it to the change request board.

221
00:12:15.850 --> 00:12:18.600
Daniel now has an answer
that's actually official.

222
00:12:18.600 --> 00:12:20.870
I have tracked it and
I'm monitoring it, and I say,

223
00:12:20.870 --> 00:12:25.470
Daniel, put the extra person that
you need on schedule next week.

224
00:12:25.470 --> 00:12:27.010
And we're ready to go.

225
00:12:27.010 --> 00:12:29.750
And that's what we talk about
in terms of management, right?

226
00:12:29.750 --> 00:12:30.720
Up until that point,

227
00:12:30.720 --> 00:12:33.890
the scenario that I gave you is something
that really does happen, right, Daniel?

228
00:12:33.890 --> 00:12:38.410
In which I go, yeah, we should replace
that, and Daniel goes, I agree.

229
00:12:38.410 --> 00:12:40.250
And for two weeks nothing happens.

230
00:12:40.250 --> 00:12:45.040
>> Yeah, Ronnie, actually, I think it's
a perfect illustration of exactly why we

231
00:12:45.040 --> 00:12:46.880
need change management, right?

232
00:12:46.880 --> 00:12:52.180
It's so that when we do identify a place
where a change needs to be occurring,

233
00:12:52.180 --> 00:12:54.160
that a change needs to happen,

234
00:12:54.160 --> 00:12:58.640
that we officially have a way to verify
that that change is going to occur.

235
00:12:58.640 --> 00:13:00.870
Because it is exactly what Ronnie said.

236
00:13:00.870 --> 00:13:04.400
It is something that happens a day
to day basis, I guarantee it.

237
00:13:04.400 --> 00:13:06.060
That Ronnie goes, man,

238
00:13:06.060 --> 00:13:10.000
that little piece of machinery
there is a real piece of garbage.

239
00:13:10.000 --> 00:13:11.060
We should change that out,

240
00:13:11.060 --> 00:13:13.840
we should get something different
that's not gonna let us down every day.

241
00:13:13.840 --> 00:13:15.085
And I go, yep.

242
00:13:15.085 --> 00:13:17.240
[LAUGH] You're absolutely right.

243
00:13:17.240 --> 00:13:22.120
Ronnie takes it as, man, you're my project
manager, you've heard my request, and

244
00:13:22.120 --> 00:13:23.110
you're gonna make that happen.

245
00:13:23.110 --> 00:13:26.100
I heard it as right, Ronnie is correct,

246
00:13:26.100 --> 00:13:30.160
that is a garbage machine [LAUGH] and
I hope he can work his way around it.

247
00:13:30.160 --> 00:13:35.730
I'm just agreeing with him,
not that I'm acquiescing to what he wants,

248
00:13:35.730 --> 00:13:37.940
which is a different machine
that's gonna work for him.

249
00:13:37.940 --> 00:13:38.820
Through change management,

250
00:13:38.820 --> 00:13:43.610
I can say I'm officially logging the fact
that Ronnie needs a new machine.

251
00:13:43.610 --> 00:13:45.250
It's going through official channels.

252
00:13:45.250 --> 00:13:48.470
There is no obscurity to it.

253
00:13:48.470 --> 00:13:50.900
Anything that is wrong about it,
Ronnie can look at and

254
00:13:50.900 --> 00:13:52.550
say, that's not what I mean.

255
00:13:52.550 --> 00:13:57.630
All the definitions and terms that
we need to come to an agreement on

256
00:13:57.630 --> 00:13:59.650
can be done before any
change actually gets made.

257
00:13:59.650 --> 00:14:04.150
And that's why we're really talking
about managing change management and

258
00:14:04.150 --> 00:14:08.290
not necessarily the processes themselves.

259
00:14:08.290 --> 00:14:09.320
That's exactly right.

260
00:14:09.320 --> 00:14:11.250
So, Ronnie, great illustration.

261
00:14:11.250 --> 00:14:13.340
I think you really nailed the point home,
and

262
00:14:13.340 --> 00:14:16.260
that takes us to some other cool
procedures that we might wanna do.

263
00:14:16.260 --> 00:14:17.080
>> It really does.

264
00:14:17.080 --> 00:14:20.070
When we start seeing this, right,
some of the changes might be easy.

265
00:14:20.070 --> 00:14:22.980
The very fact that the piece of machinery
that we mentioned really is a piece

266
00:14:22.980 --> 00:14:25.610
of junk, and everybody just agrees,
let's just go ahead and

267
00:14:25.610 --> 00:14:27.660
get this signed and let us get it done.

268
00:14:27.660 --> 00:14:28.760
But sometimes, though,

269
00:14:28.760 --> 00:14:33.670
those decisions are not as easy as we
think that they are actually going to be.

270
00:14:33.670 --> 00:14:37.710
So, the reason why that might be,
right, is just like everything else.

271
00:14:37.710 --> 00:14:43.210
And we've learned this in IT,
that regardless of how old something gets,

272
00:14:43.210 --> 00:14:46.270
if it's functional and
nobody is complaining about it,

273
00:14:46.270 --> 00:14:49.850
it's really hard to decommission
somethings at times, okay?

274
00:14:49.850 --> 00:14:53.870
And that means that regardless, right,
of whether anybody's actually using it or

275
00:14:53.870 --> 00:14:56.410
not, when you ask somebody
if anybody needs it, what,

276
00:14:56.410 --> 00:14:57.700
essentially, ends up happening?

277
00:14:57.700 --> 00:14:58.650
You better believe it.

278
00:14:58.650 --> 00:14:59.350
I need it.

279
00:14:59.350 --> 00:15:01.172
And I remember this
happening to me one time.

280
00:15:01.172 --> 00:15:06.710
I had actually set up some infrastructure
in Alabama a few years ago.

281
00:15:06.710 --> 00:15:11.370
And so, I went at there to try and kinda
move everything to these servers and stuff

282
00:15:11.370 --> 00:15:16.110
like that and there was one particular
server that was still running on the rack.

283
00:15:16.110 --> 00:15:18.250
And I said, what is this machine for?

284
00:15:18.250 --> 00:15:20.200
And they told me what it was for.

285
00:15:20.200 --> 00:15:23.280
And then, I said, all right, so
is everybody still using it?

286
00:15:23.280 --> 00:15:26.700
Said no, there's only one
person that's still using it.

287
00:15:26.700 --> 00:15:30.930
And so, I went to them and I said,
how often do you use this?

288
00:15:30.930 --> 00:15:33.760
I don't use it very often,
but I do need it, okay?

289
00:15:33.760 --> 00:15:36.030
I absolutely, 100% need it.

290
00:15:36.030 --> 00:15:38.630
And so, at that point,
we're not changing, right?

291
00:15:38.630 --> 00:15:40.320
We're leaving the thing
the way that it needs to be.

292
00:15:40.320 --> 00:15:42.720
But we really need to
move off that system.

293
00:15:42.720 --> 00:15:43.810
So, what did I do?

294
00:15:43.810 --> 00:15:46.150
I wanted to see how often you use it,
I simply turned it off.

295
00:15:46.150 --> 00:15:47.250
I probably shouldn't have.

296
00:15:47.250 --> 00:15:48.560
But I simply turned it off for
the remainder of that week.

297
00:15:48.560 --> 00:15:50.047
>> Bold, my friend.

298
00:15:50.047 --> 00:15:50.731
Bold move.

299
00:15:50.731 --> 00:15:52.847
>> It was a bold move cuz I thought,
well if he says it,

300
00:15:52.847 --> 00:15:55.776
he can't get access to that and
they all turn it back on and I'll know.

301
00:15:55.776 --> 00:16:00.731
But the whole week I was there trying to
make all the other changes Never once

302
00:16:00.731 --> 00:16:01.999
did he request it.

303
00:16:01.999 --> 00:16:03.762
And as far as I know, he never did.

304
00:16:03.762 --> 00:16:05.630
He never requested it turned back on.

305
00:16:05.630 --> 00:16:08.030
So he just wanted to know it was there.

306
00:16:08.030 --> 00:16:11.440
Sometimes you are going
to get request like that,

307
00:16:11.440 --> 00:16:14.250
where somebody will stand against it,
okay, no matter what.

308
00:16:14.250 --> 00:16:16.070
Well now, what do you have?

309
00:16:16.070 --> 00:16:20.480
You now have a change and you now have
a counter to somebody says, no way,

310
00:16:20.480 --> 00:16:22.280
we don't need to implement that change.

311
00:16:22.280 --> 00:16:24.530
Well, what do you do, okay?

312
00:16:24.530 --> 00:16:26.780
How do you manage that process, okay?

313
00:16:26.780 --> 00:16:31.790
Well, if we don't manage it what it comes
down to is Dan's work versus mine, okay?

314
00:16:31.790 --> 00:16:34.680
I justify though, we need to modernize.

315
00:16:34.680 --> 00:16:36.820
You haven't touched that
machine in two years.

316
00:16:36.820 --> 00:16:41.130
Daniel can come back and go, but I know
the information that's on that machine

317
00:16:41.130 --> 00:16:44.880
is so valuable to your organization,
we need to keep it up and running.

318
00:16:44.880 --> 00:16:49.730
And so now here you are, you wanting
to move forward with your project and

319
00:16:49.730 --> 00:16:53.020
he’s saying, no,
this is really important to me.

320
00:16:53.020 --> 00:16:55.680
And now it’s a he said, he said situation.

321
00:16:55.680 --> 00:16:56.840
Well, what do you do?

322
00:16:56.840 --> 00:16:59.300
How do you manage that process and change?

323
00:16:59.300 --> 00:17:01.050
Well, you can’t if it’s just that.

324
00:17:01.050 --> 00:17:04.677
If it comes down to an argument between
me and him, we could flip for it and

325
00:17:04.677 --> 00:17:06.235
it would come out just as good.

326
00:17:06.235 --> 00:17:07.346
As somebody trying to go,

327
00:17:07.346 --> 00:17:10.581
well Daniel's argument is actually
a little bit stronger than Ronnie's.

328
00:17:10.581 --> 00:17:13.667
That would be just as fair,
just flipping for it instead.

329
00:17:13.667 --> 00:17:16.663
But in change management though,
if you want to manage this,

330
00:17:16.663 --> 00:17:19.300
what you do instead is
our second point here.

331
00:17:19.300 --> 00:17:22.640
Which is you want to perform
what we call an impact analysis.

332
00:17:22.640 --> 00:17:26.640
Now, in the way that I performed
an impact analysis, it was simple, right?

333
00:17:26.640 --> 00:17:30.650
I turned off the machine to see whether or
not it would actually impact anybody.

334
00:17:30.650 --> 00:17:32.221
[LAUGH]
>> It was a very effective impact

335
00:17:32.221 --> 00:17:33.552
analysis, though, wasn't it Ronnie?

336
00:17:33.552 --> 00:17:38.420
>> It was incredibly effective, that let
me know that that machine could be off.

337
00:17:38.420 --> 00:17:40.470
But the problem is,
the way that I did it right,

338
00:17:40.470 --> 00:17:43.030
cuz I had no real authorization to do so.

339
00:17:43.030 --> 00:17:46.260
I simply just wanted to
see what would happen.

340
00:17:46.260 --> 00:17:49.770
So normally when we talk about
the idea of impact analysis here,

341
00:17:49.770 --> 00:17:54.125
what we wanna do is when changes like
that happen, right, is that we wanna see,

342
00:17:54.125 --> 00:17:57.895
we wanna actually be able to know by
doing a little bit more research,

343
00:17:57.895 --> 00:18:02.445
by taking a little bit more time to gather
the additional information that we need,

344
00:18:02.445 --> 00:18:05.191
to present that change management board,
okay?

345
00:18:05.191 --> 00:18:07.559
Now we're not doing this to
disprove Daniel's point, okay.

346
00:18:07.559 --> 00:18:11.945

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie evaluate the impact of potential changes to triple constraints (time/cost/scope). They begin by re-visiting the project phases of execution and monitoring as well as the triple constraints. They also introduce you to the 3 project killers, inadequate planning, poor risk planning, and lack of change process. Finally they use scenarios to explain how deviations in any one area of the triple constraints will affect the others.
episodes.title: Evaluate Triple Contraint Changes

00:20:19.690 --> 00:20:20.600
that's a great change.

355
00:20:20.600 --> 00:20:23.200
That's something that needs to be done,
let's go ahead and do it.

356
00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:26.920
Even with some of the impact analysis
here, they may not understand what it

00:20:26.920 --> 00:20:31.380
really does to the overall project
to self in terms of cost okay, and

00:20:31.380 --> 00:20:33.110
what it does to the schedule.

359
00:20:33.110 --> 00:20:36.640
So sometimes the idea of
improving on the overall project,

360
00:20:36.640 --> 00:20:38.890
they don't take that into consideration.

361
00:20:38.890 --> 00:20:42.740
Well if you're gonna add in more
additional requirements then to the scope

00:20:42.740 --> 00:20:43.920
of the project then,

363
00:20:43.920 --> 00:20:47.980
you gotta realize that your schedule is

00:20:47.980 --> 00:20:51.150
Now, if it actually gets extended

365
00:20:51.150 --> 00:20:56.600
right, well, that's fine, as long as

366
00:20:56.600 --> 00:20:59.940
But what you're gonna also end

as you are actually with the current

what if you're ready to release

00:21:11.570 --> 00:21:15.830
They could actually end up renegotiating

00:21:15.830 --> 00:21:19.530

00:21:19.530 --> 00:21:23.780
Also, if you're calling them back

00:21:23.780 --> 00:21:27.290
what if they tell you that they

Now you also have to deal with
the idea of date constraints,

00:21:30.320 --> 00:21:34.690
too, to know where you're actually

376
00:21:34.690 --> 00:21:37.850
The other thing, again,
is that idea of cost.

377
00:21:37.850 --> 00:21:41.760
If you try and say look, we can still
do this, we just need more people, or

00:21:41.760 --> 00:21:45.520

those costs are gonna rise for

00:21:45.520 --> 00:21:49.510
you on the entire schedule itself,
on the entire project itself.

380
00:21:49.510 --> 00:21:52.790
And that means that you do actually
have to account for that, too.

381
00:21:52.790 --> 00:21:56.570
So, in any factor that we've
taken a look at this, right,

382
00:21:56.570 --> 00:22:01.140
you do actually have to think out what is

383
00:22:01.140 --> 00:22:05.810
you as a project manager, realizing that,
how do you account for that situation?

384
00:22:05.810 --> 00:22:08.950
So that's what we've tried to lead
you through on these particular

00:22:08.950 --> 00:22:09.890

00:22:09.890 --> 00:22:12.280
We didn't get super in depth on them,

We just tried to show you that if you

And you as a project

If you go,
I don't have a clue what are the facts.

Then you're not actually following

00:22:33.080 --> 00:22:34.240
project management.

If you had an impact to your schedule,

your costs and your scope.

00:22:39.690 --> 00:22:40.870
It's just going to.

00:22:40.870 --> 00:22:44.260
What impacts your costs is gonna affect
your what, your schedule, and your scope.

00:22:44.260 --> 00:22:45.860
If it impacts your scope time.

399
00:22:45.860 --> 00:22:50.970
I know there's a schedule,
as well as the idea of your cost.

400
00:22:50.970 --> 00:22:54.480
So just kind of realize that
that's the key behind this, and

00:22:54.480 --> 00:22:56.330
it's nothing that we
haven't reviewed before.

00:22:56.330 --> 00:22:58.390
This time,
we just added in some scenarios to try and

404

>> Yeah, and Ronnie,

it's funny that it seems it impacts

Negatively.

>> I can't think of any scenario in which

it would be a positive impact

>> Yeah, there's sometimes it can be.

00:23:17.170 --> 00:23:22.140
But that's where you have to actually

00:23:22.140 --> 00:23:24.470
Cuz sometimes let's say
that you go all right,

I'm glad that it impacts my time let's
that what I end up doing here is we affect

the overall project cost itself, and

And what does somebody do?

They double up on the work.

And all of the sudden they double up

3 days extra.

And you say wow that's cool.

But, what did they compromise to do that.

It could be the quality,
that's the problem, right,

Or, they just said, that's good enough,

So, they're, it's okay.

It's a little bit under what my quality

And so, even though there are some

the money is the way that you

If you, actually, plan out everything in

55, or $5,500 to complete this work

Well, why?

It wasn't just the fact

Until you actually look

That whole process might now have to be,

You know, rerun again, and so,

So, [LAUGH] you will,

And in the end though, sometimes you

But at least 90% of the project got done,

if not, you can actually mark that as

So yeah, when it comes out to
at least these, when we actually

choose to follow one over the other, we're

even though the immediate results

When you do an analysis you'll find out

you, once you actually look at

It's like, yes, we did that,

We really didn't actually produce

>> Yeah, every now and

Things happen,

You are saving money at that point Don,

Usually, just like Ronnie said,

>> And now you're in front of

>> [LAUGH]
>> So

you do need to stick to the constraints,

Ronnie, is there anything

throughout are particularly planning and
then in the pre-project stages.

There's really not a lot here, but for

you as a project manager though

And that's the key, go over more scenarios

this, know what those are and try and

How would that actually end up?

00:27:24.290 --> 00:27:25.960
That's what makes you
a better project manager,

00:27:25.960 --> 00:27:27.600
is to take a look at these things.

494
00:27:27.600 --> 00:27:30.720
You get thrown a curve ball at it,
let's go, okay, I need to make sure I take

00:27:30.720 --> 00:27:34.590
care of these areas and then get us back

496
00:27:34.590 --> 00:27:35.180
>> Awesome stuff.

497
00:27:35.180 --> 00:27:35.680
Well thank you so

00:27:35.680 --> 00:27:39.300
much Ronnie for dropping by, and

00:27:39.300 --> 00:27:41.890
When we start messing around with th
one of these three different triple

00:27:42.910 --> 00:27:46.510
That being said hopefully you guys had

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to use your risk management plan to determine an appropriate response to potential risk and opportunity events. They demonstrate using both qualitative and quantitative risk analysis to identify risks and opportunities, then evaluate risk response plans for both.
episodes.title: Use Risk Mangement

[MUSIC]

All right, greetings everyone, and welcome

I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,

Joining us back in the studio again

Let's now listen to our good friend,

What we're doing today is we're gonna take

of course the goal and the idea is

It's easy to actually take

it as we're executing, as we're actually

What do we do when we are actually

And then of course, how do we actually

So, when we take a look at that,

why we actually need to use them as well.

And then we gonna talk about the

opportunities as well.

00:01:21.750 --> 00:01:23.604
So, let's go ahead and

There are several processes that we can

So I went ahead and
created on of my simple diagrams here.

29
00:01:37.067 --> 00:01:40.154
Some of the things that we need
to make sure that we do hit and

00:01:41.549 --> 00:01:45.973
The first thing that we want to
make sure that we do is to properly

Now, this is in the same process that

not really about the idea that risks and

00:02:06.008 --> 00:02:08.900
And how do we know that we need

00:02:08.900 --> 00:02:10.880

And it talks about that

okay, this idea of a formal way to,

And in our project planning,

we took at look at the use

Let me show you an example here

And we'll bring that one up to

00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:39.610
So, this is an ad hoc

And I didn't actually create
this in the term of a form.

00:02:41.910 --> 00:02:44.680
But you can actually use something
like this or maybe even some type of

00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:48.490
a spreadsheet program to help you
fill this out a little bit more.

50
00:02:48.490 --> 00:02:51.500
So what you might have over here on
the left-hand side of course is the idea

51
00:02:51.500 --> 00:02:52.360

00:02:52.360 --> 00:02:54.350
And then you can even
add in opportunities, so

00:02:56.160 --> 00:03:01.170
And I'll call this one Opp C and

Now, what is the difference?

56

Well, a risk normally is something that

58

An opportunity though, is something

So a lot of times when we talk about

00:03:24.550 --> 00:03:26.300

And here in CompTlA we're gonna

The idea of the risk register for us is

I'm not saying it can't happen but

289
00:16:52.583 --> 00:16:55.020
we've got our project team ready to go,
we're fine.

290
00:16:55.020 --> 00:16:58.569
If I'm now working though on
a bridge project, let's say,

291
00:16:58.569 --> 00:17:00.378
over in the Asian Pacific Rim,

292
00:17:00.378 --> 00:17:05.123
well then I have to worry about typhoons,
and fog, and tidal waves, and [LAUGH].

293
00:17:05.123 --> 00:17:08.279
You have to actually pay a little bit
more attention to and try and be more

294
00:17:08.279 --> 00:17:11.820
quantitative about it cuz that will
interrupt your flow and your schedule.

295
00:17:11.820 --> 00:17:13.110
>> Yeah, these things happen.

296
00:17:13.110 --> 00:17:17.420
And, that really brings up our great next
point which is, now that we've identified

297
00:17:17.420 --> 00:17:21.900
what the risks might be and we've used
either a quantitative or a qualitative

298
00:17:21.900 --> 00:17:26.050
analysis to figure that out, now what do
we do when something actually occurs?

299
00:17:26.050 --> 00:17:30.130
One of these risks have come to light,
it is a reality we've got to deal with it.

300
00:17:30.130 --> 00:17:31.390
How do we deal with it Ronnie?

301
00:17:31.390 --> 00:17:32.970
>> When we start taking a look at that,
right?

302
00:17:32.970 --> 00:17:34.070
You have to actually determine,

303
00:17:34.070 --> 00:17:38.950
first of all whether that's what we call
a threat or the idea of an opportunity.

304
00:17:38.950 --> 00:17:41.540
So I went ahead and tried to
balance these things out for us, so

305
00:17:41.540 --> 00:17:44.010
that we can see what we're talking about.

306
00:17:44.010 --> 00:17:47.710
Now normally when we start taking about
the threat, we normally use the term risk,

307
00:17:47.710 --> 00:17:50.510
when we take a look at the idea
of opportunities, we normally use

308
00:17:50.510 --> 00:17:55.400
the term opportunities, or we use positive
risk is what we're talking about as well.

309
00:17:55.400 --> 00:17:56.970
So that's the first thing
you have to determine.

310
00:17:56.970 --> 00:18:00.050
Now if you're going like,
how the heck do we determine that?

311
00:18:00.050 --> 00:18:03.470
Well you can come back here and
do the same thing, right?

312
00:18:03.470 --> 00:18:07.991
So along this line right in the middle,
right here in the number 1, right,

313
00:18:07.991 --> 00:18:11.860
if everything is a 1 and a 1 and
it slaps you right there in the center,

314
00:18:13.080 --> 00:18:17.550
well that's the only one that you really
have to worry about is right here, okay?

315
00:18:17.550 --> 00:18:20.160
So, right there,
that's actually kind of the midline.

316
00:18:20.160 --> 00:18:21.840
You can't tell whether it's a risk or

317
00:18:21.840 --> 00:18:25.030
whether it's a threat against your
project, and so what do you do?

318
00:18:25.030 --> 00:18:28.730
You plan for everything that
you possibly can plan for, but

319
00:18:28.730 --> 00:18:32.720
the very fact is the majority of these
will never follow exactly a 1 and a 1.

320
00:18:32.720 --> 00:18:37.260
Whether it's an opportunity or a threat
here, because what we're saying at that

321
00:18:37.260 --> 00:18:41.020
point, high probability, high impact,
we're essentially guaranteeing that it's

322
00:18:41.020 --> 00:18:45.400
gonna work, and whatever it is,
it's gonna impact our particular project.

323
00:18:45.400 --> 00:18:47.770
And if we have something
that certain about it,

324
00:18:47.770 --> 00:18:49.280
we should absolutely plan for it.

325
00:18:49.280 --> 00:18:51.580
If it's absolutely that certain,

326
00:18:51.580 --> 00:18:54.130
you definitely need to
make sure that you do so.

327
00:18:54.130 --> 00:18:56.822
So, being able to use
something like this then,

328
00:18:56.822 --> 00:19:01.690
will help you to be able to at least
determine whether it's a threat or

329
00:19:01.690 --> 00:19:06.260
an opportunity, and then from that point
you need to actually come up with some way

330
00:19:06.260 --> 00:19:12.540
of responding to the actual
risk that we have.

331
00:19:12.540 --> 00:19:15.380
Now when it comes down to it, there's
several ways that we can respond to it.

332
00:19:15.380 --> 00:19:17.350
We're gonna take a look at
our risk management plan and

333
00:19:17.350 --> 00:19:19.690
we'll talk about the idea
of responding to risk, and

334
00:19:19.690 --> 00:19:23.220
there's actually five different ways,
but they've kind of broken it down in

335
00:19:23.220 --> 00:19:27.790
the CompTIA here on the exam objectives,
I'll really only call out a few of them.

336
00:19:27.790 --> 00:19:30.710
If you're dealing with
an opportunity at this point,

337
00:19:30.710 --> 00:19:34.470
your risk response here is
actually one of three actions.

338
00:19:34.470 --> 00:19:37.290
Are you going to share this opportunity,
in other words,

339
00:19:37.290 --> 00:19:41.020
who are you willing to actually
bless with this other opportunity,

340
00:19:41.020 --> 00:19:43.580
that you want to bring them in on this?

341
00:19:43.580 --> 00:19:47.689
So, are you willing to spread
the joy on an opportunity like this?

342
00:19:47.689 --> 00:19:51.462
Or is it an opportunity that you
can simply exploit, in other words,

343
00:19:51.462 --> 00:19:53.023
use it to your advantage, or

344
00:19:53.023 --> 00:19:57.770
is it something that actually helps
enhance what it is that you're doing?

345
00:19:57.770 --> 00:19:59.930
So you've got to be able then,
at that point,

346
00:19:59.930 --> 00:20:03.810
to actually say, here's what I'd like
to do with this bigger opportunity,

347
00:20:03.810 --> 00:20:08.500
I'd like to use it as an enhancement,
or I'd like to share the opportunity, or

348
00:20:08.500 --> 00:20:13.230
I think I need to take advantage of what's
actually been presented to me in this way.

349
00:20:13.230 --> 00:20:15.880
And you come up with those particular
responses that you need that

350
00:20:15.880 --> 00:20:18.530
will allow you to gain
the advantage of that.

351
00:20:18.530 --> 00:20:20.540
And that way you can actually go ahead and
plan it out and

352
00:20:20.540 --> 00:20:22.120
say which one of these
three you're gonna do.

353
00:20:22.120 --> 00:20:27.020
The same thing then with the idea of
a threat to our project schedule,

354
00:20:27.020 --> 00:20:31.230
cost, or scope as well is that we
can avoid it, we can accept it, or

355
00:20:31.230 --> 00:20:33.870
we can try and mitigate it as well.

356
00:20:33.870 --> 00:20:36.110
There are a lot of things
we just want to avoid.

357
00:20:36.110 --> 00:20:38.884
Why, because mitigating takes time.

358
00:20:38.884 --> 00:20:43.563
And even though mitigating is actually
the permanent solution to most threats,

359
00:20:43.563 --> 00:20:48.100
well can you afford to take the time
to actually mitigate it right then?

360
00:20:48.100 --> 00:20:51.360
Especially if it demands that
you stop your project progress,

361
00:20:51.360 --> 00:20:53.030
you may not be able to.

362
00:20:53.030 --> 00:20:57.300
Avoidance though, you might actually
be able to hold it back for a while and

363
00:20:57.300 --> 00:21:00.760
continue on your progress until there
is a point that you can stop and go,

364
00:21:00.760 --> 00:21:02.740
hey let me deal with it now.

365
00:21:02.740 --> 00:21:05.230
Sometimes though,
you don't have that opportunity, so

366
00:21:05.230 --> 00:21:09.350
you're either gonna accept that, and
you're gonna pay for it in some way or

367
00:21:09.350 --> 00:21:12.870
you are gonna take the time
to mitigate it as well, okay?

368
00:21:12.870 --> 00:21:17.470
So those are really our responses
that we can have to our

369
00:21:17.470 --> 00:21:21.020
project actually being at risk as well,
okay?

370
00:21:21.020 --> 00:21:22.260
So there are a couple of other ones,

371
00:21:22.260 --> 00:21:25.140
remember you make sure you check
out the previous episodes.

372
00:21:25.140 --> 00:21:27.430
We don't wanna go through
the entire process again, but

373
00:21:27.430 --> 00:21:30.620
there are at least two others that you
can actually deal with at that point.

374
00:21:30.620 --> 00:21:33.940
But just kind of realize that
responding to the risk overall, okay,

375
00:21:33.940 --> 00:21:37.260
is what we wanna have, so
if we can identify the risk,

376
00:21:37.260 --> 00:21:41.970
if we can take time to analyze them and
their impact to our overall project,

377
00:21:41.970 --> 00:21:47.350
if we have a response strategy in hand,
that actually is how you begin to manage

378
00:21:47.350 --> 00:21:50.100
the risk that you end up
facing on your project.

379
00:21:50.100 --> 00:21:53.250
>> Very nice, now it's obviously
it's a very important thing,

380
00:21:53.250 --> 00:21:57.411
risk is going to happen, risk is out there
it's a part of every single project, but

381
00:21:57.411 --> 00:22:00.680
usually so are opportunities as well,
so you gotta take a look and

382
00:22:00.680 --> 00:22:02.476
be on the look out for those things.

383
00:22:02.476 --> 00:22:06.072
Use the different quantitative and
qualitative analysis that we can

384
00:22:06.072 --> 00:22:10.650
use to try to figure out what are those
risks and what are those opportunities?

385
00:22:10.650 --> 00:22:12.810
And Ronnie you gave us
some great tools and

386
00:22:12.810 --> 00:22:15.272
some great insight on
how to do that today.

387
00:22:15.272 --> 00:22:16.980
Anything else that you wanna
cover in this episode?

388
00:22:16.980 --> 00:22:19.770
>> There's just a couple of other
things that I wanna make sure that

389
00:22:19.770 --> 00:22:22.010
we also point out too that
will really help you out.

390
00:22:22.010 --> 00:22:24.320
Now even though these
are the key points by far,

391
00:22:24.320 --> 00:22:28.350
right, you being a project manager though,
you need to actually realize

392
00:22:28.350 --> 00:22:32.410
that there’re sometimes where your
project actually registers something.

393
00:22:32.410 --> 00:22:35.760
You’re actually now in the groove
of managing everything and

394
00:22:35.760 --> 00:22:38.920
now that you've actually got a good
risk response strategy in hand,

395
00:22:38.920 --> 00:22:42.545
you may find out that you start
seeing symptoms of risk occurring.

396
00:22:42.545 --> 00:22:46.280
It's what we call the idea
of risk triggers, right?

397
00:22:46.280 --> 00:22:48.980
That you might actually realize
that something has actually

398
00:22:48.980 --> 00:22:49.960
happened previously,

399
00:22:49.960 --> 00:22:55.170
let's say on a completed work package,
that ended up becoming a risk for you.

400
00:22:55.170 --> 00:22:57.980
And now as you start progressing
through your project,

401
00:22:57.980 --> 00:23:01.230
you may start to see the same
thing happening again.

402
00:23:01.230 --> 00:23:03.580
So when you start looking at
that you're actually looking for

403
00:23:03.580 --> 00:23:05.470
essentially signs, right?

404
00:23:05.470 --> 00:23:09.530
Little things that indicate that this
looks like it's gonna happen again.

405
00:23:09.530 --> 00:23:14.420
So this can be as subjective
as you want it to be.

406
00:23:14.420 --> 00:23:17.460
It could be objective as well especially
if you're right there on top of

407
00:23:17.460 --> 00:23:19.240
the risk too.

408
00:23:19.240 --> 00:23:22.720
So, you gotta, actually, just make sure
that you're paying attention there,

409
00:23:22.720 --> 00:23:26.780
in terms of different triggers that
may also happen as well, okay?

410
00:23:26.780 --> 00:23:30.080
The other thing that you've got to
remember is that, even though you might

411
00:23:30.080 --> 00:23:35.850
deal with one risk,
you may find that that risk reoccurs,

412
00:23:35.850 --> 00:23:40.460
or has what we call secondary risks
that actually occur from it, so

413
00:23:40.460 --> 00:23:42.830
in other words,
it's the idea of putting out fires.

414
00:23:42.830 --> 00:23:44.630
You think you've dealt with the issue?

415
00:23:44.630 --> 00:23:47.687
But if you didn't, if you actually
did not deal with the issue,

416
00:23:47.687 --> 00:23:49.839
if you did not actually
confront the issue and

417
00:23:49.839 --> 00:23:53.066
you used one of those different
strategies to deal with it instead,

418
00:23:53.066 --> 00:23:57.088
whether it's avoidance or whether it's
acceptance or something, you may find out

419
00:23:57.088 --> 00:24:00.629
that doing something like that actually
caused another issue to come up.

420
00:24:00.629 --> 00:24:03.850
So you need to be a little bit more
comprehensive in what you're looking

421
00:24:03.850 --> 00:24:05.299
around doing, because if not,

422
00:24:05.299 --> 00:24:09.380
you're gonna end up seeing that
secondary risk end up happening as well.

423
00:24:09.380 --> 00:24:13.050
You may also find out that
the result of dealing and

424
00:24:13.050 --> 00:24:17.520
mitigating that risk was satisfactory for
you as a project manager, but

425
00:24:17.520 --> 00:24:21.670
may have actually turned a sour stomach
for somebody else on your project, okay.

426
00:24:21.670 --> 00:24:26.490
Which now means you have to deal with some
human resources types of issues you may

427
00:24:26.490 --> 00:24:30.170
have to do with some team building,
where you have to slow down things.

428
00:24:30.170 --> 00:24:32.930
So you can never realize what the overall

429
00:24:32.930 --> 00:24:36.310
result is until you
take a moment to do so.

430
00:24:36.310 --> 00:24:38.598
Just saying okay,
it's done, it's complete,

431
00:24:38.598 --> 00:24:40.071
we can move on with our work now.

432
00:24:40.071 --> 00:24:44.692
Yes, in reality that's all it should take,
but remember because you're dealing with

433
00:24:44.692 --> 00:24:49.126
people who have feelings and personalities
and stuff, it means you also have to deal

434
00:24:49.126 --> 00:24:53.446
with the risk that hey, your answer may
not have ever been satisfactory for them.

435
00:24:53.446 --> 00:24:56.029
And that can cause a big
slowdown on your project as well.

436
00:24:56.029 --> 00:24:56.766
>> Ronnie, what are these feeling
of which you were talking about?

437
00:24:56.766 --> 00:24:59.447
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

438
00:24:59.447 --> 00:25:03.394
>> You're right though, and it's the human
factor, is a really big deal when it comes

439
00:25:03.394 --> 00:25:06.451
to risk, because when you put
people at risk for certain things,

440
00:25:06.451 --> 00:25:10.080
they tend to get emotional about it,
especially if those risks come to pass.

441
00:25:10.080 --> 00:25:11.500
So you gotta be on the ball,

442
00:25:11.500 --> 00:25:14.600
you gotta be prepared for
something that might happen that way.

443
00:25:14.600 --> 00:25:17.600
And I might have to take Ronnie of to
the side and say, how are you doing?

444
00:25:17.600 --> 00:25:20.540
Give him a pat on the back, is there
anything we can do to make you feel better

445
00:25:20.540 --> 00:25:24.420
about going through that
thing that was risky for us?

446
00:25:24.420 --> 00:25:27.112
>> And there's a couple of
other things too, right.

447
00:25:27.112 --> 00:25:30.049
The very fact is that once
you actually go through and

448
00:25:30.049 --> 00:25:34.521
you start to have to handle the risk and
deal with them using the strategies, you

449
00:25:34.521 --> 00:25:39.480
may now have to come back and reexamine
what your original assumption was.

450
00:25:39.480 --> 00:25:43.160
Your original assumption may have been
that hey, this is what caused that risk.

451
00:25:43.160 --> 00:25:46.290
Or this is why we ran into this,
but if it's coming about again and

452
00:25:46.290 --> 00:25:48.000
you said, we just solved that problem.

453
00:25:48.000 --> 00:25:49.570
Why is it coming back again?

454
00:25:49.570 --> 00:25:50.600
You may have to go back and

455
00:25:50.600 --> 00:25:56.050
deal again with your particular assumption
about what actually happened at risk.

456
00:25:56.050 --> 00:25:57.540
But then on the management side.

457
00:25:57.540 --> 00:26:01.250
So this is all stuff that you just
have to go, I need to examine.

458
00:26:01.250 --> 00:26:03.190
I need to realize what's going on.

459
00:26:03.190 --> 00:26:06.090
But even on the management side,
you need to make sure that

460
00:26:06.090 --> 00:26:09.310
you're still documenting, you're
still keeping up on all these forms,

461
00:26:09.310 --> 00:26:12.150
you're still doing all the stuff
that needs to be done.

462
00:26:12.150 --> 00:26:14.936
So that way you have it actually listed
there, and that you can go back and

463
00:26:14.936 --> 00:26:16.320
review it when possible.

464
00:26:16.320 --> 00:26:20.010
So you want to make sure that you
are actually setting everything up so

465
00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:22.920
that you can back and
actually deal with all of those too.

466
00:26:22.920 --> 00:26:26.390
Because if not, you will actually
forget a risk that happened and

467
00:26:26.390 --> 00:26:28.480
you'll be surprised it came up again.

468
00:26:28.480 --> 00:26:31.920
You won't actually have anybody that will
be able to tell you when it happened,

469
00:26:31.920 --> 00:26:34.010
what happened, so it's also up to you.

470
00:26:34.010 --> 00:26:38.001
So that way you have that risk register,
you have everything else in hand as far as

471
00:26:38.001 --> 00:26:41.237
documentation, and this way you
manage all those risks better.

472
00:26:41.237 --> 00:26:44.350
>> That's right, and
don't forget if a risk does occur,

473
00:26:44.350 --> 00:26:46.480
now it's always a bad thing, right?

474
00:26:46.480 --> 00:26:48.710
You've taken the risk,
the worst doesn't happen,

475
00:26:48.710 --> 00:26:52.760
the bottom fell out of the world and
then the sky is falling.

476
00:26:52.760 --> 00:26:53.690
What are you gonna do?

477
00:26:53.690 --> 00:26:55.321
Well, you have contingencies in place.

478
00:26:55.321 --> 00:26:57.321
You should anyway, hopefully you do.

479
00:26:57.321 --> 00:27:01.748
And you probably have a risk plan,
like what do we do when that risk happens,

480
00:27:01.748 --> 00:27:03.540
if that risk happens?

481
00:27:03.540 --> 00:27:04.880
Now you get to evaluate those, right?

482
00:27:04.880 --> 00:27:08.120
You get to see there's a bit of a silver
lining to just about every one of

483
00:27:08.120 --> 00:27:09.140
these storm clouds.

484
00:27:09.140 --> 00:27:11.362
You can see did those things work, right?

485
00:27:11.362 --> 00:27:14.946
Were we effective and
do we need to reevaluate these things?

486
00:27:14.946 --> 00:27:16.870
>> That's definitely a big part of it,
right?

487
00:27:16.870 --> 00:27:20.590
Cuz every risk is actually
bring that aspect to you.

488
00:27:20.590 --> 00:27:22.958
And you do need to take the time to do so.

489
00:27:22.958 --> 00:27:24.490
Just saying, okay, we've dealt with it and

490
00:27:24.490 --> 00:27:28.230
we need to move on, that's probably the
easiest way to get you back on schedule,

491
00:27:28.230 --> 00:27:31.770
but it's also the easiest way to
re-introduce more risk into your project.

492
00:27:31.770 --> 00:27:34.730
So take the time to see if how
you dealt with it was effective,

493
00:27:34.730 --> 00:27:37.300
take the time to actually update
all the things that you need to,

494
00:27:37.300 --> 00:27:40.750
and that will give you more and
more information, more and

495
00:27:40.750 --> 00:27:45.080
more ammo if you want to, to deal with
it again at a later date if you have to.

496
00:27:45.080 --> 00:27:48.010
>> Well Ronnie, I know it was risky
stepping into the studio today to talk

497
00:27:48.010 --> 00:27:49.010
about risk management.

498
00:27:49.010 --> 00:27:52.470
But we do appreciate it and your insights
and all that you've given us, so

499
00:27:52.470 --> 00:27:53.400
that we are better prepared for

500
00:27:53.400 --> 00:27:56.570
our projects Project+, and
our projects that we're working on.

501
00:27:56.570 --> 00:27:57.960
Thanks again for stopping by Ronnie.

502
00:27:57.960 --> 00:27:59.612
We're gonna go ahead and close the show.

503
00:27:59.612 --> 00:28:01.960
Hopefully you guys enjoyed it and
got a lot out of it.

504
00:28:01.960 --> 00:28:04.640
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

505
00:28:04.640 --> 00:28:05.330
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

506
00:28:05.330 --> 00:28:08.075
>> And we'll see you next time.

507

00:24:24.880 --> 00:24:28.920
more than likely the duration of that
task became much easier and much quicker.

448
00:24:28.920 --> 00:24:31.930
>> And you can see in the scenario where
maybe Ronnie you're doing updates right?

00:24:31.930 --> 00:24:34.890
Some of you guys have done updates,
you know what it's like,

450
00:24:34.890 --> 00:24:39.320
you're just waiting forever,
just downloading, can't speed it up.

451
00:24:39.320 --> 00:24:41.520
You can slow it down for sure,
but you can't speed it up.

452
00:24:41.520 --> 00:24:45.947
And if he was to put Dan and
I into updating a server right,

453
00:24:45.947 --> 00:24:50.480
well adding two people to one button
click when you're waiting three hours for

00:24:50.480 --> 00:24:52.410
an update,
that's not gonna speed anything up,

455
00:24:52.410 --> 00:24:55.120
and most likely in can be
a waste of resources too.

456
00:24:55.120 --> 00:24:56.470
>> It really can.

457
00:24:56.470 --> 00:24:58.400
Now we're going to talk about
something that doesn't seem like it

00:24:58.400 --> 00:25:00.560
actually shortens anything up, but

00:25:00.560 --> 00:25:04.920
it does help us to save in other
elements in our project too, and

00:25:04.920 --> 00:25:08.730
it also helps us to save a lot of headache

461
00:25:08.730 --> 00:25:11.280
Let's take a look at our
third scenario here, okay?

462
00:25:11.280 --> 00:25:16.680
In this particular scenario, your
project budget is very tight after some

00:25:16.680 --> 00:25:19.520
unforeseen expenses
early on in the project.

00:25:19.520 --> 00:25:20.260
You need to try and

00:25:20.260 --> 00:25:25.090
make sure you're not paying overtime
on any remaining work package.

00:25:25.090 --> 00:25:29.910
You're ahead of schedule, so
you do not mind losing a day or two.

00:25:29.910 --> 00:25:35.110
What technique can help you to make sure
that the work gets done without overtime?

468
00:25:35.110 --> 00:25:38.310
Now on this one, notice the elements
that we're talking about here.

00:25:38.310 --> 00:25:43.340
We're not talking about saving time
anymore, and we're not really even

00:25:43.340 --> 00:25:47.630
focusing in on the fact that our project's

that, so we're not worried about this

472
00:25:51.620 --> 00:25:54.880
What we're actually worried about

00:25:54.880 --> 00:25:56.730
is the cost, right?

474
00:25:56.730 --> 00:26:00.040
So when you're focusing in
on cost such as overtime,

00:26:00.040 --> 00:26:03.770
overtime can actually account for a lot of
what your budget can get ending up doing.

476
00:26:03.770 --> 00:26:06.290
And so what can you do there?

477
00:26:06.290 --> 00:26:08.130
There is something that we call delaying.

478
00:26:08.130 --> 00:26:13.550
Now inside of what we've also
covered before here in this area,

479
00:26:13.550 --> 00:26:16.900
we've talked about what we call the idea
of the critical path method and

00:26:16.900 --> 00:26:19.610
the critical chain method as well, okay?

481
00:26:19.610 --> 00:26:23.895
What we're saying is that we can actually
focus in on the path, the longest duration

00:26:23.895 --> 00:26:27.730
through our entire project, but that
doesn't take into account resources that

483
00:26:27.730 --> 00:26:31.940
need to be assigned here, and a lot of
times on resources they are limited,

484
00:26:31.940 --> 00:26:34.960
in other words they can only work so
many hours a day.

485
00:26:34.960 --> 00:26:38.940
So the only way that you get around that
is by paying things like overtime and

486
00:26:38.940 --> 00:26:41.500
that works as long as you have
all the money in the world.

487
00:26:41.500 --> 00:26:43.960
But notice that in our particular

00:26:43.960 --> 00:26:47.660
situation that we've given the scenario
is that we don't have that option.

489
00:26:47.660 --> 00:26:50.790
It's saying very tight,
we got to make sure no overtime happens.

490
00:26:50.790 --> 00:26:54.750
So, let's go ahead and take a look
at a couple of different elements.

491
00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:59.490
So, let's say here on the top,
on top of the dotted line here, here is

00:26:59.490 --> 00:27:03.440
the schedule for one of my resources and
I can say it's Wes if I wanted to.

493
00:27:03.440 --> 00:27:07.815
So, if Wes in these first three days
are assigned to all these task here,

494
00:27:07.815 --> 00:27:10.660
now we notice that Wes has
an eight hour work day, and

00:27:10.660 --> 00:27:12.620
that's what this red line
actually indicates here.

496
00:27:12.620 --> 00:27:15.880
A little bit of a small red line,
let me make it a little bit larger there.

497
00:27:15.880 --> 00:27:19.890
Okay, that red line actually indicates
the end of his 8 hour work day, but

498
00:27:19.890 --> 00:27:25.910
notice that task D and task F, they
essentially are saying that on Tuesday,

00:27:25.910 --> 00:27:29.580
Wes's looks like it's working about
10 hours a day, and let's say on

00:27:29.580 --> 00:27:32.720
Wednesday though, it looks like Wes is

501
00:27:32.720 --> 00:27:35.640
Pretty good overtime there, Wes-
>> That's right.

502
00:27:35.640 --> 00:27:37.550
>> That you're actually getting.

503
00:27:37.550 --> 00:27:41.890
It sounds great, except that if you
continue to do this on every single task,

00:27:41.890 --> 00:27:45.970
or on every single day that Wes has, after
a while he's gonna get tired of it, and

he's not gonna wanna do some of these
tasks, even if it's overtime, right?

00:27:49.900 --> 00:27:51.470
So, what can you do?

507
00:27:51.470 --> 00:27:55.390
If this were me and I was saying, look I
gotta actually get rid of this overtime,

00:27:55.390 --> 00:27:57.520
there's only really one
element that I can do and

00:27:57.520 --> 00:28:00.380
that's called delaying essentially, okay?

510
00:28:00.380 --> 00:28:03.250
Delaying though doesn't mean that
you're actually telling Wes to work

00:28:03.250 --> 00:28:04.760
any less, okay?

00:28:04.760 --> 00:28:07.680
The overall time factor
is actually still there.

00:28:07.680 --> 00:28:10.840
You add up all the time in these elements
here, they still have to be true for

00:28:10.840 --> 00:28:12.560
Wes regardless.

515
00:28:12.560 --> 00:28:15.550
So, now if you take a look
at the bottom here, after

00:28:15.550 --> 00:28:20.560
actually implementing some type of delay,
what we actually end up doing is this.

00:28:20.560 --> 00:28:24.400
Notice that task D was split over 2 days.

00:28:24.400 --> 00:28:28.010
So we worked Wes on Tuesday all

00:28:28.010 --> 00:28:33.710
then on Wednesday, we took task E and

00:28:33.710 --> 00:28:37.920
Then whatever he was supposed

00:28:37.920 --> 00:28:40.190

00:28:40.190 --> 00:28:43.020
So it actually did delay a little bit,

00:28:43.020 --> 00:28:47.934
So the overall duration that he had

00:28:47.934 --> 00:28:52.070
working his task as a resource and

00:28:52.070 --> 00:28:55.090
If you count up the same number of hours,

00:28:55.090 --> 00:28:59.690
you'll see it's actually the same

527
00:28:59.690 --> 00:29:03.900
But notice that it's actually the time

528
00:29:03.900 --> 00:29:08.330
and now that I have him not working

529
00:29:08.330 --> 00:29:12.620
the work that needs to be done, where
we've now leveled him as a resource and

00:29:12.620 --> 00:29:16.550
the only thing we've done here is

531
00:29:16.550 --> 00:29:19.880
Now that may work as long as he

00:29:19.880 --> 00:29:22.830
like that Thursday he was supposed

00:29:22.830 --> 00:29:27.640
even if he did, we would essentially take

00:29:27.640 --> 00:29:33.120
next available free day that he had, that

535
00:29:33.120 --> 00:29:34.900
So, it does allow us to do that.

536
00:29:34.900 --> 00:29:39.030
But that time limit or
that time added in can stretch out a lot

537
00:29:39.030 --> 00:29:44.010
further than we realize, so
in this particular scenario then,

538
00:29:44.010 --> 00:29:47.960
what you have to actually look out for is

539
00:29:47.960 --> 00:29:51.820
Delaying really does help us out

540
00:29:51.820 --> 00:29:56.760
Sometimes we do work with time constraints

541
00:29:56.760 --> 00:30:00.570
Let's say for an example that even though

00:30:00.570 --> 00:30:02.730
let's say on Thursday, we call them and

00:30:05.600 --> 00:30:08.940
Well, that means that even Thursday we
wouldn't actually be able to do that and

00:30:08.940 --> 00:30:12.730
we would essentially take that and then
move that over there to Friday instead,

00:30:12.730 --> 00:30:14.960
and that's what ended up happening.

547
00:30:14.960 --> 00:30:17.820
So these things can actually be

00:30:21.620 --> 00:30:25.970
in delay is essentially the next

00:30:25.970 --> 00:30:28.620
And even if it doesn't show

00:30:28.620 --> 00:30:33.710
it may show up where he was working

Daniel just didn't schedule

But you had originally said, no, Wes

00:30:42.400 --> 00:30:46.920
that you don't worry about it, well

00:30:46.920 --> 00:30:49.860
Thursday and Daniel goes, whoa,
wait a minute you can't do that.
