00:30:49.860 --> 00:30:53.960
And so now you have to actually
coordinate around that a little bit more.

557
00:30:53.960 --> 00:30:58.480
But all three of these plans, all three of
these ways that we can deal essentially

558
00:30:58.480 --> 00:31:02.600
with optimizing our schedule are some of
the concepts that we need to understand.

559
00:31:02.600 --> 00:31:05.610
If you're using a project

00:31:05.610 --> 00:31:09.690
well a lot of this will be taking care for

you do things like over-allocation

hey, this resource is actually
over-allocated at this point in time,

you may need to do some

00:31:20.460 --> 00:31:22.610
And it can automatically
take care of it for

565
00:31:22.610 --> 00:31:25.710
you if you actually choose to do that,
okay?

566
00:31:25.710 --> 00:31:29.930
But it's not gonna automatically do it cuz

00:31:29.930 --> 00:31:33.610
These are all decision that have to be

00:31:33.610 --> 00:31:37.970
that is another key, so make sure you

you're gonna realize that any one of
them will actually work so look for

00:31:41.170 --> 00:31:43.390
the elements that differentiate them.

If you do end up seeing a couple

00:31:45.593 --> 00:31:50.600
man that was just about identical to what

that there's something that's gonna set

00:31:54.470 --> 00:31:55.750
But if it doesn't, right?

575
00:31:55.750 --> 00:31:57.820
Either one of those answers
will probably work for

00:31:57.820 --> 00:32:00.810
you regardless of which

577
00:32:00.810 --> 00:32:03.710
So Wes, that's pretty much all
that I really have on the idea of

578
00:32:03.710 --> 00:32:04.830
resource leveling here.

579
00:32:04.830 --> 00:32:05.560
>> All right, very good.

580
00:32:05.560 --> 00:32:09.420
So in this episode, remember we've looked
at optimization through resource leveling.

581
00:32:09.420 --> 00:32:11.280
Remember the three types
that Ronnie showed you.

00:32:11.280 --> 00:32:14.190
We had fast tracking, crashing, and delay.

583
00:32:14.190 --> 00:32:16.260
Ronnie, thank you for
all that information,

584
00:32:16.260 --> 00:32:19.120
and thank you guys out there for watching,
it's great to have you guys here,

585
00:32:19.120 --> 00:32:21.270
but we're gonna go ahead and
wrap it up for this episode.

00:32:21.270 --> 00:32:23.820
So signing off for ITProTV, I'm Wes Bryan.

00:32:23.820 --> 00:32:24.750
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

00:32:24.750 --> 00:32:26.581
>> And we'll see you next time.

589
00:32:26.581 --> 00:32:34.120

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Ronnie explore the concepts of quality assurance. They talk about monitoring quality by establishing a baseline and comparing the baseline to actual process. They explain performance analysis and variance identification as well as change request generation and implementation.
episodes.title: Use Quality Assurance

Now, during our planning phase,

Now we have to make sure that as we are

But the overall goal, right, is so

our project here, something that

And the way that we do that,

process of things, we're not even

is we introduce what we call, and

The idea of quality assurance and

Well when we take a look at both those say

but they are actually different processes

So when we take a look at the realm and

And that's the idea of quality assurance,

When we talk about quality control, we are

So the assurance side is

50
00:02:54.650 --> 00:02:57.900
our project to where what we
are saying is, here’s how we know

that we're gonna produce the highest

52

And then the quality control is

00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:07.360

00:03:07.360 --> 00:03:09.240
the things that
are a little bit different.

55
00:03:09.240 --> 00:03:13.800
So we wanna go through essentially
five different steps that we can here,

56
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:17.950
to essentially assure quality assurance
is what we're taking a look at.

57
00:03:17.950 --> 00:03:22.010
At least on a high level overview during
our execution on our monitoring and

58
00:03:22.010 --> 00:03:23.310
controlling phase.

59
00:03:23.310 --> 00:03:26.230
And so when we talked about
the idea of planning it out,

00:03:26.230 --> 00:03:28.610
we talked about the management of it,
right?

61
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:31.390
What are some of the things
that we need to have in place.

00:03:31.390 --> 00:03:35.500
And now, when it starts here and
we're now in the midst of our project,

00:03:35.500 --> 00:03:40.140
we're now actually saying, is our quality

00:03:40.140 --> 00:03:41.770
What are we really looking at?

65
00:03:41.770 --> 00:03:44.970
What we're starting to look at
the very beginning in our first step

66
00:03:44.970 --> 00:03:48.910
of quality assurance is gonna be the idea
of taking a look at what we call

00:03:48.910 --> 00:03:51.260
work performance as what we want.

68
00:03:51.260 --> 00:03:53.400
So I went ahead and created a diagram, or

69
00:03:53.400 --> 00:03:57.340
kind of more than anything else here, a
list of some of the things that we need to

70
00:03:57.340 --> 00:04:02.400
ensure if we are gonna have some type
of high quality in our product and

71
00:04:02.400 --> 00:04:04.850
whatever we're doing for
our project here, okay?

72
00:04:04.850 --> 00:04:07.050
What we wanna do when we talk
about this idea of course,

73
00:04:07.050 --> 00:04:10.270
is monitor the overall work performance.

74
00:04:10.270 --> 00:04:14.840
Now remember that this actually does,
it is part of quality assurance.

75
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:18.640
If our work performance is poor,
the chances

They look at how to analyze data for quality control through comparitive analysis of baseline line reports. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to calculate an Earned Value Measurement(EVM) and interpret the results. They begin by explaining the EVM and defining the components therein. This includes values like Planned Value(PV), Actual Cost(AC), and Earned Value(EV). Then they describe how to work with the efficiency indicators, Cost Variance and Schedule Variance. Finally, they work through Cost Performance Index, Schedule Performance Index, and To Completion Performance Index(TCPI).
episodes.title: Use Earned Value Measurement

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie run through a few more value measurement calculations. Here they cover Estimate At Completion(EAC), Estimate To Completion (ETC), Variance At Completion(VAC), and Budget At Completion(BAC).
episodes.title: Use Earned Value Measurement Part 2

not we actually need to do more, or

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to effectively manage stakeholders through information distribution. They begin by looking at 4 methods to aid in this endeavor. These methods are: Managing Communications with stakeholders, Resolving Issues in a Timely Manner, Implementing Requested Changes, and Manage Stakeholders' Concerns Proactively. They finish up by explaining the most effective ways to run project meetings and send out periodic updates.
episodes.title: Manage Information Distribution

situations like that, because if it

269
00:13:26.830 --> 00:13:30.810
is a written statement of some sort
that you're actually dealing with.

270
00:13:30.810 --> 00:13:35.380
The very fact is you can now go,
all right here's the official plan,

271
00:13:35.380 --> 00:13:37.720
here's what needs to be communicated.

272
00:13:37.720 --> 00:13:41.960
Anybody who has any disagreement on it you
better come and see me about it now, okay.

273
00:13:41.960 --> 00:13:44.650
Now the other thing that you also wanna
deal with in terms of your stakeholders

274
00:13:44.650 --> 00:13:48.500
and senate expectations is how you
directly communicate with them.

275
00:13:48.500 --> 00:13:50.690
A lot of times, they are looking for
information and

276
00:13:50.690 --> 00:13:53.670
what you need to know is what
information they're looking for, and

277
00:13:53.670 --> 00:13:56.490
this means you being
willing to ask questions.

278
00:13:56.490 --> 00:13:59.740
I know that there's a lot of times where
there's an assumption that goes on.

279
00:13:59.740 --> 00:14:03.410
I just assume that these stakeholders
understand what's actually going on on

280
00:14:03.410 --> 00:14:07.010
the project, and then when they
ask me information, I'm like yeah.

281
00:14:07.010 --> 00:14:09.240
That just seems logical to me.

282
00:14:09.240 --> 00:14:11.100
It didn't seem logical to them.

283
00:14:11.100 --> 00:14:13.760
So, if you need to,
make sure you ask questions and

284
00:14:13.760 --> 00:14:16.710
say what information would
you like me to provide?

285
00:14:16.710 --> 00:14:19.730
And when you do that,
make sure you provide that information,

286
00:14:19.730 --> 00:14:22.810
not a ton of extraneous
details need to go into that.

287
00:14:22.810 --> 00:14:27.300
But, if they ask you a question, provide
a direct answer at that point as well.

288
00:14:27.300 --> 00:14:30.160
If this is supposed to be
a project status meeting update,

289
00:14:30.160 --> 00:14:32.320
make sure you actually
update about the status.

290
00:14:32.320 --> 00:14:33.170
It's very easy for

291
00:14:33.170 --> 00:14:36.880
project meetings to essentially denigrate
into, did you see the game last night?

292
00:14:36.880 --> 00:14:39.900
And I'm not saying that those aren't
great things to talk about, but

293
00:14:39.900 --> 00:14:43.650
the very fact is your time is valuable and
their time is valuable.

294
00:14:43.650 --> 00:14:45.750
Make sure you answer questions directly.

295
00:14:45.750 --> 00:14:48.920
Make sure you actually keep it on
point the way that you want to.

296
00:14:48.920 --> 00:14:52.190
And there's just some type of
regular type of meeting, right?

297
00:14:52.190 --> 00:14:54.170
Make sure you actually
keep it that way and

298
00:14:54.170 --> 00:14:55.680
keep to your boundaries
that you actually set.

299
00:14:55.680 --> 00:14:58.530
If it's a 30 minute meeting
make sure you do that as well.

300
00:14:58.530 --> 00:15:00.570
Don't sit there and
have a 30 minute meeting and then and

301
00:15:00.570 --> 00:15:03.260
hour and a half later you're
wondering why you're still there and

302
00:15:03.260 --> 00:15:04.950
anybody else is wondering
why they're still there.

303
00:15:04.950 --> 00:15:05.650
Okay?

304
00:15:05.650 --> 00:15:10.410
Also, my last point here in terms of
managing the communications here is do not

305
00:15:10.410 --> 00:15:15.540
emphasize or do not over emphasize what
doesn't need to be over emphasized.

306
00:15:15.540 --> 00:15:17.370
Don't make everything into an emergency.

307
00:15:17.370 --> 00:15:19.380
Don't make everything into
an urgency when it's not,

308
00:15:19.380 --> 00:15:24.010
when you are asking them to consider
something, give them some idea that,

309
00:15:24.010 --> 00:15:29.110
hey this is on this priority list here and
not up here.

310
00:15:29.110 --> 00:15:32.670
So it brings me back to a scene
in a movie on Apollo 13,

311
00:15:32.670 --> 00:15:35.640
is when somebody's actually
worried about this.

312
00:15:35.640 --> 00:15:39.829
And Captain says goes, look,
we're on step eight, and

313
00:15:39.829 --> 00:15:43.940
what you're talking about is step 5,042 or
whatever it is.

314
00:15:43.940 --> 00:15:47.770
And that actually shows you like
this guy's worried about 5, 042.

315
00:15:47.770 --> 00:15:51.736
Jack's saying, hey, let's worry about step
nine [LAUGH] is what we're talking about

316
00:15:51.736 --> 00:15:53.214
here and the same thing goes on.

317
00:15:53.214 --> 00:15:56.619
It's easy to bring up every single little
detail because you're not sure what

318
00:15:56.619 --> 00:15:57.764
you should communicate.

319
00:15:57.764 --> 00:16:01.494
But bring up the priorities, okay, and
then remember, don't treat everything as

320
00:16:01.494 --> 00:16:04.780
an emergency unless everything
you're telling them is an emergency.

321
00:16:04.780 --> 00:16:07.111
>> That's right, keep the main
thing the main thing as well.

322
00:16:07.111 --> 00:16:08.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> Don't get sidetracked.

323
00:16:08.910 --> 00:16:11.830
Stay on course and that's gonna help
the communication flow a whole lot better.

324
00:16:11.830 --> 00:16:14.150
And then everybody's gonna
be on the same page.

325
00:16:14.150 --> 00:16:14.840
Just like Ronnie said,

326
00:16:14.840 --> 00:16:19.630
a lot of times these meetings can
dissolve down into just a hang out.

327
00:16:19.630 --> 00:16:22.810
But what's the purpose of them
if information isn't flowing and

328
00:16:22.810 --> 00:16:25.060
being transmitted from
one person to the other?

329
00:16:25.060 --> 00:16:27.490
So we gotta stay on point
when it comes to that stuff.

330
00:16:27.490 --> 00:16:31.130
>> Yeah, the other thing that we also need
to do here as we're trying to manage our

331
00:16:31.130 --> 00:16:32.676
stakeholders' expectations,

332
00:16:32.676 --> 00:16:36.770
is how we tend to deal with issues
that actually do arise on our project.

333
00:16:36.770 --> 00:16:40.694
The very fact is, a lot of us are great
at avoidance more than anything else.

334
00:16:40.694 --> 00:16:45.740
So when issues arise that are a little bit
negative, we may try and suppress them.

335
00:16:45.740 --> 00:16:48.950
We may try and actually just go,
I'll deal with that later.

336
00:16:48.950 --> 00:16:51.480
And when you do that,
they end up stacking up.

337
00:16:51.480 --> 00:16:54.920
And this idea of issues stacking
up is never a good thing because

338
00:16:54.920 --> 00:16:57.420
they will come to a head,
in this way, right?

339
00:16:57.420 --> 00:16:59.950
The very fact you haven't addressed
it means somebody is gonna

340
00:16:59.950 --> 00:17:01.120
address it for you.

341
00:17:01.120 --> 00:17:05.828
It just ends up happening, especially when
you're under a time crunch, money crunch,

342
00:17:05.828 --> 00:17:09.488
and a scope crunch, a requirement
sort of crunch that you deal with.

343
00:17:09.488 --> 00:17:11.031
And when you have that, right,

344
00:17:11.031 --> 00:17:15.060
that's something that's actually
going to end up reflecting on you.

345
00:17:15.060 --> 00:17:18.320
So one of the things that really
helps manage stakeholder meetings, or

346
00:17:18.320 --> 00:17:23.220
stakeholder perspective,
what did I say, satisfaction.

347
00:17:23.220 --> 00:17:25.360
I couldn't remember what I
was meaning to say there.

348
00:17:25.360 --> 00:17:28.080
Satisfaction, is when you
take the time to try and

349
00:17:28.080 --> 00:17:31.470
resolve the issues that
arise in a timely manner.

350
00:17:31.470 --> 00:17:32.290
Now that's key.

351
00:17:32.290 --> 00:17:33.210
Let's go ahead and take a look here,

352
00:17:33.210 --> 00:17:36.320
and I've put up three bullet points for
us to help us out, okay.

353
00:17:36.320 --> 00:17:39.640
So you don't wanna allow issues to stack
up because that actually just shows

354
00:17:39.640 --> 00:17:42.780
something about you that you're not
willing to deal with the issue.

355
00:17:42.780 --> 00:17:44.510
Not a great thing, okay.

356
00:17:44.510 --> 00:17:45.515
So you deal with them.

357
00:17:45.515 --> 00:17:47.800
That doesn't mean you have to
deal with them in rapid fire, but

358
00:17:47.800 --> 00:17:50.910
you need to show progress in
dealing with issues that do arise.

359
00:17:50.910 --> 00:17:52.880
And it needs to be done
in a timely manner.

360
00:17:52.880 --> 00:17:56.630
Don't sit there and say, I think we'll

361
00:17:56.630 --> 00:17:59.250
Go ahead and deal with them cuz they
wanna actually know you have an action

362
00:17:59.250 --> 00:18:00.290
plan for this.

363
00:18:00.290 --> 00:18:03.250
Make time to resolve and not avoid, okay.

364
00:18:03.250 --> 00:18:07.525
Most of us, and we've said this
before about certain people like,

365
00:18:07.525 --> 00:18:11.733
that guy can find 62 ways so
that he doesn't have to do one thing.

00:18:11.733 --> 00:18:14.400
And it would only have taken him

00:18:14.400 --> 00:18:16.218
>> If he worked as hard at avoiding work-
>> [LAUGH]

368
00:18:16.218 --> 00:18:16.878
>> As he does, or

00:18:16.878 --> 00:18:19.573
if he worked as hard at doing
work as he does avoiding work,

370
00:18:19.573 --> 00:18:21.068
he'd be a master at this thing.

371
00:18:21.068 --> 00:18:24.300
>> Yeah, and that's something that we
don't want to actually see, right.

372
00:18:24.300 --> 00:18:26.580
The very fact that we keep
saying we'll deal with it later,

00:18:26.580 --> 00:18:28.470
we'll deal with it later, guess what?

00:18:28.470 --> 00:18:29.970
Stakeholders are not impressed.

00:18:29.970 --> 00:18:31.050
Stakeholders are not impressed,

team members are not impressed when

00:18:34.490 --> 00:18:37.840
And what happens, you don't deal with

00:18:37.840 --> 00:18:42.090
In your way, that is a deal, but in their
way it's not really resolving an issue so

00:18:42.090 --> 00:18:43.080
that they can move forward.

00:18:43.080 --> 00:18:44.340
>> Just rug sweeping basically,
at that point.

00:18:44.340 --> 00:18:45.820

00:18:45.820 --> 00:18:49.190
You do want to make sure you communicate

00:18:49.190 --> 00:18:50.260

00:18:50.260 --> 00:18:53.115
Now, it's not the idea of
a bragging session, per se.

Saying, yes, you know,
here's the issue that I solved today.

That's not the goal, right.

The goal is to, what,

00:19:06.070 --> 00:19:07.710
Okay, that's what you're trying to do.

00:19:07.710 --> 00:19:12.010
So if you can do that, you are satisfying

00:19:12.010 --> 00:19:14.810
Daniel Lowrie is the project

00:19:17.280 --> 00:19:17.860
Well imagine that,

00:19:17.860 --> 00:19:21.640
don't you feel more confidence in that

says, I think I'll deal with it next
week cuz I'm going on vacation.

00:19:24.840 --> 00:19:28.670
I might as well just take the, I'll deal

00:19:28.670 --> 00:19:30.380
It doesn't really inspire confidence,

especially when people are waiting for

00:19:33.570 --> 00:19:38.030
So that's one of the ways that you
can really end up managing that idea

00:19:39.490 --> 00:19:42.360
of expectation as well, okay?

00:19:42.360 --> 00:19:46.880
Also, we want to take a look at

00:19:46.880 --> 00:19:49.390

00:19:49.390 --> 00:19:50.794
This is something else that can happen,

It goes through the process,
we do everything possible,

change board approves everything.

00:19:55.335 --> 00:20:00.816
And then we go, yeah, I just don't see

And don't get me wrong, you may find

So make sure that your approved

Now in that, that means you at the end,

it becomes a cartoon at that point.

The other thing, let's go and

is you've gotta actually realize

00:20:58.170 --> 00:21:02.260
Not everything's personal,

Sometimes, and we use this phrase around

00:21:06.090 --> 00:21:11.207
It's actually part of our mottoes and

The very fact is,

So you do have to actually go and

It's easy to look down on it,

Well, it's because I didn't

When I do my project status meetings and

Ask about the concerns

And then you do your best to address

00:23:06.840 --> 00:23:10.901

Is making sure that we can
end up helping out the way

00:23:15.246 --> 00:23:19.080

00:23:19.080 --> 00:23:24.292

493
00:24:21.960 --> 00:24:26.200
the changes I want to make is a benefit
for the project and ultimately it's gonna

494
00:24:26.200 --> 00:24:30.225
benefit them, and monetarily,
that's always a good one, right?

495
00:24:30.225 --> 00:24:31.110
And that's what they're gonna think.

496
00:24:31.110 --> 00:24:32.570
So they're gonna help you out.

497
00:24:32.570 --> 00:24:36.244
If they think, man this guy never listens
to me, [LAUGH] he never does anything and

498
00:24:36.244 --> 00:24:39.377
he just kind of comes by and says,
yeah, project's moving along and

499
00:24:39.377 --> 00:24:41.380
it was good to see you guys again.

500
00:24:41.380 --> 00:24:44.130
And I'm like, wow,
nothing's happening here.

501
00:24:44.130 --> 00:24:45.510
I get no information.

502
00:24:45.510 --> 00:24:49.310
They're gonna be really skeptical
about approving any changes because

503
00:24:49.310 --> 00:24:50.690
they don't know what's happening.

504
00:24:50.690 --> 00:24:51.410
They're in the dark.

505
00:24:51.410 --> 00:24:55.510
You had to keep them in there, keep them
close to the vest, you invest in them and

506
00:24:55.510 --> 00:24:57.720
they'll invest in you and
that's the way you gotta come at it.

507
00:24:57.720 --> 00:25:00.670
There is no doubt that all it
really does help in managing

508
00:25:00.670 --> 00:25:03.720
those stakeholder expectations
are really key, right?

509
00:25:03.720 --> 00:25:06.840
Because of the issues that
we will end up arising

510
00:25:06.840 --> 00:25:08.800
just when progress ends up happening.

511
00:25:08.800 --> 00:25:11.320
Now, there's two other issues
that we want to address just

512
00:25:11.320 --> 00:25:13.570
briefly here as well, okay?

513
00:25:13.570 --> 00:25:16.560
One, is if you tend to actually
like to do the communication,

514
00:25:16.560 --> 00:25:19.770
the majority of your communication
through meetings, it's perfectly fine.

515
00:25:19.770 --> 00:25:22.640
The recommendation, though,
is that you use an agenda.

516
00:25:22.640 --> 00:25:26.080
Do not just go, well, is there anything
that somebody needs to talk about now?

517
00:25:26.080 --> 00:25:28.610
[LAUGH] No,
if you're actually doing a status meeting,

518
00:25:28.610 --> 00:25:31.970
make sure you actually follow an agenda
and give the information that you need.

519
00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:34.070
That's pretty much the clear idea.

520
00:25:34.070 --> 00:25:37.070
Don't call a meeting where all of
the sudden somebody goes, well, Daniel,

521
00:25:37.070 --> 00:25:38.260
you called the meeting.

522
00:25:38.260 --> 00:25:39.162
What's this about?

523
00:25:39.162 --> 00:25:40.029
I don't know.

524
00:25:40.029 --> 00:25:42.629
Yeah, we were supposed to
have a status meeting.

525
00:25:42.629 --> 00:25:45.350
That's [INAUDIBLE]
>> Just figured we'd all get together,

526
00:25:45.350 --> 00:25:46.670
hanging out and talk a little bit.

527
00:25:46.670 --> 00:25:48.410
No, that's not a good way to do it.

528
00:25:48.410 --> 00:25:52.130
Have that bulleted list of
points that you want to address.

529
00:25:52.130 --> 00:25:55.410
Make sure you give it time to say,
hey, if anybody has any questions,

530
00:25:55.410 --> 00:25:58.590
now's a great time to ask them
because we're all right here.

531
00:25:58.590 --> 00:26:01.090
Go ahead and face-to-face,
look at my body language and

532
00:26:01.090 --> 00:26:03.690
my facial expressions,
the tone of my voice,

533
00:26:03.690 --> 00:26:08.350
it's not some sterile email that I'm
sending you with just a list of things.

534
00:26:08.350 --> 00:26:12.440
We can actually interact, and talk,
and maybe ideas will flow, and

535
00:26:12.440 --> 00:26:13.760
we can be more productive.

536
00:26:13.760 --> 00:26:16.340
>> There is no doubt that that is
actually kinda one of the key things,

537
00:26:16.340 --> 00:26:17.570
if you really do like meetings.

538
00:26:17.570 --> 00:26:20.690
Now if you're like me,
meetings are not my thing.

539
00:26:20.690 --> 00:26:25.620
I just sat through so many meeting
where you're just like, just me go so

540
00:26:25.620 --> 00:26:27.150
I can work on the project.

541
00:26:27.150 --> 00:26:29.210
Just let me get out of here so
I could do that.

542
00:26:29.210 --> 00:26:30.530
Well that's not the situation we want.

543
00:26:30.530 --> 00:26:32.550
So use an agenda, make sure you cover it.

544
00:26:32.550 --> 00:26:34.460
If you set a time limit for
it, follow that.

545
00:26:34.460 --> 00:26:35.770
It is kinda the key.

546
00:26:35.770 --> 00:26:38.947
The last thing that we wanna talk
about is, of course, updating, okay?

547
00:26:38.947 --> 00:26:41.698
Updates, I'm not talking
about emergency things but

548
00:26:41.698 --> 00:26:45.763
updates to your project, in other words,
showing the progress of everything,

549
00:26:45.763 --> 00:26:47.822
it should be done periodically, okay?

550
00:26:47.822 --> 00:26:51.326
Whether you actually schedule this being
a daily, hopefully it's not but if you do

551
00:26:51.326 --> 00:26:55.520
that, that's fine, every two days, every
week, every month, whatever it might be.

552
00:26:55.520 --> 00:26:57.980
Make sure you do it on the same day or

553
00:26:57.980 --> 00:27:00.560
about the same time is what
I'm trying to get, right?

554
00:27:00.560 --> 00:27:03.820
Because periodic updates are how they
know it's actually progressing, and

555
00:27:03.820 --> 00:27:05.700
how things are actually going.

556
00:27:05.700 --> 00:27:09.780
When you don't do it, when you skip some,
what ends up happening is then they'll

557
00:27:09.780 --> 00:27:11.910
get one, and they'll go, well,
what about last month's?

558
00:27:11.910 --> 00:27:14.560
You didn't have one, and
that's all you have to report is,

559
00:27:14.560 --> 00:27:15.980
I didn't have one last month.

560
00:27:15.980 --> 00:27:18.089
It doesn't again,
show a great light on you.

561
00:27:19.100 --> 00:27:20.850
You wanna make sure
that if you do updates,

562
00:27:20.850 --> 00:27:22.550
make sure you do them periodically.

563
00:27:22.550 --> 00:27:23.920
Keeps everybody informed.

564
00:27:23.920 --> 00:27:26.710
Lets them know that things
are still going on on your project.

565
00:27:26.710 --> 00:27:29.170
Keeps your project in their mind as well.

566
00:27:29.170 --> 00:27:32.170
And that is something you really want us
especially if you want your stakeholders

567
00:27:32.170 --> 00:27:33.440
to be on your side.

568
00:27:33.440 --> 00:27:35.742
So, being able to mange
those expectations.

569
00:27:35.742 --> 00:27:40.329
Being able to use whatever advantage that
you can in your distribution plan, is

570
00:27:40.329 --> 00:27:44.921
the key to making sure that your project
is gonna have the success that it needs.

571
00:27:44.921 --> 00:27:47.909
And that your stakeholders feel like
that they're really involved and

572
00:27:47.909 --> 00:27:49.161
invested into your project.

573
00:27:49.161 --> 00:27:51.181
>> Nail on the head,
Ronnie, nail on the head.

574
00:27:51.181 --> 00:27:53.380
Thank you so much for
explaining these things to us.

575
00:27:53.380 --> 00:27:57.350
Obviously, these are the kind of things
that we might not think about as we become

576
00:27:57.350 --> 00:28:01.780
project managers, but are extremely
important as far as our projects go.

577
00:28:01.780 --> 00:28:05.040
And obviously, we're trying to
pass an exam here and Project+,

578
00:28:05.040 --> 00:28:08.490
they might ask you a question or
two based of of this information.

579
00:28:08.490 --> 00:28:10.740
So take heed,
listen to what we had to say.

580
00:28:10.740 --> 00:28:13.400
Especially what Ronnie had to say and
learn it.

581
00:28:13.400 --> 00:28:16.920
Assimilate it so that you can pass
the exam and more effectively

582
00:28:16.920 --> 00:28:20.920
work with your stakeholders and distribute
information throughout your project.

583
00:28:20.920 --> 00:28:22.420
Ronnie again, thank you for stopping by.

584
00:28:22.420 --> 00:28:25.800
We appreciate your input and
your insight into these topics.

585
00:28:25.800 --> 00:28:27.250
We thank you guys for joining us today.

586
00:28:27.250 --> 00:28:28.800
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

587
00:28:28.800 --> 00:28:30.811
For ITProvTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

588
00:28:30.811 --> 00:28:31.531
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

589
00:28:31.531 --> 00:28:33.411
>> And we'll see you next time.

590
00:28:33.411 --> 00:28:41.130
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie help you identify some constraints that my be negatively affecting communication between project team members and/or Stakeholders. Specific constrains addressed in this episode include: Time Zones, communication preferences, language barriers, hierarchical barriers, technological barriers, and cultural differences.
episodes.title: Identify Communication Contraints
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.088 --> 00:00:17.070
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:17.070 --> 00:00:18.280
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.280 --> 00:00:21.650
in today's episode we are moving
on with our Project Plus series.

5
00:00:21.650 --> 00:00:24.820
Hopefully you guys have been enjoying that
and joining us back in the studio again

6
00:00:24.820 --> 00:00:27.970
today is our good friend and
our guiding star, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:27.970 --> 00:00:29.300
Ronnie, welcome back to the show today.

8
00:00:29.300 --> 00:00:29.880
>> Well thank you for

9
00:00:29.880 --> 00:00:34.010
having me back on the show as we
continue on with our CompTIA Project+.

10
00:00:34.010 --> 00:00:37.090
Now today we're actually looking
at different types of what we call

11
00:00:37.090 --> 00:00:40.710
communication constraints in
the project management world.

12
00:00:40.710 --> 00:00:43.560
We normally talk about the idea of
communication barriers is what we

13
00:00:43.560 --> 00:00:44.640
talk about.

14
00:00:44.640 --> 00:00:47.330
So remember that as a Project Manager,
there's a lot of

15
00:00:47.330 --> 00:00:50.770
times where especially when you start off,
your projects are fairly,

16
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:53.750
I'm not gonna say super small,
but normally, they're actually

17
00:00:53.750 --> 00:00:57.970
gonna be with people that you feel fairly
confident about working together with.

18
00:00:57.970 --> 00:01:00.520
A lot of times they're may
even actually be able to fit

19
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:02.490
all in the same room when you start.

20
00:01:02.490 --> 00:01:03.660
Or maybe even smaller.

21
00:01:03.660 --> 00:01:05.590
It may only be two or three people.

22
00:01:05.590 --> 00:01:08.720
But as your management experience
gets larger and larger and

23
00:01:08.720 --> 00:01:12.480
as you actually start working for
different companies sometimes, you might

24
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:17.500
find that realm of your project management
experience begins to grow very rapidly and

25
00:01:17.500 --> 00:01:23.200
beyond your skill set very quickly,
especially in the realms of communication.

26
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:26.440
Now, remember when we talk about
the idea of communications right now.

27
00:01:26.440 --> 00:01:30.180
We are not talking about controlling those
communications that we spent several

28
00:01:30.180 --> 00:01:32.910
shows, at least a couple
of shows I should say

29
00:01:32.910 --> 00:01:35.330
on managing our communication
with stakeholders and

30
00:01:35.330 --> 00:01:38.540
that's something that's actually great,
something that we actually have to do.

31
00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:41.480
We also understand the process of
course of communicating with our

32
00:01:41.480 --> 00:01:42.860
team members as well.

33
00:01:42.860 --> 00:01:46.960
But there's always this particular
experience that you may run across,

34
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:50.270
in which you're gonna find out that
there are some constraints that you have

35
00:01:50.270 --> 00:01:51.380
to deal with.

36
00:01:51.380 --> 00:01:54.790
Because the very fact that
the team that you may be managing,

37
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:58.050
or a portion of your team,
is gonna be remote to you.

38
00:01:58.050 --> 00:02:01.770
In other words, it's not gonna be
people that you'll see day to day.

39
00:02:01.770 --> 00:02:04.960
Sometimes it's not even,
not only people that you see day to day.

40
00:02:04.960 --> 00:02:08.190
But it could be people that she
work in a different time zone and

41
00:02:08.190 --> 00:02:10.610
that she speak a different language

42
00:02:10.610 --> 00:02:15.220
in which now all the sudden you have a big
barrier that's actually in between you and

43
00:02:15.220 --> 00:02:19.170
them and what you have to do is
actually make sure that you understand.

44
00:02:19.170 --> 00:02:23.300
And that you can identify a lot of
those different constraints and

45
00:02:23.300 --> 00:02:25.680
that way be able to actually figure out

46
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:30.150
how can actually manage the communication
stuff between us a lot better.

47
00:02:30.150 --> 00:02:31.720
So that's what we're really focusing on.

48
00:02:31.720 --> 00:02:36.010
We are going to take a look at a few very
practical types of constraints that we

49
00:02:36.010 --> 00:02:39.680
have to deal with and then we'll talk
about a few cultural constraints as well.

50
00:02:39.680 --> 00:02:42.700
And we will try and
give a couple of examples when we do this.

51
00:02:42.700 --> 00:02:44.800
So, let's go ahead and jump right in.

52
00:02:44.800 --> 00:02:48.060
And so, when we start taken look at
one of the most practical things.

53
00:02:48.060 --> 00:02:50.950
I remember, Daniel one of the very
first time that I've actually got

54
00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:52.610
set up to do some training.

55
00:02:52.610 --> 00:02:56.490
Actually in a different time zone and
I didn't think about it at all.

56
00:02:56.490 --> 00:02:59.280
And all of the sudden I realize
something that I had forgotten

57
00:02:59.280 --> 00:03:02.730
a very important element of some
of the training that I was doing.

58
00:03:02.730 --> 00:03:07.440
So of course I called back into the office
not realizing I was in a different time

59
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:12.810
zone and now all of a sudden when I had
actually called back, it was actually

60
00:03:12.810 --> 00:03:16.500
later than I thought it was and so
nobody was actually in the office.

61
00:03:16.500 --> 00:03:18.560
Daniel, have you ever
experienced anything like that?

62
00:03:18.560 --> 00:03:21.850
>> Yeah, I worked for a company here in
Florida and if anybody knows anything

63
00:03:21.850 --> 00:03:25.360
about Florida, there are multiple
time zones in the state of Florida.

64
00:03:25.360 --> 00:03:26.820
Once you get over into the panhandle,

65
00:03:26.820 --> 00:03:31.550
you move into central time after
a certain amount of distance to the west.

66
00:03:31.550 --> 00:03:36.260
And you think, I gotta call this office
up and I need them to reboot a piece of

67
00:03:36.260 --> 00:03:39.390
hardware there right, cause I'm
a network guy, I'm a systems guy.

68
00:03:39.390 --> 00:03:42.930
So I'm running the network and the systems
for each one of our branch offices.

69
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:45.210
I call them up and they're not there.

70
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:48.830
Unfortunately, it was like a missions
critical type of thing and

71
00:03:48.830 --> 00:03:49.890
it was too far for me to drive.

72
00:03:49.890 --> 00:03:52.780
So I just had to sit there and
wait until the time zone changed.

73
00:03:52.780 --> 00:03:54.080
People start coming into work.

74
00:03:54.080 --> 00:03:55.890
It can be very, very frustrating.

75
00:03:55.890 --> 00:03:58.210
And then again, hey,
call me back at lunch.

76
00:03:58.210 --> 00:03:59.715
Well, lunch has a frame of reference.

77
00:03:59.715 --> 00:04:01.560
>> [LAUGH]
>> Most people think 12 o'clock.

78
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:03.760
Well, it is 12 o'clock Eastern time.

79
00:04:03.760 --> 00:04:06.470
If I don't say Eastern time,
then they don't understand.

80
00:04:06.470 --> 00:04:09.570
They probably are gonna default
to their own frame of reference.

81
00:04:09.570 --> 00:04:12.440
It's what we do at the shows
when we close our shows out.

82
00:04:12.440 --> 00:04:14.750
Between episodes we say, hey,

83
00:04:14.750 --> 00:04:19.840
join us tomorrow at around 1:30 eastern
time because not every viewer here is

84
00:04:19.840 --> 00:04:23.150
on the east coast of the United States or
in the eastern time zone.

85
00:04:23.150 --> 00:04:25.250
So you have to make sure
to preference those things,

86
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:27.250
otherwise your gonna have
some communication issues.

87
00:04:27.250 --> 00:04:30.500
>> And with projects, this is incredibly
important and remember why, right?

88
00:04:30.500 --> 00:04:33.060
Because every projects has
it's triple constraints.

89
00:04:33.060 --> 00:04:36.940
We're limited by time, cost as well
as the actual requirements here.

90
00:04:36.940 --> 00:04:40.850
Well now imagine that what ends up
happening during your project is that say,

91
00:04:40.850 --> 00:04:44.490
hey I'm gonna set a standard
project status meeting.

92
00:04:44.490 --> 00:04:46.720
And every time you do so, okay?

93
00:04:46.720 --> 00:04:49.170
Let's say you actually go look
here in the Eastern Time Zone,

94
00:04:49.170 --> 00:04:50.870
this is a great one for us to use.

95
00:04:50.870 --> 00:04:55.510
We say, we'll have set this for right,
an hour before lunchtime, okay?

96
00:04:55.510 --> 00:04:56.850
That sounds good to us.

97
00:04:56.850 --> 00:04:59.090
And normally, here in the Eastern
time zone, at least for

98
00:04:59.090 --> 00:05:04.300
us at ITProTV Studios; that means
12 to 1 is normally our lunch time.

99
00:05:04.300 --> 00:05:08.120
Well now let's say that I have a portion
of my team that's remote from me

100
00:05:08.120 --> 00:05:10.360
that is in that central time zone.

101
00:05:10.360 --> 00:05:14.580
And that means it's actually
an hour back from that as well.

102
00:05:14.580 --> 00:05:18.270
So that actually does work out as
long as I actually let people know

103
00:05:18.270 --> 00:05:20.150
that it's actually that way, okay?

104
00:05:20.150 --> 00:05:23.530
But now if I tell them, what,
an hour before lunch time, and

105
00:05:23.530 --> 00:05:28.130
they wait until, what,
11 AM to start in their time.

106
00:05:28.130 --> 00:05:30.400
It's already noon, and
I'm already eating my sandwich.

107
00:05:30.400 --> 00:05:33.020
And so I don't wanna be disturbed
during my eating of my sandwich,

108
00:05:33.020 --> 00:05:36.210
but you kinda get this
idea that this can happen.

109
00:05:36.210 --> 00:05:38.800
So time zones are actually a very
important constraint for us.

110
00:05:38.800 --> 00:05:40.430
Let's go ahead and take a look here.

111
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:44.140
And I even took a little of time
of doing some diagrams here.

112
00:05:44.140 --> 00:05:47.960
Let's say we call that meeting that
is 9 o'clock in the morning here.

113
00:05:47.960 --> 00:05:52.240
But let's say our time zone is much more
removed, and this one's actually earlier.

114
00:05:52.240 --> 00:05:55.910
Let say is wealth and this guy
actually they start calling in and

115
00:05:55.910 --> 00:05:57.720
said, hey, it's 9 o'clock.

116
00:05:58.990 --> 00:06:00.490
Welcome to our status meeting here.

117
00:06:00.490 --> 00:06:04.690
I want to, wait a minute,
it's a quarter 'til 6 right now.

118
00:06:04.690 --> 00:06:08.810
And now all of a sudden you kinda realize
you woke with somebody up at a quarter

119
00:06:08.810 --> 00:06:09.860
to 6 AM and.

120
00:06:09.860 --> 00:06:12.600
They were probably not very happy that you
called them up to actually attend their

121
00:06:12.600 --> 00:06:14.090
project status meeting.

122
00:06:14.090 --> 00:06:17.980
So sometimes even stuff like that, right,
very practically that could actually help

123
00:06:17.980 --> 00:06:21.820
us out in actually thinking about it,
when we actually realize where they are.

124
00:06:21.820 --> 00:06:25.520
Secondly, we also have to think about
the idea of communication preferences.

125
00:06:25.520 --> 00:06:28.460
It's very easy, right,
to think that everybody

126
00:06:28.460 --> 00:06:31.270
loves to communicate the same
way that you do, okay?

127
00:06:31.270 --> 00:06:35.220
I know, I see it every day as I drive
home, and you probably see it every day as

128

348
00:17:53.734 --> 00:17:55.653
language, they know and they struggle and

349
00:17:55.653 --> 00:17:58.178
they may even play with you
on the language a little bit.

350
00:17:58.178 --> 00:18:01.271
And they get a little bit annoyed that
you're not actually using their timezone

351
00:18:01.271 --> 00:18:03.730
and stuff like that, but
they'll overcome things like that.

352
00:18:03.730 --> 00:18:07.740
But what they won't overcome is the idea
of cultural differences if you're

353
00:18:07.740 --> 00:18:10.790
not even willing to respect
the cultural differences

354
00:18:10.790 --> 00:18:13.040
as you're working on these projects.

355
00:18:13.040 --> 00:18:16.770
So let's just take for
an example the idea of formality here.

356
00:18:16.770 --> 00:18:18.443
So when you think about this idea.

357
00:18:18.443 --> 00:18:20.840
Let's say, that Dan and I,
we work in an office together.

358
00:18:20.840 --> 00:18:24.381
And so in the morning Daniel says hey,
Ronnie or good morning, Ronnie and

359
00:18:24.381 --> 00:18:26.508
I say the same thing hey,
good morning Dan.

360
00:18:26.508 --> 00:18:30.568
That's perfectly fine, but you may
actually come from a country in which

361
00:18:30.568 --> 00:18:34.370
you don’t actually do that as
far as that informality goes.

362
00:18:34.370 --> 00:18:38.110
You may actually end up working with
a bunch of people in which you're actually

363
00:18:38.110 --> 00:18:41.581
suppose to address by surnames instead and
not actually the first name.

364
00:18:41.581 --> 00:18:45.639
Especially if you are not actually told
hey, why don't you just call me Ronnie or

365
00:18:45.639 --> 00:18:48.040
call me Dan, whatever it might be here.

366
00:18:48.040 --> 00:18:52.131
So even something as simple as that, even
when the culture is not that different

367
00:18:52.131 --> 00:18:54.282
sometimes, you may actually have that.

368
00:18:54.282 --> 00:18:58.110
You can actually see
people like this even now.

369
00:18:58.110 --> 00:19:01.964
And I've run into this a couple of
times where I've actually done some

370
00:19:01.964 --> 00:19:05.162
training even on army bases and
in some navy bases as well,

371
00:19:05.162 --> 00:19:07.266
actually airforce base, excuse me.

372
00:19:07.266 --> 00:19:12.410
And some airforce bases in which
one time that my point of contact.

373
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:16.930
He actually said hey, just call me Frank.

374
00:19:16.930 --> 00:19:21.320
Another time the guy said, call me Master,
Sergeant so and so, that's what he said.

375
00:19:21.320 --> 00:19:24.393
So you kind of understand
that they're saying what,

376
00:19:24.393 --> 00:19:27.889
no you're not gonna address me as Bob or
Dan or whoever it is.

377
00:19:27.889 --> 00:19:30.380
You're gonna address me as Master,
Sergeant, so and so.

378
00:19:30.380 --> 00:19:33.520
And that's what they actually mean,
is that did you use that.

379
00:19:33.520 --> 00:19:36.410
Make sure you don't just walk
in with an informality that

380
00:19:36.410 --> 00:19:38.730
you're not supposed to have as well.

381
00:19:38.730 --> 00:19:44.630
Also remember that in some cultures, it's
a big direct communication is a big thing.

382
00:19:44.630 --> 00:19:48.530
In Western society we really do,
we want to get to the point and

383
00:19:48.530 --> 00:19:49.950
we want that to happen.

384
00:19:49.950 --> 00:19:51.980
But if you are an Eastern culture,

385
00:19:51.980 --> 00:19:56.181
you're mindset a lot of times it is
not their responsibility of someone

386
00:19:56.181 --> 00:20:01.100
that's actually not at the same level of
you to actually suggest you do something.

387
00:20:01.100 --> 00:20:06.292
It is up to them to actually indirectly
just try and bring you along or to

388
00:20:06.292 --> 00:20:12.102
actually just say, you tell me what needs
to be done and then that will be done.

389
00:20:12.102 --> 00:20:13.862
And then when it doesn't work again,

390
00:20:13.862 --> 00:20:16.630
you essentially just kind
of continue to do that.

391
00:20:16.630 --> 00:20:20.701
But you do not have that right to just
go up and go no, you are doing it wrong.

392
00:20:20.701 --> 00:20:22.550
It has to be done this way.

393
00:20:22.550 --> 00:20:26.616
So a lot of times you might find
out that indirect communication for

394
00:20:26.616 --> 00:20:31.568
people in that culture may actually be the
way to go instead of the direct one too.

395
00:20:31.568 --> 00:20:33.510
So what does that mean for you then?

396
00:20:33.510 --> 00:20:35.330
It means a little bit of background and

397
00:20:35.330 --> 00:20:41.520
research if you end up having to deal
with some type of cross cultural element.

398
00:20:41.520 --> 00:20:43.630
Especially in your project too, and

399
00:20:43.630 --> 00:20:46.240
also the idea of being
aware of certain customs.

400
00:20:46.240 --> 00:20:49.730
Just because I am US centric here,

401
00:20:49.730 --> 00:20:55.380
cuz everything I do is in the country that
we live in, that I might think about thing

402
00:20:55.380 --> 00:21:00.670
like observing certain holidays here that
might not be observed in another country.

403
00:21:00.670 --> 00:21:03.540
But remember that there maybe times
when I have to actually do what?

404
00:21:03.540 --> 00:21:08.050
Observe their holidays when to me
it's actually a regular workday.

405
00:21:08.050 --> 00:21:11.780
And I saw one of these perfect examples of
this on one of the shows that they have on

406
00:21:11.780 --> 00:21:15.050
TV where they do like a documentary, where
they have like Mega Builders or something.

407
00:21:15.050 --> 00:21:17.200
In which they were building a bridge,

408
00:21:17.200 --> 00:21:22.810
I think it was in Hong Kong going
across and it was the Chinese New Year.

409
00:21:22.810 --> 00:21:28.824
Well they stopped, and they actually
did this kind of little ceremony for

410
00:21:28.824 --> 00:21:31.445
that day and honoring that day.

411
00:21:31.445 --> 00:21:35.820
And so the entire project stopped for that
particular point in time, just to do that.

412
00:21:35.820 --> 00:21:38.350
I know that's just a couple of hours or
three hours, but

413
00:21:38.350 --> 00:21:40.810
the project manager turned around and
said, this is very important for

414
00:21:40.810 --> 00:21:44.830
us to show that we do respect the customs,
that we are actually grateful to

415
00:21:44.830 --> 00:21:48.210
be allowed work here and
to be able to work with the people.

416
00:21:48.210 --> 00:21:51.210
And so they did that,
had their celebration just briefly,

417
00:21:51.210 --> 00:21:53.040
and then they all went back to work.

418
00:21:53.040 --> 00:21:56.150
It was kind of neat, just being able
to say, here's what needs to be done,

419
00:21:56.150 --> 00:21:58.600
and they were able to do that as well.

420
00:21:58.600 --> 00:22:01.333
And you may also find yourself
in that situation too.

421
00:22:01.333 --> 00:22:04.508
So just kind of realize that the idea
of barriers for your project,

422
00:22:04.508 --> 00:22:08.310
you're gonna run into them because,
you're gonna work with remote people and

423
00:22:08.310 --> 00:22:11.420
sometimes those remote people
won't speak the same language.

424
00:22:11.420 --> 00:22:14.500
Sometimes they won't even have
same reference that you'll have.

425
00:22:14.500 --> 00:22:16.030
You still have to overcome them.

426
00:22:16.030 --> 00:22:17.950
There's different ways for us to do that.

427
00:22:17.950 --> 00:22:21.510
But the key for you as a project manager
is to understand all of those things that

428
00:22:21.510 --> 00:22:25.120
actually will exists for you and
that means you have to be on top of it.

429
00:22:25.120 --> 00:22:26.600
>> Yeah, Ronnie and it does so deep.

430
00:22:26.600 --> 00:22:29.090
There's so many ways,
we've just given you a good general.

431
00:22:29.090 --> 00:22:31.290
Of course this is a things that come
to you and want you to know for

432
00:22:31.290 --> 00:22:34.100
the exam, but
it's basically a generalization.

433
00:22:34.100 --> 00:22:37.330
Here are the main ways in which
you'll see barriers brought up

434
00:22:37.330 --> 00:22:38.860
to your communication with other people.

435
00:22:38.860 --> 00:22:43.114
And I think about language, and
I think even accent can cause a problem.

436
00:22:43.114 --> 00:22:47.641
I don't understand because your accent is
thick, and usually that's because it's not

437
00:22:47.641 --> 00:22:51.870
a native language speaker of whatever
language that you're working with.

438
00:22:51.870 --> 00:22:53.651
And therefore the action
comes in colloquialisms.

439
00:22:53.651 --> 00:22:54.220
>> Right.
>> Right?

440
00:22:54.220 --> 00:22:56.777
I don't understand this analogy
that you've thrown at me.

441
00:22:56.777 --> 00:22:59.570
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Yeah, it doesn't make any sense to me.

442
00:22:59.570 --> 00:23:01.110
So you gotta be careful,

443
00:23:01.110 --> 00:23:04.990
you can't just use your own
colloquialisms that you're used to.

444
00:23:04.990 --> 00:23:07.520
The idioms that you've grown up with,
they might not apply and

445
00:23:07.520 --> 00:23:11.510
somebody might even take offence to them
because of the way their culture is.

446
00:23:11.510 --> 00:23:16.788
So it's just better to be, I would say,
to be as direct as possible and

447
00:23:16.788 --> 00:23:20.380
always be as formal as
you can until otherwise.

448
00:23:20.380 --> 00:23:21.437
>> [LAUGH]
>> Told, right?

449
00:23:21.437 --> 00:23:23.991
Unless someone says hey, call me Bob.

450
00:23:23.991 --> 00:23:25.185
That way you start off

451
00:23:25.185 --> 00:23:27.436
with Master Sergeant Wilkerson-
>> [LAUGH]

452
00:23:27.436 --> 00:23:28.664
>> Or whatever his name is.

453
00:23:28.664 --> 00:23:30.390
And then he goes, call me Bob,
then you call him Bob.

454
00:23:30.390 --> 00:23:33.150
Don't start off with calling him Bob,
and then have to be told hey,

455
00:23:33.150 --> 00:23:34.800
call me Master Sergeant Wilkerson.

456
00:23:34.800 --> 00:23:36.041
That's the better way to go.

457
00:23:36.041 --> 00:23:38.990
Ronnie, is there anything else we need to
talk about before we wrap this episode up?

458
00:23:38.990 --> 00:23:42.550
>> Well not really as far as the different
barriers that we're gonna run into when

459
00:23:42.550 --> 00:23:43.930
we're working with remote teams.

460
00:23:43.930 --> 00:23:47.070
But remember, communications is
a huge part of everything that we

461
00:23:47.070 --> 00:23:48.890
do as a project manager.

462
00:23:48.890 --> 00:23:51.310
And a lot of times and
if you even read inside the PNP, and

463
00:23:51.310 --> 00:23:53.650
I mentioned this during
our project planning.

464
00:23:53.650 --> 00:23:56.393
They really do recommend about 90%.

465
00:23:56.393 --> 00:24:01.613
So 90% of your time as a project manager
during this phase is about communication.

466
00:24:01.613 --> 00:24:04.603
In other words, you actually making
sure that good communication is going,

467
00:24:04.603 --> 00:24:06.312
that you're having good communications.

468
00:24:06.312 --> 00:24:08.530
It means you need to
spent more time on it.

469
00:24:08.530 --> 00:24:10.870
Don't just look and see what pleases you.

470
00:24:10.870 --> 00:24:12.548
Look at what's gonna be effective for
your project.

471
00:24:12.548 --> 00:24:15.435
Make sure you actually provide
those communication pathways and

472
00:24:15.435 --> 00:24:17.333
make it easier for everybody else to work.

473
00:24:17.333 --> 00:24:17.957
>> Well Ronnie,

474
00:24:17.957 --> 00:24:19.925
great communication here with us-
>> [LAUGH]

475
00:24:19.925 --> 00:24:21.760
>> And our viewers.

476
00:24:21.760 --> 00:24:24.200
Hopefully there were no barriers
in that way and if there are,

477
00:24:24.200 --> 00:24:26.290
now you are equipped to overcome them.

478
00:24:26.290 --> 00:24:29.500
Thanks again for showing up today,
and explaining these concepts to us.

479
00:24:29.500 --> 00:24:30.720
Thank you guys for watching.

480
00:24:30.720 --> 00:24:32.984
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off, we're ITProTV.

481
00:24:32.984 --> 00:24:34.410
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

482
00:24:34.410 --> 00:24:35.160
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

483
00:24:35.160 --> 00:24:36.986
>> We'll see you next time.

484
00:24:36.986 --> 00:24:44.590
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the Project Closure procedure. They begin by explaining the importance and benefits of conducting a formal project close, discussing the Close Project process and the Close Procurements process. Then they detail the Post-project review process and finally walk you through preparing a Project Close Report.
episodes.title: Explain Project Closure
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.921 --> 00:00:12.465
Greetings everyone!
And,

3
00:00:12.465 --> 00:00:16.940
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:16.940 --> 00:00:18.160
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

5
00:00:18.160 --> 00:00:21.760
in today's episode we are continuing
on with our Project+ series.

6
00:00:21.760 --> 00:00:24.940
Hopefully you'll be getting a lot of
information out of that moving up to where

7
00:00:24.940 --> 00:00:26.630
you're actually taking the exam.

8
00:00:26.630 --> 00:00:29.680
Joining us back in the studio today
to help you in that very endeavor

9
00:00:29.680 --> 00:00:31.160
is our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:32.490
Ronnie, welcome back to the show sir.

11
00:00:32.490 --> 00:00:33.690
>> Well thank you for
having me on the show.

12
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:36.970
As we continue on to take
a look at CompTIA's Project+.

13
00:00:36.970 --> 00:00:41.140
Now we're actually beginning a brand
new domain objective for us,

14
00:00:41.140 --> 00:00:46.900
which means we're coming close toward the
end of our series here in project plus.

15
00:00:46.900 --> 00:00:50.110
And that means we're actually at
the closing stage is what we're

16
00:00:50.110 --> 00:00:51.580
taking a look at here.

17
00:00:51.580 --> 00:00:56.280
So what we actually want to do today,
right, is to take a little deeper look

18
00:00:56.280 --> 00:01:01.490
at the idea and importance of what
a formal project closure is about.

19
00:01:01.490 --> 00:01:04.710
And why it's something that
we want to be able to do.

20
00:01:04.710 --> 00:01:08.770
Now there's a lot of things that go on
inside of a project and it's fairly easy

21
00:01:08.770 --> 00:01:12.470
that you might think about here, but
overall though, we want to actually

22
00:01:12.470 --> 00:01:16.390
establish some type of formal method that
says that we are done with our project.

23
00:01:16.390 --> 00:01:19.890
So, when we start taking a look at
the overall project phases themselves,

24
00:01:19.890 --> 00:01:22.640
remember we had that pre-project setup or
the initiation.

25
00:01:22.640 --> 00:01:24.500
We also then went into the planning stage.

26
00:01:24.500 --> 00:01:28.160
We've talked about execution as
well as monitoring and controlling.

27
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:29.770
And we've actually mentioned all of that.

28
00:01:29.770 --> 00:01:34.260
So now we're moving into the final
stage of the overall project that

29
00:01:34.260 --> 00:01:38.960
we're actually in, which is the idea
of course of closing out our project.

30
00:01:38.960 --> 00:01:44.580
And establishing the need and the reason
for actually doing a project closing.

31
00:01:44.580 --> 00:01:48.670
So in our reality what
happens at a project closing?

32
00:01:48.670 --> 00:01:52.280
Most of the time we get done
with our project we simply say,

33
00:01:52.280 --> 00:01:53.440
right good job, bye.

34
00:01:53.440 --> 00:01:55.870
And we're done and that's pretty much it.

35
00:01:55.870 --> 00:01:59.650
And a lot of times, it may not even go off
with so much as a formal like we're done

36
00:01:59.650 --> 00:02:03.020
with the project is just that
we finished that last task.

37
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:06.310
And it's like, all right we're done and
we don't do anything else.

38
00:02:06.310 --> 00:02:09.920
Now that is not actually is not exactly
the worst way to actually finish

39
00:02:09.920 --> 00:02:10.920
out a project.

40
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:13.480
But the problem with that,
especially in project management,

41
00:02:13.480 --> 00:02:14.980
is something that's simple.

42
00:02:14.980 --> 00:02:18.930
You can't really then end up using a lot
of the information that you might have

43
00:02:18.930 --> 00:02:23.600
learned from managing that overall
project let's say in a future project.

44
00:02:23.600 --> 00:02:26.840
In other words you've actually just said
look we're winging this and you know we'll

45
00:02:26.840 --> 00:02:30.340
do some project documentation when we have
the time, but it's more essential that

46
00:02:30.340 --> 00:02:34.750
I actually do all this then think about
the idea of the posterior of the project.

47
00:02:34.750 --> 00:02:37.610
Where it was left off,
how it was done, no matter what.

48
00:02:37.610 --> 00:02:40.370
So a lot of times projects
essentially just kind of peter out.

49
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:43.920
In other words they just kind of whimper
and that's pretty much all there is.

50
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:47.270
What the idea behind the PMBOK and

51
00:02:47.270 --> 00:02:50.310
the PMI and all these projects
mentions that can be together.

52
00:02:50.310 --> 00:02:52.760
As well as there’s so
much that can be learn from

53
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:57.000
every single project does ever done
that what everybody needs to do,

54
00:02:57.000 --> 00:03:00.980
what every project manager needs to
do it is a century formally closed

55
00:03:00.980 --> 00:03:06.170
out of the project and
go through a closing process itself.

56
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:09.750
So what happens inside of
the closing process or the closing

57
00:03:09.750 --> 00:03:14.170
phase of our project is usually a couple
of separate elements that go on.

58
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:17.550
One is what we call the closed
project process and

59
00:03:17.550 --> 00:03:21.000
the other one is actually the closed
procurement process as well.

60
00:03:21.000 --> 00:03:23.570
And we're gonna kind of dive into that and

61
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:27.720
talk about what each one of those
components are actually made of, and

62
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:31.160
allows us to be able to see, and
why we actually want to do that.

63
00:03:31.160 --> 00:03:35.710
So let's go ahead and start here by taking
a look at the closed project process here.

64
00:03:35.710 --> 00:03:37.430
And why it's actually important for us.

65
00:03:37.430 --> 00:03:40.420
And I've tried to bring up all the
elements that we need to remember here.

66
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:41.310
Okay?

67
00:03:41.310 --> 00:03:43.610
One is a formal sign off.

68
00:03:43.610 --> 00:03:46.250
Now that's actually very important for
us here.

69
00:03:46.250 --> 00:03:46.760
In other words,

70
00:03:46.760 --> 00:03:50.370
what we're doing as a project
manager is we're saying we are done.

71
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:52.680
There's no more processes to work on.

72
00:03:52.680 --> 00:03:55.610
There's no more anything for
me to produce.

73
00:03:55.610 --> 00:03:58.690
That what we have now is
essentially a deliverable.

74
00:03:58.690 --> 00:04:00.430
It is what I signed on to create.

75
00:04:00.430 --> 00:04:02.900
As what I believed that
we've actually done here.

76
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:08.610
And now I'm saying that this particular
result, product, or whatever it might be.

77
00:04:08.610 --> 00:04:13.960
Process that we came up with,
is now done and completed.

78
00:04:13.960 --> 00:04:18.470
And the other part of it of course
then is also the idea of the hand off

79
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:20.070
that we also have too.

80
00:04:20.070 --> 00:04:25.350
Which is turning it over then or
transitioning to the idea of operations.

81
00:04:25.350 --> 00:04:28.650
So sometimes it could be a product where
we actually say here's the finished

82
00:04:28.650 --> 00:04:32.680
product here, and now we're actually
turning it over to these operations

83
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:37.840
that can then reproduce that product that
we actually ended up making and doing.

84
00:04:37.840 --> 00:04:40.320
So in that particular phase there,

85
00:04:40.320 --> 00:04:44.530
it actually is a formality where
we go this is what we believe.

86
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:48.472
And so this way we actually document
that point in time where we say,

87
00:04:48.472 --> 00:04:52.276
we've done our job and

00:16:48.910 --> 00:16:52.560
we call that administrative closure,
now what does that mean?

311
00:16:52.560 --> 00:16:57.030
That means at this point, that we're
saying, we are finally completing all

312
00:16:57.030 --> 00:17:01.000
the details and the paperwork,
I know that that sounds strange, right?

313
00:17:01.000 --> 00:17:02.960
We've done all the work,
we've done the planning,

314
00:17:02.960 --> 00:17:04.910
we've done the pre-planning,
we've done everything.

315
00:17:04.910 --> 00:17:08.441
We've actually gotten the work done,
we've monitored, we've controlled, and

316
00:17:08.441 --> 00:17:13.190
there's still paperwork,
that's the reality of things.

317
00:17:13.190 --> 00:17:17.410
The post mortem review is actually
saying after the project has now really

318
00:17:17.410 --> 00:17:20.030
completely ceased its working.

319
00:17:20.030 --> 00:17:23.780
We want to make sure that as we review
things that we keep some things in mind

320
00:17:23.780 --> 00:17:25.740
for the future as well, okay?

321
00:17:25.740 --> 00:17:29.740
It allows us at the meeting to review what
went right and what went wrong, okay?

322
00:17:29.740 --> 00:17:32.300
And this is very important, because
what we wanna do is we want to take

323
00:17:32.300 --> 00:17:34.880
the pre-planning phase and
wanna review that.

324
00:17:34.880 --> 00:17:38.300
And verify that, hey here's what we
did right, here's what we did wrong.

325
00:17:38.300 --> 00:17:42.950
Same thing as we move into the planning,
execution, monitoring and controlling, and

326
00:17:42.950 --> 00:17:47.140
not the closing, but all four of those
we wanna make sure that we do, okay?

327
00:17:47.140 --> 00:17:51.990
So that's a big part of what
we wanna do because later on,

328
00:17:51.990 --> 00:17:56.200
there's other project managers that
can actually learn from what you did.

329
00:17:56.200 --> 00:18:01.350
If the project closes out in a different
way than just a full functioning project,

330
00:18:01.350 --> 00:18:04.800
sometimes projects get canceled, sometimes
projects just get left behind and

331
00:18:04.800 --> 00:18:07.190
we'll talk about that in
a future episode here.

332
00:18:07.190 --> 00:18:10.480
But when you start taking a look at
this right you can now go ahead and

333
00:18:10.480 --> 00:18:13.822
pick up a project whether it's
been half way done or abandon and

334
00:18:13.822 --> 00:18:15.710
some things end up happening here.

335
00:18:15.710 --> 00:18:19.200
And you can actually now figure out,
why did that project get abandoned?

336
00:18:19.200 --> 00:18:22.840
The reason why is that you might now
be assigned as a project manager

337
00:18:22.840 --> 00:18:24.960
to actually say this is really

338
00:18:26.200 --> 00:18:31.050
revision two of that earlier project that
got abandoned and now you're saying, okay.

339
00:18:31.050 --> 00:18:34.310
I'm picking it up but
why did the first one get abandoned?

340
00:18:34.310 --> 00:18:35.470
Now six months later,

341
00:18:35.470 --> 00:18:40.510
a year later, three years later,
people are going, I don't remember why.

342
00:18:40.510 --> 00:18:42.730
Well, if you have documentation,
guess what?

343
00:18:42.730 --> 00:18:47.770
You can actually go back and go, okay,
and actually use that now in the future.

344
00:18:47.770 --> 00:18:51.070
The other thing you also want to do
is what's officially called lessons

345
00:18:51.070 --> 00:18:52.620
learned here.

346
00:18:52.620 --> 00:18:56.180
Make sure you mark the successes and
failures of the project, it's actually

347
00:18:56.180 --> 00:19:01.050
fairly understandable, if you do have
corrective action that had to be done,

348
00:19:01.050 --> 00:19:05.800
make sure you actually know what actions
they were, and the outcome of this.

349
00:19:05.800 --> 00:19:09.300
It's very easy to say, I needed to make a

350
00:19:09.300 --> 00:19:14.180
again, express why, and then actually tell

351
00:19:14.180 --> 00:19:18.380
Also, especially large performance
variances that happen, in other words,

00:19:18.380 --> 00:19:21.070
the things that really did take

00:19:21.070 --> 00:19:24.890
also what got you back on course as well,
unplanned risk.

354
00:19:24.890 --> 00:19:28.230
Now in your risk register you should
have every risk that you came across or

every risk that you're expecting to, that
doesn't mean you accounted for everything.

356
00:19:31.850 --> 00:19:32.410
Okay?

357
00:19:32.410 --> 00:19:34.580
So make sure that you note the ones

358
00:19:35.590 --> 00:19:39.600
Mistakes, this is the one that most of the
time when we talk about lessons learned,

00:19:39.600 --> 00:19:43.650

00:19:43.650 --> 00:19:48.810
This is incredibly important, but
a lot of Project Managers fail to do it,

00:19:48.810 --> 00:19:53.030
because sometimes,

00:19:53.030 --> 00:19:56.390
mistakes boil down to somebody

00:19:56.390 --> 00:19:59.390
And nobody wants to attach
Ronnie Wong to this mistake,

00:19:59.390 --> 00:20:02.380
especially Ronnie Wong, he doesn't wanna

365
00:20:02.380 --> 00:20:03.436
>> Now Ronnie-
>> [LAUGH]

366
00:20:03.436 --> 00:20:05.296
>> If the project is over and done with,

00:20:05.296 --> 00:20:08.420
and it's all closed up why would

368
00:20:08.420 --> 00:20:11.690
>> Yeah, you would think that that's it,
but the idea is that,

369
00:20:11.690 --> 00:20:15.810
the project manager is saying, look, it's
not that it's so important that we know

00:20:15.810 --> 00:20:19.525
who made a mistake, unless we're about
to hire him to do a project, I guess.

371
00:20:19.525 --> 00:20:23.760
[LAUGH] But it's about the idea that we
can learn from one another as a community

372
00:20:23.760 --> 00:20:27.620
and what you do want to do here
is to make sure that you do know.

373
00:20:27.620 --> 00:20:30.550
Certain mistakes were made if you
actually did make major mistakes that

374
00:20:30.550 --> 00:20:33.290
caused your project to
kind of really veer off.

375
00:20:33.290 --> 00:20:38.180
But most us would rather not attach any
one person's name especially your own

376
00:20:38.180 --> 00:20:39.490
to those mistakes.

377
00:20:39.490 --> 00:20:41.940
But they should be noted
because it's not that you're,

00:20:41.940 --> 00:20:45.150
like I said it's not the idea of assigning
blame now that everything is done.

379
00:20:45.150 --> 00:20:49.710
It's the idea of actually making sure you
note those mistakes, so most of the time,

380
00:20:49.710 --> 00:20:50.760
project managers are busy.

381
00:20:50.760 --> 00:20:53.200
In other words, they're actually
lined up one project after the other,

00:20:53.200 --> 00:20:56.070
if there's any part of the closure that

383
00:20:56.070 --> 00:20:58.949
>> So this really boils down to,
it's all about posterity,

384
00:20:58.949 --> 00:21:02.675
it's all about the people that are coming
after you to do another project.

385
00:21:02.675 --> 00:21:05.255
They're going to learn from what
you learned on your project,

00:21:05.255 --> 00:21:06.870
that's why we document these things.

387
00:21:06.870 --> 00:21:09.475
I love the old quote, and
I'm probably gonna butcher it, but it's,

00:21:09.475 --> 00:21:12.171
if you see farther than other people
do it's because you're standing on

00:21:12.171 --> 00:21:13.473

00:21:13.473 --> 00:21:16.977
You're standing on the foundation
that has been laid before you and

00:21:16.977 --> 00:21:20.870
you're building a foundation for
the people that are coming after you.

392
00:21:20.870 --> 00:21:26.740
If for that reason only that is the best

393
00:21:26.740 --> 00:21:28.500
Figure out what you can
figure out from it,

394
00:21:28.500 --> 00:21:31.660
learn from the mistakes that were made.

395
00:21:31.660 --> 00:21:34.520
And if there is blame to be

00:21:34.520 --> 00:21:35.140

00:21:36.230 --> 00:21:39.060
Our boss Tim used to say,

00:21:39.060 --> 00:21:41.580
make a decision,
you're gonna learn something.

00:21:41.580 --> 00:21:44.583
If you're wrong you'll learn something, if
you're right you'll learn something, and

00:21:44.583 --> 00:21:47.157
that's basically the idea we're trying
to convey when it comes to this type of

401
00:21:47.157 --> 00:21:47.752
documentation.

402
00:21:47.752 --> 00:21:50.562
>> Right, and our last one here

00:21:50.562 --> 00:21:54.200
now, we tend to do this,

Usually, of course, the performance

Most of us would always

I know I don't like giving myself

you know the very [CROSSTALK]

So just realize that
stuff does go in there,

and that's what we wanna have

Without having to kinda get you to recall

>> Yeah, yeah, you do have to

So lessons learned, making sure that

making sure that we understand
that the procurement closeout and

everything we're doing, we're essentially

everything else too, and

And finally we want to make sure that

Now, when you have this particular

The recommendation is that you still

point, and saying are you insane that

No it really is cuz you wanna figure out

Ronnie that sound like that fact that

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue discussing project closure, this time looking at a few scenarios in which project closure might occur. They begin by revisiting the steps involved when closing a project and then introduce you to the 4 formal project closure types. This includes Addition, Starvation, Integration, and Extinction.
episodes.title: Identify Closure Scenarios
