00:12:57.840 --> 00:13:00.770
But this is the terminology
you need to understand, right?

237
00:13:00.770 --> 00:13:02.270
It's the term extinction.

238
00:13:02.270 --> 00:13:03.600
To me extinction is bad.

239
00:13:03.600 --> 00:13:07.130
>> The giant meteor comes and
slams to your project.

240
00:13:07.130 --> 00:13:08.010
And it's over right?

241
00:13:08.010 --> 00:13:09.850
>> That's what exactly
what you think about but

242
00:13:09.850 --> 00:13:12.790
in project management terms,
primarily this is a good thing.

243
00:13:12.790 --> 00:13:17.280
And the reason why it needs to
actually become extinct because what?

244
00:13:17.280 --> 00:13:18.980
You actually did you project.

245
00:13:18.980 --> 00:13:22.700
The project was accepted by
the stakeholders at this point and

246
00:13:22.700 --> 00:13:27.230
now your project really has no
other reason to be in existence.

247
00:13:27.230 --> 00:13:32.220
And then from that point,
it is the last dodo bird on the island

248
00:13:32.220 --> 00:13:35.160
that gets there, so that's the idea.

249
00:13:35.160 --> 00:13:38.350
If everything goes perfectly,
that's extinction.

250
00:13:38.350 --> 00:13:41.780
So we take a look at the idea
of addition where essentially

251
00:13:41.780 --> 00:13:45.740
the project just becomes
the ongoing operations.

252
00:13:45.740 --> 00:13:49.090
Integration where your project is
swallowed by another project and

253
00:13:49.090 --> 00:13:52.920
it's kind of weird that we're kind
of using these dinosaur terms here.

254
00:13:52.920 --> 00:13:56.850
>> It's funny,
with addition I thought of evolution.

255
00:13:56.850 --> 00:14:00.960
It's changing in nature from being
a project to being an ongoing operation.

256
00:14:00.960 --> 00:14:04.240
>> I think that's a great
analogy on that one.

257
00:14:04.240 --> 00:14:06.610
Then there is this idea of starvation.

258
00:14:06.610 --> 00:14:11.830
Now, starvation here is kind of weird
because we really don't know why

259
00:14:11.830 --> 00:14:15.310
It ends up happening except
that it happens, and

260
00:14:15.310 --> 00:14:17.880
the reason is because this is
gonna happen for any reason right.

261
00:14:17.880 --> 00:14:21.790
Resources are simply removed from
your project or no longer considered

262
00:14:21.790 --> 00:14:25.590
available to you, and more than likely
when that happens you've ticked off

263
00:14:25.590 --> 00:14:29.920
the stakeholder somewhere is probably what
has actually ended up happening here.

264
00:14:29.920 --> 00:14:32.010
Now, not always don't get me wrong and

265
00:14:32.010 --> 00:14:36.140
because the reason why it's integration
right it's essentially the same thing.

266
00:14:36.140 --> 00:14:40.780
But what we see is not that those
particular other projects need more

267
00:14:40.780 --> 00:14:45.760
emphasis but we essentially are actually
moving them off of your project

268
00:14:45.760 --> 00:14:49.860
to move them off of your project with
withholding is what we're doing.

269
00:14:49.860 --> 00:14:52.480
So somewhere along the line
we are actually withholding

270
00:14:52.480 --> 00:14:55.810
whereas the integration is say, well,
look, here's some that takes priority or

271
00:14:55.810 --> 00:14:58.530
here's another project that we
really need the resources on.

272
00:14:58.530 --> 00:15:00.990
And that we have to rob it from you,
that's one thing.

273
00:15:00.990 --> 00:15:04.320
But the idea of starvation is simply
withholding the resource as well.

274
00:15:04.320 --> 00:15:06.220
>> This is from vindictive stakeholders?

275
00:15:06.220 --> 00:15:07.410
Why does it occur?

276
00:15:07.410 --> 00:15:08.850
>> Yeah, it can be, right.

277
00:15:08.850 --> 00:15:13.480
Sometimes what ends up happening is that
it is something that you did kind of

278
00:15:13.480 --> 00:15:15.924
mess around with someone's pond.

279
00:15:15.924 --> 00:15:19.070
>> [LAUGH]
>> Whatever you wanna do.

280
00:15:19.070 --> 00:15:22.460
And you've really got- [CROSSTALK]
>> Ripples in the water.

281
00:15:22.460 --> 00:15:24.040
>> Yeah, you've done that.

282
00:15:24.040 --> 00:15:27.900
Or it could be for one reason or
another, let's say this.

283
00:15:27.900 --> 00:15:30.730
Your company is really having
a bad budget month and

284
00:15:30.730 --> 00:15:32.740
they've decided to lay off workers.

285
00:15:32.740 --> 00:15:35.450
And so when those people
are just no longer there,

286
00:15:35.450 --> 00:15:39.870
the possibility of your existence as
a project may not be there either.

287
00:15:39.870 --> 00:15:42.740
And so even if you're in the middle
of your project, it can happen.

288
00:15:42.740 --> 00:15:47.740
It can just be one day where those workers
end up disappearing and you can't do that.

289
00:15:47.740 --> 00:15:50.380
So at that point,
remember that if you can't have resources,

290
00:15:50.380 --> 00:15:52.210
you can't complete the requirement and

291
00:15:52.210 --> 00:15:55.420
essentially, yes, you are left with
an unfinished product as well.

292
00:15:55.420 --> 00:15:56.080
Okay?
So

293
00:15:56.080 --> 00:15:59.560
it could be that other projects
do end up taking precedence and

294
00:15:59.560 --> 00:16:02.770
if they absolutely move it
off of your project and

295
00:16:02.770 --> 00:16:06.360
they have other means available,
well they're doing it on purpose, right?

296
00:16:06.360 --> 00:16:10.700
So if they go no we need yours and to but
you have plenty of reserve go ahead and

297
00:16:10.700 --> 00:16:12.070
hire your own team.

298
00:16:12.070 --> 00:16:17.360
Well that kinda lets you know as well
budget cuts, key resource quits and

299
00:16:17.360 --> 00:16:21.270
that's a big one that can happen too which
is something that's very important for

300
00:16:21.270 --> 00:16:25.080
us, right, a lot of times on your
team you may find that there's really

301
00:16:25.080 --> 00:16:29.520
just a handful of key people that
really keep everything working and

302
00:16:29.520 --> 00:16:33.030
going and doing everything
that we need to do and if that

303
00:16:33.030 --> 00:16:37.650
particular person decides that he quits,
it becomes a little more difficult for

304
00:16:37.650 --> 00:16:41.900
the team to actually coalesce and
do everything that needs to be done.

305
00:16:41.900 --> 00:16:42.610
Can it be overcome?

306
00:16:42.610 --> 00:16:43.920
Yes okay.

307
00:16:43.920 --> 00:16:47.360
As long as you actually do
have a team that's willing to

308
00:16:47.360 --> 00:16:49.250
come together and do that.

309
00:16:49.250 --> 00:16:52.910
But not every team is and you might
find yourself as a project leader.

310
00:16:52.910 --> 00:16:54.450
Like I don't know who else I would call,

311
00:16:54.450 --> 00:16:57.980
cuz I would just call them and
everything would be taken care of.

312
00:16:57.980 --> 00:16:59.830
So if you don't know the strengths and

313
00:16:59.830 --> 00:17:03.070
the weaknesses of your team
it really isn't gong to help.

314
00:17:03.070 --> 00:17:05.010
And so sometimes you will see that.

315
00:17:05.010 --> 00:17:07.950
And I was part of an organization
like that where was a person that

316
00:17:07.950 --> 00:17:12.900
thought they were the key, the pin,
that if that guy left, his,

317
00:17:12.900 --> 00:17:15.340
if I leave,
everybody's just gonna disperse.

318
00:17:15.340 --> 00:17:18.950
The guy left and guess what,
everybody kinda came back together and

319
00:17:18.950 --> 00:17:21.880
I believe we became a stronger
after that believe it or not.

320
00:17:21.880 --> 00:17:25.840
So, this stuff does end up
happening at a times, right?

321
00:17:25.840 --> 00:17:27.990
Where it could be, where that person does.

322
00:17:27.990 --> 00:17:30.440
And now all of the sudden
everybody else scatters too.

323
00:17:30.440 --> 00:17:33.190
So, you just never know what
ends up happening here.

324
00:17:33.190 --> 00:17:37.340
But those particular scenarios
are usually what you'll end up seeing.

325
00:17:37.340 --> 00:17:41.930
As far as different ways that projects
can essentially end up closing.

326
00:17:41.930 --> 00:17:44.180
So not everything's always perfect, right?

327
00:17:44.180 --> 00:17:48.460
And these are some of the reasons that
you might end up seeing and finding.

328
00:17:48.460 --> 00:17:50.070
A lot of everything that we go across.

329
00:17:50.070 --> 00:17:51.710
Whether we're talking about cancellations,
or

330
00:17:51.710 --> 00:17:54.540
whether we're talking about
abandonment of projects or.

331
00:17:54.540 --> 00:17:57.730
Or the idea that you don't have
enough resources to finish.

332
00:17:57.730 --> 00:18:00.350
They all fall in these
particular four categories.

333
00:18:00.350 --> 00:18:03.480
And these are the formalized one
CompTIA but they want you to know for

334
00:18:03.480 --> 00:18:04.310
the exam as well.

335
00:18:04.310 --> 00:18:05.890
So make sure you take a look at them.

336
00:18:05.890 --> 00:18:09.170
>> That's right, and harkening
back to someone quitting the team,

337
00:18:09.170 --> 00:18:12.470
I've always said, listen,
everyone's replaceable.

338
00:18:12.470 --> 00:18:16.540
But you might not be easily replaceable,
so don't think we can't replace you.

339
00:18:16.540 --> 00:18:19.450
We might have a hard time doing it and
it will be a horrible thing, but

340
00:18:19.450 --> 00:18:20.540
it can be done.

341
00:18:20.540 --> 00:18:24.730
So there's always a good level
of humility that needs to be

342
00:18:24.730 --> 00:18:26.600
expressed when you're on any team.

343
00:18:26.600 --> 00:18:28.650
No one is indispensable.

344
00:18:28.650 --> 00:18:30.140
There's always some one
that can replace you.

345
00:18:30.140 --> 00:18:32.625
It might no easily be done but
it can be done.

346
00:18:32.625 --> 00:18:35.270
Ronnie, is there anything else we
need to cover when it comes to

347
00:18:35.270 --> 00:18:38.000
project closure
>> Well just remember

348
00:18:38.000 --> 00:18:39.590
the scenarios more than anything else.

349
00:18:39.590 --> 00:18:42.270
That these are kind of key.

350
00:18:42.270 --> 00:18:45.190
Every scenario that you think about that
you're presented with make sure you go,

351
00:18:45.190 --> 00:18:49.370
is this something that can be dealing with
addition, integration, extinction, or

352
00:18:49.370 --> 00:18:51.060
the idea of starvation here?

353
00:18:51.060 --> 00:18:54.450
The two that are most difficult to deal
with of course is the idea of integration

354
00:18:54.450 --> 00:18:55.915
and starvation.

355
00:18:55.915 --> 00:19:00.960
But, once you've figured that out you're
pretty much fine and get ready to face

356
00:19:00.960 --> 00:19:04.980
whatever exam that you're on, but you'll
also be presented with these scenarios and

357
00:19:04.980 --> 00:19:09.280
if you keep a good as a project
manager on top of your project.

358
00:19:09.280 --> 00:19:12.300
You'll be of a spot when these
things are also happening and

359
00:19:12.300 --> 00:19:16.210
then either try to work around it or you
bring your project to a close regardless

360
00:19:16.210 --> 00:19:18.530
of the way that she ends up closing.

361
00:19:18.530 --> 00:19:21.920
>> Well, Ronnie, as always,
thank you so much for stopping by and

362
00:19:21.920 --> 00:19:23.910
lending your expertise on these topics.

363
00:19:23.910 --> 00:19:24.510
We need that.

364
00:19:24.510 --> 00:19:26.500
We want to pass this project plus exam.

365
00:19:26.500 --> 00:19:28.440
That's exactly what we want for you.

366
00:19:28.440 --> 00:19:32.150
That being said, look's like we've come to
the end of another great show hopefully

367
00:19:32.150 --> 00:19:36.110
you've learned something and take away
a lot of knowledge, go pass that exam.

368
00:19:36.110 --> 00:19:38.230
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV,

369
00:19:38.230 --> 00:19:39.780
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

370
00:19:39.780 --> 00:19:40.470
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

371
00:19:40.470 --> 00:19:42.400
>> And we'll see you next time.

372
00:19:42.400 --> 00:19:46.463
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you a few common Project Closure Documents. They examine and explain the details in Lessons Learned documents, Close Reports, and Post Mortem Analysis documents. They also discuss individual performance appraisals.
episodes.title: Identify Closure Documents
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.139 --> 00:00:16.711
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.711 --> 00:00:18.161
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:18.161 --> 00:00:21.540
in today's episode we're moving
on with our Project Plus series.

5
00:00:21.540 --> 00:00:24.540
Joining us back in the studio again
today to help in that very endeavor,

6
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:25.960
it's our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:25.960 --> 00:00:27.430
Ronnie, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:27.430 --> 00:00:31.275
>> Well thank you, as we continue on
taking a look at Comptia's Project Plus.

9
00:00:31.275 --> 00:00:34.980
We're actually taking a look at
just a few final documents today

10
00:00:34.980 --> 00:00:39.110
in the closeout procedures that we need
to make sure that we pay attention to.

11
00:00:39.110 --> 00:00:43.181
Because in the end, it really is about
documentation, finishing everything out,

12
00:00:43.181 --> 00:00:46.848
to ensure that we actually have everything
we need to say that the project was

13
00:00:46.848 --> 00:00:50.205
successful or at least completely
closed out the way that we need to.

14
00:00:50.205 --> 00:00:54.012
And we just wanna make sure that you have
a chance to see some of those documents

15
00:00:54.012 --> 00:00:56.250
and understand what they're really about.

16
00:00:56.250 --> 00:00:58.810
So I've got a few different
examples of some of them.

17
00:00:58.810 --> 00:01:02.664
And some of them we've actually already
taken a look at previously in other

18
00:01:02.664 --> 00:01:03.649
episodes as well.

19
00:01:03.649 --> 00:01:07.690
So when we start talking about some
of the close out procedure documents,

20
00:01:07.690 --> 00:01:11.924
one of the things that we had talked about
way back in the planning stage here,

21
00:01:11.924 --> 00:01:15.020
is the idea of a project transition plan,
right?

22
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:17.490
That when we start talking about
transitioning we're moving from

23
00:01:17.490 --> 00:01:22.210
one particular stage in our project,
going through the stages as well.

24
00:01:22.210 --> 00:01:24.840
And normally there is a plan for
us to do that.

25
00:01:24.840 --> 00:01:29.450
So we showed you the idea of moving from
the initiation phase into the planning

26
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:32.640
phase, that you normally
have a plan there that says,

27
00:01:32.640 --> 00:01:34.190
here's how you know
that everything's done.

28
00:01:34.190 --> 00:01:36.080
Here's what you're
expecting to produce here.

29
00:01:36.080 --> 00:01:37.130
And then you move through that.

30
00:01:37.130 --> 00:01:40.390
The same thing when you're moving
from planning into execution.

31
00:01:40.390 --> 00:01:42.670
You're actually doing
that same thing again.

32
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:47.330
So you normally will follow the procedures
that you've set up during that project

33
00:01:47.330 --> 00:01:50.550
transition phase to make sure
that you actually are hitting all

34
00:01:50.550 --> 00:01:55.230
the key points you want as you
move through everything else too.

35
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:59.470
Also included inside of some of
those close out dockets, maybe, and

36
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:03.125
this is one of these optional
documents that you'll have,

37
00:02:03.125 --> 00:02:07.729
is that you may have everybody that works
on your project to also go ahead and

38
00:02:07.729 --> 00:02:10.680
fill out what we call
evaluation forms as well.

39
00:02:10.680 --> 00:02:15.455
You might actually do an evaluation
form where they actually evaluate you as

40
00:02:15.455 --> 00:02:21.370
a project manager, and also, you actually
do maybe evaluations on the individuals.

41
00:02:21.370 --> 00:02:24.220
Now, it doesn't always
have to be that way.

42
00:02:24.220 --> 00:02:28.030
It may be instead where, well yes, you
evaluate that contractor who might have

43
00:02:28.030 --> 00:02:31.780
a team of people or that department and
they may have a team.

44
00:02:31.780 --> 00:02:36.046
But normally that's what you're looking
for as well, is that everybody has

45
00:02:36.046 --> 00:02:39.341
a chance to have some input in
to the closure of that as well.

46
00:02:39.341 --> 00:02:42.664
And those evaluations are gonna be
dependent upon what type of project

47
00:02:42.664 --> 00:02:45.367
you're working on,
what industry that you're in, and

48
00:02:45.367 --> 00:02:48.360
sort of specific measurements
that you may do there.

49
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:51.720
But besides that, though, I wanna show
you just some of the other ones that we

50
00:02:51.720 --> 00:02:56.630
already talked about during our
closing procedures here, too, okay?

51
00:02:56.630 --> 00:02:59.350
So one of the first ones that
we wanna look at is this idea

52
00:02:59.350 --> 00:03:03.010
of the lessons learned
type of documentation.

53
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:05.870
Now this can actually become very long.

54
00:03:05.870 --> 00:03:07.658
In other words, if you're good at writing.

55
00:03:07.658 --> 00:03:11.881
If you're really good at actually
prose and telling the story and

56
00:03:11.881 --> 00:03:15.872
doing stuff like that,
you can weave an entire mini novella or

57
00:03:15.872 --> 00:03:19.422
[LAUGH] whatever length of
book that you really want to.

58
00:03:19.422 --> 00:03:23.010
But most of us though, we really wanna
get down to the meat and potatoes.

59
00:03:23.010 --> 00:03:25.800
And the meat and
potatoes is lessons learned, right?

60
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:28.123
It's to actually be able
to show the strengths and

61
00:03:28.123 --> 00:03:30.490
weaknesses that we had in our project.

62
00:03:30.490 --> 00:03:34.810
So what you might have is a document that
looks something similar to this here,

63
00:03:34.810 --> 00:03:37.960
where you're taking a look at
the project performance analysis.

64
00:03:37.960 --> 00:03:42.260
And you start listing out your
work packages that you have.

65
00:03:42.260 --> 00:03:46.360
So like here, requirements and
definition management, scope definition,

66
00:03:46.360 --> 00:03:49.660
developmental control, you name it
when you're actually doing that.

67
00:03:49.660 --> 00:03:53.665
And notice that we also have these
unusual numberings here too,

68
00:03:53.665 --> 00:03:55.825
this idea of a legend that goes on.

69
00:03:55.825 --> 00:03:58.008
And what you can do at this
particular point, right?

70
00:03:58.008 --> 00:04:02.026
Instead of writing out the actual
project work package name itself,

71
00:04:02.026 --> 00:04:04.460
you might put the WBS skill in here.

72
00:04:04.460 --> 00:04:08.112
Or you might actually have a code
that you've actually said, hey,

73
00:04:08.112 --> 00:04:11.590
this is actually something
that worked well, A1, B1, C1.

74
00:04:11.590 --> 00:04:14.619
And that way you can actually just
go ahead and knock those in there.

75
00:04:14.619 --> 00:04:19.104
And then in then end, you might have
a little definition that explains what

76
00:04:19.104 --> 00:04:21.680
these particular things are for.

77
00:04:21.680 --> 00:04:24.560
So you might even say what can be
improved and you go through and

78
00:04:24.560 --> 00:04:26.560
you fill that out very quickly.

79
00:04:26.560 --> 00:04:30.792
And once you actually get through
everything that you're actually supposed

80
00:04:30.792 --> 00:04:34.370
to do, then on another page,
this is when you list those risks and

81
00:04:34.370 --> 00:04:36.540
those issues that you did not plan for.

82
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:38.900
And you wanna make sure you
actually do have something here.

83
00:04:38.900 --> 00:04:41.380
Now, this is actually done
in just a small form.

84
00:04:41.380 --> 00:04:43.660
But remember,
you don't always have to type or

85
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:46.120
write actually just within that space.

86
00:04:46.120 --> 00:04:49.390
You can always take longer to
write this stuff out of course

87
00:04:49.390 --> 00:04:51.330
if you need more details as well.

88
00:04:51.330 --> 00:04:52.974
Quality defects you've come across.

89
00:04:52.974 --> 00:04:55.640
Vendor management,
whether everything's been in control.

90
00:04:55.640 --> 00:04:59.280
Anything else you want to add in there
you also include in your lessons learned

91
